webTitle: The minds are still willing but what about the flesh?

fields.headline: The minds are still willing but what about the flesh?
fields.trailText: Vivek Chaudhary reports on the parade of ghosts from football's glorious past when the PFA yesterday announced the launch of the first national veterans' tournament.
fields.body:
They emerged like ghosts from football's glorious past, the receding hairlines and thickening midriffs the most obvious signs of the passing years.

But at times yesterday it seemed as if nothing had changed as some of British football's most notable pensioners arrived for a press call almost an hour late at the Premier League's central London base, spoke of their will to win and how they planned to "take one game at a time".

"The lads are really up for this," said Ray Wilkins, referring to the likes of Mark Hateley, aged 38, Kenny Sansom, 41, John Wark, 42, and Micky Hazard, 40. "It's going to be very competitive once it kicks into action; some of the lads are in good shape." In football, it seems, men will always be boys.

Now, at last, with the launch of the first national veterans' tournament, today's retired lads will have the chance to prove that though the pace may have faded the guile lives on. The football brain, they aim to show, is as nimble as ever.

Organised by the Professional Footballers' Association (PFA), this summer's over-35s Masters indoor tournament will include other notable lads such as Glenn Hoddle, Peter Beardsley, Chris Waddle, Ally McCoist and Ian Rush. Teams will compete in regional groups with the winners playing in a final tournament at Wembley Arena in October.

Matches will be shown live on satellite television and, with an investment of £5m, organisers are hoping that veterans' football will become just as popular as veterans tennis and golf events.

Gordon Taylor, chief executive of the PFA, said: "We have had some of the finest players in the world and they want to continue playing. There's a demand to see the heroes of yesterday. We have found it to be an extremely successful formula. The football brain is still there."

A total of 308 former professionals are taking part but the organisers refused to reveal how much money each will receive. A number of televised pilot events last year proved popular with crowds and viewers alike, with the best attracting higher ratings than some Nationwide League fixtures.

Given that many of the "masters" have played for more than one club, all must nominate which team they will represent. No swaps or transfers will be allowed.

The matches of eight-minute halves - one minute of half-time, no extra-time - will be six-a-side. The PFA has modified the rules to take into account the passing years: no injuries will be treated on the pitch and any player hurt must be immediately substituted.

There will also be rolling substitutions so that tired or battered players can go off temporarily to recover.

For the old lads, however, the event is about more than meeting old friends. "I still train four times per week and we aim to win it," said the former Spurs midfielder Hazard. "There's no point in playing if you don't want to win."

The senior circuit

The regional tournaments, to be shown on Sky Sports.

Midlands: May 25, Nottingham Arena

Aston Villa, Coventry, Birmingham City, Nottingham Forest, Derby County, Leicester

North-east: June 1, Telewest Arena, Newcastle

Newcastle, Middlesbrough, Sunderland, Aberdeen

Scottish: June 8, Braehead Arena, Glasgow

Celtic, Rangers, Hearts, Dundee United

Yorkshire: July 12, Sheffield Arena

Sheffield Wednesday, Sheffield United, Leeds, Bradford

North-west: July 19, MEN Arena, Manchester

Manchester United, Manchester City, Liverpool, Everton

London: July 26, Docklands Arena

Arsenal, Charlton, Chelsea, Tottenham, West Ham, Wimbledon

Final: October 8, Wembley Arena

The six group winners qualify

fields.headline: 'Tyson' weighs in at Sunderland
fields.standfirst: Deadline-day deals
fields.trailText: Milton Nunez will become the first Honduran to play in the Premiership after Sunderland paid an initial £1.6m, rising by a maximum £1m, for the diminutive striker.
fields.body:
A squat, powerful Central American nicknamed "Tyson" splashed some colour across a drab transfer-deadline day when he headed for the Stadium of Light after ground-breaking moves by Peter Reid.

Milton Nunez will become the first Honduran to play in the Premiership after Sunderland paid an initial £1.6m, rising by a maximum £1m, for the diminutive striker who Reid believes will inject "that bit of extra pace up front".

Nunez, who has 50 caps, was bought from the Greek club PAOK Salonika but he made his name at Nacional of Uruguay, where he had his nickname shaved into his head.

There were fears he would not gain a work permit because Honduras are outside the world's top 70 footballing countries. They are currently rated 78th. But approval came from the employment authorities only an hour before yesterday's 5pm deadline. Nunez, 27, also received his international clearance and is likely to be on the substitutes' bench in tomorrow's home game with Everton.

Sheffield Wednesday's caretaker manager Peter Shreeves made the 37-year-old Barry Horne his first signing, giving the midfielder a contract until the end of the season. Horne moved from Huddersfield, where Steve Bruce signed two strikers, Chris Hay from financially stricken Swindon and Alun Armstrong from Middlesbrough until the end of the season.

David Platt paid £350,000 for Manchester City's Tony Vaughan, who has been on loan at Nottingham Forest, and took another defender, Chelsea's highly rated John Terry, until the end of the season.

Gary Megson, at West Bromwich, re-signed Albion's former striker favourite Bob Taylor from Bolton for £95,000 and spent £140,000 on Port Vale's defender Tony Butler. In all, Megson brought in five players within 48 hours.

Aston Villa have failed to agree a long-term contract with Benito Carbone and now run a greater risk of the Italian striker, whose current deal ends in June, signing a pre-contract agreement with another European club. He is thought to have been asking for about £40,000 a week.

However, Villa reached agreement with their 31-year-old midfielder Ian Taylor, who has now signed to stay until the summer of 2003.

Ipswich's manager George Burley has signed a new 4-year deal with the First Division club, and Darren Anderton formalised a one-year contract extension with Tottenham.

webTitle: Fans bid Fletcher a frosty farewell

fields.headline: Fans bid Fletcher a frosty farewell
fields.trailText: The Newcastle United chairman and chief executive Freddie Fletcher yesterday announced he would stand down, prompting a self-congratulatory, almost ebullient mood among members of the Toon Army.
fields.body:
The Newcastle United chairman and chief executive Freddie Fletcher yesterday announced he would stand down, prompting a self-congratulatory, almost ebullient mood among members of the Toon Army.

Fletcher, known on Teesside as "the Rottweiler", became the focus of supporter disenchantment last month when a small group of Newcastle fans took on the club in the high court as a long-running dispute over season tickets and bonds reached its climax.

As the 59-year-old Fletcher prepared to leave St James' Park, supporters' groups insisted yesterday that he was the fall guy for the high-profile court case which has tarnished the club's image.

"There was always the feeling that there would be a fall guy within the boardroom and Freddie Fletcher has been the man most closely associated with what has happened," said Jane Duffy, a leading light in the Save Our Seats campaign.

Fletcher's departure was part of a major boardroom reshuffle which also included the loss of the finance director and chief operating officer Les Wheatley, who is to become Liverpool's director of finance.

Fletcher, who will end his duties at the end of May and become a non-executive director, will be replaced as chief executive on April 3 by David Stonehouse, the current finance director of Sunderland.

John Fender, presently an independent non-executive director, will take over as Newcastle's non-executive chairman. He has had business dealings in the past with the club's president Sir John Hall, and City analysts viewed his appointment as a sign that the Hall family was taking a firmer grip on the club.

"I think what is most interesting is that the club has taken on someone like David Stonehouse from Sunderland, a club who have said they put their ordinary supporters first," said Duffy. "I do believe that there will be a feeling of great relief amongst the Newcastle supporters."

There is no doubt that Fletcher's decision to back a scheme which drove a wedge between the club and its fans cost him the job, which paid him over £200,000 last year.

Duffy and five other fans lost their legal battle after they claimed that the £500 bonds they bought as season ticket-holders in 1994 should have guaranteed them the same seats for 10 years. Six years into the bond the six fans, with 4,000 others, were asked to move to the newly built upper tier of St James' Park to make way for the construction of corporate hospitality facilities.

Frank Gilmour, the Newcastle United Independent Supporters' Club chairman, said few fans would shed tears over Fletcher's departure.

"I'm glad he's gone," he said. "It's not just because of the court case but the way he has handled matters with the fans in recent years. He also stood up for Douglas Hall and Freddy Shepherd after they had made derogatory remarks about Newcastle fans."

Fletcher yesterday conceded that his club had mishandled the relocation of the bond-holders. "I accept that a lot of the anger with regard to the seats problem was directed at me," he said.

"I think the decision the club took - and it was a unanimous board decision - was the right decision. [But] I think we handled it badly."

fields.headline: The last eight
fields.trailText: David Lacey offers a team-by-team analysis.
fields.body:
Quarter-final draw rules:
Group winners play runners-up with their first leg away. Qualifiers from the same second-phase group cannot meet at this stage.

Group winners

Barcelona
Coach: Louis van Gaal (Dutch)
Much more consistent in the Champions League than the Spanish league, Barcelona are the clear favourites after coming undefeated through 12 group matches, with 36 goals scored. Rivaldo, Luis Figo and Van Gaal's strong Dutch contingent give them the ability to switch from defence to attack in a trice. Surely finalists at the very least. Chances: Very good
Odds: 5-2

Manchester United
Coach: Sir Alex Ferguson (Scottish)
Having carefully paced their season, at home and abroad, in order to be ready for the run-in, United should be in the right mood and form to defend the trophy. Ryan Giggs and Andy Cole are in exceptional form, Dwight Yorke is coming back to the boil and Roy Keane remains the best midfielder in Europe. Just so long as United do not leak goals at home. Chances: Very good
Odds: 3-1

Bayern Munich
Coach: Ottmar Hitzfeld (German)
The aftershock of losing last year's European Cup final to Manchester United in stoppage-time has long since been replaced by a stern resolve on Bayern's part to earn themselves another chance. Unremarkable in the first group phase, they have reached the last eight with something to spare. Lothar Matthäus has gone Stateside but Stefan Effenberg and Jens Jeremies are still around. Chances: Good
Odds: 9-2

Lazio
Coach: Sven-Goran Eriksson (Swedish)
Winning when you have to, as Lazio did at Stamford Bridge on Wednesday, is always a good recommendation for success at the knockout stage. Eriksson's team certainly have the quality to go all the way and the all-round strength of Sinisa Mihajlovic is awesome. A strong Argentine element remains equally essential to Lazio's style. Chances: Good
Odds: 4-1

Group runners-up

Porto
Coach: Fernando Santos (Portuguese)
Possible dark horses, Porto cruised through the opening phase before choking on Barcelona's vapour trails in the second. They are a neat, well organised team with a strong Brazilian presence and a natural goalscorer in Jardel. But Ryan Giggs terrorised their defence the last time they played Manchester United and would doubtless look forward to doing so again. Chances: Fair
Odds: 33-1

Valencia
Coach: Hector Cuper (Argentine)
Valencia's poor away form may find them out sooner rather than later although at Mestalla they will usually be a handful. Miguel Angel Angulo, Juan Sanchez and Kily Gonzalez bring a high quality of passing and movement to their football and Jocelyn Angloma makes powerful runs on the right. But the Romanian Adrian Ilie, their most likely matchwinner, is in and out of the side. Chances: Modest
Odds: 12-1

Real Madrid
Coach: Vicente del Bosque (Spanish)
Real may have reached the last eight but their season remains full of problems, most answering to the name Nicolas Anelka. Yet they do have a world-class striker in Raul, a player capable of conjuring goals out of virtually nothing, and talents like of those of Roberto Carlos, Fernando Hierro and Fernando Morientes can hardly be dismissed lightly. Chances: Fair
Odds: 10-1

Chelsea
Coach: Gianluca Vialli (Italian)
On paper, in terms of defensive efficiency and attacking technique, Chelsea look the best-equipped of the quarter- finalists but as Wednesday's home defeat against Lazio showed they sometimes find it hard to chase a game. And for all their foreigners they are still heavily dependent on Dennis Wise, who was missing the night before last, for their combustion. Chances: Fair
Odds: 8-1

fields.headline: Parlour's three-piece sweet
fields.standfirst:
Bode 41; Bogdanovich 60 | Parlour 8, 25, 70; Henry 59
Arsenal win 6-2 on agg
fields.trailText:
Werder Bremen 2 - 4 Arsenal

Arsenal strolled into the semi-finals last night on the back of a true collectors' item: a Ray Parlour hat-trick.
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger will not be booking the civic reception just yet but he must have been impressed with the way his Arsenal team strolled into the semi-finals of the Uefa Cup last night on the back of a true collectors' item: a Ray Parlour hat-trick.

The midfielder's three goals were complemented by an assist for Thierry Henry as Arsenal secured a 6-2 aggregate win, although the gloss was taken off slightly by Henry's ridiculous 63rd-minute dismissal for a trip on Mike Barten. The referee, Kim Milton Nielsen, will be familiar to David Beckham. Henry will miss both legs of the semi-final.

Wenger cannot have expected such a comfortable night. Bremen may have been dismal and defensive in their 2-0 defeat at Highbury last week but a capacity crowd here by the river Weser indicated local hopes were high.

Bremen had overturned a 1-0 deficit against Parma and before that had fought back from a 3-0 defeat in Lyon. Like all good German sides they were supposed not to know when they were beaten. The news that Alex Manninger would deputise in Arsenal's goal for David Seaman, who has a neck injury, produced a huge cheer.

More bizarre was hearing the Bremen fans singing along to a tinny, German version of Football's Coming Home - Fussballer kommen Raus - before kick-off. Their team, though, began as if driven by 30 years of hurt, Ailton bursting down the left flank and Andreas Herzog testing Manninger with a free-kick.

Yet no sooner were they getting into their stride than their hopes of reaching the semi-finals were over. In the eighth minute Parlour scored from Arsenal's first attack. Not long after he added No2 to leave the German side needing five goals to go through.

Marco Bode brought them back to earth by heading in from a corner but it was not hard to see why Bremen have not kept a clean sheet since mid-December. Just before the interval Tony Adams should have added a third but somehow Rost recovered to save.

Bremen introduced Rade Bogdanovic at half-time to form a three-pronged attack, though Ailton was lucky to stay on the pitch for what looked a clear elbow into Grimandi's face. The referee kept his red card in his pocket.

Despite that change, the German Cup holders rarely threatened to penetrate Arsenal's defence and always looked vulnerable to a swift counter-attack. Henry wasted one chance when sent clear by Kanu but soon made amends. This time Parlour was architect rather than executioner, picking up Kanu's pass and crossing for Henry to slide in his 17th goal of the season.

Foolishly Arsenal immediately went to sleep, enabling Bogdanovic to volley Bremen's second. Then Nielsen showed Henry a red card for a trip which deserved nothing more than a yellow.

The defender rolled about as if shot. On the touchline Wenger had to be restrained but his anger turned to elation when Parlour completed his hat-trick, beating the oncoming Rost, from Kanu's ball.

fields.headline: Player loans appeal to counties
fields.trailText: The English counties have responded to the growing competitive edge of the two-division structure by sanctioning player loans for the coming season.
fields.body:
The English counties have responded to the growing competitive edge of the two-division structure by sanctioning player loans for the coming season. It will apply only to players aged under 25 and each deal must be approved by the England and Wales Cricket Board.

Loans have become more attractive as counties slim down their full-time squads to get rid of the unambitious time-servers who are perceived to be lowering standards and limiting opportunities for younger players. But many will believe the policy is another step towards an open transfer system as the introduction of promotion and relegation brings more anxiety for success.

Loan deals will be permitted only between June 1 and July 31 and must be for at least six weeks. The county taking the player on loan will pay his wages for the duration of the loan and the cup-tied rule, as used by football, will bar him from appearing in the Benson & Hedges Cup and NatWest Trophy.

fields.trailText: "The hospital's just rung to say Mr Midgley's father has been taken ill," said Miss Tunstall to Mr Horsfall, explaining her interruption.
fields.body:
"The hospital's just rung to say Mr Midgley's father has been taken ill," said Miss Tunstall to Mr Horsfall, explaining her interruption.

Denis Midgley, who had been having a tricky conversation about Mr Horsfall's son's hopelessness at English, realised he had just heard at second-hand his father was dying.

"You want to pray it's not his hip," said Miss Tunstall, as Midgley tried to negotiate the hospital switchboard.

"He's not at all well," said a reproachful voice. "We think he's had a stroke. It's touch and go." "Been on the phone again, Midgley," said the headmaster. "I'll have to explain it to the finance committee."

"His father's ill. Apparently it's touch and go," mediated Miss Tunstall.

"Of course you must go," the headmaster muttered. "One's father. It's awkward, though."

Death reshuffled everything. Even the timetable. "I just never expected it," said Mr Midgley, as his wife made him some sandwiches before he left for the hospital.

"I expected it," she said, "Last time I went over, he came to the door to wave me off. He'd never done that before. It was a farewell."

"I'm not going to let him down. I want to be there when he goes - He loved me."

"I can't think why," countered Mrs Midgley. "It's not as if you take after him."

"I thought you'd have been here before now," said Aunt Kitty, when Midgley arrived at the bedside. "I don't dislike the oatmeal colour of the room. His doctor's black."

Midgley's father lay motionless in bed, the ghostly pallor of his arms and body contrasting with the ruddiness of his face as the regular blips of the heart monitor punctuated the silence.

"I'm sorry, Dad."

Midgley waited as a man made a series of lengthy phone calls. "Could I make just one call," he said eventually.

"Won't it wait? I'm a father."

"I'm a son. My father's dying."

"Slack tonight," said Nurse Lightfoot, the night nurse, as Midgley sat by his father's bedside through the night. "Still it just needs one drunken driver."

"What do you do all day?" Midgley asked nurse Lightfoot the following evening as his father continued to hang on.

"Sleep."

"Maybe we could have a coffee if he's unchanged."

"OK."

"What would you say if I asked you to go to bed?" Midgley asked, as they sat on a divan in the nurse's quarters.

"I'm on an early turn."

"Tomorrow then?"

"That would be better."

The phone rang the next evening as Midgley slid his hand up Nurse Lightfoot's thigh.

"I think he's smiling," said Mrs Midgley, looking down at her father-in-law.

"Of course he's smiling," replied Midgley. "He's won. Scored in the last minute of extra time."

And if you really are pressed - The digested read, digested:
Unregarded English teacher grapples with the banality of his own mortality in a deadpan tale of sex and death in a northern hospital.

webTitle: What to say about... John Ruskin

fields.headline: What to say about... John Ruskin
fields.standfirst: How to survive polite conversation about  the 19th-century art critic cum painter who is the subject of two new biographies and a Tate exhibition
fields.trailText: John Ruskin was the art critic to end all art critics; more than that, he was a sort of Jay Jopling of his time, who tirelessly promoted the Young British Artists (YBAs) - Turner and the Pre-Raphaelites - of the late-19th century. It is unnecessary to have read all, or indeed any, of the 38 volumes of Ruskin's complete works. No one on earth has, except perhaps his most respected biographer, Tim Hilton. Do say that Hilton's new book is itself deliciously Ruskinian in its wide-ranging erudition, far superior (London's Evening Standard) to the much shorter biography by John Batchelor, also published to mark the centenary of Ruskin's death . As for Ruskin's own writings, suggest airily that they influenced the early Labour movement more than Marx (he hated capitalism - Scotland On Sunday); the Green movement (he hated pollution, anything made from iron, and trains - Financial Times); Wilde; Gandhi; and Proust (Independent).
fields.body:
John Ruskin was the art critic to end all art critics; more than that, he was a sort of Jay Jopling of his time, who tirelessly promoted the Young British Artists (YBAs) - Turner and the Pre-Raphaelites - of the late-19th century. It is unnecessary to have read all, or indeed any, of the 38 volumes of Ruskin's complete works. No one on earth has, except perhaps his most respected biographer, Tim Hilton. Do say that Hilton's new book is itself deliciously Ruskinian in its wide-ranging erudition, far superior (London's Evening Standard) to the much shorter biography by John Batchelor, also published to mark the centenary of Ruskin's death . As for Ruskin's own writings, suggest airily that they influenced the early Labour movement more than Marx (he hated capitalism - Scotland On Sunday); the Green movement (he hated pollution, anything made from iron, and trains - Financial Times); Wilde; Gandhi; and Proust (Independent).

The essential painting in the Tate's exhibition, Ruskin, Turner And The Pre-Raphaelites, is John Everett Millais's portrait of the writer standing by a mountain stream. The thing to say about it is that Ruskin is "not really there" (the Guardian) - the background was painted first, and Ruskin's body was added later . The effect is that his feet seem not quite planted on the ground - appropriately for a man who was repressed and estranged from his own body. (Gossip has it that he had a wedding-night shock when he discovered that his wife, Effie Grey, had pubic hair - the marriage was never consummated.) Ruskin was also responsible for burning nearly all the erotic pictures by Turner. Express surprise when your friends admit they never knew Turner painted well-endowed satyrs and saucy girl-on-girl action, even though the few pictures that survived are on show for the first time.

It's OK to like Turner, even if you say the erotica is a little gamey (Daily Telegraph). But it is essential to dislike the Pre-Raphaelites. They were sentimental and fatally disconnected from the modern world (Observer). As for Ruskin's watercolours and drawings - the subjects are flora, fauna, scenery and architecture - praise his acute observation of nature and talk about the "Ruskinian way of seeing". Say he was very good, for an amateur.

Dinner-party observation number one: It is the first time the Tate has employed an architect (Richard MacCormac) to design a show but is nicely incongruous that Jocasta Innes, queen of stencilling, has done all the paint colours.

Dinner-party observation number two: Isn't it amusing how the critics have to write about one of their own - a critic who was often wrong and went mad.

 Ruskin, Turner and the Pre-Raphaelites at the Tate, London SW1 (020 7887 8000) until May 29.
 John Ruskin: The Later Years by Tim Hilton (Yale University Press, £20)

 John Ruskin: No Wealth But Life by John Batchelor (Chatto Windus, £25).

webTitle: Dons to lose at Hammer time

fields.headline: Dons to lose at Hammer time
fields.standfirst: You want a sure-fire accumulator? Mike Hodgkinson, our man with more betting accounts than you've had hot dinners, has got one. Read on...
fields.trailText: You want a sure-fire accumulator? Mike Hodgkinson, our man with more betting accounts than you've had hot dinners, has got one. Read on...
fields.body:
At Upton Park on Sunday, West Ham will face a side who have consistently turned them over in recent years. Wimbledon have lost only three of their last ten games here, and over the last six Premiership visits they have won three convincingly - especially last season when they overturned a three-goal lead. But don't count on them continuing this impressive trend over the weekend. As a party-crashing force to rival an Oliver Reed/Lee Marvin tag team, the Dons have lost much of their swagger of late. Expect Harry Redknapp's team to deal with them comfortably.

Last weekend, the Hammers held Euro-dudes Chelsea to a draw but Wimbledon were humiliated by Leeds and will not relish yet another trip away from home which has defeat written all over it. They have failed to snatch three points on the road since the opening day of the season when they beat Watford - the Premiership's least coveted scalp. If you fancy backing Wimbledon to lose their fight against relegation, take the fives now - the odds will have shortened by Saturday evening.

Sunderland's home run is not looking impressive at the moment, which doesn't prepare them too handsomely for Everton's visit on Saturday. This season's sister fixture at Goodison brought a 5-0 defeat for Peter Reid's men, who have lost the form that held them up there with the best at the turn of the year. Expect Everton to bounce back from last week's defeat by Newcastle and prolong the Mackems' misery. Sunderland's interest in mouldy Toffee Don Hutchison should add even more colour to what is already a top scrap on paper.

Manchester United travel to Bradford on Saturday where anything less than a resounding victory will be deemed a failure. However, the trip to Valley Parade should have held no fears for Arsenal a couple of week's back, but ended in bitter disappointment - the Gunners lost 2-1. With that result behind them, another Bantams win is well within the realms of possibility. It's worth remembering that they scored against Leeds and lost by only one goal. "We need to start picking up points on Saturday and that will give us all the lift for the final run in," says City skipper Stuart McCall. Dead right, but he should also heed the masterplan of Bantam defender Gunnar Halle, who has suggested bringing in a tractor to rough the pitch up a bit. If United get stuck in the ruts, Bradford might just nick it.

When you get to the bookies on Saturday it may be a good idea to add these three tips to home wins for Arsenal and Chelsea (the weekend's Premiership bankers) and an away win for Spurs at Watford. Then write "six fivefolds and one accumulator" on the weekend coupon, at £1 per line (total £7), which means you'll get paid if one of the predictions goes down and the rest come in. Good luck.

Recommended

West Ham v Wimbledon - home win

Sunderland v Everton - away win

Bradford v Manchester United - home win

Arsenal v Coventry - home win

Chelsea v Southampton - home win

Watford v Tottenham - away win

webTitle: Assembly turns down BAe Airbus grant

fields.headline: Assembly turns down BAe Airbus grant
fields.trailText:
BAe Systems has warned that its Broughton factory in Flintshire might not reap the full benefit of expected work on the A3XX Airbus project after the refusal of £25m in grant aid by the Welsh
assembly.
fields.body:
BAe Systems has warned that its Broughton factory in Flintshire might not reap the full benefit of expected work on the A3XX Airbus project after the refusal of £25m in grant aid by the Welsh assembly.

The company, which has already been promised £530m in start-up investment from the government towards the £2bn UK element of the project, had been expected to create 1,400 new jobs at the north Wales site where it wants to build a £100m-plus factory alongside existing facilities for the assembly of the new-generation Airbus's wings.

But workers have now been told that BAe's application for regional selective assistance towards construction of the plant has been turned down by national assembly first secretary Rhodri Morgan.

An internal memo told staff that the decision would force the company "to look again" at the extent of work that would be carried out at Broughton.

The company's warning has caused consternation among union leaders and politicians in north-east Wales. Mr Morgan, who yesterday was opening a new Toyota castings plant in nearby Deeside, refused to be drawn into a slanging match over the decision to turn down BAe.

But sources in the Welsh assembly pointed out that all applications for RSA grants are subject to rigorous appraisal and that Mr Morgan had taken his decision following advice from the Welsh Industrial Development Advisory Board, an independent statutory body.

Regional selective assistance is a discretionary grant available in UK-assisted areas towards capital investment projects that create or safeguard jobs.

Officials pointed out that in order to qualify for such aid projects had to be viable, provide a net benefit to the UK economy and demonstrate a need for assistance.

Val Feld, who chairs the Welsh assembly's economic development committee, said: "We all want to see support given to British Aerospace, but we are subject to very clear rules on the whole question of the funding that goes to businesses."

Val Feld, who chairs the Welsh assembly's economic development committee, said: "We all want to see support given to British Aerospace, but we are subject to very clear rules on the whole question of the funding that goes to businesses."

webTitle: Smyth in bid to oust Trimble

fields.headline: Smyth in bid to oust Trimble
fields.standfirst: Opponent of Good Friday deal announces challenge
fields.trailText:
24/03/2000: David Trimble is facing the most serious crisis in his leadership
                                                  of the Ulster Unionists, after the party's chief whip at
                                                  Westminster announced that he would mount a leadership
                                                  challenge this weekend.
fields.body:
David Trimble is facing the most serious crisis in his leadership of the Ulster Unionists, after the party's chief whip at Westminster announced that he would mount a leadership challenge this weekend.

Rev Martin Smyth, the MP for South Belfast, ended weeks of speculation about a "stalking horse" leadership candidate when he declared that he would attempt to topple Mr Trimble, after the UUP leader indicated that he was prepared to re-establish Northern Ireland's power-sharing executive.

Hardline unionists were angered when Mr Trimble suggested during a visit to Washington last week that he would be prepared to sit down in government with Sinn Fein again - ahead of IRA disarmament - provided the republicans offered cast-iron guarantees about decommissioning their weapons.

Mr Smyth, an opponent of the Good Friday agreement, made it clear that he would abandon the peace process when he said yesterday that he would offer a "more vigorous promotion of Ulster Unionist policy".

A close ally of the former UUP leader Jim Molyneaux, Mr Smyth is unlikely to unseat Mr Trimble at tomorrow's meeting in Belfast of the 858-strong Ulster Unionist council. But a strong vote for the former grand master of the Orange Order could severely weaken Mr Trimble, paving the way for a heavyweight challenger, such as the party's deputy leader, John Taylor, or the dissident MP Jeffrey Donaldson.

Mr Smyth indicated that this was his aim when he said that he "had no real desire" to lead the party.

Mr Donaldson, who walked out of the Good Friday agreement hours before the 1998 signing ceremony, last night threw his weight behind Mr Smyth. "A vote for Martin Smyth on Saturday will be a clear warning to the government and to republicans that unionists have given enough," he said.

His remarks were echoed by MPs William Ross and William Thompson, who have been adamant opponents of Mr Trimble. Mr Thompson said: "Martin Smyth will have very significant support and I certainly believe he will give David Trimble a run for his money."

Mr Trimble remained defiant last night, saying that he was confident that his policy would be endorsed by the UUP council tomorrow. At a press conference at Stormont, he said he was "somewhat surprised and a little bit disappointed" by Mr Smyth's decision to challenge him.

"I think what Martin needs to do is to explain to people clearly what the objective is, and what policy is being pursued," Mr Trimble said.

The British and Irish governments will be carefully monitoring tomorrow's meeting, knowing that a strong vote for Mr Smyth could kill off hopes of reviving the power-sharing executive and set the peace process back by years.

Mr Smyth will tell the council that Mr Trimble was severely undermined when he entered government with Sinn Fein last year ahead of disarmament. He will hope to build on the 42% of party members who voted against Mr Trimble's decision to form the power-sharing executive.

Mr Trimble will seek to reaffirm his position by reminding the council that he honoured his pledge to abandon the executive if the IRA failed to disarm.

He yesterday received the support of the chairman of his party, Lord Rogan, his Westminster colleague Ken Maginnis and the former Stormont minister Michael McGimpsey, who said he was "astonished" by Mr Smyth's challenge.

Hardlinerwith a folksy appeal

For diehard Ulster Unionists who long for a return to the days when Sinn Fein was excluded from the political process, the Rev Martin Smyth is a comforting figure.

A Presbyterian minister who served as grand master of the Orange Order for 25 years, Mr Smyth made his greatest contribution to Northern Ireland during the annual Orange parades in July. In his familiar bowler hat, Mr Smyth delivered speeches which delighted his Orange audience but perplexed outsiders. His message appeared to be that the Union was at risk from the dark forces of nationalism, but that the good Orange folk should rely on the leadership provided by himself and the former UUP leader, Jim Molyneaux.

Mr Smyth, 68, and Lord Molyneaux, who resigned as party leader in 1995, refused to engage with nationalists in serious negotiations throughout the 1980s and early 1990s, ensuring that London and Dublin moulded the political process above the heads of Unionists.

It was only with the election in 1995 of David Trimble, who punched at the same intellectual weight as British and Irish ministers, that Unionism was able to influence the peace process.

Mr Smyth's leadership challenge will probably be remembered as his most remarkable achievement in an 18-year career as an MP.

Mr Smyth, married with two daughters, joined the Orange Order in the hardline Sandy Row area of Belfast and was educated at Methodist College, one of Northern Ireland's best schools.

fields.headline: My time at Summerhill
fields.trailText: Being a pupil at Summerhill turned you into a kind of anthropologist's field study, such was the fascination with what A.S. Neill's free school was really like on the ground. Less exotic and sensational most of the time than the endless tabloids that visited and bribed boys and girls to bathe naked together or wrote stories about staff having sex on the front lawn (there wasn't one) believed.
fields.body:
Being a pupil at Summerhill turned you into a kind of anthropologist's field study, such was the fascination with what A.S. Neill's free school was really like on the ground. Less exotic and sensational most of the time than the endless tabloids that visited and bribed boys and girls to bathe naked together or wrote stories about staff having sex on the front lawn (there wasn't one) believed.

My memories of the four years from age eleven that I spent at the ramshackle Victorian house with its overgrown grounds are a mix of camping in the big field on summer nights, sitting around in the long grass discussing pubescent feelings with friends and never worrying a member of staff would shoo you off to do something more purposeful.

In fact they often came and joined in. There was time pottering in the art room or going to the wonderful sewing groups held by Ulla, who took a great pride in getting us making our own clothes while lecturing us on the perils of bathing too often. Then there were the hours of what Philip Larkin called "forgotten boredom" - time when the freedom to do what you wanted seemed like an imposition. How I longed for compulsory activities on those occasions, although with hindsight I can see how much thinking and flowing of the imagination took place.

The freedom to choose whether or not to go to lessons was central to Neill's philosophy and he seemed at times to sabotage the possibility of learning too much even if we did go. I recall being in his English class while preparing for O levels and him complaining that the set text, The Autobiography of a Supertramp, was "awful rubbish".

Nor was he always very good at picking teachers - they would be selected for great personality and love of kids rather than pedagogic skill rather too often. But perhaps that was part of the grand plan: it had those of us - most in fact - who wanted to get a decent education feeling like omnivores put on to a macrobiotic diet. We emerged from Summerhill desperate for more.

What we did learn a lot about was democracy. Sitting around the large wooden hall for the weekly school meeting we discussed proposed new rules, and catapulted those we didn't like with a one person one vote system. We tried and punished pupils and staff who transgressed - and that included Neill, who sat like a giant garden gnome, watching and smiling his narrow, sardonic smile.

But did it succeed as a school? Depends what you mean by success. I didn't get the kind of academic grounding I'd have liked, but I chose to continue studying and got into my desired profession. I emerged with a great sense of the world being on my side, and Summerhill with its freedom philosophy was the model for the primary school I chose for my own children - who are now both at university.

fields.headline: Frock tactics
fields.standfirst: Last year Gwyneth wore an old-fashioned pink party dress... and it drew almost as much comment as her tearful acceptance speech. But what will she be wearing this year?  Jess Cartner-Morley  reports on the serious business of dressing for the Oscars
fields.trailText: Last year Gwyneth wore an old-fashioned pink party dress... and it drew almost as much comment as her tearful acceptance speech. But what will she be wearing this year? Jess Cartner-Morley reports on the serious business of dressing for the Oscars
fields.body:
On any other Sunday morning of the year, Rodeo Drive is empty. This Sunday, however, assistants at Gucci and next door at Prada will be at work at the crack of dawn, steaming creases out of dresses that have been sent over from Milan, ready to be driven to exclusive addresses around town. Just a few yards away at Van Cleef & Arpels, reinforced security vehicles will be waiting to courier millions of dollars worth of jewellery to the chosen few. At the upmarket beauty salons in the surrounding bijou streets, some of Hollywood's biggest names will be being waxed and buffed, while those not important enough to bag the coveted 2pm slot with the make-up artists and hairdressers will be having their foundation applied and preparing to sit around fully made-up all day.

Ridiculous? No. The Oscars draws the second largest TV audience of any event in the US (only the Superbowl is more popular). Last year, a cool one billion people worldwide watched the ceremony. For an actor or actress, that means more people might see you on Sunday night than saw your last film. When 30-second ad slots are snapped up for $1m, it's clear the perfect dress could get you a lottery win-worth of publicity for nothing. Equally, one unflattering hemline and your going rate will plummet.

This is not about wanting to look nice for a night out: it's about having to look perfect. Inevitably, the pressure is far higher for women than for men: while Tom Cruise told Entertainment Tonight he planned to "pull something out of the closet and dust it off", one actress asked to present an award last year almost cancelled when she discovered that her make-up artist and hairstylist were double-booked.

Jeannine Lobel, who did Julianne Moore's make-up last year, says the Oscars are "just too scary. You're such a target for criticism." And it's not even as simple as looking beautiful: you must also look appropriate. The Versace number Jennifer Lopez wore to the Grammies no doubt won her more admirers (the image was downloaded from the Grammy website 642,917 times in the next 24 hours) but too much overt sexiness is frowned upon by the Academy.

Similarly, patriotism can win you support: darling of the British press Kate Winslet wore Alexander McQueen to her night of Titanic triumph, while this year's Brit nominee, Janet McTeer, is tipped to be dressed by Vivienne Westwood. Gwyneth Paltrow was lauded last year for a dress that, arguably, was one of her less flattering, less stylish outfits, but as a proper pink party dress it scored on the glamour-for-all-the-family rating - and it was by Ralph Lauren, an American designer.

Philip Bloch, celebrity stylist and contributing fashion editor on InStyle magazine, says: "It's a chance for actresses to show different sides of their personality." Hence Hilary Swank, Best Actress nominee for her role as a transsexual in Boys Don't Cry, is widely tipped to be "doing sexy" at the Oscars (she wore tight black Versace to the Golden Globes), while Bloch predicts Paltrow might cause raised eyebrows. "She is getting a little bored of the whole good girl Gwyneth thing. Look at the see-through dress she wore to meet the president."

Of course, the fashion frenzy benefits the designers as much as the actresses. Dressing women for the Oscars is a holy grail for many: after all, as Bloch says: "No designers grew up thinking: I want to dress Mrs Hoffermeyer for her daughter's wedding. They grew up thinking: I want to dress Catherine Deneuve for the Oscars." Even more important is what it can do for business: a movie star looking fabulous in one of your creations not only garners unlimited publicity but stamps your label with the kind of fairytale prestige money can't buy. You've got to spend serious money to be in the running, though, which is why Oscar night is dominated by giants such as Giorgio Armani (the wealthiest designer in the world) and Versace, who last year scored with Madonna and Catherine Zeta Jones.

Greg Link runs StyleFile, an LA-based company that liaises between designers and celebrities. On previous Oscar nights, he has worked his magic for Versace and Alberta Ferretti. "When the nominees are announced, we pick who we think is right for the designer's image and send out look books [books of images from the catwalk shows], flowers and gifts. Then we have their stylists come in and look at the clothes, and if they like something, we'll have it altered for them." Rumours abound of designers offering trips on Concorde, 50% discounts for life and other extravagant gifts. The most anyone will admit to is flowers, but actresses do get to keep what they wear - except Chanel, who allegedly demand everything back.

As publicist for LA company People's Revolution, Ted Byrne is experienced in trying to get the right people to wear a designer's clothes. "It's hard work," he says, "because there aren't that many girls to go after."

Byrne thinks the hottest tickets to dress this year are Hilary Swank ("There's a buzz about her"), Julianne Moore, Cate Blanchett ("She's got the body"), Gwyneth Paltrow, Selma Hayek, Charlize Theron and Jennifer Lopez. Bloch adds Heather Graham to the list ("She's so sexy and so pretty and wears clothes so well") and Lucy Lui, who will be presenting (and is tipped to be wearing Versace). According to Bloch, actresses who go out on a limb in their image are less in demand. "Cameron [Diaz] has worn so many odd outfits recently that designers don't look to her so much now. And Drewy [Barrymore], she does her own thing." Similarly Chloe Sevigny, with her penchant for vintage YSL and brand-new St Martins graduates, is considered a wild card.

Film and fashion have always fed off each other. Back in 1934, sales of men's vests plummeted when Clark Gable wore a shirt over bare skin in It Happened One Night. Uma Thurman single-handedly caused a trend for dark nail varnish when she wore Chanel Rouge Noir in Pulp Fiction. But the fashion machine that now exists around the Oscars did not come into being until the late 80s, when Giorgio Armani set up an office in LA to network with Hollywood, with the wife of one of the producers of The Godfather as his publicist.

In the past five years, another important influence has been added to that of the designers: the high-profile stylist. Robert Triefus, head of communications for Giorgio Armani, insists: "Armani still has personal and meaningful relationships with personalities like Jodie Foster and Annette Bening. But there's no doubt that celebrities are increasingly surrounded by influential stylists, make-up artists and publicists."

Stylists such as Jessica Paster, who "does"Jennifer Aniston and Minnie Driver, wield huge power and Ted Byrne predicts that, because of this, the Oscars of the future will look less like a ballroom and more like a catwalk. "For instance, people are starting to accept that wearing pants can be chic - like the Chloe outfit Gwyneth wore to the Golden Globes. There are a lot of very sophisticated stylists working in LA these days." There may still be a few plot twists to come in the story of Hollywood's love affair with fashion.

fields.headline: Joint governors may end Ripon 'apartheid'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The first grammar school in England to survive a ballot on retaining its status is considering joint governor arrangements with the local comprehensive as part of moves to create a "single educational process" in a city historically divided by the 11-plus.
fields.body:
The first grammar school in England to survive a ballot on retaining its status is considering joint governor arrangements with the local comprehensive as part of moves to create a "single educational process" in a city historically divided by the 11-plus.

Governors from Ripon grammar school and Ripon College, the former local secondary modern which recently won specialist technology status, will formally propose the tie-up at meetings in the two schools next month.

The initiative coincides with plans to allow a pilot group of pupils to split their A-levels between the college and the grammar in the coming year, and is backed by the Ripon schools partnership which led the ballot campaign. Both governing bodies are expected to endorse the idea and seek approval from North Yorkshire local education authority, as a prelude to more radical steps.

"There is a feeling in favour of the schools going further, to have a group of governors in common, and perhaps a group whose membership rotates to encourage as much mingling between the two schools as possible," said David Curry, Conservative MP for Ripon and a former minister. "We made it clear during the ballot that the Ripon schools part nership was not going to be just an electoral expedient, but something which expressed much deeper intentions about the future of education in Ripon."

The joint governor proposal, which would be a national first, would be designed to ease a series of combined initiatives which were launched last week at an event in Ripon College for younger students from the school, the grammar and the independent Ripon choir school. The headteacher of Ripon College, Paul Lowery, said: "This arises from talks among governors and others about the need for partnership and what we could do in practice to encourage it. We already share some facilities with the grammar school and we hope that we'll be able to enlarge the A-level scheme in 2001 - a joint group of staff is working out timetables for both schools for that year to make the arrangement easier."

The pilot group will be offered the chance to combine two A-levels at their own school with one at the other - a college student doing business studies and computer studies, for example, will be able to take history at Ripon grammar. Similarly, a grammar pupil taking two traditional academic studies but wanting a vocational course for a third A-level, will join a sixth form course at the college.

The idea has been tried successfully this year with a handful of students - Mr Lowery has two grammar students in his current A-level business studies class with eight college pupils, in spite of the fact that the grammar tops the North Yorkshire academic league tables and the college comes bottom. Mr Curry said: "It can only benefit all the children of Ripon if people start to think instinctively about both schools, each with their particular strengths. That is the way to make sure that any residual apartheid is ended.

Governors from Ripon grammar school and Ripon College, the former local secondary modern which recently won specialist technology status, will formally propose the tie-up at meetings in the two schools next month. The initiative coincides with plans to allow a pilot group of pupils to split their A-levels between the college and the grammar in the coming year, and is backed by the Ripon schools partnership which led the ballot campaign. Both governing bodies are expected to endorse the idea and seek approval from North Yorkshire local education authority, as a prelude to more radical steps. "There is a feeling in favour of the schools going further, to have a group of governors in common, and perhaps a group whose membership rotates to encourage as much mingling between the two schools as possible," said David Curry, Conservative MP for Ripon and a former minister. fields.headline: Sounds familiar? Zut alors!
fields.standfirst: The Paris mayoral contest is strangely reminiscent of the London one, writes Alexandra Fouché
fields.trailText: The Paris mayoral contest is strangely reminiscent of the London one, writes Alexandra Fouché.
fields.body:
A celebrity-obsessed and media-loving rogue contender on the left; a weakened right unable to get its act together; bickering over the selection of the main party candidate. Sounds familiar?

Except that we're not talking about London, but about the Paris mayoral election, which promises to be as fraught as the London race. Things are already hotting up in the French capital for a ballot not due to take place until March 2001. Candidates on both sides of the political divide are lining up to represent their respective parties and speculation is rife as to who will come out on top.

Paris has traditionally had a rightwing mayor, but the recent problems encountered by the incumbent Jean Tiberi, whose image has been badly damaged by five years of scandals and judicial investigations, means that the left might for the first time gain control of the City of Light.

President Jacques Chirac was mayor of Paris for 18 years - from 1977 when Parisians were first allowed to elect their own mayor, until his election to the top job in 1995. He was succeeded by Mr Tiberi, a fellow member of the RPR Gaullist party.

Candidates seeking the mayoral nomination for the left include former socialist culture minister Jack Lang, currently mayor of the Loire Valley town of Blois and head of the parliamentary foreign affairs committee, and a relative unknown, Bertrand Delanoë, the president of the socialist group of the Council of Paris, the municipal body which elects the mayor.

Lang, an old-guard socialist and the most popular of the declared candidates on the left, is something of a Ken Livingstone figure, though the parallel has clear limits. Lang, who is closely associated to the reign of the late president François Mitterrand, is a limelight-loving, designer-suit wearing socialite - the archetypal "champagne socialist".

To those who suspect that Lang wishes to return to Paris for no other reason than his own ambition, the king of soundbites retorts that his dream is to restore Paris's supremacy over rivals such as Rome, Berlin or indeed London.

His vision for Paris is, like the man himself, nothing short of grandiloquent: "To give the city back to its inhabitants", he says, and "restore Paris to the rank befitting an economic, financial and intellectual capital".

Lang will first need to get past the hurdle of the socialist selection process, a secret ballot of Parisian party members on March 30.

The RPR candidate will be nominated by a party committee at the end of April, after consultation with the grassroots. In another similarity with the London contest, dispute is raging over the selection process, with many clamouring - so far in vain - for either a direct vote by party activists or at least some sort of primary ballots.

So intense is the infighting among the right that former RPR prime minister Edouard Balladur has called for an emergency meeting of opposition leaders "to find the best process to select the best candidate for the right" and avoid surrendering the right's hold on the capital.

Among potential rightwing candidates, the tarnished Tiberi has quite clearly become a liability, even though he will be standing again this time around and may even stand as an independent should he be rejected by his own party. More echoes of Livingstone? And then there is the rightwing heavyweight and unashamed eurosceptic Philippe Séguin, who's quietly waiting in the wings to declare himself. Once touted as a likely president of the RPR, the former mayor of Epinal in the Vosges is deemed a favourite if he puts himself forward - which is looking more and more likely.

fields.headline: M&S supplier cuts 600 Scottish jobs
fields.trailText: The textiles industry yesterday saw a further 600 jobs fall victim to the shake-out by Marks & Spencer.
fields.body:
The textiles industry yesterday saw a further 600 jobs fall victim to the shake-out by Marks & Spencer.

The closure and layoffs announced by Daks Simpson at two plants in Scotland bring the UK job losses caused by M&S's decision to buy more supplies abroad to 6,800 - on top of a similar number lost before last November's formal statement.

Unions see it as a further symptom of ministerial neglect of the manufacturing sector - as evidenced by this week's Budget package - and contrast it to the fuss made over the BMW closures.

John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB union, protested that "Marks & Spencer are bringing the same devastation to the UK clothing industry that BMW are bringing to the UK car industry. We urge ministers to intervene on behalf of M&S workers as vigorously as they are on behalf of workers at Rover."

M&S, which has lost market share in the high street, announced in November that it would cut its historic dependence on British suppliers from 70% to the national retail average of around 30%.

Yesterday's layoffs at Larkhall and Polbeth followed a series at Coats Viyella and Bairdswear. Mr Edmonds said: "It is imperative that the government starts to take action to prevent destruction of UK manufacturing industries."

fields.headline: 'Neo-Nazis responsible' for racist stabbing
fields.standfirst: Black Olympic athlete Ashia Hansen has gone into hiding with her white boyfriend Chris Cotter following a racially-motivated assault in a Birmingham car park
fields.trailText: Investigators suspect neo-Nazi extremists were responsible for the racially-motivated stabbing of the  boyfriend of British Olympic triple jumper Ashia Hansen.
fields.body:
Investigators suspect neo-Nazi extremists were responsible for the racially-motivated stabbing of the boyfriend of British Olympic triple jumper Ashia Hansen.

Chris Cotter, 28, was attacked by up to five men after parking his car in Birmingham on Tuesday night. Cotter, who is white, was approached by a man and subjected to abuse over his relationship with Hansen, who is black.

Police said three or four other white men then approached Cotter from behind, stabbed him three times in the back, slashed his forehead and kicked and punched him.

Mr Cotter was released from a hospital Thursday. He and Ms Hansen were reported in hiding Friday at an undisclosed location outside Birmingham.

"The attack was specific to Mr Cotter," West Midlands police superintendent Tony Garbett said. "We have no doubt it was racially motivated because of the connection between him and Ashia Hansen."

Ms Hansen, 28, is the reigning Commonwealth champion and indoor world-record holder in the triple jump. She is considered one of Britain's top medal hopes for the Sydney Games. Mr Cotter is a former long jumper.

Superintendent Garbett said Mr Cotter received a call of a "racist nature" on his mobile phone about three to four days before the attack. In addition, Ms Hansen received a "poison-pen style" unsigned letter Thursday which police say was linked to the attack.

Hours after the incident, Hansen received a note in the mail, saying: "You were lucky last night. We won't make the same mistake again," the Daily Express newspaper reported.

"The men who did this are evil," Hansen was quoted as saying. "They should be locked up and the key thrown away."

Hansen set the world indoor record in the triple jump in Valencia, Spain, in 1998 with a leap of 15.16 meters. She was placed fourth at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics and fifth at the 1997 World Championships. She won the gold medal at the 1998 Commonwealth Games and was world indoor champion in 1999.

Cotter's stabbing is the latest and most serious in a string of racist threats and attacks against high-profile mixed-race couples in Britain.

Olympic swimmer Sharron Davies and her former husband, runner Derek Redmond, were sent obscene and abusive letters, including some from the far-right group Combat 18, after their marriage in 1994. In 1997, a letter bomb concealed in a video cassette was sent to their house but it was intercepted and defused.

Retired heavyweight boxer Frank Bruno, former hurdler Kriss Akabusi and soccer star Paul Ince have all been warned by police they could be targets because of their mixed-race marriages or relationships.

webTitle: English clubs draw a mixed bag

fields.headline: English clubs draw a mixed bag
fields.standfirst:
Lazio upset quarter-final calculations
Champions League last eight: Team-by-team analysis
fields.trailText: An all-British Uefa Cup final looks a very real possibility, and the dream European Cup final between Manchester United and Chelsea is still on - but the chances of the latter happening looks slim.
fields.body:
An all-British Uefa Cup final looks a very real possibility, and the dream European Cup final between Manchester United and Chelsea is still on - but the chances of the latter happening looks slim.

Chelsea discovered the cost of losing their final group game at home to Lazio when they drew tournament favourites Barcelona - Gianluca Vialli's men will have to play out of their skins to overcome a side undefeated in Europe for two seasons.

They would then face either Lazio, their midweek conquerors, or Valencia in the semis.

Meanwhile, holders and second favourites United also face a big Spanish test - they have been drawn with 1998 winners Real Madrid.

If the champions beat Roberto Carlos, Steve McManaman et al, they would then face the team they defeated so dramatically in last year's final - Bayern Munich. But only if the Germans manage to defeat Porto, who did a United by scoring twice in the last 13 minutes of the 1987 final to turn Bayern victory into abject defeat.

Meanwhile, the first all-British Uefa Cup final since 1972 is still a possibility - Leeds and Arsenal have avoided each other in the draw for the semi-finals of the Uefa Cup.

Leeds have had the better of the draw. They face Galatasaray, who capitulated 5-0 at home the last time they faced British opposition - Chelsea doing the damage. David O'Leary's men will also play the crucial second leg at Elland Road.

Arsenal must play their home leg first, although that is the least of Arsene Wenger's worries. The Highbury club have drawn Lens, who beat them over two "legs" in last year's Champions League.

Valencia v Lazio
Real Madrid v Manchester United
Porto v Bayern Munich

Champions League semi-finals

Real Madrid or Manchester United v Porto or Bayern Munich
Valencia or Lazio v Chelsea or Barcelona

Uefa Cup semi-finals

Galatasaray v Leeds United
Arsenal v Lens

webTitle: Dot.com drama starts up on BBC2

fields.headline: Dot.com drama starts up on BBC2
fields.standfirst:
Art mimics life in everyday story of internet business by This Life team

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Confirmation that the internet start-up is the hippest career decision of the moment came yesterday when the producers of the celebrated series This Life announced their next project will be set in the world of the net entrepreneurs.
fields.body:
Confirmation that the internet start-up is the hippest career decision of the moment came yesterday when the producers of the celebrated series This Life announced their next project will be set in the world of the net entrepreneurs.

Where the cult BBC2 show about a group of thrusting young lawyers sharing a house focused on their messy relationships, drug consumption and frenzied socialising, its successor concentrates on the professional lives of the next generation.

With a working title of dot com, the multimillion-pound series will feature a group of 20- and 30-somethings trying to launch an internet start-up company. It will track their efforts to raise finance, generate new ideas to produce their dream website and become fabulously wealthy.

Any similarities to the recent story of the millions garnered by the young entrepreneurs Martha Lane-Fox and Brent Hoberman when they floated their lastminute.com business are purely coincidental, according to the BBC, which has commissioned the series.

A spokesman said dot com had been in development in strict secrecy for over a year and was not inspired by the rash of internet launches.

World Productions, run by Tony Garnett, one of the nation's leading drama producers, will film the 20-part series this summer.

Mr Garnett, who refused to make a third series of This Life despite its popularity and the pleas of the BBC, is notoriously unwilling to talk about his projects. He was abroad yesterday and refused to comment on the commission.

His programmes, though, are known for their controversial characters and storylines. The Cops, his last BBC 2 series, opened with footage of a policewoman taking drugs in a nightclub, while This Life featured explicit sex scenes and drug taking.

Jane Root, the channel's controller, said dot com was one of the first programmes she commissioned on taking over the channel last year and described it as "surprising and inventive", adding "aspects of it are like nothing that has been seen before on British television".

A team of writers, including This Life veterans Amelia Bullmore and Richard Zajdlic, are working on the drama. It will feature an ensemble cast of unknowns.

Despite the lack of bankable stars on screen, dot com is believed to be one of BBC2's biggest commissions. The BBC refused to comment on budgets, but a contemporary drama series of this scale would generally cost around £8m.

fields.headline: Doreen
fields.trailText: You won't have heard of Doreen. She's responsible for the shapely figure of thousands of women throughout the UK, yet her presence is virtually undetectable. Doreen is the silent heroine of the lingerie world, uplifting a million women every year with her silken charms. For Doreen is a bra.
fields.body:
You won't have heard of Doreen. She's responsible for the shapely figure of thousands of women throughout the UK, yet her presence is virtually undetectable. Doreen is the silent heroine of the lingerie world, uplifting a million women every year with her silken charms. For Doreen is a bra: Triumph's bestseller, no less, a position she has held for 30 years. At last month's Lingerie Industry Awards, she was honoured with the Classic Design Award for the third year running.

So what's the secret of Doreen's success? "She's very comfortable," a Triumph spokesperson says simply. "She's more of an older person's bra, I suppose, though my sister wore one when pregnant with triplets and she hasn't looked back."

True, Doreen isn't exactly a bra designed for seduction. Those of you with an eye for these things might have noticed a certain... generosity of strap width and fullness of cup. When compared with your skimpy Ultrawondersuperboosts, she comes off rather badly; a kind of stoic Mondeo to their flashy Mazda. But underwear ain't all about sex appeal. Sometimes a woman wants to feel supported, too.

"It does look quite a heavy garment, but for the customer who wants to be covered, it's the best," says David Hornbuckle, Triumph's director. "Ladies of all ages like the support it gives. Fit a lady in a Doreen bra, put her blouse or jumper back on, and that's the bra she'll want. It does a superb job in terms of support and shape."

Doreen costs £19 from major department stores (stockist enquiries 01793 720232), has 39 separate components and comes in 63 different fittings across nine back and eight cup sizes - the largest Doreen is a whopping 46H. Colour options are restricted to black or white, though a limited edition run in mango and lilac appeared last autumn. "We decided it was about time we did something different for Doreen," Hornbuckle explains.

We say: leave Doreen alone. She shouldn't bow to the vagaries of fashion but should remain purely functional. There will always be a place in the lingerie firmament for boulder holders. Although we don't advise wearing Doreen under this season's chiffon blouse.

fields.trailText: Nuff Gisele already: who's the hot new model for spring? Any takers? Are you busty and Brazilian enough? This month's star is in fact Belgian and as flat-chested as a 20s pin-up. It's Hannelore, an aubergine-haired waif with limpid blue eyes and pale, pale skin.
fields.body: Nuff Gisele already: who's the hot new model for spring? Any takers? Are you busty and Brazilian enough? This month's star is in fact Belgian and as flat-chested as a 20s pin-up. It's Hannelore, an aubergine-haired waif with limpid blue eyes and pale, pale skin. Already featured in Harper's Bazaar, W and Dutch, true proof that she has arrived comes in March's Italian Vogue, arguably the most influential Vogue of all on the photography front. As well as gracing the cover, she's the star of a 36-page fashion shoot by Steven Meisel. She also appears in April's Face, in a story whose title, Joan Alone, goes some way to explaining her current success. Devoid of make-up and fancy styling, Hannelore could be a ringer for Patti Smith: sallow, wistful and a little bit evil looking. But put her hair in rollers, rim her eyes in kohl and wrap her in Pucci, and she morphs into a young Joan Collins. Perfect for this season's fixation with the 80s. "Hannelore is one of the most adaptable models working today," says her booker at Models One. "She has such an interesting look. Oh, and she's a lovely girl, too." Next season, expect some big ad campaign action: book her now before her rates go up, while she's still a lovely girl.

webTitle: Ineffectual winger, Reluctant official and Unhappy striker

fields.headline: Ineffectual winger, Reluctant official and Unhappy striker
fields.trailText: YOU REALLY SHOULDN'T HAVE LOST TO LAZIO
fields.body:
YOU REALLY SHOULDN'T HAVE LOST TO LAZIO

The draw for the rest of this season's Big Cup was made this morning to whoops of delight in police stations all across Surrey. That's because vicious brawling between rival sets of fans on the streets of Guildford has thankfully been avoided - Manchester United and Chelsea will not be playing each other in this year's competition.

Well, they could do, we suppose. In the final. But Chelsea have drawn Barcelona, so come off it. Louis Van Gaal's team, which includes Rivaldo, Luis Figo, Patrick Kluivert and the De Boers, are undefeated in this year's competition and have already scored 36 goals - Gianluca Vialli has started penning poetry which has been favourably compared by members of the literati to the work of Wilfred Owen in his later years.

Manchester United also face Spanish opposition, as the last two winners of Big Cup clash. Real Madrid should be an easier proposition than Barca, although United won't be taking anything for granted with the likes of lonely Nic Anelka dangerously holding his breath until he's sick on the sidelines, or Steve McManaman ready to boss the very peripheries of midfield with his trademark ineffectual runs into touch.

If United do the business, they'll not fancy meeting crack German outfit Bayern Munich in the semis (FC Hollywood would have to beat Porto to get there). And if Chelsea defeat Barcelona they'll face the winners of Lazio and Val... is there really any point in continuing with this?

HEY BIG SPENDER

Economist.com - Forthright opinion and lively analysis of global politics and business, plus handy summaries of the week's news. www.economist.com

HEY WEEKENDER

Football Unlimited's Saturday service. All the latest scores and match reports by 7pm. Isn't it lovely?

NOT BIG CUP, BUT STILL BIG. ALTHOUGH OBVIOUSLY NOT AS BIG

Big Cup wasn't the only competition on the Uefa agenda today. Uefa officials also spent a couple of minutes on their other prestigious competition, euro-vase. The Fiver has been following euro-vase, the exciting competition for Big Cup failures and people who come fifth, all season. And finally we've worked out which round it's at. Although admittedly that's only because a man said "semi-finals" in a very loud voice before making this morning's draw.

The draw took place because Uefa needed to kill a bit of time before the draw for Big Cup. So they shoved a couple of bored and unwilling Teutonic blokes on to the stage with a bag of four balls. They dragged their feet, yawned, stretched, had a quick scratch, and finally yanked the four spheres reluctantly out of their sack. Before you knew it, Leeds were playing Galatasaray, Arsenal were taking on Lens, and Gerhard and Ulf were scuttling off the stage to grab themselves a well-earned cup of coffee and a marzipan fancy.

It's a good draw for English football - both clubs should, in truth, beat their opponents. Leeds have a slightly harder tie than Arsenal, but then on the other hand they've got home advantage in the crucial second leg, something the Wengerboys won't enjoy. So should all go to plan, we'll have the first all-English euro-vase final since Alan Mullery beat Wolves in 1972. "Wouldn't that be a wonderful occasion?" chirruped Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale. It certainly would.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"It's fantastic for England, and we foreigners, who are hated by everybody, are pleased to help England to be the first country in Europe!" Chelsea defender Frank Leboeuf makes a point as his team avoid Man Utd in the Big Cup draw. By the way, we think you'll find it's not foreigners we've got the problem with, Frank.

THREE IS THE MAGIC NUMBER

There are three big games being played this Sunday. In the Premiership, title-chasing Leeds go to Leicester, while Arsenal host Coventry. Meanwhile, in Scotland, Celtic go to Ibrox for the season's 137th Old Firm game. But we're not going to mention any of that, because Sunday is the Sabbath and a day of rest. So the biggest matches played on Saturday will have to do. Follow the light of the Lord!

Bradford v Man Utd

It's not that big a mismatch and you never know. Just don't put your mortgage on Bradford, that's all we're saying. Paul Jewell has a full complement of players to choose from, but the Bantams are coming off the back of humiliation at the hands of Coventry - and when was the last time you saw that phrase? - so Jorge Cadete could force his way into the starting line-up. Ryan Giggs and David Beckham return to United's threadbare midfield, while Smiley and Surly (aka Dwight Yorke and Andy Cole) replace Teddy Sheringham and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer up front. There must be a time and a place to play Ted and Ole together, but it's not here and it's damn well not now.

Chelsea v Southampton

Southampton let in seven goals during their last away game. Oh look, here comes George Weah and free-scoring midfield dynamo Dennis Wise, both back from injury, refreshed and raring to go. And that's not the end of Saints manager Glenn Hoddle's worries. Tahar El Khalej has an ankle injury, Matthew Oakley has hamstring trouble, and Claus Lundekvam is fit and available for selection.

Liverpool v Newcastle

Titi Camara will partner £11m new boy Gentle Ben up front for Liverpool, as an unhappy Michael Owen has been left completely out of the squad. But that's not because his hamstring is looking like it's about to pop. Oh no no no no no no no. No! Newcastle can once again call upon Portuguese defender Mr Helder, but Bobby Robson won't be able to pick Nobby Solano or Diego Gavilan, who are on international duty with Peru and Paraguay respectively. Although at least he won't have to attempt to pronounce their names, bless him.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Celtic have denied reports that Willem II coach Co Adriaanse has been appointed as the club's new manager.

Leeds are preparing to make a move for teenage Dundee defender Lee Wilkie, according to Opta Soccer.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Fifa have agreed to introduce a harmonised international calendar by the year 2004. "Each association will be able to organise their own competition as they wish but they will have to respect the framework which has been elaborated," explained Fifa president Sepp Blatter.

Liverpool will be listed on the stock exchange within two years, according to a report in The Times. Their share value is expected to be around £400m.

The Nigerian FA have lodged a protest with Fifa after Chelsea ordered Celestine Babayaro to miss Nigeria's Olympic qualifying game tomorrow against Zimbabwe.

Leicester City striker Tony Cottee today signed a new 12-month deal with the Foxes.

Dunfermline have signed Motherwell's 31-year-old Dutch defender Michel Doesburg.

George Kirby, the former Watford and Halifax manager, died yesterday. He was 66. During his playing days with Everton, Coventry and Sheffield Wednesday, he was recognised as one of the bravest strikers in the top league. Until his illness from cancer, he was northern scout for QPR.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Hold The Back Page (7pm, 11pm, 3am SS2, 4.30am)

No ***'** ** *** ******! today. But your caring, sharing McCaff Message Board never rests, folks! "Elvis - you can say what you like, but for me the peregrine will always be THE number one bird of prey. Uncle Grayzie."

International Schoolboy Football (8pm, 12midnight SS2, 4am SS2)

They like football, the little boys.

British Eurosport: Uefa Cup Football (7.30pm)

Football occasionally interrupted by badly dubbed adverts for brands of tyre your local garage doesn't sell.

ONdigital: Don't Mention the Score (5.55pm)

Live coverage of Arminia Bielefeld v Hansa Rostock. It's German, you see, and the title's a reference to the second world war. That's both clever and not xenophobic.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Sport (7pm)

There might be football on it. If so, let's hope Alan Green has been given the night off after the views he's had to put up with this week.
