fields.headline: To die for
fields.standfirst: While most British followers of fashion wouldn't be seen dead in fur, skin as style statement is alive and well and living in Milan.  Judith Watt reports
fields.trailText: While most British followers of fashion wouldn't be seen dead in fur, skin as style statement is alive and well and living in Milan.
fields.body:
At last week's Furs a go-go award party in Milan, it wasn't just the fur that was flying. Egos were rampant, opinions were heated and animal welfare was a distant concern as the fasherati battled for the ethically dubious award for most creative use of fur. There was Nija, the black Native American designer, personal furrier to Puff Daddy, telling me that furs were "a black thang. Let me tell you, all those top designers, they watch me, oh, yes, they watch me and then they copy. Oh, yes, baby, they copy me."

Fur is a very Italian thang, too. As the centre of the fur market since Byzantium, Italy takes seriously its role as promoter of fur in fashion. Furs a go-go was the brainchild of Franca Sozzani, editor-in-chief of Italian Vogue. Her aim: to host a party, in conjunction with Saga Furs of Scandinavia, to show "fur as funky" and promote it as a versatile fabric that can be used right across the design spectrum.

Furs a go-go was a very Milanese occasion: held at 10 Corso Como, the chic shop-cum-gallery-cum-restaurant owned by Franca's sister, Carla Sozzani, it was the sort of event that would outrage PETA - and your average British animal lover. This year's award went to Fendi, the Italian label whose monogrammed baguette bag is a favourite with It girls the world over. Under the creative direction of Karl Lagerfeld, Fendi has reinvented itself as label of choice for those who love glamour, opulence and wearing dead animals with pride. Leopardskin? Lynx? Fox? Mink? Fendi use them all.

Paola Fendi, small, immaculately groomed, dressed in grey knitwear to match her hair, was delighted with her award. "Of course, fur has never been out of fashion. In Italy, never."

"I don't know what Milan would do without the Sozzani sisters," says Sara Kapp, PR and former model. "Without them... this would be just like that party in Breakfast at Tiffany's." Perhaps, although Holly Golightly might have balked at some of the decorations on offer at this particular soiree. In a kaleidoscope of fuchsias, oranges, purples, pinks and greens were furnishings in every permutation of fur imaginable: rugs made from skunks, foxes and rabbits, wall hangings styled à la Rothko in shaved lamb, a patchwork counterpane in fox, mink poufs and curtains, fox cushions and an antelope bedside rug. Models were dressed in Fendi, one an exotic bird of paradise in a coat with multicoloured tufts of sprouting mink, others in the coats of the same creature sheared down to a fine felt nap that felt like cashmere.

African American designer Lawrence Steele was smitten by all the fur on display. "Fabulous. I've never seen it used in so many ways. It's an education."

It is certainly an education to see how inventive Saga has been in promoting the use of fur within the fashion industry. Thanks to their initiatives, we can expect fur to be everywhere this autumn - like it or not. Saga produces the majority of the world's farmed fox and mink. Their marketing campaign has managed to entice many of the world's leading designers - Brits like John Galliano and Alexander McQueen among them - into using fur in their collections.

The big push has been going on since 1994, when US marketing mastermind Steve Gold first invited designers to "try out" Saga's full range of fur at their Design Centre in Copenhagen - for free, of course. Saga has been at the frontier of fur innovation, working traditional pelts into all sorts of modern, tactile permutations. A recent project in Copenhagen has produced mink and fox woven with chenille, for example.

Saga spokesperson Tom Christensen explains: "We want to see fur used in a more technically advanced fashion, with designers using it in new ways that are more linked to the rest of their collections. Jean Paul Gaultier is doing very interesting stuff and Tom Ford is styling fur in a completely modern way. So, of course, is Fendi."

By reworking fur into such obscure permutations, of course, Saga is also cleverly disguising its origins: making the final effect as far removed as possible from the basic fact that it's the pelt of a dead animal.

Saga is also canny enough to push fur at college level, just when impoverished students are most vulnerable to the offer of free fabric, whatever it's made out of. Saga works with students at Central Saint Martins and the Royal College of Art: last year, the RCA's Jose Rodriguez was sponsored by Saga and designed a Russian ratskin (sic) coat. It is currently in talks with a variety of colleges, specifically to promote the use of fur as a fibre with textile students, and it has recently worked with Bella Freud, Jeremy Scott, Michael Kors and Julien Macdonald, although Macdonald dropped Saga as a sponsor hours before his autumn/winter show at the Dome last month, after receiving threats from animal rights protesters.

This winter, Lawrence Steele has designed fox and mink coats with the skin side covered in 24 carat gold leaf. "I love the quality of luxury about fur," he says. Naomi Campbell (who once famously declared that she would rather go naked than wear fur), Oprah Winfrey and Julia Roberts are all rumoured to be clients of Steele's.

Saga might be fighting to invest fur with a new, radical chic, but in Europe and America, the battle for fur acceptance was won years ago. In societies such as the US and Milan, where money defines class, fur is inextricably linked with anxieties over status. It defines who you are.

Lisa Strathdee of cutting-edge London design consultancy L.I.T.E. shrugs at the idea that Milan could ever give up fur. "It wears too well with gold," she says simply.

At the Furs a go-go party, nobody was sitting on the fence. "It's very important for fur to be valued. It has always dressed kings and queens, and is a precious and beautiful thing," said fashion consultant Sonja Baras. Distasteful as such opinions may be to animal lovers, the reality is that fur use is on the up in the fashion industry and nothing can stop its progress. Now that it comes in ever more imaginative guises, the message for autumn is: make sure you know what you are buying.

webTitle: Most wanted:  Wild at Heart flowers

fields.headline: Most wanted:  Wild at Heart flowers
fields.trailText: Wild at Heart, Notting Hill's petal preener of choice, is opening a new concession in the trendier-than-thou Great Eastern Hotel in Liverpool Street.
fields.body: City boys aren't famed for their knowledge of all things floral; standard Interflora fare is the most they stretch to. Now, however, you can rest safe in the knowledge that if your beau works in the square mile, you'll be treated to an array of blooms that are as fashionable as you are. On Monday, Wild at Heart, Notting Hill's petal preener of choice, is opening a new concession in the trendier-than-thou Great Eastern Hotel in Liverpool Street, (020-7618 5350). fields.headline: William Gibson online: the transcript
fields.trailText:
jj1: Do you think the internet will be entirely consumed by dot com commercialism, or will there still be a place for information sharing and community?
William Gibson: Always room for interstitial activity.
fields.body:
jj1: Do you think the internet will be entirely consumed by dot com commercialism, or will there still be a place for information sharing and community?
William Gibson: Always room for interstitial activity.

mmreed: Hi, I can't make the ICA talk - could you sum up what you'll be saying about technology's effect on culture? Thanks
WG: Main point: that technology isn't legislated into existence, hence the market runs the show.

shem32: Neuromancer seemed to come from nowhere, but it can't have been that weird... who or what were your influences? And what drove you to write it? And - by the way - do you get annoyed at still being called a cyberpunk?? Thanks a lot, really like the books
WG: Burroughs, Ballard, Pynchon... Desperation. It seems a rather tired phrase today.

MPotter: Do you still use a typewriter to write your novels - kinda paradoxical for "the father of cyberpunk"? Or is it a deliberate choice on your part, a conscious rejection of the "techno-world"?
WG: Mac Performa. When I wrote NEUROMANCER there were virtually no PCs. The myth of the luddite is just that.

SKDavies2: What does cyberpunk actually mean?
WG: A FLAVOR OF POPULAR CULTURE.

tamara: I believe the Japanese created cyberpunk. Were you heavily influenced by manga or anime?
WG: In a distant, peripheral way.

greenday234: How do you think your subjects and style have changed since you started writing - ie as technology itself has changed and advanced? It often seems that with the matrix you envisaged the net before it happened... are you disappointed with what we have now? do you think experience of surfing as a 3-D environment will ever happen - and do we even want it to...?
WG: I think the whole thing is coming along very nicely, and in its own good time.

greenday234: There's now a virtual newsreader on the net... is this the idoru made not flesh but reality?
WG: Not unless she has a fan club and rock stars willing to marry her.

Rebeccar: Is the web just the new home shopping channel?
WG: Depends what you want to buy...

hartmam: You: "I really don't see myself as a futurist. I think the world we live in is so hopelessly weird and complex that in order to come to terms with it, you need the tools that science fiction develops." Me: "What are the tools that science fiction develops?"
WG: Extrapolation, recontextualization, exaggeration.

TezukaOzamu: The rate of change in the modernisation of Japan since World War II was rapid, but not as fast as that happening in China now. What do you think the west can learn by looking to East Asia for clues on how to rapidly adapt to technological changes? Or would you reject the East Asian model as it leads to high levels of dehumanisation?
WG: The east is where it's happening NOW.

djoakey: Hi. Yes, yes, I know, cyberspace and vison of the future and all that, but I think your novels also have gripping plots and are great reads. Furthermore, "Count Zero" is the only book I've read which contains a character with the surname "Oakey". Of course, he had to be a leather-jacketed villain who was zapped mid-story. Any chance of a more humane reincarnation for this character?
WG: Thanks.

gwrach: I have really enjoyed ALL your books. Thanks for writing them. 1 One thing I have noticed is that gradually your characters seem to be relying less and less on some sort of virtual reality, and becoming more removed from/independent of/aware of the influence and power of data transmitted through various media technologies. -- Is our current obsession with data foraging a danger you are trying to warn us of?

2 The UK is just beginning to wake up to the use of the Internet, and the WWW in particular - or less waking up to, more being manipulated into using. Do you think we shall end up being wired from the womb - and doomed (for want of a better word) to endless surfing for superficial information.. ie window shopping for data as well as secondhand watches?

3 The Sagrada Familia Cathedral features in the virtual background in one of your novels (Count Zero) - as Baron Samedi successfully sees the villain (Josef Virek) off.--- Did you know Gaudi is being considered for Beatification. Is this your influence? (!) Hope your ICA talk goes well tonight. Jen Cairns, Wales. We'd all be there this evening, but no trains, no buses, no roads, no money!
WG: One should always be aware of what one invites into the home... I think that one day literally everything will be interconnected. St. Gaudi? First I've heard of this. Extraordinarily peculiar structures. They must have a sense of humour, the Catholics of Barcelona.

desconocid: How do you think people will cope psychologically later this century as machines and computers become more smart than people; as people are increasingly not needed to do paid work; as people become increasingly unnecessary and expendable (to those who hold the money in our societies)?
WG: If what we are experiencing is in fact the end of the industrial age, there will be a great deal of dispossession in any case.

sgcc2: An earlier poster talked about Japanese influence, and those are visible through a lot of earlyish cyberpunk. But do you think that the far east is losing its technological allure? Will India become a new sci-fi locus?
WG: I think that if there were a contemporary version of cpunk (not that there should be) Indian material would be quite hot.

TezukaOzamu: In a rapidly changing world lateral thinking becomes imperative in order to adapt quickly to new technology, and to incorporate it into modern culture. What do you think?
WG: Read Edward De Bono.

dfic1999: Someone once said that the two driving forces behind the invention and use of new technology were sex and the military. What do you think? (I feel your early work only embraces the military side)
WG: Pornographers invariably pick up on and learn to use latest media.

demannu: To what extent have Burroughs and Pynchon been an influence on your work? How is the Abel Ferrara film coming on? p.s. do you use hotline? and if so for what?
WG: The Ferrara film's gone to video already. Says something.

TezukaOzamu: 1) Do you have any views at all on the activities of hackers? 2) Do you intend to take your stories off earth in any significant way? love your work, thanks
WG: Hackers aren't so much fun anymore... No space fic for WG.

tamara: Hello William What music are you listening to at the moment? (I'm thinking of the space station dub here...) Do you think a well-honed lyric and decently-distorted riff still has the power to effect social change - or, tracking back, did it ever in the first place? hope the ICA goes well thanks
WG: The Who on BBC. "Substitute".

Meatloaf: Can you see a day when a vast network of computers will enable human beings from all over the globe to talk to each other as if they were in the next room? Or at least allow them to look at porn?
WG: Yes...

tamab: One criticism or comment on your Sprawl trilogy (fairly or not) was that it fetishised escaping the body; retreating into a world where the mind/body split bordered on absolute when mediated through technology (Case = mind in cyberspace/ body = 'meat'). However, the Idoru's fate at the end of ATP seems to reintroduce 'the body' as a goal or something to be desired/strived for. Do you see 'the body' as a concept something that needs more attention in terms of technology or in the science fiction writing that has emerged form the 'cyberpunk' authors?
WG: In ATP the digital reverts into the physical.

Maryet99: What do you think about screening of your books? Thousands of people wait for many years for "Neuromancer" movie; when it will be created, if it really will be? And, what do _you_ think about Johnny Mnemonic movie? Does it show your original ideas or not? Some people here (in Russia) think that this movie isn't real "cyberpunk" and that the book is definitely better than the movie; what will you say yourself? What do you think about "New Rose Hotel" movie? What do you think about other movies which declare "cyberpunk" style, for example, "The Matrix", "Nirvana" or others?.. So I'm glad to say you that here in Russia are living many real fans of your books ;) Thank you for everything you've done. *big* thanks.
WG: JM was a brave try, didn't quite make it. Same for NRH. I like THE MATRIX quite a LOT.

tamab: Do you see nanotechnology as potentially changing the very fabric of society (as suggested, really, in ATP)? More to the point, do you see the possibility of making information (eg Rei) into 'reality' as the point 'where it all changes' and yet nothing changes?
WG: Nanotech resets every parameter in the human universe. Utterly.

tamab: Once the global(?) publicity tour for ATP is over, what do you think your next novel might be like? Oh, and is there any chance of your publicity tour bringing you to Australia (I can hope)?
WG: More like a contemporary novel but more hallucinatory? I love Australia, by the way.

jonCG: First off, I loved All Tomorrow's Parties... And liked it better than Idoru or VL, much as I liked MLO more than the first two Sprawl novels... Your recent books have some characters display an almost Zen approach to information gathering; as if you see (or they see) the use of information technology as intuitive rather than a learned skill. Is that a fair comment? Also, what's you favourite watch?
WG: Jaeger-LeCoultre Mark XI, 1953.

Maryet99: Will you give someday an online interview not in plain message board, but in real-time chat? And if so, how can we get the information? Where is the best source of information "what is new about you", your new works, books/movies, interviews etc? Do you think that the future you described in "Neuromancer" has a real chance to become _real_ future?
WG: I can't type!!!!

m23: I have noticed in the work of others (Jeff Noon, the Wachowski Brothers for example) references to Lewis Carroll's Alice. Do you feel that contemporary explorations of the virtual are as much about an escape to a new Wonderland as they are techno-adventures? Do the Alice stories have any resonance to you?
WG: Distantly and very far away...

robmew: Hey William, Love your books. The film the Matrix lent heavily on lots of your ideas from your books but I don't think there was a credit for you. How do you feel about this? Cheers, Rob
WG: Fair cop. All WG bits nicely digested.

demannu: is there anybody out there?
WG: Out where?

gwrach: I think it was Eco who said that something along the lines of.. after writing a book authors should die because they interfer with the text... don't you get fed up with being asked to interpret your books? Thanks, Jen WG: I am only another reader, in that sense. My function here is largely ritual.

tom26: How much of your success as an author do you think you owe to Philip K Dick, if any?
WG: He was not an influence. On me, anyway.

truthfully: What is your definition of CyberPunk?
WG: "I don't call it anything, said Frankie Lee, with a smile."
Okay people, Elvis has left the building. I'm outta here. Bye. Thanks. Wm.

fields.headline: Prophet of the new
fields.standfirst: Eternal  enfant terrible  Pierre Boulez is 75 this week. As the South Bank celebrates his birthday with a weekend of concerts, Andrew Clements considers the composer's musical legacy
fields.trailText: Eternal enfant terrible Pierre Boulez is 75 this week. As the South Bank celebrates his birthday with a weekend of concerts, Andrew Clements considers the composer's musical legacy
fields.body:
For those of us who have thought of Pierre Boulez as a fixed star in our concert-going firmaments for as long as we can remember, it's hard to accept that he will reach his 75th birthday on Sunday.

London, quite rightly, is doing the anniversary proud; the London Symphony Orchestra has already put on the four concerts of Boulez 2000, in which he conducted new works as well as 20th-century staples from his repertory, and this weekend the South Bank is hosting two days of celebrations, which will include a recital by Pierre-Laurent Aimard, two concerts by the London Sinfonietta, and the premiere of 12 specially commissioned birthday tributes. It will end with Boulez conducting the Ensemble Intercontemporain in his masterpiece Pli Selon Pli.

It's a worthy salute to the musician who has worked harder than anyone else to broaden the musical perspectives of audiences on two continents over the last half-century. When I first heard him conduct live, at the Festival Hall in 1972, he was already in full flight in his attempts to shake up the musical culture of London; he was chief conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra and just about to take on the New York Philharmonic as well.

With both orchestras his mission was the same - to persuade concert-goers that the music of the 20th century was their music, that the barrier between them and much of what had been written since 1900 was imaginary and not real. Only if we got to grips with the music of yesterday, Boulez reasoned, could we fully appreciate the music of today.

There was also artistic self-interest in that crusade, of course. Though there have been periods in his life - especially during the late 60s and the early 70s - when the opposite seemed true, Boulez was and remains a composer first and a conductor second (he began his second career by taking charge of his own early scores), and he belongs to a generation of composers (also including Berio, Stockhausen, and Nono) who in the 50s took forward the implications of modernism in a ruthlessly rigorous fashion.

His revolutionary approach took few prisoners in those days - even the patron saint of serialism was castigated in Boulez's infamous 1951 article "Schoenberg is Dead" for failing to carry through the implications of his radicalism. The tag of "intolerant propagandist" that is still sometimes hung around Boulez's neck (as recently as this week in the pages of the Daily Telegraph) dates back to that time, when his dismissals of composers like Britten, Shostakovich and Henze as hopelessly conservative carried real venom.

He's mellowed a lot since then, even if not quite enough to conduct any of those composers, any more than he has come round to accepting the artistic worth of Verdi and Puccini or embraced the wonderful world of minimalism. But he commands a far wider range of repertoire now than he did even 30 years ago.

It would been hard then, for instance, to imagine Boulez recording Bruckner's Eighth Symphony, or Strauss's Also Sprach Zarathustra, both of which are due to appear this year, and in old age he now uses charm to achieve what he wants rather than the razor-sharp polemics of old. And what he wants is much the same as what he wanted when he first conducted a symphony orchestra in London 35 years ago - for the music of our time to be heard in the best possible performances with the best possible acoustics, before an audience that has been given the maximum amount of help in getting to grips with it.

In his native France, where he has had a tempestuous relationship with the successive governments, his persistence has brought into being not only IRCAM, the research centre beneath the Pompidou Centre in Paris, but more recently the Cité de la Musique on the outskirts of the capital, which is its complement. Where IRCAM was meant for composers, offering them state-of-the-art facilities to explore the ways in which new technology could extend their aesthetic possibilities, the function of the Cité is primarily educational.

In London, of course, Boulez was unable to wield the same financial clout or to effect such a sea change in the government's sponsorship of the arts. But what he did achieve here, both through the experiments in concert-giving that he tried out during his years at the BBC and in the revelatory performances that he continues to conduct, has left an indelible mark. The masterpieces of modernism at least - works by the Second Viennese School, Stravinsky, and Bartók - are established in the London repertory largely thanks to his exemplary interpretations, while even the music of his own contemporaries no longer guarantees certain box-office death.

At the moment it is much harder to place Boulez's own works in the same certain perspective. It is hard to decide, for example, whether his intense activity as a conductor has prevented him from composing as much as he might have done, or whether the apparent diversion into the concert hall was in fact a necessary change of emphasis. It's possible that in the 60s, when his conducting career really took off, that Boulez already knew he was facing a creative impasse in his work, that the line of development he had been following so unswervingly for 20 years was beginning to peter out. He would need a fresh impulse to start again.

IRCAM eventually provided that, but meanwhile conducting offered him an alternative creative role that he could fill magnificently, while he subjected his own past efforts to continual revision. "Work in progress" became an ever more frequent description of his pieces; as if he were attempting to recreate on his terms the concept of his hero Mallarmé, whose famous notional Livre had an indeterminate number of pages ordered in an infinite number of ways. For Boulez the idea of the finished, circumscribed artwork suddenly lost its meaning, and the technical processes he applied to his pieces seemed as if they could go on generating new material and new versions ad infinitum.

In 50 years, when Boulez will have long finished his revisions, and his whole output will be fixed forever, it might be easier to appreciate his achievement as an integrated whole. His music will survive, I've no doubt of that - works like Pli Selon Pli, Le Marteau Sans Maître, Le Soleil Des Eaux, Eclats/Multiples and ...explosante-fixe... have a clarity of organisation and a beauty of sound that will keep them fresh. Now, though, Boulez is still composing and still conducting with as much verve and energy as ever, and that is good news for us all.

London, quite rightly, is doing the anniversary proud; the London Symphony Orchestra has already put on the four concerts of Boulez 2000, in which he conducted new works as well as 20th-century staples from his repertory, and this weekend the South Bank is hosting two days of celebrations, which will include a recital by Pierre-Laurent Aimard, two concerts by the London Sinfonietta, and the premiere of 12 specially commissioned birthday tributes. It will end with Boulez conducting the Ensemble Intercontemporain in his masterpiece Pli Selon Pli. It's a worthy salute to the musician who has worked harder than anyone else to broaden the musical perspectives of audiences on two continents over the last half-century. When I first heard him conduct live, at the Festival Hall in 1972, he was already in full flight in his attempts to shake up the musical culture of London; he was chief conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra and just about to take on the New York Philharmonic as well. With both orchestras his mission was the same - to persuade concert-goers that the music of the 20th century was their music, that the barrier between them and much of what had been written since 1900 was imaginary and not real. Only if we got to grips with the music of yesterday, Boulez reasoned, could we fully appreciate the music of today. There was also artistic self-interest in that crusade, of course. Though there have been periods in his life - especially during the late 60s and the early 70s - when the opposite seemed true, Boulez was and remains a composer first and a conductor second (he began his second career by taking charge of his own early scores), and he belongs to a generation of composers (also including Berio, Stockhausen, and Nono) who in the 50s took forward the implications of modernism in a ruthlessly rigorous fashion. His revolutionary approach took few prisoners in those days - even the patron saint of serialism was castigated in Boulez's infamous 1951 article "Schoenberg is Dead" for failing to carry through the implications of his radicalism. The tag of "intolerant propagandist" that is still sometimes hung around Boulez's neck (as recently as this week in the pages of the Daily Telegraph) dates back to that time, when his dismissals of composers like Britten, Shostakovich and Henze as hopelessly conservative carried real venom. He's mellowed a lot since then, even if not quite enough to conduct any of those composers, any more than he has come round to accepting the artistic worth of Verdi and Puccini or embraced the wonderful world of minimalism. But he commands a far wider range of repertoire now than he did even 30 years ago. It would been hard then, for instance, to imagine Boulez recording Bruckner's Eighth Symphony, or Strauss's Also Sprach Zarathustra, both of which are due to appear this year, and in old age he now uses charm to achieve what he wants rather than the razor-sharp polemics of old. And what he wants is much the same as what he wanted when he first conducted a symphony orchestra in London 35 years ago - for the music of our time to be heard in the best possible performances with the best possible acoustics, before an audience that has been given the maximum amount of help in getting to grips with it. In his native France, where he has had a tempestuous relationship with the successive governments, his persistence has brought into being not only IRCAM, the research centre beneath the Pompidou Centre in Paris, but more recently the Cité de la Musique on the outskirts of the capital, which is its complement. Where IRCAM was meant for composers, offering them state-of-the-art facilities to explore the ways in which new technology could extend their aesthetic possibilities, the function of the Cité is primarily educational. In London, of course, Boulez was unable to wield the same financial clout or to effect such a sea change in the government's sponsorship of the arts. But what he did achieve here, both through the experiments in concert-giving that he tried out during his years at the BBC and in the revelatory performances that he continues to conduct, has left an indelible mark. The masterpieces of modernism at least - works by the Second Viennese School, Stravinsky, and Bartók - are established in the London repertory largely thanks to his exemplary interpretations, while even the music of his own contemporaries no longer guarantees certain box-office death. At the moment it is much harder to place Boulez's own works in the same certain perspective. It is hard to decide, for example, whether his intense activity as a conductor has prevented him from composing as much as he might have done, or whether the apparent diversion into the concert hall was in fact a necessary change of emphasis. It's possible that in the 60s, when his conducting career really took off, that Boulez already knew he was facing a creative impasse in his work, that the line of development he had been following so unswervingly for 20 years was beginning to peter out. He would need a fresh impulse to start again. IRCAM eventually provided that, but meanwhile conducting offered him an alternative creative role that he could fill magnificently, while he subjected his own past efforts to continual revision. "Work in progress" became an ever more frequent description of his pieces; as if he were attempting to recreate on his terms the concept of his hero Mallarmé, whose famous notional Livre had an indeterminate number of pages ordered in an infinite number of ways. For Boulez the idea of the finished, circumscribed artwork suddenly lost its meaning, and the technical processes he applied to his pieces seemed as if they could go on generating new material and new versions ad infinitum. In 50 years, when Boulez will have long finished his revisions, and his whole output will be fixed forever, it might be easier to appreciate his achievement as an integrated whole. His music will survive, I've no doubt of that - works like Pli Selon Pli, Le Marteau Sans Maître, Le Soleil Des Eaux, Eclats/Multiples and ...explosante-fixe... have a clarity of organisation and a beauty of sound that will keep them fresh. Now, though, Boulez is still composing and still conducting with as much verve and energy as ever, and that is good news for us all. fields.headline: Cannes contenders
fields.trailText: Top tips for a competition slot
fields.body:
The official line-up for the festival is announced on April 20, but if industry gossip is to be believed, the festival could be shaping up as one of the strongest competitions in Cannes' chequered history. These are our favourites for a competition slot:

Dancer in the Dark
Lars Von Trier

Von Trier dumps the Dogma in favour of a heady cocktail of kitchen-sink grit and high-flown fantasy. Icelandic popster Bjork headlines as the Walter Mitty-esque factory girl who re-stages her humdrum existence as a Hollywood musical, while Von Trier simultaneously rolls 100 cameras for the central dance sequences.

Cecil B Demented (pictured)
John Waters

A freewheeling dash through the land of low-budget cinema from a man who knows the terrain back to front. Waters's lunatic farce follows the fortunes of a crop of guerilla film-makers who press-gang a Hollywood star (Melanie Griffith) into their poverty-row production

The House of Mirth
Terence Davies

Typically painterly, slow-burning adaptation of Edith Wharton's novel from the Distant Voices, Still Lives director that plays out in a perfectly textured 19th-century New York. Gillian Anderson stars as the socialite who falls from grace after she is suspected of having an affair and running up gambling debts.

Memento
Christopher Nolan

Fresh from the success of his ingenious debut Following, London director Nolan has moved Stateside, beefed up his budget and coralled in a few major stars in LA Confidential's Guy Pearce and The Matrix's Carrie-Anne Moss. The result is a spry, bag-of-tricks thriller.

A la Verticale de L'Ete
Anh Hung Tran

The Vietnamese director behind Cyclo and The Scent of Green Papaya woos the art-house crowd with this exotic Chekhovian fable of the shifting dynamic between three sisters.

The Luzhin Defense
Marleen Gorris

Dutch film-maker Gorris (Antonia's Line, Mrs Dalloway) turns in an appropriately elegant adaptation of the Nabokov short story, starring Emily Watson and John Turturro.

Requiem for a Dream
Darren Aronofsky

The creator of last year's high-math thriller Pi returns with another hallucogenic little brain-teaser. Jared Leto, Ellen Burstyn and Jennifer Connelly are the pieces in the puzzle.

The Golden Bowl
James Ivory

Farmed through the Merchant-Ivory mill, Henry James's tale of romantic intrigue in 1900s Europe emerges as a stately, well-upholstered human drama. The gilt-edged cast-list includes James Fox, Kate Beckinsale, Anjelica Huston and Uma Thurman.

Gohatto
Nagisa Oshima

The old guard of Japanese cinema clashes swords with the new: Oshima's first film in a decade teams him up with Takeshi "Beat" Kitano for a homoerotic saga of samurai warriors at large in the 1860s.

O Brother, Where Art Thou?
Joel and Ethan Coen

The brothers' eagerly anticipated chain-gang comedy drops a bemused George Clooney in amongst a roster of Coen regulars (John Turturro, Holly Hunter, John Goodman). The title is lifted from the great unfilmed project in Preston Sturges's Sullivan's Travels.

Bread and Roses
Ken Loach

Britain's great social-realist relocated to America to shoot this fact-based account of a union drive on the Mexican border. Happily, the California climate hasn't mellowed Loach one jot. The backdrop may change; the concerns stay reassuringly, satisfyingly the same.

webTitle: MPs say PFI has had its day

fields.headline: MPs say PFI has had its day
fields.standfirst: The prime minister's moves to modernise Britain's public services with private money has been into question by a powerful commons committee and by parliament's spending watchdog.
fields.trailText: In March 2000, days after the prime minister announced a rise in spending on health and education, the commons Treasury select committee raised doubts about whether the programme of private finance initiatives was the most effective way of funding public projects.
fields.body:
The prime minister's moves to modernise Britain's public services with private money was called into question yesterday by a powerful commons committee and by parliament's spending watchdog.

Days after the prime minister announced a rise in spending on health and education, the commons Treasury select committee raised doubts about whether the programme of private finance initiatives was the most effective way of funding public projects.

Schools and hospitals worth billions of pounds have been financed through the PFI - introduced by the Conservatives in the 1980s as a means of reducing the public sector borrowing requirement. Labour, however, has adopted PFI - hailed by Tony Blair as a powerful example of his "third way" philosophy combining the best elements of left and right to reform public services.

But in its report yesterday the Treasury select committee said the PFI may have had its day. MPs said that the arguments for the PFI were now "very much weaker" because the new fiscal framework has made it easier to provide publicly funded investment.

"Publicly funded investment has no effect on the golden rule, [so it] could be increased significantly without exceeding the chancellor's chosen guideline that debt should not exceed 40% of gross domestic product," the report said.

"In the new framework, the case for PFI as the main means of obtaining extra investment is very much weaker."

The committee cited the work of the economist Peter Robinson, who said in a recent report that ministers could have paid for all the new schools and hospitals funded under PFI without straining the Treasury's guidelines.

Mr Robinson, chief economist at the left-leaning Institute for Public Policy Research, estimated that the PFI would provide £11bn or 14% of investment in the public sector from 1991 to 2001.

webTitle: Time for the west to stop being Saddam's scapegoat

fields.headline: Time for the west to stop being Saddam's scapegoat
fields.standfirst: Severe sanctions imposed by the west have proved a convenient way for Iraq's president Saddam Hussein to deflect the blame for his nation's woes, but the forthcoming election of a new US president could engender a fresh approach to the Iraqi dictator
fields.trailText: American presidents come and go, but Saddam Hussein clings on to power with the persistence of a barnacle. Despite losing the Gulf War, and suffering 10 years of crippling sanctions, which have seen Iraq - once a modern state - crumble around him, President Saddam's hold on power seems as secure as ever.
fields.body:
American presidents come and go, but Saddam Hussein clings on to power with the persistence of a barnacle. Despite losing the Gulf War, and suffering 10 years of crippling sanctions, which have seen Iraq - once a modern state - crumble around him, President Saddam's hold on power seems as secure as ever.

As the suffering of the Iraqi people deepens, the US and Britain - the two principal proponents of sanctions - are coming under increasing pressure to lift the economic siege. As a UN security council debate gets underway on the UN oil-for-food program - which was designed to alleviate the humanitarian plight of ordinary Iraqis - several human rights groups, including Human Rights Watch and Save the Children (UK), have called for a radical overhaul of the sanctions. They are, in effect, urging the west to junk most of the measures which have been in place since Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990.

The US and Britain argue that President Saddam bears the prime responsibility for Iraq's devastation, particularly the high child death rate caused by a medicine shortage. Peter Hain, minister of state at the Foreign Office, said recently that children are dying because the Iraqi government does not order enough medicines and fails to distribute the drugs the country does receive. President Saddam, Mr Hain argues, is playing politics with suffering.

One expects no less from someone demonised as an evil dictator. The situation is reminiscent of Cambodia after the Vietnamese drove out the Khmer Rouge in the late 1970s. The west isolated the Vietnamese-backed regime in Phnom Penh and supported the Khmer Rouge in its camps in Thailand. Even those Cambodians who had little time for the Phnom Penh regime criticised the west for wanting to fight the Vietnamese and their allies down to the last Cambodian. At times, it seems the US and Britain want to fight Saddam down to the last Iraqi.

Given Saddam's ruthlessness, the present policy is a moral and a practical dead end. As the Guardian's Ewen MacAskill has reported from Iraq, the sanctions provide Saddam with an all-too-convenient scapegoat for the country's problems - the west.

Saddam is going to be a headache for the next US administration. Vice president Al Gore has hinted at a more aggressive stance by agreeing to meet dissident Iraqi exiles, despite the fact that the opposition is notoriously divided. George W Bush, the Republican candidate, has spoken of forceful responses to any sign that Iraq is developing weapons of mass destruction. Neither approach seems very promising, taken on its own.

There is, however, an approach that would really put the frighteners on Saddam - cosying up to Iran, Iraq's bitter regional rival. There are signs that America is planning to play the Iranian card. US secretary of state Madeleine Albright last week announced an easing of sanctions against Iran, in acknowledgement of the more moderate policies being pursued by Iranian president Mohammad Khatami. Baghdad has already betrayed its nervousness at this diplomatic duet between the US and Iran. After this week's mortar attack in Baghdad, Iraq blamed the US for encouraging Iranian "aggression" against Baghdad.

With a new president in the White House, there will be a chance for a fresh approach to Iraq. With the prestige of being the new president, the next incumbent could well agree to less a draconian regime of sanctions and deflect Iraqi resentment away from the west towards its rightful target, Saddam. Couple that with the west's rapprochement with Iran and there is the making of a more effective policy towards Iraq.

webTitle: Sabotage spurs Swiss to join Sellafield exodus

fields.headline: Sabotage spurs Swiss to join Sellafield exodus
fields.trailText: Fears over the future of Sellafield intensified last night as Switzerland, the nuclear plant's most loyal customer, joined Germany and Sweden in suspending shipments of spent fuel.
fields.body:
Fears over the future of Sellafield intensified last night as Switzerland, the nuclear plant's most loyal customer, joined Germany and Sweden in suspending shipments of spent fuel.

The intervention of Switzerland's safety regulator in revoking licences to ship fuel to British Nuclear Fuel's (BNFL) £1.8bn Thorp reprocessing plant is another bitter blow to its 5,000 workers.

The case for opening Thorp six years ago was based on 7,000 tonnes of spent fuel being put through the plant in the first 10 years and realising £500m profit. This is now extremely unlikely, and it looks as if BNFL has a white elephant on its hands.

The Swiss inspectorate also complained of deliberate damage done in what is a high security area at the plant, amounting to sabotage, which has led to police fingerprinting dozens of workers in a vain attempt to find the culprit.

Wires on five giant robots used for handling highly radioactive glass blocks of waste were cut last month, putting the entire vitrification plant out of action for three days. With this coming after the falsification of documents and an attack on management standards by Britain's safety inspectorate, the Swiss finally reacted. Switzerland is BNFL's biggest overseas customer after Japan and Germany, with £400m worth of contracts. Most of the spent fuel rods to be reprocessed have been delivered, but 90 out of 422 tonnes are still in Switzerland.

The Swiss inspectorate said it would resume giving the necessary transport permits only when there was proof the plant had made "significant improvements" to security.

"The Swiss federal nuclear safety inspectorate is concerned about the disrespect of safety standards in the Sellafield reprocessing plant," it said in a statement. It expressed alarm at information that some installations had been deliberately damaged, said it expected to be kept informed, and planned to send a team to Sellafield to check for itself.

The move came as the UK chief inspector for nuclear installations, Laurance Willliams, confirmed to members of the European parliament that he had the power to close the Thorp plant, if his recommendations were not implemented within the two month deadline he set the company in February.

The Swiss inquiry team may meet American and Japanese teams sent to Sellafield after their governments also reacted to events at the Cumbrian plant. On Tuesday the US energy secretary, Bill Richardson, said "business as usual with BNFL is over". The company has contracts worth £6bn to clean up former US nuclear weapons sites.

The Japanese are demanding BNFL takes back plutonium fuel delivered to Japan in the autumn and later found to have falsified documentation; they have said they were angry at being misled, and talked of a loss of trust.

The Germans suspended their plutonium fuel contracts for the same reason, and there is doubt over the future relationship with German utilities.

Every single one of BNFL's customers is expressing concern, and even British Energy, the privatised nuclear electricity generator, has said it would like to drop some contracts. It is far more expensive for British Energy to reprocess spent fuel than store it, and it has no use for the plutonium and uranium recovered.

BNFL has also spent £300m on a plant to make plutonium fuel from the recovered materials, to sell back to overseas customers. This has been ready for two years but an operating licence has not been granted because there are yet no economic grounds to justify opening it.

fields.headline: The Oscars
fields.trailText: 1. Late on Sunday, the film world gets its night of glory when the Oscars are given out.
fields.body:
1. Late on Sunday, the film world gets its night of glory when the Oscars are given out.

2. American Beauty, The Insider and The Sixth Sense are tipped to win the awards.

3. There will be live coverage from 2am on Film Unlimited with sound clips, screen grabs and video of the ceremony.

4. Jude Law, Erykah Badu, Mike Myers and Roberto Benigni (who created a stir last year when he picked up two Oscars for Life is Beautiful) are among the 32 film industry types lined up to present the awards.

5. There is, however, a danger of anarchy: pro-lifers are threatening to disrupt the ceremony over The Cider House Rules, the film for which Michael Caine is nominated as best supporting actor for his role as an orphanage doctor who also carries out abortions.

6. The statuettes, which this year were stolen and found in a skip, are made from a metal alloy plated in copper, nickel, silver and finally, 24-karat gold.

7. They're officially called academy awards of merit and though the origin of Oscar's name is debatable - one theory suggests academy librarian and eventual executive director, Margaret Herrick, said it looked like her Uncle Oscar - the name was well enough known for Walt Disney to use it in his 1934 acceptance speech...

8. ... Which was one of many: Walt Disney is the all-time academy award winner with 26 Oscars to his name. The most successful films are Titanic and Ben Hur which gobbled up 11 statuettes in their years of glory.

9. After the awards there are, of course, the parties. Did you know the first 1,000 guests at Elton John's after-show event will get gift bags valued at over £400?

10. But if you are not part of the Hollywood set, why not stage your own soiree, screw the Oscars and announce your own winners.

webTitle: Tears at memorial to the victims

fields.headline: Tears at memorial to the victims
fields.trailText: In his most resonant gesture yet of reconciliation, Pope John Paul II yesterday visited Israel's Holocaust memorial, walking in semi-darkness over stone slabs engraved with the names of the Nazis' killing places, and bowing his head in prayer.
fields.body:
In his most resonant gesture yet of reconciliation, Pope John Paul II yesterday visited Israel's Holocaust memorial, walking in semi-darkness over stone slabs engraved with the names of the Nazis' killing places, and bowing his head in prayer.

For many Israelis and Jews around the world, the symbolic importance of the visit to Yad Vashem far outweighs the Pope's earlier condemnations of anti-semitism, representing a turning point after two millennia of recrimination.

However, some will doubtless be disappointed by his failure to offer a full apology for the Catholic church's conduct during the Nazi era.

"In this place of memories the mind and heart and soul feel an extreme need for silence. Silence in which to try to make some sense of the memories, which come flooding back. Silence because there are no words strong enough to deplore the terrible tragedy of the Shoah [Holocaust]," the Pope said.

All six of the Nazi extermination camps - as opposed to 16 other sites remembered at Yad Vashem where Jews were rounded up or worked to death as slave labourers - were on Polish soil, and the Pope was born and raised about 15 miles from Auschwitz.

The Pope said he had come to Yad Vashem, on the south-western edge of Jerusalem, to remember Jewish neighbours and friends from his home town of Wadowice, who were killed during the Holocaust, and to pay homage to the millions who died.

Several of the assembled dignitaries dabbed at their eyes during the ceremony.

For Israel, the visit to Yad Vashem was the pinnacle of a day in which the Vatican was forced to affirm the Jewish state. A session between the Pope and chief rabbis was followed by a meeting with Israel's president, Ezer Weizmann, which ended warmly.

"I assure the Jewish people that the Catholic Church... is deeply saddened by the hatred, acts of persecution and displays of anti-semitism directed against the Jews by Christians at any time and in any place," the Pope said.

But Israel's chief rabbi, Israel Meir Lau, said, after attending the ceremony: "This apology was quite fine... but I wait for chapter number two."

After the raucous reception the Pope had been given by the Palestinians in Bethlehem, yesterday was Israel's turn to seek the Vatican's blessing, and to try to extract maximum political advantage from the visit.

But it was an entirely official affair. The city was largely deserted - an evident surprise for the authorities, which had put up crowd control barriers at points along the Pope's route.

It was a telling indicator of Israeli attitudes towards Christianity which are unlikely to be helped by the Pope's failure to apologise for earlier Catholic teachings - since repudiated - which vilified Jews, and for his contention that the Nazi ideology never fed off Christianity.

There are 300,000 survivors of the Nazi Holocaust in Israel, and many were watching for John Paul II to condemn the silence of his own church and its wartime shepherd, Pius XII, while the Jews were being slaughtered. Religious experts knew that was an impossibility because of the doctrine of papal infallibility.

For some, nothing the Pope could say could erase the horrors of the past. "He is recognising the Holocaust more than 50 years later. It is a little late, isn't it?" said Claude Belassen, who is Jewish and from Paris.
