Six of the 10 Ulster Unionist MPs at Westminster, including the leading dissident Jeffrey Donaldson, are supporting the Rev Smyth, a 68-year-old former Orange Order chief who has been an MP for 20 years. Up to 858 delegates from constituency associations throughout Northern Ireland will vote on the leadership at tomorrow's Ulster Unionist Council meeting. Mr Trimble has said the vote is a choice between moving with the times and harking back to a golden age of unionism which never existed. Mr Smyth strongly denied any suggestion that he was unwilling to share power with nationalists and republicans. In 1993 he had been first to say that if republicans went down the road to peace there were many people in Northern Ireland who would accept them as a democratic political party, he said. He insisted his campaign was "not a personal campaign, it's a political campaign". He said there was a place for partnership government and he had no difficulty with the concept of a devolved Stormont assembly, though he did have concerns about whether the system of 108 assembly members and 10 departments was too much to govern such a small province. At his own news conference shortly afterwards, Mr Trimble called on Mr Smyth and other opponents of the Good Friday agreement within his party to accept the wishes of the Ulster Unionist Council if it endorses his leadership tomorrow. A confident-looking Mr Trimble, flanked by 17 assembly members as well as MPs Ken Maginnis and John Taylor, said it was a shame that some unionists appeared more eager to fight their colleagues rather than to take on the "enemies of unionism". Mr Trimble said the leadership challenge was a "distraction" from the battle to force republicans to honour their obligation to disarm if they were going to take their seats in a power-sharing executive. "The problem lies not with unionism. The problem lies with republicans," the Ulster Unionist leader said. "It was the republican movement which withdrew from the table. "Part of what I was doing in Washington was calling on republicans to come back to the table and put back more on the table than what was on it in the past."

fields.trailText: The world of gurning is in mourning this week following the death of Leonard "Lenny" Wells, one of the sport's truly great practitioners. For those unfamiliar with the term, gurning involves screwing up one's face into the most grotesque and unface-like expression possible. Although Mr Wells, of Thornhill, Cumberland, never actually won the world title, he was nonetheless widely recognised as a giant of the sport.
fields.body:
Death knocks bottom out of gurning


The world of gurning is in mourning this week following the death of Leonard "Lenny" Wells, one of the sport's truly great practitioners. For those unfamiliar with the term, gurning involves screwing up one's face into the most grotesque and unface-like expression possible. The pastime is now so well established that it has its own world championship contest. Although Mr Wells, of Thornhill, Cumberland, never actually won the world title, he was nonetheless widely recognised as a giant of the sport.

"He was one of the most popular gurners ever," said Alan Clements, organiser of the Egremont crab fair, where Mr Wells was a regular performer. "He was always well supported, and everyone was amazed was never crowned champion." In a long and illustrious career, Mr Wells distorted his features in numerous television adverts, as well appearing on GMTV with Anthea Turner, herself allegedly a gurner of some repute.

Although also a keen rugby fan and devoted family man, it is for the unique rubberiness of his lips and cheeks that he will be most fondly remembered. "I'll never forget the 1996 world championships," enthused one gurning fan. "Gordon Blacklock was ahead on points, but then Lenny stepped up and pulled a face like a rhino's anus. I tell you, the audience went beserk."
Whitehaven News

Fat lot of good


Those looking for ways of controlling unruly youngsters could do worse than take a lesson from Marlow youth club in Buckinghamshire. Concerns about the behaviour of club members have led to the creation of a unique contract under which those who misbehave are suspended from the club, while those who stick to the rules are rewarded with a constant supply of discounted chips and hamburgers.

"The idea came from the kids," explained club chairman John Spink. "We asked them for their suggestions about the club's future and they decided there should be a conduct code governing unacceptable behaviour."

Members agree to abjur offensive language, smoking, drugs and discrimination, and in return they can purchase as much fast food as they can eat at a bargain price of 50p per item.

"It's not really bribery," opined 13-year-old Paul Brown. "It's more like a reward. I think it's a very good idea." His reaction has been shared by local parents, who have welcomed the effect of the scheme on their children. "My son used to be a right tearaway," admitted one man. "But now he's basically too fat to do anything naughty. I think they should extend it to schools throughout the country."
Bucks Free Press

Holy terror


The worlds of Christianity and nightclub bouncing, never the most obvious bedfellows, came together this week in the person of Charlie Hill, a 17-stone doorman from Lancaster who is about to start training as an Anglican vicar.

Mr Hill, 22, who is also a rugby prop and blue belt in judo, can be found every weekend dealing with unruly drinkers at Lancaster's H2O club. His burly frame and intimidating presence, however, belie a mild-mannered soul whose greatest wish in life is to help his fellow man, as opposed to putting him in an armlock and telling him to sod off.

"People do find it a bit surprising," he admitted, "but the two things aren't actually that different. Being a doorman is about listening to people and creating a safe environment, and you could say the same about being a vicar."

He has wanted to go into the Church since he was a teenager, and will soon be taking up a place at Oxford to study theology. "He always tries to be civil with people," said one colleague, "but if they take the piss then verily the wrath of God is visited upon them three score times and 10."
The Lancaster Guardian

One for the road


While we in England do nothing but complain about our roads, Dutchman Pieter Boogaart takes an altogether more optimistic view of Britain's highways and byways. Or at least one of Britain's highways and byways, namely the A272 from Canterbury to Winchester.

A lifelong Anglophile, Mr Boogaart, of Eindhoven, has recently produced a book dedicated solely to what he considers the most beautiful stretch of tarmac anywhere in the world. Ode to a Road, published by Pallas Athene, promises modern day continental visitors that once they are on the A272, they will be so overwhelmed that they simply won't want to turn off.

He traces the history of the road, which stretches back to Roman times, and waxes lyrical about the towns and villages along its route, including such picturesque gems as Haywards Heath, Cuckfield and Lower Pittleworth. The book is packed with beautiful photographs and illustrations, costs £14.95, and is already having to be reprinted because its initial run of 5,000 has sold out.

"Apparently parts of the road are almost 2,000 years old," said one local reader. "Which is about how long they've spent building the Haywards Heath bypass."
The Mid-Sussex Times

Letter of the Week


I have just read in Your Letters a letter from Paula Black about dogs' mess on the pavements in Bath, and it reminded me of a dreadful thing that happened to a friend of mine last summer.

He was courting a very attractive lady who lives in your city, and spent a lot of money on a dress he bought her. She put it on and they went out for a meal.

When they left the restaurant this poor girl not only slipped up in a pile of dog poo, but also fell back in it, smearing it all over her new frock. You can imagine the devastating effect this awful occurrence caused to their plans of continuing to enjoy their evening together. Some of it was on her hair.

Please, dog owners, pick it up, put it in a bin, because one of you ruined a beautiful relationship by being thoughtless. Victor House
The Bath Chronicle

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15 | Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes | On the menu: wild rice | Cheat's kitchen: Raunched-up tortilla | Food on the net
fields.body:
Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15

The Engineer, 65 Gloucester Avenue, London NW1. Tel: 0171 722 0950

A gastro-pub that's more gastro than pub. Go for a table in the bar if you want a more laid-back, if pleasantly crowded, atmosphere or the restaurant for a more sedate dining experience. Either way, you'll be choosing from the same, well-sourced menu (meats are organic and free-range), which is short on frills, but big on matching flavours (such as organic burger - very beefy - with beetroot confit and the best chips for miles). A good wine list with thoughtful "drinkability" pointers for the amateur. Service is sharp, but don't make this a quick bite. A leisurely weekend brunch among the fresh flowers and wooden furniture is called for here.

Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Sauce, 214 Camden High Street NW1. Tel: 0171 482 0777

The Engineer isn't the only place in Camden to do a hot-diggety organic beef burger. Sauce "barorganicdiner" underneath the esteemed Camden brasserie, does them, too. In fact, as its subscript suggests it does organic everything - juices, smoothies, cocktails, teas, tisanes, coffees, wines, fritters, crab cakes, salads, sandwiches, tortilla wraps, and even a virtual virtuous veggie burger. The puddings may be organic, too, but they're a dietary nightmare. The decor is equally recycled - or should we say retro? Vinyl banquettes, plastic table clothes, Apicella floor tiles, fun, funky and kind of post-modern dinerish. So you've got the moral high ground and street cred all in one.

On the menu: wild rice

What is it? Cereal.

What do you mean, cereal? Just that - cereal, wild cereal if you like, and related to rice, but cereal all the same - zizania aquatica to be exact.

Don't you get technical with me, sonny. Where does it grow, then? Mostly in the Upper Mississippi Valley, where it is harvested by Native Americans, or Indians as we used to call them.

That's it? Well, there is a near relative, zizania latifolia which grows in Manchuria, but the Manchurians like to nibble the young shoots rather than the seeds.

What's this super-cereal like? Nutty, chewy and ever so slightly smoky.

How do you cook this romantic food stuff? See the packet. Or simmer gently in stock for a longish time.

Cheat's kitchen: Raunched-up tortilla

225g potatoes, one container of M&S corn salsa, olive oil, four eggs, salt and pepper.

1 Heat oven to 180C (350F), gas mk four

2 Microwave potatoes for four to six minutes on high.

3 Skin and cut into coarse cubes.

4 Fry in olive oil until brown and crisp.

5 Loosely beat the eggs and start to make an omelette in a frying pan

6 Add the potatoes and salsa.

7 Put pan into oven to cook through.

8 As it sets, turn over with a spatula.

9 Eat hot, with Tabasco sauce if inclined. (Serves two people.)

 Peter Lewis, London

Food on the net

www.allrecipes.com

An all-American, all recipe-based site. The searchable database of thousands of tried and tested dishes is guaranteed to throw up the odd gem, and the A to not-quite-Z meal planner can take you from Appetisers to Vegetarian.

Pros: As user-friendly as can be. The dedicated home chef can swap recipes, pick up cooking tips, make the best of seasonal produce and adapt recipes for a diabetic guest.

Cons: Its very down-to-earth home-style approach - how to keep your greens green is a big concern - might put off the more sophisticated foodie.

Coming soon: Personalised recipe recommendations.

webTitle: Lost Oscars hero in happy ending

fields.headline: Lost Oscars hero in happy ending
fields.trailText: This year's Oscars will have a very special and unexpected guest of honour. Willie Fulgear, the scrap metal dealer who found 52 of 55 stolen Oscars while on a scavenger hunt behind a cheap supermarket was given a $50,000 reward yesterday, and will be attending Sunday night's ceremony.
fields.body:
This year's Oscars will have a very special and unexpected guest of honour. Willie Fulgear, the scrap metal dealer who found 52 of 55 stolen Oscars while on a scavenger hunt behind a cheap supermarket was given a $50,000 reward yesterday, and will be attending Sunday night's ceremony.

Fulgear, who currently lives in a one-room apartment in Los Angeles, said he will use the money to buy a home in his native Mississippi, and said his story should serve as a lesson that honesty pays.

The junk salvager said it was his dream to meet host and comedian Billy Crystal and Oscar-nominated actor Denzel Washington, and hoped he would be brought onstage.

"I'm a poor man who stumbled on some gold, I guess,'' Fulgear told reporters at a press conference to announce his award. "Some people wouldn't have given them back, but my momma didn't raise me that way.''

Authorities are still hunting for the three missing Oscars.

fields.headline: Cannes openers announced
fields.trailText: Vatel, a $37m costume drama starring Gerard Depardieu and Uma Thurman, will open this year's Cannes International Film Festival.
fields.body:
Vatel, a $37m costume drama starring Gerard Depardieu and Uma Thurman, will open this year's Cannes International Film Festival.

The Gaumont-financed film, co-scripted by Tom Stoppard, directed by Roland Joffe and produced by Alain Goldman - tells the true tale of France's first celebrity chef (Depardieu), whose legendary culinary skills were called upon to help his boss, the out-of-favour prince de Conde, ingratiate himself with France's King Louis XIV.

The May 10 opening ceremony will be hosted by one of France's hottest young actresses, Virginie Ledoyen, currently starring opposite Leonardo DiCaprio in the Beach.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: • The Kentucky Supreme Court ruled yesterday that Woody Harrelson must stand trial for marijuana possession, following his well-publicised arrest for planting four hemp seeds in 1996. This latest ruling appears to be the end of the road for Harrelson, who challenged the state over its laws that put industrial hemp in the same stoner league as marijuana. His case rolled through three different courts, but the high court has finally ruled there's no legal difference between the cannabis kin. The People vs. Larry Flynt star must now face possession charges.

 The Kentucky Supreme Court ruled yesterday that Woody Harrelson must stand trial for marijuana possession, following his well-publicised arrest for planting four hemp seeds in 1996. This latest ruling appears to be the end of the road for Harrelson, who challenged the state over its laws that put industrial hemp in the same stoner league as marijuana. His case rolled through three different courts, but the high court has finally ruled there's no legal difference between the cannabis kin. The People vs. Larry Flynt star must now face possession charges.

 Johnny Depp has dismissed rumours that his girlfriend Vanessa Paradis is pregnant with their second child.

 Waiting for Speed 3? Well, you'll be waiting a very long time, says Sandra Bullock. The bankable girl-next-door actress, whose career skyrocketed with the first Speed and nearly sank with the second says, "Never in a million years. Even if you offered me $20 million and threatened to stick needles in my eyes, the answer would still be no!"

Casting couch

 Cate Blanchett will star with Bruce Willis and Billy Bob Thornton in Outlaws, a romantic comedy being called a contemporary Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid. Barry Levinson will start shooting for MGM in September.

 LL Cool J is to collect a seven-figure sum when he joins Chris Klein in Rollerball, directed by John McTiernan. Rollerball will be an update of Norman Jewison's 1975 cult classic about a futuristic society in which corporations have replaced countries and a violent game known as Rollerball is now the world's recreational sport.

 Whoopi Goldberg is in final negotiations to star in comedy-drama Kingdom Come. LL Cool J and Don Cheadle (Mission to Mars) are said to be interested in the picture as well.

 Tim Burton has officially committed to direct the remake of Planet of the Apes.

 Tom Sizemore has been cast in Disney's Pearl Harbour. The Hollywood Reporter states that he "will play a rough-edged mechanic who banters with the pilots and is in charge of maintaining the base's planes and equipment. He also assists the pilots as they fight back during a surprise attack."

fields.headline: Soderbergh on the record
fields.trailText: Steven Soderbergh's been busy recently. The director's latest movie, Erin Brockovich, is wowing audiences all over America, and meanwhile Soderbergh is firming up plans for his next project, Traffic.
fields.body:
Steven Soderbergh's been busy recently. The director's latest movie, Erin Brockovich, is wowing audiences all over America, and meanwhile Soderbergh is firming up plans for his next project, Traffic.

In an interview with Entertainment Weekly, the indie auteur admitted that he considered casting Julia Roberts - who stars in Erin Brockovich - in his upcoming drug trade saga, Traffic, but he found he just couldn't do it.

"I [told her] 'It would require you to extinguish everything that I find compelling about you,'" Soderbergh says. "It's unimaginable to me to cast her [in a somber] role, when her gift is her life force and that really makes you want to watch."

Soderbergh's also been talking to Harry Knowles of Ain't It Cool News about his future plans.

Knowles is eager to confirm casting rumours that surround the remake of Ocean's Eleven, another Soderbergh project. The word, straight from the horse's mouth, is that George Clooney is definitely committed, and Brad Pitt, Julia Roberts, Michael Douglas and Don Cheadle are "looking hopeful". Bill Murray is considering an offer, as is Mark Wahlberg, who might consider it a bonus to work with Clooney again.

webTitle: Hornby's unfaithful film wins rave review

fields.headline: Hornby's unfaithful film wins rave review
fields.trailText: They said it was sacrilege and a sell-out to Hollywood. But after enduring a chorus of complaints for allowing the film of his novel High Fidelity to be transplanted to Chicago because it was deemed too British, the writer Nick Hornby can allow himself a wry smile this morning.
fields.body:
They said it was sacrilege and a sell-out to Hollywood. But after enduring a chorus of complaints for allowing the film of his novel High Fidelity to be transplanted to Chicago because it was deemed too British, the writer Nick Hornby can allow himself a wry smile this morning.

For he and the film's British director, Stephen Frears - who has also come in for criticism for not sticking with its north London setting - have a huge hit on their hands.

Variety, the film industry bible, has given their movie, about an obsessive record shop owner who lists his life in top ten moments, the kind of review studios dream of.

"Top five reasons why High Fidelity is some kind of wonderful," it begins. "1) John Cusack's fresh, fearless and ferociously funny lead performance; 2) a trenchantly witty and acutely insightful script; 3) surprising faithfulness to first rate source material; 4) cunningly graceful direction by Stephen Frears, who manoeuvres through mood swings and tempo variegations; and 5) this is the first great date movie of 2000."

The pair, who are preparing for the premiere in Los Angeles next week, are said to be "well chuffed".

Frears' wife, Annie Rothenstein, said the plaudits felt doubly sweet. "There's been all the aggro about setting the film in Chicago, and rubbish about Stephen going to Hollywood and selling out, when all he has ever done is flirt with it. It's a great film - it's very funny, popular stuff, handled in a really intelligent way."

Although Hornby's first book, the semi-autobiographical soccer memoir Fever Pitch, transferred badly to the big screen, he said even if he had gripes with an adaptation he'd keep them to himself. "Goodness no, you can't complain," he said. "It would be like making a leather jacket, selling it and then complaining you don't want a fat person to wear it."

webTitle: Throw-out books to yield £50,000 for Oxfam

fields.headline: Throw-out books to yield £50,000 for Oxfam
fields.trailText: Some people literally take centuries to throw out old books from their attics and shelves - and when they do, Oxfam strikes gold.
fields.body:
Some people literally take centuries to throw out old books from their attics and shelves - and when they do, Oxfam strikes gold.

A copy of Pufendorf's classic Of the Law of Nature and Nations, published in 1717, is expected to make up to £150 at auction as part of a £50,000 bonanza for the charity.

It is still in good condition, though slightly stained, after being left in a plastic bag outside an Oxfam shop or dumped in a book bank.

So is Bergeron's pioneering 1735 travel book Voyages Fait Principalment en Asie, which is forecast to raise £200. So is the 1835 Dictionnaire de L'Academie Française (£200) - complete with labels from the public library from which it was borrowed and not returned.

So are first editions of three of Florence Upton's once beloved, now politically incorrect Golliwogg tales for children, bought in the 1890s (£400).

And so is the poet TS Eliot's Selected Essays - signed by the author (£600).

This revelation of how long house owners keep unvalued books in their lumber rooms and shelves is thanks to Oxfam's watchful central book depot in Leeds.

Instead of letting the volumes be resold in charity shops for 25p, the depot spotted their cash potential and amassed 300 of them to go under the hammer at Phillips in Bath on April 27.

Sarah Allen, of Phillips, said yesterday: "Every now and again people clear their bookshelves and, often inadvertently, give away a literary classic.

"This will be a unique sale of donated works."

Nearly half the books in the auction date from before the 1950s.

First editions of two of Beatrix Potter's earliest stories, The Tale of Timmy Tiptoes and the Tale of Mr Tod, printed in the early 1900s, are expected to fetch £300 each.

Kelly's once-essential Handbook to the Titled, Landed and Official Classes for 1918, should make £200. Tolkien's Lord of the Rings (£500), published in 1954-55, came from a midlands Oxfam shop. The newest book in the sale is JK Rowling's Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (£600), left in a Canterbury book bank.

Gill Atkins, Phillips' book specialist, said, "Some of these books have been donated by people who knew they were worth something.

"But a lot have probably come from those who were largely in the dark. People often tend to have inherited them and either have no idea which ones are worth keeping or simply don't know books are likely to be valuable in the first place".

In case news of the sale incites the reading classes to take a beady look at their own shelves, Phillips got together with Christie's of South Kensington to compile a shortlist of bestsellers at recent auctions.

Top of the list are first editions of The Wind in the Willows, with dustjacket (£40,000), Graham Greene's Brighton Rock, with dustjacket (£20,000), Ian Fleming's Casino Royale (£5,000) and Greene's first novel Babbling April or Kingsley Amis's Lucky Jim (both £2,760).

Do you have one of these in the attic?

Casino Royale - Ian Fleming's first book (1953): estimate £4,000-£5,000

For Whom the Bell Tolls - Ernest Hemingway (1940): estimate £100-£200

Babbling April - Graham Greene's first book (1925): sold for £2,760

Brighton Rock - Graham Greene (1938): with dust jacket, up to £20,000; without dust jacket, £150

Winnie-the-Pooh - AA Milne (1926): £500-£700

Watership Down - Richard Adams (1972): estimate £300-£400

Lord of the Flies - William Golding's first novel (1952): sold for £2,185

The Hobbit - JRR Tolkien (1937): £6,000-£10,000

The Wind in the Willows - Kenneth Grahame (1908): with dust jacket: up to £40,000; without dust jacket, £1,000-£1,500

The Seekers - HE Bates (1927): sold for £320

A Dance to the Music of Time - Anthony Powell (1951), 12 volumes: estimate £1,000-£1,500

For Kicks - Dick Francis (1965): sold for £600

Death of a Naturalist - Seamus Heaney (1966): sold for £750

Poems - William Golding (1934): sold for £1,610

Lucky Jim - Kingsley Amis (1953): sold for £2,760

Angel Pavement - JB Priestley (1930): sold for £100

The Grapes of Wrath - John Steinbeck (1939): sold for £920

Under Milk Wood - Dylan Thomas (1954): sold for £180

Scoop - Evelyn Waugh (1933): sold for £300

The Jewel in the Crown - Paul Scott (1966): sold for £400

The Winslow Boy - Terence Rattigan (1946): sold for £120

Brave New World - Aldous Huxley (1932): sold for £2,185

Figures from Christie's South Kensington and Phillips, New Bond Street.

fields.headline: The spoof is out there
fields.standfirst: This week a newspaper claimed that Beryl Bainbridge tricked an audience of book-lovers into singing the praises of non-existent author Rhoda F Comstock. But the truth is very different. Paul Bailey, Comstock's creator, reveals how a literary joke turned into a surreal nightmare.
fields.trailText: This week a newspaper claimed that Beryl Bainbridge tricked an audience of book-lovers into singing the praises of non-existent author Rhoda F Comstock. But the truth is very different. Paul Bailey, Comstock's creator, reveals how a literary joke turned into a surreal nightmare.
fields.body:
On Tuesday the Daily Mail - the newspaper refugees love to read - carried a story that was inaccurate in almost every detail. Under the headline "Beryl's latest fiction", reporter Lucie Morris revealed that Beryl Bainbridge had upset the erudite audience at the King's Lynn literary festival by choosing the masterpiece As Flies to Wanton Boys by Rhoda L Cornstock as her favourite novel. Far from being upset, the people in the auditorium laughed immoderately as Beryl, Michael Holroyd and I discussed the peculiar merits of Rhoda F Comstock, to give her back her proper name, in rapturous terms. Michael spoke glowingly of Rhoda's handwriting, and was particularly appreciative of her "exquisite margins". Beryl, who can be squeamish about sexual matters, asked me to explain the plot. As Flies, I said, is a "subtle study of rural incest". In Morris's hands "rural" became "royal" - a ploy, perhaps, to enrage the easily enraged flag-waving Mail readers, for whom the Windsors are sacrosanct. The sad truth is that the twins in Rhoda's book are about as rural, or rustic, as you can get. Rhoda is a lifelong devotee of Thomas Hardy, which is why Corin and Chloe are as doomed as Jude or Tess, if not more.

Does Rhoda exist? Ten years ago, Beryl and I would have answered the question which no one had asked with a decisive "Of course not". Today we are no longer confident that Rhoda is the earnest novelist I dreamed up one afternoon in a moment of silliness. She first wrote to Beryl in about 1980, via me, anxious for advice on how to cure her "blockage". The novel she was writing, When I Do Count the Clock, had stopped in mid-sentence on page 520 and was refusing to move. What, Rhoda wondered, could Beryl suggest? Beryl's reply was compassionate, but to the point: "Press onwards if you can, and if you can't, don't." Rhoda abandoned her "Proustian miscarriage" and embarked on Throw Physic to the Dogs, a Joycean day-in-the-life saga of a harassed vet practising in Rhoda's native East Clyst in Devon. This, too, was abandoned, though Beryl was quick to praise the scene in which Jake calms a deranged greyhound with a smile and a biscuit.

I made Rhoda a resident of East Clyst after reading an untitled novel which had been sent to my then publisher, Jonathan Cape. The author called himself or herself S Tipping. The opening chapter had several women taking tea at the vicarage. It reminded me of Barbara Pym, but without her wonderful beadiness of perception. All thoughts of Pym vanished with the arrival of the vicar, who dropped his trousers and said: "Don't all start at once" or something similar. The story became muckier and muckier, and the rather tatty typescript was returned to S Tipping at an address in East Clyst. Within weeks, I had made S Tipping and Rhoda the stars of the East Clyst literary and debating society, with Rhoda outshining her rival by attracting the attention of Beryl Bainbridge.

Beryl introduced other East Clystians into our correspondence. The unfrocked clergyman, Reg, was like a character from her early novels. He had a milk round before he was drummed out of Devon. Rhoda bore him a daughter, who is called Dot Comstock. In spite of the domestic problems she had to endure, Rhoda persevered with her uncompromising fiction. Sweet Fortune's Minion, set in a merchant bank in the 80s, won Beryl's admiration for its "thrusting satire", while It Is My Only Suit, about a waif left to fend for himself in an unnamed city "somewhere in Europe", moved her to "uncontrollable depths of primitive emotion". Rhoda was "getting there, by degrees".

It was then that the real Rhoda, if there is such a person, intervened. Beryl had a weekly column in the Evening Standard at the time, and she often referred to her friends Señor Bailey and Miss Rubens (Bernice of that ilk). In an article devoted to the verifiable fact that I had been mugged by an aggressive nun at Rome airport, she disclosed that I was helping an unpublished writer, Rhoda F Comstock, to get into print. Two days later, a letter arrived from a Rhoda who wasn't Beryl. I replied, but my letter came back with NOT KNOWN AT THIS ADDRESS boldly written on the envelope.

A few months passed, and Beryl - desperate to achieve her deadline - added an afterthought to her column on the subject of Rhoda's struggle to finish As Flies to Wanton Boys. It was with some trepidation (a typical Rhoda phrase) that she opened the door to the postman the following Wednesday. "It weighs a bloody ton, Miss Bainbridge," he said, as he handed her the manuscript of Rhoda's novel. "I'm out of breath and no mistake, and I'll take a medicinal whisky if you can spare it." She could spare it, and the postman went on his way in a happier mood.

The address on the title page of As Flies to Wanton Boys turned out to be bogus, too. Yet the book is undeniably there, even as it's collecting dust in Beryl's attic. I think I understand why she mentioned Rhoda at King's Lynn. I think she wants Rhoda to declare herself, to come forward and say: "I am the Rhoda F Comstock who wrote, with every fibre of her being, As Flies to Wanton Boys." I can only aid Beryl in a search that, we hope, will not be fruitless. If Rhoda is a Guardian reader, will she please respond? What started as a harmless tease by a writer who loves daft invented titles - like Profiles in String by X Trapnel and I Stopped at a Chemist by Ada Leintwardine, in Anthony Powell's A Dance to the Music of Time - is now becoming a surreal nightmare.

The piece by Lucie Morris, in which a "54-year-old man who refused to be named" accused Beryl, Michael and me of patronising the audience and making them "feel stupid", could have been instigated by a vengeful Rhoda. If Lucie Morris had looked carefully at that 54-year-old man, she would have noticed that "he" wasn't a man at all, but Rhoda in - to use another of her phrases - "fell disguise".

The King's Lynn literary festival is an annual treat for the writers who are invited and for the readers who attend it. Seriousness is in order, but not pomposity and self-aggrandisement. When a member of the audience remarked that the conflagration in As Flies to Wanton Boys was "unforgettable", we on the platform could only agree. Rhoda was voted the best novelist of the 90s by everyone present. Justice has been done to a brave and lonely spirit.

Poetic licence: famous fakes

Oliver Burkeman Nat Tate

The New York art world flocked to a Manhattan loft in 1998 for the launch of novelist William Boyd's biography of the brilliant but forgotten American artist Nat Tate. Tate - a depressive, alcoholic orphan - conducted a torrid affair with Peggy Guggenheim before slipping off the back of the Staten Island ferry and into oblivion. Or would have done, had he not been invented by Boyd, with the editor of Modern Painters magazine Karen Wright. The Sunday Telegraph printed extracts, later maintaining it always knew Tate was a fiction. "We never meant it maliciously," said Wright, unconvincingly.

Araki Yasusada

The American Poetry Review dedicated much of a 1996 edition to the poems of avant garde Japanese poet Yasusada, who supposedly lost his family at Hiroshima and whose notebooks were posthumously translated. References to scuba-diving in a 1925 poem (the word dates from the 1940s) should have alerted the journal's editors, but when lecturer Kent Johnson emerged as the probable hoaxer the Review opted for righteous indignation, declaring itself the victim of a "criminal act".

Rahila Khan

Toby Forward, an Anglican vicar from Brighton, persuaded Virago to publish a collection of stories in 1987 on the pretence that he was really a reclusive Asian teenage girl. The publisher pulped the books - but not before a complimentary copy had been sent to London Guildhall University's Cavendish Bentinck Library, where it is still held today. Forward has since published numerous books under his own name.

Anton Krashny

The radical Polish artist began as a jape designed by Joan Bakewell and STV executive Clerk Tait to fool a know-it-all TV researcher they worked with at the 1979 Edinburgh Festival; celebrities queued up to make speeches at the annual Krashny dinners they instituted. But the hoax developed a life of its own when, a few years later, Krashny's escape from behind the Iron Curtain hit the Scottish headlines. The artist - a close friend of Princess Margaret's, apparently - was said to be heading for Scone airport.

Ern Malley

The inventors of the now legendary Australian modernist poet left plentiful clues to his unreal nature in The Darkening Ecliptic, the purportedly posthumous "tragic lifework" they submitted to the highbrow journal Angry Penguins in 1943. "It is necessary to realise / That a poet may not exist", wrote "Malley" - really Australian soldiers James McAuley and Harold Stewart, who mailed the poems with a covering letter from Malley's suburban poetry-hating sister Ethel. Max Harris, editor of Angry Penguins, credulously devoted an entire issue to Malley, but later maintained that his genius was unaffected by his non-existence.

Ern Malley The inventors of the now legendary Australian modernist poet left plentiful clues to his unreal nature in The Darkening Ecliptic, the purportedly posthumous "tragic lifework" they submitted to the highbrow journal Angry Penguins in 1943. "It is necessary to realise / That a poet may not exist", wrote "Malley" - really Australian soldiers James McAuley and Harold Stewart, who mailed the poems with a covering letter from Malley's suburban poetry-hating sister Ethel. Max Harris, editor of Angry Penguins, credulously devoted an entire issue to Malley, but later maintained that his genius was unaffected by his non-existence.

fields.headline: Carlo Parola
fields.trailText: Carlo Parola, who has died aged 78, won only 10 caps for Italy, but he will long be remembered there as one of the most elegant and accomplished centre-halves of his time. He was also, at 26, the only Italian in the Rest of Europe team which lost 6-1 to Great Britain at Hampden Park in May 1947.
fields.body:
Carlo Parola, who has died aged 78, won only 10 caps for Italy, but he will long be remembered there as one of the most elegant and accomplished centre-halves of his time. He was also, at 26, the only Italian in the Rest of Europe team which lost 6-1 to Great Britain at Hampden Park in May 1947.

This was a game in which Parola was unfortunate enough to put through his own goal for Britain's fifth. Yet, in a team hastily cobbled together from a plethora of nationalities, he stood out for his aplomb and cool command - and for his reverse, over-the-head bicycle kick, now a standard weapon in the footballers' armoury.

As Parola recalled years later: "I was at once complimented by the managers and by my team-mates for my famous flying bicycle kick, which had the effect of putting an opponent off his stroke, the ball being whipped away from under his nose when he thought he had full control of it. I was [then] very good in anticipation, and in guessing my opponents' moves in advance. I felt full of energy, but I could not, logically, be everywhere at once when danger threatened."

Though he joined Lazio of Rome in 1954, aged 33, Parola had by then lost his pace; it was sad to see so fine a player struggling to compete. At 38, he would return to Juventus, the club with which he had excelled, as manager, flanked by their former Argentinian star Renato Cesarini, but he was not destined for success in management. His debut for Juve came when he was 18.

His first international appearance was made for Italy against Hungary in Turin in 1942. His full international debut, however, did not come until November 1945, when, in Zurich, he played against Switzerland in a 4-4 draw. He was in Turin again, in May 1948, when England defeated Italy 4-0, but two years later, in Sao Paolo, he met his nemesis, in the shape of the forceful Swedish centre-forward, Hans Jeppson.

In the World Cup qualifying rounds, Italy had been drawn against the Swedes and were favoured to beat a team so much reduced by departures of star players abroad; chiefly to Italy. But Jeppson gave Parola a torrid time, scoring twice in a 3-2 victory, and Parola would never play for his country again.

Of him, the journalist and historian Antonio Ghirelli wrote: "The man of Glasgow, as he came to be called, effectively represented the most complete example of the third-back defender. Coming out of the ranks of the northern working-class, brought up in the technical and style school of Juventus, tall, slim and robust in person, alien to any harshness in contact, more inclined to the acrobatic and the elegant, rich in commitment and fair play, master of ball control like few others, and always looking for the constructive pass, rather than the hasty clearance, you couldn't name a formation player more harmonious than Parola.

"His weakness, naturally exacerbated by his physical decline, lay, if anything, in an excess of sportsmanship, and in a certain elegant exhibitionism, both prejudicial defects in the modern game."

Parola played 35 out of 38 games for Juventus, when they won the Italian championship in 1949-50, and 15 when they won it again in 1951-2.

 Carlo Parola, footballer, born September 20 1921; died March 22 2000

fields.headline: Europe's very own movie brat
fields.standfirst: He's Danish and he doesn't give a damn about Dogme: as Nicolas Winding Refn's new, more mature second feature is released here, he tells Danny Leigh why he still likes to frighten the grown-ups
fields.trailText: He's Danish and he doesn't give a damn about Dogme: as Nicolas Winding Refn's new, more mature second feature is released here, he tells Danny Leigh why he still likes to frighten the grown-ups
fields.body:
While he is rarely given to self-doubt, one scene in his impending second feature, Bleeder, troubles Nicolas Winding Refn. It goes like this: a guy walks into a Copenhagen video store in search of porn. Until, that is, he finds himself waylaid by the blank-faced guy behind the counter, impassively namechecking the shop's contents.

"Fritz Lang," announces the clerk, scanning shelf on shelf of grubby boxes.

"Sergio Leone, Scorsese, Sergio Corbucci. George Romero, Lucio Fulci, Sam Peckinpah, Jean Rollin. John Carpenter, Wes Craven, Jack Hill, Richard Fleischer. Argento, Herzog, Paul Morrissey, Ed Wood..." He pauses for breath. "John Waters, Seijun Suzuki, Stanley Kubrick, Fellini. Hitchcock, Tod Browning, Don Siegel, David Lynch..."

And on it goes, an epic, encyclopaedic dash through John Woo and Russ Meyer, Jess Franco and Akira Kurosawa; a two-minute litany of the directorial great, good and just plain cult. Except that there is one person missing.

"You know what I should have done?" the garrulous Dane mutters. "I should have included myself. I should have put my own name in there."

He bangs the table in irritation.

"I should have, I really should have. You know, Roger Corman, James Whale, Tobe Hooper, Nicolas Winding Refn. It would have been great. So great. Aw... fuck!"

Despite such a glaring omission, Bleeder's auteurist roll call remains a stroke of chutzpah every bit as fearless as the ensemble singalong of Paul Thomas Anderson's Magnolia, or Spike Jonze's massed ranks of Malkovi in Being John Malkovich. These are not idle comparisons. At a time when young Hollywood is ablaze with plaudits and innovation, the fierce poise of Bleeder - wherein a twentysomething couple unravel into tragedy after conceiving a child - probably represents Europe's brightest hope. The same could also be said of the gangling 29-year-old behind it: gifted and cocksure in equal measure, he could be Europe's very own movie brat.

As such, it takes a certain droll self-awareness to locate your celluloid mission statement in the video shop, the Mecca of film geeks ever since Tarantino banged out the script to True Romance between reminders to rewind. Indeed, Refn happily admits he's obsession incarnate: "I have to confess," he says, "every one of those directors is a close personal favourite of mine".

Sitting back, fingers drumming, he glances round the room as he recalls the source of his fixation: a childhood move to New York with his film-maker father Anders (latterly editor to the quixotic Lars Von Trier). Haunting the fleapits of Times Square in its squalid early-80s heyday, exploitation double-bills were the spine of his pubescent existence. Formal education came later. Eventually obliged to attend high school, he learned to read at age 13.

"Sure, I can identify with that kind of manic film enthusiasm," Refn says. "For a long time it was really all I cared about. I mean, I grew up on Godzilla and Kung Fu. It was only later that I learned to appreciate other artforms and more" - he raises one eyebrow - "correct movies."

By 21, he was back in Denmark, his accent flecked with the same East Coast drawl that colours his speech today. It wasn't his only keepsake: rejected by the London Film School ("Say hello from me"), he set up shop in his native Copenhagen with enough money to make a five minute short from a script first written in the US. Revolving around the last hours of a Faustian smack dealer, it was called Pusher; by 1996, with a $1m production deal in the bag, both title and premise were recycled for his debut proper. A cold-eyed morality tale with more than a touch of Mean Streets in its narrative swagger, it briefly made him the toast of the international arthouse circuit.

And then, nothing. Three years of silence broken finally by the release of Bleeder, a film that, fortunately, proves more than worth the wait. The storytelling muscle of Pusher remains, but there's a new subtlety, a craftsmanship beyond mere flash. Gone is the raw machismo of Pusher's ill-fated anti-hero Frank; instead, in the breadth of its central characters struggling through relationship trouble and thinly veiled psychosis, Bleeder displays something akin to (whisper it) maturity.

Refn seems embarrassed by such language. "Well, I've grown up since Pusher," he smirks. "It's been three years. I guess everyone grows up over three years. Plus it would have been easy for me to make Pusher 2, and that would have killed me artistically. So this time I wanted something different. No gangsters. No drugs. I mean, now people ask me, 'So what is Bleeder about?' " He gives a theatrical shrug. "To which I can only say I don't know. I mean, of course, you can say there's this guy, and then this happens, and then this happens, but that's not what it's about. Because it's about... everything. It's about life."

Which also means it is about the absence of black and white. Where Pusher at times seemed too enamoured of its aura of violence, too attached to its desperate men in bad company, now, even when his characters cause your jaw to drop with their ferocity, Refn empathises. What he does not do is lionise.

"Right, and that's important," he affirms, "because the world is not black and white. This isn't villains and good guys. It's like we were saying, if Bleeder is about anything, it's about consequences. How every day, everything is consequences - you come out of your front door, you either walk this way or that way, and your decision has consequences. And I think the biggest fear in the West is confronting that idea. But that's what's beautiful about art, because you have the power to make people face up to it.

"I mean, I'm aware how corny this sounds, but I believe in the mind. Because the mind is the most powerful muscle in the body. A gun isn't powerful. The mind is. And with art you can deal with the mind, so the obligation of the artist is to think of yourself as a soldier, and use your talent as a weapon."

It all sounds so simple. Except that Bleeder - perhaps unsurprisingly, given its relentless sting of intensity - was hardly a cakewalk in the making. For a start there was the "lack of any real money to play with". Then came the death of the acquaintance whose apartment played host to much of the filming. To cap it all, a series of debilitating run-ins with leading man and former "best friend" Kim Bodnia, of whom Refn now cautiously remarks: "Mr Bodnia had certain things in his life which made him hard to work with. There were demons battled on both sides. He had his problems, I had mine."

Not least, you suspect, the incessant hostility to both Refn and his films in his home country. Vocal in his contempt for both the Danish film-making old school and their avant-garde counterparts, Refn remains at war with the traditionalists (one veteran producer bluntly describes him as a "silly kid") but equally distanced from the mischief-makers of Dogme 95. When the subject of Von Trier's merry pranksters comes up, he turns terse, defensive: "I saw Festen, which was great, but that's the only Dogme film I've ever seen. They do what they do, and I do what I do. It's not my bag."

A nerve, it seems, has been touched, and the director's thoughts on Dogme segue into a broader critique of the country which spawned it. "It's weird," he reflects, "because I don't really consider myself a Dane. I like Copenhagen, but I like it the same way you would, as a foreigner. I mean, everyone thinks Denmark is so liberal, so idyllic, just paradise. And because my parents' generation have been in power for so long, there's this idea of" - his voice grows shrill - " 'oooh, don't mention that, don't talk bad about people.' And yet within the idyll something is rotten..."

We both know what's coming next: he can't resist it. "Something is rotten in the state of Denmark."

Hence his imminent departure, geographically and spiritually, for an English language thriller, co-written with beat novelist Hubert Selby Jr and starring the ever-iconoclastic Vincent Gallo. As yet untitled, the project will be shot in Rio de Janeiro - about as far from Copenhagen as it is possible to get. He allows himself a wry smile at the thought of further antagonising the folks back home.

"Yes, I'm looking forward to that. Although things are already easier for me in Denmark, because now all these people come up to me saying how great Bleeder is, and how much I've accomplished with it. And, of course, they're like, 'Oh, I always believed in you,' and, 'Oh, I was with you all the way.' And it's like yeah, OK..." His accent slides into purest downtown Manhattan. "Whatever..."

It is that satisfaction, you feel, that told-you-so insolence which drives him on. During his promotion of Pusher, Refn spent much of his time trashing every cinematic sacred cow he could think of, all the while referring to himself as a "middle-class terrorist". Now, three years later, does the older, wiser model still get his kicks from frightening the grown-ups?

"Oh, without a doubt," he exclaims. "That's the greatest joy you can have, fucking with people's mindsets. If you asked Picasso or Mozart, I'm sure they'd have given the same answer. I mean, what gets you out of bed is being on a mission, you know? And I'm very optimistic - optimistic about the technical side of my film-making, optimistic about my storytelling, optimistic about having absolute control of whatever I'm working on. Because that's the mark of a great director. It's like Bela Lugosi says in Glen or Glenda, a truly great director is a puppetmaster. He who pulls the strings."

And when the dust has settled and the rhetoric put back to bed, does Refn see himself as a truly great director - he who pulls the strings? "Like I say," he replies, barely suppressing a grin, "I'm very optimistic."

webTitle: Tory outcry at flights cost of 'three jets' trio

fields.headline: Tory outcry at flights cost of 'three jets' trio
fields.standfirst: Lisbon summit: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was accused last night of wasting taxpayers' money when it emerged that the prime minister, the foreign secretary and the chancellor flew out to the European summit in Lisbon on three separate RAF aircraft.
fields.byline: Nicholas Watt and Ian Black  in Lisbon
fields.body:
Tony Blair was accused last night of wasting taxpayers' money when it emerged that the prime minister, the foreign secretary and the chancellor flew out to the European summit in Lisbon on three separate RAF aircraft.

The cabinet's three most senior ministers were awarded the collective epithet of "three jets" - inspired by John Prescott's "two Jags" - when their planes were seen clogging up Lisbon airport.

Robin Cook was the first when his RAF VC10 touched down at 6pm on Wednesday ahead of a dinner with fellow European Socialist party leaders.

As the foreign secretary tucked into dinner, the prime minister arrived three hours later on board a BAe146 of the Queen's Flight. He was accompanied by 18 officials, including his spokesman, Alastair Campbell, and his chief of staff, Jonathan Powell.

Not to be outdone, Gordon Brown flew in for the day on an RAF HS125 executive jet, with six officials.

The Tories last night seized on the travel arrangements to attack the government for extravagance in the week that the chancellor had presided over an increase in overall tax burden. Andrew Lansley, shadow cabinet office minister, said: "This shows Blair, Brown and Cook don't care very much about how they spend [people's money]. They are willing to waste hard-earned taxpayers' money and, what is worse, Robin Cook is willing to do so not just on government business but to attend a party political event."

Mr Campbell replied that the government had saved money by ensuring the three had flown on small aircraft. Referring to the BAe146, he said: "If anyone else had come on our plane they would have had to sit on my knee. The plane is not exactly Air Force One, and we do have to get here and back. It's time we had a different and more grown-up media agenda."

The "three jets" row enlivened the European summit ahead of the real business today. But the Tory attacks lacked credibility, because the three followed standard practice.

The prime minister never uses scheduled flights on official visits for security reasons and because he always has a large delegation. Mr Blair needed his own plane to travel to Lisbon because his flight had to be held to allow him to make his statement to the Commons on the NHS.

The foreign secretary also usually flies on RAF planes for security reasons, though the chancellor, who delights in his hair shirt image, once found himself stranded at a South African airport when he took a scheduled flight on official business.

The Ministry of Defence said each plane cost £2,000 an hour to fly, bringing the total cost for the round trip for all three planes to £30,000. The same number of club class seats on a commercial airline would have cost £23,000.

The foreign secretary also usually flies on RAF planes for security reasons, though the chancellor, who delights in his hair shirt image, once found himself stranded at a South African airport when he took a scheduled flight on official business. The Ministry of Defence said each plane cost £2,000 an hour to fly, bringing the total cost for the round trip for all three planes to £30,000. The same number of club class seats on a commercial airline would have cost £23,000.

webTitle: Keep digging for a Longbridge victory

fields.headline: Keep digging for a Longbridge victory
fields.standfirst:
Hunt for rescuer must continue

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Trade secretary Stephen Byers has little choice but to dig for Longbridge. We all know the potential number of votes involved. But if the City's gin 'n' tonic circuit is to be believed - and it is right rather more often than it is wrong - Mr Byers is digging rather more furiously than we all imaged the man could.
fields.body:
Trade secretary Stephen Byers has little choice but to dig for Longbridge. We all know the potential number of votes involved. But if the City's gin 'n' tonic circuit is to be believed - and it is right rather more often than it is wrong - Mr Byers is digging rather more furiously than we all imaged the man could.

Intrigue now surrounds the position of John Hemmings, the software magnate who has mayoral ambitions in Birmingham. His plan to save the plant looked rather too low on detail and over-heavy on publicity to have any chance of success - until last night, that is, when the name of John Towers, the former Rover Group executive, entered the frame.

One presumably scurrilous version of events has Mr Towers working directly and secretly for Mr Byers. Paperwork to this effect is even said to exist, mapping out a detailed proposal to take over Rover, minus Land Rover, shore up the financials with all sorts of government underwriting guarantees, bring in a small party of venture funds ready to inject some high-risk working capital and then continue to run the business - albeit in slimmed-down form. Mr Hemmings, according to this version of events, is just on the periphery of a much more powerful plan.

Officials who should know whether there is any truth to all this continue to insist that no viable alternative has yet emerged to the Alchemy bid - and an association between Mr Towers and Mr Byers has been flatly denied.

What is more, this alleged "Project Phoenix," as told in the bars of the Square Mile, seems to lack the involvement of a motor industry major - which everyone, unions included, agrees is crucial for any alternative plan to succeed.

But then this is a very sensitive issue. Mr Byers is in a hole and he has little choice but to break the first rule of such a position. Now he has started, he should keep digging.

Treasury logic

Like all previous occupants of Number 11, Gordon Brown is keen to take steps to secure the tax base. On top of this, it is safe to assume that he believes firms and individuals have a moral duty to pay the right amount of tax. Multinationals, egged on by the big accountancy firms, are nevertheless up in arms over the chancellor's plans to tighten tax rules for UK-based companies with overseas subsidiaries. It is claimed that a measure that the Treasury reckons will cost businesses based in Britain £300m will actually produce a whopping £10bn bill. The claims have, of course, been accompanied by all the regular scare-mongering about big firms fleeing Britain, putting thousands out of work, and so on.

To Mr Brown, using subsidiaries outside Britain to re-route dividend and interest income from overseas operations in order to minimise tax liabilities here is a morally just target.

But there is also a certain logic to the Treasury's move. The world's major economies are shaping up for a serious scrap with the world's most successful offshore financial centres. Developments such as offshore betting which the internet has brought us are seen, potentially, as just the tip of a colossal iceberg.

An important OECD ministerial meeting on the subject is slated for June, at which Mr Brown will be looking to lead a united fight against tax-dodging. The loophole for multinationals which was quietly tackled in the Budget does not exist, for example, in the United States. In short, the Treasury had to get Britain's own house in order before Mr Brown can chivvy others into action under the OECD umbrella.

Leaving aside for now issues such as enforcement, the draft OECD plan is to publish a black list of offshore financial centres which set artificially low tax rates to attract capital. In the first instance, it is hoping to embarrass them into opening up their highly secretive banking systems and co-operating with other tax jurisdictions - yes, naming and shaming. But if they do not change their ways, the OECD is threatening an array of sanctions which could ultimately lead to a ban on banking transactions between institutions in countries belonging to the OECD and banks in problematic locations.

Far from undermining the government's case, claims that the loophole now being closed affects £10bn of profits underlines how routine complex tax avoidance measures have become within multinationals.

It is clear that in the same way the internet threatens to destroy traditional business models across so many sectors, so new technology is threatening to turn governments' systems for raising money on their head. As far off as it might sound, concerted international action to tie down corporate profits so they can be taxed would appear to be the only course of action.

fields.headline: Robinson reopens Mandelson feud
fields.standfirst:
New Labour in power: special report
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Geoffrey Robinson, the former paymaster general, has reignited his feud with Peter Mandelson by blaming his dilatory stewardship at the Department of Trade and Industry for BMW's decision to pull out of mass car production in Britain.
fields.body:
Geoffrey Robinson, the former paymaster general, has reignited his feud with Peter Mandelson by blaming his dilatory stewardship at the Department of Trade and Industry for BMW's decision to pull out of mass car production in Britain.

Mr Mandelson's allies said the criticisms were not worthy of comment. But they fear the attack could be a foretaste of the kind of assault Mr Robinson is likely to launch against the Northern Ireland secretary if he presses ahead with his inside account of his role in the Treasury.

The two men fell out after they both resigned from government in December 1988 amid controversy over Mr Robinson's secret £373,000 home loan to Mr Mandelson.

Mr Robinson, writing in the New Statesman, claims that as paymaster general in November 1988 he had for weeks been seeking a meeting with Mr Mandelson to discuss the deteriorating Rover situation.

He claims "the ostensible reason" for the meeting was to prevent the Treasury being squeezed by a DTI-No 10 pincer movement aimed at securing unconditional support to help BMW keep its Longbridge plant open.

He adds: "I was deeply concerned that the DTI was too laid back about the situation... I confided my thoughts to the private office at No 10, which shared them and agreed that I should draft a letter for Mandelson to send to BMW."

The letter urged BMW management to take a closer interest in the low productivity in the plant. If BMW did so, the letter promised, the government would offer financial aid.

DTI officials insist that Mr Mandelson took a close interest in Longbridge. They said it made no sense to accuse Mr Mandelson of showing a lack of concern when, as Mr Robinson admits in the article, he went to the DTI trying to forestall excessive financial support to Rover.

webTitle: Blair put on spot at internet summit

fields.headline: Blair put on spot at internet summit
fields.standfirst: Lisbon summit: special report
fields.trailText: Europe should strive for full employment in a new economy which adopts internet and e-commerce skills to compete with the United States, Tony Blair urged the EU's "dot.com" summit yesterday.
fields.body:
Europe should strive for full employment in a new economy which adopts internet and e-commerce skills to compete with the United States, Tony Blair urged the EU's "dot.com" summit yesterday.

Speaking on the first day of the Lisbon gathering, the prime minister declared that the event marked "the most significant point of economic change and reform" in Europe for many years.'

Mr Blair had to suffer a few embarrassing moments as he stood awkwardly during a carefully-choreographed photocall next to the Austrian chancellor, Wolfgang Schussel - shunned because of his controversial coalition with the far right.

He solved the problem by chatting to the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, conspicuously ignoring Mr Schussel's repeated attempts to make small talk.

Intensive behind-the-scenes diplomacy was necessary to avoid a symbolic boycott by the leaders of France and Germany, unwilling to appear in a traditional EU 'family photograph" with the Austrian leader.

In the end, the group was expanded to include the Mexican president, in Lisbon to sign a free trade agreement with the EU, as well as assorted foreign ministers to "dilute" the Austrian presence.

But Mr Blair insisted that the other 14 members of the EU were right to have imposed bilateral sanctions against Vienna while ensuring that the union carried on with business as usual.

Later, Mr Blair argued passionately that reforming Europe's economy would help combat anti-EU feeling in Britain, and, by extension, improve the prospects for entry into the single currency.

Leaders are expected today to agree ambitious measures designed to bring the union into the internet age. But clear differences emerged over how far to go on social reform, trade liberalisation and employment targets.

"It's a very strong body of action going along with the words," the prime minister said. "This summit is not just about the internet and electronic commerce. It's about completing the internal market, structural reform and welfare reform.

"There's a totally different type of economy today where new technology is revolutionising the workplace and industry. We have got to make changes in education and skills."

But Britain, the Netherlands and Germany, among others, all opposed fixing an EU-wide unemployment target of 4% by 2010 - down from 10% today.

The US, with a booming economy based largely on deregulation, innovation and advanced electronics, currently has a 4% jobless rate.

Portugal's prime minister, Antonio Guterres, the summit's host, said that EU governments need "a common strategy" to reform social welfare systems and make labour cheaper and more adaptable.

But there were signs that France was opposing moves to speed further liberalisation of Europe's energy and rail markets and that it would not back too drastic a line on telecoms liberalisation - a high priority for Britain.

"As far as transport and energy are concerned they have no direct link with the new economy and should be discussed in a more general framework of the evolution of public services in Europe," said the French premier, Lionel Jospin.

Mr Blair said however that French objections were largely over timing and that there was broad agreement on "bench marking" to ensure that agreed goals were met across the union.

Proposals by the European Commission, which had been expected to form the basis of today's summit conclusions, had called on leaders to agree to cut internet access charges by opening up access to telephone lines into people's homes "by the end of 2000" and by adopting all pending e-commerce and telecoms legislation during next year.

In London, the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, challenged the prime minister to use the Lisbon summit to "turn rhetoric into reality", focusing particularly on the European Commission's working time directive, which places a statutory restriction on the working week. "I trust you will rise to the challenge, or have the courage to admit that Labour, on Europe as on so many issues, is all talk and no delivery," he said.

fields.headline: Fruitfly's genetic code is cracked
fields.standfirst: Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: Biologists claim today to have all but completed the search for all the genetic code of their favourite laboratory creature - the fruitfly.
fields.body:
Biologists claim today to have all but completed the search for all the genetic code of their favourite laboratory creature - the fruitfly.

The effort is a rehearsal for the "rough draft" of the entire DNA sequence of humanity later this year and a lesson in how to study the causes of inherited illness. The fruitfly carries counterparts for 177 of the 289 genes known to cause inherited human diseases.

It also has nearly three fourths of the genes involved in human cancers. Because fruitfly lives are measured in days, researchers can watch the effect of altered genes - something impossible in human subjects.

Researchers from the Howard Hughes medical institute at Berkeley, California, and Celera Genomics in Rockville, Maryland, report in the US journal Science, that they have deciphered almost 98% of the DNA "code" of the fruitfly, Drosophilia melanogaster, and have 99% of the creature's estimated 13,600 genes.

The sequence will be available through a genetic database managed by the US National Institutes of Health - and it will be a vital resource for geneticists, medical scientists and biologists.

DNA is a four letter chemical alphabet in which the blueprint for all life is written and passed on through the generations in the chromosomes. The research began at Berkeley in 1991, but accelerated in 1998 when Craig Venter, of Celera Genomics, offered free of charge a controversial technique for "shredding" the DNA into small pieces, reading it and then assembling the data together using sophisticated computer algorithms.

Dr Venter's Institute for Genomic Research in Maryland has been a powerful force in deciphering the DNA of disease-causing microbes. But his commercial biotechnology company, Celera, is also competing with a consortium of US and British publicly-funded scientists to complete the entire 3bn human letter code.

Fears that a commercial business might patent huge amounts of genetic information about humans last week prompted President Clinton and Tony Blair jointly to declare that the human genetic code should be freely available to everyone.

webTitle: Minister arrested in Mugabe's surprise corruption crackdown

fields.headline: Minister arrested in Mugabe's surprise corruption crackdown
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: President Robert Mugabe's government has charged a cabinet minister and two other prominent figures with corruption in a move widely seen as an attempt to clean up its image before parliamentary elections in April.
fields.body:
President Robert Mugabe's government has charged a cabinet minister and two other prominent figures with corruption in a move widely seen as an attempt to clean up its image before parliamentary elections in April.

The arrest on Monday of the agriculture minister, Kumbirai Kangai, surprised the nation, as it had been thought that cabinet ministers were beyond the reach of the law. Mr Kangai was charged with corruption involving the siphoning away of Z$228m (£3m) in government funds.

Yesterday, two other well connected figures also appeared in court. A former mayor of Harare, Solomon Tawengwa, and Nicholas Vingirai, a former chairman of the state-owned Commercial Bank of Zimbabwe, were charged with corruption.

Efforts to improve the image of the ruling Zanu-PF party may be too late. Zimbabwe is in the grip of a severe fuel shortage, which is widely seen to be the result of corruption and mismanagement.

John Makumbe, chairman of Transparency International in Zimbabwe, said: "I would like to see five or six cabinet ministers arraigned before I am convinced that Mugabe is legitimately trying to clean up his government."

The Zimbabwe Lawyers for Human Rights group yesterday called for the resignation of Mr Mugabe, the home affairs minister, Dumiso Dabengwa, and the police commissioner, Augustine Chihuri, for their failure to uphold a high court ruling which ordered the police to remove squatters supporting Mr Mugabe, who are illegally occupying 650 farms.

Its statement said: "When the state refuses to abide by its own laws, and refuses to obey its own courts, there is only one appropriate word: dictatorship."

webTitle: Haider is gay, says German report

fields.headline: Haider is gay, says German report
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Jörg Haider, the de facto leader of the far-right Freedom party in Austria, has been "outed" by German and Austrian newspapers who claim he is a homosexual.
fields.body:
Jörg Haider, the de facto leader of the far-right Freedom party in Austria, has been "outed" by German and Austrian newspapers who claim he is a homosexual.

A report in the leftwing Berlin Tageszeitung, or Taz, headlined "Jörg simply wants a cuddle", and repeated in the Austrian daily Der Standard yesterday, says that the gay community in Austria has had evidence that Mr Haider is gay for some time.

But, say the newspapers, it has been reluctant to release the evidence, fearing an outburst of hate towards the gay community "that would overtake the hatred towards foreigners", according to the owner of one of Vienna's well-known gay bars.

Mr Haider threw Europe into turmoil after the Freedom party entered government with the conservative People's party under the leadership of Chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel almost two months ago.

Political analysts have largely viewed his resignation as head of the party last month as a tactical move, but some now claim he wanted to withdraw from the limelight, fearing that his outing was imminent.

According to Taz, many members of Vienna's gay scene are ready to confirm the reports. They claim he regularly has sex with young men below the age of consent - 18 for homosexuals.

As a result, says Taz: "These days he prefers to meet with boys from nearby Slovakia" (where the age of consent is 15). The paper also refers to Mr Haider's alleged cocaine habit.

Following yesterday's reports, the Freedom party's parliamentary leader, Peter Westenthaler, said: "I refuse to comment on such absurdities and sleaze-mongering." Mr Haider has made no comment, though it is expected that he will now be forced to break his longstanding silence on the issue.

According to Taz, Haider's current partner is a youthful member of the Freedom party who has worked as his private secretary.

Hosi, or Homosexual Initiative, the biggest gay pressure group in Austria, said: "We've known about Haider's homosexuality for about 10 years. On the one hand we think it's positive that the rumours are no longer capable of ruining a political career, on the other hand an earlier outing of Haider would have been justified."

webTitle: Executive class support from a skilled hostess

fields.headline: Executive class support from a skilled hostess
fields.standfirst:
Despite careful grooming, Russia's first lady in waiting is anxious about life after Sunday's election

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: When Lyudmila Putin heard that Boris Yeltsin had handed his presidential seat in the Kremlin to her husband, she was so horrified that she spent the entire day weeping.
fields.body:
When Lyudmila Putin heard that Boris Yeltsin had handed his presidential seat in the Kremlin to her husband, she was so horrified that she spent the entire day weeping.

"I cried all day, because I knew that this was the end of our private life," she said in an officially sanctioned interview. She considered pleading with her husband not to accept the job, but decided to stay silent.

While Vladimir Putin has been preparing for a virtually guaranteed victory in Sunday's presidential election, Mrs Putin has been reluctantly bracing herself for her new role as first lady.

That, at least, is what the acting president's smooth team of PR advisers is at pains to stress. In his artfully understated campaign for the presidency, Mr Putin has made little active use of his wife, but her quiet, retiring presence in the shadows has been crucial.

Snippets of information from authorised sources consistently emphasise her unwillingness to take the limelight and her preference for family life. In a country where feminism is underdeveloped and female domesticity still attracts approval, these characteristics have been highlighted as useful campaigning tools.

Alongside this picture of Mrs Putin as a devoted wife and nest-builder, Mr Putin's image as a loyal young husband and a good father is accentuated. And this irreproachable family portrait conveniently underlines once again the stark contrast between the virtually teetotal, clean-living Mr Putin and his drunken, unreliable predecessor: a contrast which advisers hope will prove an instant vote-winner.

In a recently published book of Putin interviews, Mrs Putin, a former air hostess from the provincial city of Kaliningrad, hinted that she was dismayed by the corrosive effect her husband's duties were already having on their home life.

"I don't make plans any more," she said. "I used to make them, but when they were broken or didn't work out I would be terribly upset and offended. Then I began to understand that in order to avoid being disappointed, it's better not to make any plans at all."

Offering a few carefully chosen insights into the home life of the acting president, Mrs Putin revealed that she waits up for him every night, no matter how late he returns. But the intense security surrounding the family has disrupted the domestic routine: both children have been withdrawn from secondary school and are being educated at home.

Family friends interviewed for the book stressed Mrs Putin's domesticity, saying admiringly that she is the kind of woman who can stay up late at night enjoying herself and still have the energy the next day to do the housework.

The tradition of first lady is not well developed in Russia and Mrs Putin's image advisers have only two role models to study. It is already quite clear which she has been advised to adopt.

Raisa Gorbachev, the Soviet Union's first and last prominent spouse, sparked vitriolic hatred throughout the country by her enthusiastic acceptance of the celebrity role, her glamorous appearance in a time of deprivation, and her perceived meddling in affairs of state. It was only when she died last autumn after a long battle against leukaemia that she finally attracted a degree of public affection.

By contrast, Naina Yeltsin's modest, homely demeanour and her readiness to remain an almost invisible housewife figure won her widespread approval.

"Lyudmila Putin is following Naina's example," the political analyst Nikolai Petrov commented. "She fits into the mould of a typical Soviet civil servant wife: not flashy, not very noticeable. Educated at a technical college in Kaliningrad, the future Mrs Putin dropped out to work as an air hostess on internal flights. She was introduced to Mr Putin by friends during a stop-over in Leningrad. At first she branded him "unprepossessing", but soon became convinced that he was the man for her.

She moved to Leningrad to be with him, and studied French and Spanish at the city's university, to which she later returned briefly as a German teacher. She passed stringent KGB vetting before she and her husband were posted to East Germany.

Despite the PR emphasis on her homeliness, Mrs Putin has performed the few official duties required of her so far - most prominently hosting an informal visit by Tony and Cherie Blair - with supreme professionalism.
