What I saw in their faces does not tally with the touted image of Romanian Gypsies arriving by the lorryload, happy as Heidis on a hayride. And where are the reports about the situation in Romania now? Or are we supposed to imagine that there are people prepared to uproot themselves and their small ones, with maximum uncertainty and danger, on a whim? Nor is there any talk of how dramatically immigration policy has shifted in Britain and throughout the European Union: of how, since the 1980s, important distinctions between asylum seekers and other kinds of deserving migrants have been eroded, so that, for the first time in our modern history (and in pitiful contrast to the benevolent policies of the post-war period), the low immigration targets set by governments have taken priority and influenced the assessment of would-be immigrants from the poorer world. In other words, the question of "need" is no longer about them and theirs, it's about us and ours. The barbaric feel of many recent reports has much to do with ignorance - both genuine and wilful: the easiest way to dehumanise people is to strip them of any context, of any history. And, with very little in the way of a written history of their own, with no book, no anthem, no flag or popular story about the founding of their nation; with no state or power of any kind except in numbers, the Gypsies are particularly vulnerable to such mythologising. The centre-piece of the current story, and its proud centerpiece, is the assertion that Gypsies despise their own children - the flipside of the old favourite that they steal other people's babies - and cynically use them as "props". Here is what I know about Gypsies and their babies, gleaned from many years of study, predominantly in eastern and central Europe. First, being a mother is regarded as a woman's single-most important task; indeed, failure to bear children often leads to shame and even exclusion from the group. Second, Gypsy women, whatever the earnings of their husbands, are ultimately charged with supporting and feeding their children. Third, the women - for whom begging is not generally felt to be shameful (as it would be for the men) - are deeply resistant to being separated from their children under any circumstances. They, in turn, are reliably scandalised by the way non-Gypsy women willingly arrange for their children to be cared for by non-family members. Gypsies are profoundly mistrustful of outside influences: understandable, when you consider the draconian drives, at least in eastern and central Europe, to assimilate them. Since the 18th century such measures have included the removal of Gypsy children into Christian institutions and homes (a practice continued in Switzerland until 1973), and, under the communists, the compulsory changing of Gypsy names. All in all, in any interaction with non-Gypsies, at home or abroad, they live in tense anticipation of ill-will, bad faith, rejection and harm. If children are toughened by what they see, their parents may feel that this is appropriate training for an expected lifetime of hate directed at them. It is worth reminding ourselves of their extraordinary past, not as "some sopping-wet liberal excuse", but as the only meaningful basis for intelligent discussion about their future, in Britain and elsewhere. And such a discussion must be of interest to us all, not just because they are Europeans too, but because they are Europe's largest and fastest growing minority. The lives of Gypsies, since they left India at the beginning of the last millennium, has consisted of deportation and nomadism, homelessness and statelessness, interwoven with episodes of forced assimilation as well as incarceration and massacre. In Romania, where most of these recent arrivals come from, Gypsies were slaves for 400 years, until 1864 when slavery was abolished in Romania. Under the Nazis, at least half a million were murdered. They were the only group apart from the Jews slated for annihilation on racial grounds. Gypsies have only recently begun to commemorate their Holocaust dead, but they remain without a homeland. Perhaps uniquely they are also without any apparent desire for one. Instead, these periods of extreme persecution are reasonably regarded by them as forming part of the great continuum of persecution. It would not be far-fetched to wonder whether, in the case of the Gypsies, "nomad" is perhaps nothing more than a travel agent's kind of term for "deportee". And what of the situation of Gypsies today? A brief look at a recent week in the life of Gypsies around Europe shows that there is rather more to the story than the nursery frighteners and prejudices of our grandparents that are emotionally invoked in place of investigation. On March 2, in Tirgu-Mures, Romania, four policemen reportedly punched a drunk Gypsy to the ground and then kicked him as a crowd of Gypsies looked on. Approximately 25 further police were called in to disperse the crowd, beating them, yelling racial epithets and spraying children with teargas. The European Roma Rights Centre, a Budapest-based public-interest law group and monitoring organisation, reports 19 cases of police brutality in Romania between 1996 and 1998, none of them resulting in the conviction, or even the prosecution, of an officer involved. On March 3, on the outskirts of Rome, some 400 carabinieri reporting to the ministry of defence, swooped in the early hours on a "camp for nomads". They detained and checked all residents for the required permits, issued by local police. The 112 "nomads" who did not have permits were taken in two police buses to Fiumicino airport, whence at least 56 of them, including a couple of under-age girls without their parents, were that afternoon deported to Bosnia. A similar operation took place the next day at a different camp in Rome. The collective expulsion of aliens in Italy is - like the treatment of Gypsies in most other states - in clear contravention of a number of conventions to which the host country is a signatory. In Slovakia the persecution is mainly by skinheads. Last year in the Czech Republic the northern Bohemian city of Usti Nad Labem erected a high wall around its Gypsy ghetto, creating a Gypsy enclosure. Another report from the ERRC, called A Special Remedy, details, over 137 pages, the routine placement of Gypsy children (some 62%) in schools for the mentally handicapped, often on the basis of tests lasting half an hour, or without any test at all. These Gypsy placements, made in vastly disproportionate numbers to the Czech population (of which Gypsies account for less than 3%), are most often effected without the full comprehension of their parents. They are not given to understand, for example, that once in the "special" schools their children will have almost no chance of further education or decent employment. Here is the genuine scandal about Gypsy children - one which has not yet attracted the attention of the press. You begin to see why defiance may be the characteristic most necessary to their survival, but also the one most annoying to others. As visitors, they would be much more popular if their desperation was not so demanding. It has seemed particularly to irritate people that they don't even bother to try to arouse our pity. And it's true, they don't ask for it and they don't want it. Meanwhile, across eastern Europe, it would be hard to overstate the reflexive hatred people feel for them, even among otherwise nice, rational people. And yet, that non-engagement, their eternal separateness, has been the price of their survival. The unpleasant aggressiveness of these incomparably weak people is a godsend to politicians. As is the press campaign against the beggars. Just as Gypsies have consistently kept people at bay by frightening them, the government must be hoping that the rumour of a "hard" Britain will discourage new immigrants. If so, they dangerously underestimate the need and ambitions of many people from the east and the south. In 1993, I went to a castle in eastern Germany to join politicians, academics and a handful of Gypsy leaders - including Romania's only Gypsy MP - in search of alternative solutions to the already dismal pattern of asylum seeking and rejection for the huge numbers of new post-cold war migrants, and to explore any possible benefit from the Gypsy migration in particular. Over a few days, contributors shared experiences and outlined various survival strategies for migrants. At the end, as the different working groups met to report on their "findings", it was apparent that most of the Gypsy delegation was absent. They were outside in the castle parking lot, larking about in a pair of toy-like two-door cars, the twin Trabants they had just picked up for $45 (£28) and $90 (£56) respectively. The Gypsies, including our lone MP, looked like boy teenagers anywhere, poking under the hoods of their new wheels. They were jubilant - after all, this was what most Gypsy migrants were coming to Germany for: to buy cars for resale in the east, at no cost to the German social or welfare system. No, these were not people who needed to be schooled in survival strategies. The 1951 Convention, the central international instrument designed to protect refugees, guarantees asylum for those with a "well-founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion." It doesn't actually specify state-sponsored persecution, as it is sometimes interpreted to mean. Many of the Gypsies from the former eastern bloc seem solid candidates. But for reasons of pride and of income, they, like their Romanian MP, would rather come over for short visits, as businessmen. The car-dealing parliamentarian was, in many ways, an average sort of Gypsy (and an ideal modern European). He had several professions and spoke many languages; he preferred and intended to live in the country of his birth but also, periodically, even seasonally, he needed to travel for work. Like nearly all Gypsies I have met, he had no cause to expect a hand-out and no desire for one. His behaviour in eastern Germany did not undermine the project of the conference. On the contrary, it showed how very naturally such solutions can work. Most Gypsies, like most people with the wrong address, would like to be given the chance to earn and to contribute, but asylum seekers have neither. And, since the quiet abandonment of other legal options, "asylum" is the only game in town - a battle of wits we can't win. Expecting deportation, they have nothing to lose. The sooner we admit it the better: our topsy-turvy restrictions make beggars of us all.

fields.headline: My moustache man
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: They said it couldn't be done. They said that one man could not take on the entire political establishment of Britain - and win! But, from where I'm sitting, Mr Kenneth Livingstone seems set to prove 'em wrong.
fields.body:
They said it couldn't be done. They said that one man could not take on the entire political establishment of Britain - and win! But, from where I'm sitting, Mr Kenneth Livingstone seems set to prove 'em wrong.

As the tabloids never tire of repeating (c'mon, guys - give us a break!), way back in the early 70s I was, for a brief time, what they insist on referring to as "the constant companion" of Ken Livingstone. I suppose it was his moustache that first attracted me. At that stage, it was extended at both ends, and went right down to the corners of his chin, making him a dead ringer for TV's Jason King. In fact, Ken was a great fan of that seminal drama series, and was always pretty chuffed whenever anyone pointed out the resemblance.

But in those days, a little glamour could be a dangerous thing in activist circles, and it was during his early days as a leftwing firebrand at the GLC that one of the older comrades took him to one side and advised him, as a friend, that a less exuberant moustache might earn him more supporters within the party.

He told him that a donkey-jacket, T-shirt and jeans were more likely to attract the working classes to the overthrow of international capitalism than Ken's more regular uniform of a highly-frilled shirt with voluminous cuffs, plus misty purple, skin-tight crushed-velvet jump-suit, topped off with a silverplated CND pendant, worn snug against a bared chest.

Ken was determined, even then, not to let his moustache stand in the way of his political convictions, so that very afternoon he clipped it off (carefully brushing up the remnants from his living-room floor and, with the aid of a little sticky-tape, transforming them into a nest for his beloved newts - a nest they still enjoy to this very day) and placing his Jason King-style suit and shirt in mothballs, for use at a later date.

The rest, as you know, is history. Before the year was out, Ken's no-nonsense style and cheery disposition had catapulted him to the leadership of the GLC.

But he never lost that early fascination with the world of showbusiness: every night, after a hard day posing for this or that hard-hitting political poster campaign, there was nothing he liked more than to peel off his jeans and donkey jacket, place some Barry White on the stereo, slip into his fabulous misty-purple, skin-tight crushed-velvet jump-suit and boogie, boogie, boogie.

In those precious few hours that followed each hectic day of mobilising the workers to gain ownership of the means of production, Ken was determined to put the cares of the world behind him and do what he loved best - having a few celebrity friends round and enjoying an evening of anecdote and badinage over a bottle or two of vintage bubbly and some tasty cheese straws, courtesy of Justin de Blank. Christopher Biggins, Peregrine Worsthorne, the Singing Nun, Renee and Renato, Noele Gordon, Gyles Brandreth, Sheridan Morley, the bass guitarist with Kajagoogoo, Alvin Stardust: it was not long before Ken's modest south London dwelling came to resemble the golden days of the Kennedy White House.

It was here, surrounded by the creme de la creme of London's showbiz community, that Ken was to hone the after-dinner speaking skills that were soon to earn him his fortune. His friends soon became his mentors, freely giving Ken tips on how best to project himself in public.

"Bubble, darling!" exclaimed Biggins. "Cultivate an image, dear boy!" advised the irrepressible Donald Sinden - and within days Ken had come up with the "cheeky rebel" persona that has since become his hallmark. It was, oddly enough, the Singing Nun who taught him how best to offset any criticism. "If anyone heckles, or is rude to you, Ken," she said, to a light acoustic accompaniment of her number one hit, Dominique, "Just accuse them of orchestrating a 'dirty tricks' smear campaign. That'll make 'em put a sock in it!"

This last tip has come in ever so handy these past few weeks. Only yesterday, an opponent claimed that Ken had once sported whiskers. "Downing Street up to its dirty tricks once again, I see!" said Ken, swatting the accusation down. And the day before, when a smear-merchant publicly - and, to my mind, quite disgracefully - implied that Ken had in some way "promised" never to stand against the official Labour candidate, he gave one of his lovely, lovely grins and said, quick as a flash, "I do wish Frank's supporters wouldn't descend to these smears. Sadly, it's not helping the poor fellow's campaign one iota."

Touché! Jason King would have been proud of him! Londoners like me want a famous London character for mayor, an honest-to-goodness Cockney in the tradition of Burlington Bertie, Reggie Kray, Dirty Den and Dr Crippen. And if he can also make the trains run on time, well, who could argue against a leader like that?

fields.headline: Waiting for the messiah
fields.trailText: The penultimate paragraph of the splendid article by Amos Oz (Rabbi Jesus, March 21) requires one very small addition. To slightly paraphrase Amos Oz: If the messiah comes along and says, "How are you, nice to be back," then the Jews will have got it all wrong.
fields.body:
The penultimate paragraph of the splendid article by Amos Oz (Rabbi Jesus, March 21) requires one very small addition. To slightly paraphrase Amos Oz: If the messiah comes along and says, "How are you, nice to be back," then the Jews will have got it all wrong. If the messiah comes along and says, "How are you, sorry I could not get here before," then the Christians will have got it all wrong. But if the messiah does not come along at all, then both will have got it wrong.
Michael H Abraham
London

 Now that the Catholic hierarchy is in apologetic mood, will it apologise to gay people for Cardinal Thomas Winning?
Peter Bradshaw
Liverpool

 The idea that Bill Gates and Microsoft are involved in some sort of money-spinning chain email makes, as Jim White says, a useful metaphor for our times (In the middle of a chain reaction, March 23). Sadly the email describing the scheme which White, and almost every other internet user in the world, has received is a hoax. Email chain letters penetrate the internet community at a vast speed and if everyone who's received the mail carried out its instructions and, as a result, received the promised sum from Microsoft, the company would go bankrupt overnight.
John Diamond
London
john@jdiamond.demon.co.uk

webTitle: The latest Archer: Queen Trixie and her fertile pigs

fields.headline: The latest Archer: Queen Trixie and her fertile pigs
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: How do politicians cope with the concept of shame? Some don't have it; their brains aren't wired that way, just as colourblind people don't know when the traffic lights have changed. Ken Livingstone is one; that's why his apology to the Commons this week was so perfunctory, so like a teenager's " sor-ee!"
fields.body:
How do politicians cope with the concept of shame? Some don't have it; their brains aren't wired that way, just as colourblind people don't know when the traffic lights have changed. Ken Livingstone is one; that's why his apology to the Commons this week was so perfunctory, so like a teenager's " sor-ee!"

Tony Baldry, the Tory MP for Banbury, who pushed a City lawyer for an honour without revealing that the fellow had just lent him £5,000, comes out of the other box.

Yesterday in the Commons he pleaded and scraped and grovelled. "This was an error of judgment on my part, for which I have already apologised unreservedly in person to the committee," he said.

"I fully accept that I deserve to be criticised. I wish to say 'sorry', sincerely, to the House without reservation or hesitation of any kind."

Nothing would stop the tidal wave of contrition. "I should wish to apologise to each and every member of the House." Was he going to go round on his knees and beg forgiveness from every single MP? Or grab Ken's legs and let him drag him into the lobby while blubbing out yet more remorse?

Thank goodness, no. So I cut across to the Lords to catch the most shameless legislator of the lot.

Labour spin doctors could strap Frank Dobson to a table and surgically remove his beard and whiskers without exposing more bare-faced cheek than Jeffrey Archer generates in five minutes.

When he turned up at the House of Lords a fortnight ago, for the first time after the latest scandal, he sat on the steps to the throne. This was brassy enough, but yesterday he went one further - he not only sat on the Tory benches, in spite of the fact that he has been expelled from the party, but he even had his man phone us beforehand to tell us he was going to do so. This is chutzpah on rye bread with a side order of pickles and sour cream.

He placed himself gingerly between two grand dames, baronesses Seccombe and Miller, both of whom were Tory fund-raisers during the Archer glory years.

He stared ahead as if fascinated by the questions. Perhaps he was gathering material for a novel about a successful writer who is forced out of public life by tiny-minded Pecksniffs, but who braves their jeers and so boldly reclaims his rightful place at the top.

"He was impeccably dressed in a silk tie from Giorgio of Goodge Street's closing down sale, and a worsted suit from the Scope charity shop..."

Questions began with rail safety and signals passed at danger - "spads". Hmm, yes, that's it, our hero had lunched at the Euston Spad U Like, where the maitre'd, Paolo, had welcomed him as an old and valued customer.

Next Lord Mackie of the Benshie spoke about pig fertility: it seems they multiply too quickly. He blamed the strong pound for the crisis. Something there, perhaps.

Baroness Gardner of Parks, an Australian dentist whose real name is Trixie McGirr, started talking about female circumcision. Yes, the plot was almost in place. The heroine, who has her own suite at the Ritz, has discovered a plot by Australian republicans to replace Elizabeth II with a native monarch, Queen Trixie. They have sent a squad of evil north African female circumcisors to terrify her into silence.

But she has been away, skiing in Gstaad. In the meantime her pet pigs have multiplied. Ravenous with hunger they set upon the gang, whose gored remains are found...

The plot perhaps complete, Lord Archer scurried out. None of his former colleagues acknowledged him on his way.

fields.headline: Take care of the future
fields.trailText: As a daughter leading a campaign to prevent the closure of a residential care home in which my 91-year-old mother has lived happily for the past three years, I read David Brindle's article (Lonely old age, March 20) with interest.
fields.body:
As a daughter leading a campaign to prevent the closure of a residential care home in which my 91-year-old mother has lived happily for the past three years, I read David Brindle's article (Lonely old age, March 20) with interest.

This crisis in residential care for older people is not confined to the private sector. It affects all independent sector providers. The care home in which my mother lives is owned and managed by Servite Houses, a large, prestigious, national housing association which has charitable status.

Mary Court, my mother's care home in Battersea, was opened in 1992 to act as a model for the care of older people in the 21st century. Its design, high-quality standards and philosophy of care are unique. This is not a care home struggling to achieve the minimum standards laid down by the government's forthcoming care commissioning body.

Servite Houses give Wandsworth's lack of willingness to pay the full unit cost of a place at Mary Court as the reason for closure. Wandsworth has set a cost ceiling of £340 for payment of residential care homes fees, but it actually pays that amount less the individual's state benefits and/or private income. This means that Wandsworth, even for the poorest of its residents with no savings, pays, from its own budget, a maximum of just over £200 per week.

Wandsworth, which has contracted out all of its residential care services for older people, is risking the closure of a unique and high-quality resource because it will not pay its true unit cost of £460. This is the case even though the actual cost to the borough would be around £320, which is less than its own stated cost ceiling.

The issue of how we care for older people crucially affects us all. If we wish to live in a humane society, fit for the 21st century, we need to develop high-quality services for ourselves in the future.
Linda Goldsmith
London

This is not a care home struggling to achieve the minimum standards laid down by the government's forthcoming care commissioning body. Servite Houses give Wandsworth's lack of willingness to pay the full unit cost of a place at Mary Court as the reason for closure. Wandsworth has set a cost ceiling of £340 for payment of residential care homes fees, but it actually pays that amount less the individual's state benefits and/or private income. This means that Wandsworth, even for the poorest of its residents with no savings, pays, from its own budget, a maximum of just over £200 per week. Wandsworth, which has contracted out all of its residential care services for older people, is risking the closure of a unique and high-quality resource because it will not pay its true unit cost of £460. This is the case even though the actual cost to the borough would be around £320, which is less than its own stated cost ceiling. The issue of how we care for older people crucially affects us all. If we wish to live in a humane society, fit for the 21st century, we need to develop high-quality services for ourselves in the future. Linda Goldsmith London

fields.headline: Mr Trimble on trial
fields.standfirst:
The peace process may hang on his victory

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: David Trimble grew tired long ago of his rejectionist opponents within Ulster Unionism, urging them either to back him or sack him. Now the MP for South Belfast, Martin Smyth, has taken Mr Trimble at his word.
fields.body:
He demanded they put up or shut up - and now they have heeded his call. David Trimble grew tired long ago of his rejectionist opponents within Ulster Unionism, urging them either to back him or sack him. Now the MP for South Belfast, Martin Smyth, has taken Mr Trimble at his word, launching a leadership bid in time for tomorrow's meeting of the party's ruling council. Disingenuously he told BBC Northern Ireland yesterday that his campaign "will not be pro- or anti-agreement," referring to the landmark accord of Good Friday 1998. Instead he was offering his own, previously unheralded talents as a healer - whose leadership challenge would not divide the party still further but end Unionist "in-fighting" at last.

There is no doubt that Mr Trimble has his flaws. His awkward personal manner would hardly make him leadership material in mainstream British politics. And, as we have pointed out before, he has never quite risen to the FW de Klerk or Yitzhak Rabin level of international statesmanship. He has come across instead as a reluctant peacemaker, conceding inch by inch, trench by trench. Rarely does Mr Trimble tell Northern Ireland of the future he glimpses beyond the horizon.

These are weaknesses, but they are not grounds to remove David Trimble as leader of the Ulster Unionist party or as the designated first minister of the province. For, despite what Mr Smyth says, this vote is indeed a referendum on the Good Friday agreement and on the peace process itself. For that reason, anyone who supports the effort to bring quiet and normality to Northern Ireland can only hope for one outcome from tomorrow's clash: that Mr Trimble wins and wins handsomely.

Before casting their votes, the 860-odd council members should ponder Mr Trimble's record so far. Under his leadership, unionism has won a string of extraordinary victories. It has persuaded its mortal enemy, republicanism, to accept the partition of the island of Ireland as a political fact. The fact that Sinn Fein has elected members sitting in both an assembly and executive for the province (both now suspended) is a historic achievement for unionism: few of Mr Trimble's predecessors could have imagined persuading Sinn Fein to endorse such partitionist institutions. Also on his watch, the Republic of Ireland has removed the two articles of its constitution which staked a claim on the north and which served as a constant offence to unionism. Thanks in part to Mr Trimble's efforts during the Good Friday talks, that claim has been rescinded. Above all, republicanism has accepted that there can be no move toward its dream of a united Ireland unless the people of the province, including its unionist majority, want it. All told, it is a remarkable record - judged in unionism's own terms. The fact that Mr Trimble has done so little to brag about his own accomplishments - allowing his internal enemies to focus on what has not been achieved - is one of the failings to which we referred earlier. All the same, that is David Trimble's record. Do the 860 activists of the UUP as they ponder their decision genuinely believe that a Smyth-led party could have done as well?

But tomorrow's voters need not dwell only on the past. They should also pay heed to the current attempts to thaw the peace process, which has been in the deep freeze since the executive was suspended last month. Mr Trimble has taken two positive steps. First, he has refused to be bullied into the doomed demand that there should be no revival of the executive unless the Royal Ulster Constabulary is allowed to keep its name. A motion to that effect will be debated tomorrow and Mr Trimble has wisely steered well clear of it (Mr Smyth plans to vote for it). Such a move would only make progress even more elusive than it is already, limiting the room for manoeuvre of all parties. Second, Mr Trimble has dared say that he is prepared to re-enter government alongside Sinn Fein even without "guns up front". He imagines a "fresh sequence" in which decommissioning does not happen first but "follow[s] swiftly." This is a much more moderate stance than the Smyth-ite demand for guns first, progress later.

The Trimble approach has a chance of success. It fits with the noises coming from both Dublin and London, which have sought to shift the focus away from decommissioning and toward a commitment from the IRA that the guns remain silent and that the threat of violence is gone for good. Others are speaking about pressing the IRA to explain what sequence of events might lead it to disarm and then working backwards from that. All this thinking is fruitful, but it requires the flexibility of progressive unionism if it is to have a chance of success. The representative of that approach today is David Trimble. He may not be the most eloquent advocate of his cause. He may have frustrated his fellow peacemakers over and over again. But he is their best hope. They need him to win tomorrow - and so does Northern Ireland.

fields.headline: Questions over Kosovo
fields.trailText: A year ago today, Nato began its military campaign in Kosovo (Hugo Young: Europe must make the peace, March 23). In June, our servicemen won the conflict over Yugoslav forces. Since then, our political leaders have been in danger of losing the peace.
fields.body:
A year ago today, Nato began its military campaign in Kosovo (Hugo Young: Europe must make the peace, March 23). In June, our servicemen won the conflict over Yugoslav forces. Since then, our political leaders have been in danger of losing the peace.

Last July the foreign secretary said: "There can be no long-term future of the stability, peace and prosperity for the Balkans if we try to sweep every ethnic group into its own pure cantonment". Events show that Mr Cook's own benchmark for stability has not been achieved.

In Mitrovice, division along ethnic lines has already happened: Serbs in the north and Kosovo Albanians in the south are divided by barbed wire. Despite 39,000 Nato-led troops, paramilitaries of all colours are taking control of the streets.

Slobodan Milosevic continues to undermine the peace by fuelling ethnic hatred in northern Kosovo. Albanian extremists from the "demilitarised" KLA are engaged in cross-border provocations in southern Serbia. Meanwhile, Montenegro is still a focus of intense instability. The west's stability pact for south- eastern Europe remains on the drawing board.

The Kosovo police force is 2,000 members short of the original request of 4,700. Arrested criminals cannot be tried as there is no functioning judicial system.

The threat of continued bloodshed is real. There are important lessons to be learned from Kosovo, which may in future save the lives of Balkan civilians and British and western servicemen and women. It is time that the government called an independent inquiry into the international community's response to the crisis.
Francis Maude MP
Shadow foreign secretary

fields.headline: Mandela and MI6
fields.trailText: Though Anthony Sampson dismisses the allegation in my book (Mandela mocks idea he was an M16 man, March 23), there is nothing implausible in the idea that someone such as Nelson Mandela might have been recruited.
fields.body:
Though Anthony Sampson dismisses the allegation in my book (Mandela mocks idea he was an M16 man, March 23), there is nothing implausible in the idea that someone such as Nelson Mandela might have been recruited. During the late 50s and early 60s, MI6 was particularly interested in African students and all the British-based anti- colonial and pro-national groups were penetrated by the security services. I quote from MI6 training manuals on the methods used to recruit "agents of influence", who, internal reports state, were often not "conscious" they had been recruited. These operations were undertaken through third parties.

My admiration for Mr Mandela is no way diminished by this claim made by a former MI6 officer. Many of the quotes attributed to me concerning allegations surrounding his trip to Libya were, in fact, not made by me.
Stephen Dorril
Holmfirth, W Yorks

fields.headline: New men come clean
fields.trailText: Mary Kenny says that men's brains "are not programmed for domestic detail" (Grow up, Cherie: men don't clean, March 23). What twaddle. In my household I take on all the chores that have been the traditional preserve of women.
fields.body:
Mary Kenny says that men's brains "are not programmed for domestic detail" (Grow up, Cherie: men don't clean, March 23). What twaddle. In my household I take on all the chores that have been the traditional preserve of women. My next-door neighbour does more or less the same. Most of my male friends have divided up the worlds of work, domesticity and child-care on an equal basis with their partners.

No respectable neo- Darwinian thinker would ever claim that the effects of natural selection and evolution can be traced into the web of intricate social and cultural relationships that we have with each other. It is probably impossible, not just practically but theoretically, to tweeze apart the strands of nature and nurture. Even very broad-brush observations are generally treated with caution, especially when they relate to our own species.

If Mary Kenny had been around 100 years ago, no doubt she would have been saying that women aren't cut out to be columnists, since all the empirical evidence was there that it was something they just didn't do.
Jonathan Erskine
Cockermouth, Cumbria
jefm@compuserve.com

 Mary Kenny manages to miss the point entirely. It may be that males and females are wired up differently. However we have a mechanism for overcoming the urge to submit to our basest instincts. It's called civilisation. Now I'm going out to kill a woolly mammoth.
Alan Craig
Shadforth, Durham
alan@shadforth.u-net.com

 I have done housework, changed babies' nappies and cooked for all of my married life (36 years) and my wife has never complained of my manliness.
George Lawrence
Cheltenham
george@bloomfield30.freeserve.co.uk

 Mary Kenny says men "can't see" domestic disorder. In my experience, they be come extraordinarily clear-sighted when the choice is between doing a necessary chore themselves, or not getting it done at all. The trouble is that we women all too often step in to shoulder the burden ourselves. Probably, Mary Kenny would say, because our genetic make-up means we can't bear the sight of a man plugging in an iron.
Deborah Bennison
Clifford, W Yorks
deb@britishlibrary.net

 The real reason men still don't iron is because domestic work is boring, low status, unglamorous and invasive of their leisure time, and having had it easy for the past few millennia, men (quite understandably) simply aren't willing to make the change. It's a national disgrace that women still have on average 10-15 hours a week less leisure time than men, mostly due to the work they are expected to do around the house, and it's about time we had a bit more equality in this respect.
Caroline Woodley
London

 Mary Kenny says that "everywhere, men have shorter lives than women", thus perpetuating a myth about longevity. The difference is not primarily to do with biological differences between the sexes. In countries where it has been studied, overall differences in non-violent mortality are shown to be almost entirely due to differences in tobacco consumption. In the UK and other countries where women have closed the smoking gap, the sex difference in mortality will narrow as the years proceed.
David Simpson
Director, International Agency on Tobacco and Health
ds@iath.org

webTitle: The last thing we in the NHS need is more change, Tony

fields.headline: The last thing we in the NHS need is more change, Tony
fields.trailText: As a GP who has been working in the NHS for over 30 years, I am, on the one hand, ecstatic that Mr Blair has finally acknowledged publicly that the health service is so seriously underfunded that only a radical injection of new money can save it (Priority No 1: the NHS, March 22).
fields.body:
As a GP who has been working in the NHS for over 30 years, I am, on the one hand, ecstatic that Mr Blair has finally acknowledged publicly that the health service is so seriously underfunded that only a radical injection of new money can save it (Priority No 1: the NHS, March 22). This has been transparent to all of us "on the ground", who have struggled to maintain a safe, compassionate and professional service to patients in an ever more meagre context.

On the other hand, I am desperately depressed by Mr Blair's pronouncements that the money is conditional on the people working in the health service being prepared to change. Over the past 10 years, we have had one "reorganisation" after another imposed on us from above, unpiloted, with no evidence base. Voters might like the idea of drop-in clinics and late-night surgeries, but there is no evidence that this is either an effective or efficient way of delivering high-quality, medical care. Nor is there, as yet, any firm evidence that NHS Direct is a cost-effective service.

The NHS has survived because of the generosity, devotion and dedication of the people who work in it. That is what Mr Blair should be proclaiming from the dispatch box. Carping and ill-founded criticism is out of place. If any goodwill still exists, Mr Blair is in danger of losing it.
Dr Susan Dukes
London

 Tony Blair says the price of new funding for the NHS is acceptance of yet more new reforms. Where has he been for the past two decades? I've been a nurse since 1984, during which time we've had the purchaser/provider split, opt-out, trust mergers and take-overs, primary care groups and now trusts, more internal management restructurings than I can count (on average one every 18 months), the reversal of almost every change which has been imposed, and need I go on? Leave us alone, Tony and let us do our jobs.
David Dallard
Enderby, Leics
daved02@surfaid.org

 The prime minister believes that the solution to problems in the NHS is the same that has produced an education system in which there are unprecedented levels of stress and demoralisation among staff (Health service failures face hit squads, March 23). When will the government see that setting up "transparent" accountability systems communicates a lack of trust and undermines commitment?
Martyn Hammersley
Milton Keynes

 Many years ago when I was a member of a hospital management committee, our papers for monthly meetings came through the post. Then came the review recommending the abolition of hospital matrons. In their place arose a huge bureaucracy and our monthly papers for meetings of the new health authority came by van. Bring back matrons, I say, and get rid of the bureaucratic monsters.
Richard Kimberley
Wirral, Merseyside
KIMBLE58@aol.com

fields.headline: Nato chief rings Kosovo alarm
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The future of Kosovo is on a "razor edge between success and failure", a year after the western allies launched their air assault on Yugoslavia to drive Serbian troops from the province, Lord Robertson, Nato's secretary general, warned yesterday.
fields.body:
The future of Kosovo is on a "razor edge between success and failure", a year after the western allies launched their air assault on Yugoslavia to drive Serbian troops from the province, Lord Robertson, Nato's secretary general, warned yesterday.

In a grim assessment of the outcome of Nato's 78-day bombing campaign, in which he compared EU forces to a "paper army", the former British defence secretary said that while much had been achieved, there was still "too much violence, too much revenge".

His intervention reflects the increasing concern in Nato about attacks on Serbs by hardline Albanians, and growing frustration about the failure to establish a semblance of civil order, more than 10 months after K-For peacekeepers entered the province.

He said that on a visit to Kosovo today to mark the first anniversary of the start of the bombing, he would deliver a "blunt message"to the ethnic Albanian majority there: "We did not do what we did last year, risking all those lives, to see it all washed down the Ibar river." The Ibar splits the divided city of Mitrovice.

Nato's bombing campaign cost between £2bn and £3bn, yet only a fraction of this amount is being spent on rebuilding the province. Washington says the US paid for the war and the EU should meet the bill for the peace, but the EU expects to spend just £220m on Kosovo this year.

"The sad reality is that we rise to the crisis in the military context. After that people are not willing to follow it through," Lord Robertson said. There was an "enormous gap" which no one was filling. Paratroopers and Gurkhas and the French foreign legion were directing traffic."

His wake-up call - directed to the UN as well as to Nato's European allies - coincided with a stark warning about Kosovo's future by Javier Solana, Lord Robertson's predecessor and now the EU's security supremo, and Chris Patten, the European commissioner for external relations.

The UN was experiencing "considerable difficulties" in Kosovo, with ethnic violence continuing at "high levels" and the civil administration there deprived of sufficient personnel and resources, they said.

In Belgrade, the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic laid a wreath on a memorial to mark the anniversary of the bombing. His government plans rallies and demonstrations today. However, the opposition leader Zoran Djindjic said: "There is nothing to celebrate; everyone has lost, Serbia most of all."

Faced with Washington's growing impatience at having to carry the military burden of European crises, Lord Robertson also delivered a devastating attack on the state of Europe's defences. "European credibility is on the line," he said.

fields.headline: Debate rages over male menopause
fields.trailText: Men who go to their doctor complaining of depression, flushing and sweats, loss of sexual potency, tiredness and memory loss may be suffering from a male menopause, doctors report in this week's British Medical Journal.
fields.body:
Men who go to their doctor complaining of depression, flushing and sweats, loss of sexual potency, tiredness and memory loss may be suffering from a male menopause, doctors report in this week's British Medical Journal.

The existence of the male menopause is much disputed among clinicians. The BMJ is running one article supporting the thesis and one against. But both agree that many middle-aged men would like to explain their increasing exhaustion and poor concentration on something as easily rectified as a hormone imbalance.

Duncan Gould and colleagues of the WellMan Clinic in London think some of these men might benefit from a male version of hormone replacement therapy in the shape of testosterone doses.

They said any man who had the symptoms in late middle age should be investigated.

They took issue with the phrase "male menopause" because it suggested a sudden and inevitable drop in hormones of the sort that women experience. "It is not an inevitability but may occur mainly in middle-aged and elderly men when testosterone production and plasma concentrations fall," they said.

In the middle of the last century, the phenomenon was known as "male climacteric", from the Greek klimakter (rung of a ladder) - which was more appropriate as it suggested a decline and not a sudden drop in hormone levels.

"Ageing is usually associated with a decline in sexual interest and potency," they said, which suggested that the changes might be linked to declining testosterone, but did not prove it.

Studies had shown that low testosterone could be a factor in depressed mood; others that testosterone could ease symptoms of depression, anger, irritability, sadness and nervousness, and help to restore friendliness, sense of wellbeing and energy levels. Declining levels of sex hormones might even be a factor in middle-age spread.

But Howard Jacobs, emeritus professor of endocrinology at the Royal Free and University College school of medicine in London, is not convinced that testosterone is the answer to men's middle-age woes.

HRT might stave off brittle bones in women, but studies had not proved that hormone doses could do the same in men, even though it might improve their muscle tone, he said.

And as for libido and sexual performance, elderly men who had problems getting an erection already had a proven treatment available to them: Viagra.

fields.headline: Appeal court boosts accident damages
fields.standfirst: Lawyers criticise ruling for 'tapered' increase
fields.trailText: The court of appeal yesterday boosted the most severely injured accident victims' damages for pain and suffering by one third, but drew fire from claimants' lawyers who had hoped that damages would be doubled.
fields.body:
The court of appeal yesterday boosted the most severely injured accident victims' damages for pain and suffering by one third, but drew fire from claimants' lawyers who had hoped that damages would be doubled.

The ruling, by a special panel of five judges, means that the most disabled victims will get £200,000 instead of £150,000 for their suffering.

The decision will be welcomed by the NHS, which would have had to find an extra £133m a year if awards had been doubled.

But claimants' lawyers criticised the ruling that there should be a tapered increase up to a maximum rise of one third for those at the highest level, but no increase for awards below £10,000. The master of the rolls, Lord Woolf, convened the unprecedented panel to consider a recommendation by a law commission report that awards should rise by between 50 and 100% in the most severe cases.

Tom Jones, of the law firm Thompsons, who represented the claimant in one of the eight test cases reviewed by the judges, said: "It beggars belief. What world are these judges living in to make these kinds of awards?

"Accident victims throughout England and Wales have been short-changed by a shortsighted court of appeal."

Lord Woolf said in the judgment that the court had taken into account "the impact of the level of damages on the level of insurance premiums and on the resources of the NHS".

Yesterday's ruling will have a greater impact on the NHS, where awards are higher because injuries are more severe, than on the insurance industry, which covers road and work accidents.

Mr Jones added: "The court of appeal has sided with the insurance industry ... It should hang its head in shame. It ... has put the interests of profit before justice."

He would be seeking permission to take the issue to the House of Lords.

John Pickering, head of personal injury at the solicitors Irwin Mitchell, said: "While our cases represent the upper end of the general damages scale and have received increases of around 35%, the overall decision is disappointing."

The judgment does not affect the £1m-plus awards paid in the biggest cases for the costs of lifetime care and future loss of earnings.

It covers only the element of damages for pain, loss of bodily functions, inability to enjoy leisure activities and the psychological effects of sufferers' awareness of their plight.

The eight test cases involved personal injury awards ranging from a medical negligence claim against an NHS trust involving £135,000 to a £3,000 award for a road accident whiplash injury.

webTitle: Blunkett doubles budget for school repairs

fields.headline: Blunkett doubles budget for school repairs
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: An extra 3,000 schools will be refurbished over the next year as the government doubles the repairs budget to £500m, David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, said yesterday.
fields.body:
An extra 3,000 schools will be refurbished over the next year as the government doubles the repairs budget to £500m, David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, said yesterday.

Announcing details of the additional £1bn for education promised by the chancellor on Tuesday, he said: "We will now be able to repair roofs, replace temporary classrooms, replace heating systems and modernise up to 6,000 schools in 2000-01."

By next year at least half the schools in England should have benefited from the programme to tackle the repairs backlog.

Mr Blunkett pre-empted the Treasury's review of education spending after 2001 with a reassurance to schools that the extra £1bn was a permanent part of the budget.

"How could we possibly start programmes in September and finish them at the end of March 2001?" he told the Commons.

But he alarmed local education authorities with a hint that their powers might be further curtailed during a review by the Department for the Environment, Transport and the Regions. It was widely accepted that the system for distributing funds to schools needed reform, he said.

"If we didn't have education authorities, we would have to invent something like them, but they would be invented differently for an entirely new era."

Sir Jeremy Beecham, chairman of the Local Government Association, told BBC Radio 4's Today programme that councils were unhappy about Mr Blunkett's plans to pass £300m directly to heads and governors, bypassing LEAs.

"The danger of a centralised authority is that you will have a uniform level of spending for people across the country, which won't reflect different needs."

The package also included:

£58m for inner city schools in an expanded excellence in cities programme;

£60m to give failing schools a fresh start and set up business-sponsored city academies;

£20m for catch-up literacy and numeracy classes for under-achievers in primary schools;

and £53m for education maintenance allowances to encourage disadvantaged pupils to stay at school after the age of 16.

fields.headline: Sex education 'parents' job'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Most teachers think parents should take control of their children's sex education, according to a poll published yesterday by the centre-left Institute of Public Policy Research.
fields.body:
Most teachers think parents should take control of their children's sex education, according to a poll published yesterday by the centre-left Institute of Public Policy Research.

As ministers push plans to regulate discussion of sexuality in the classroom, the survey showed 87% of teachers want parents to take prime responsibility for the child's personal, social and health education.

And 89% said parents should play the main part in preparing the child to become an "active citizen" instead of leaving it to citizenship classes. The IPPR surveyed 936 primary and secondary teachers in partnership with the Association of Teachers and Lecturers.

fields.headline: Dance troupe takes bold step
fields.trailText: Adventures in Motion Pictures, the ground-breaking dance company whose gender-bending Swan Lake was seen by a staggering 75,000 on its West End run last month, is to take over London's Old Vic theatre.
fields.body:
Adventures in Motion Pictures, the ground-breaking dance company whose gender-bending Swan Lake was seen by a staggering 75,000 on its West End run last month, is to take over London's Old Vic theatre.

Even for a troupe which has stormed Broadway and returned with a clutch of Tony awards for Matthew Bourne's wickedly subversive choreography, this is a bold move. The Royal Ballet alone among British dance companies has a home of its own, and even that is shared with the Royal Opera.

But producer Katherine Dore, who has guided the company since the days when it toured from the back of a Transit van, said the time was right to settle down.

"Our shows are written and created in the rehearsal room - you have to do that in dance, it's a slow process," she said. "And since we never had a place to call our own we have had to move round all over the place, which has been very disruptive. We want to make the Old Vic the place people go to see AMP like they go to the Coliseum to see the English National Opera," she said.

Bourne's new show, The Car Man, a noirish "auto-erotic thriller" set to the score for Bizet's Carmen, opens at the Old Vic in September, though the company will not officially take up residence until 2002.

AMP have built a huge, hitherto untapped audience for contemporary dance on the back of Swan Lake and Bourne's versions of Nutcracker and a Cinderella set in wartime.

Their plans for the Old Vic are being seen as a way of reviving the dreams of a "people's ballet" held by the theatre's founder, Lilian Baylis.

The Royal Ballet started there in 1931, and Dore said it could be the perfect platform for AMP to launch its own apprenticeship scheme for dance graduates.

"The Old Vic is perfect for us," said Dore. "It's got the history and it has got the space."

webTitle: CPS told to think again on dockside death

fields.headline: CPS told to think again on dockside death
fields.standfirst: High court backs family's fight to get firm and manager to face manslaughter charges over student crushed by unsafe crane
fields.trailText: The family of an untrained casual worker killed while unloading a ship in Shoreham docks won a historic high court battle yesterday when two judges overturned a decision by the director of public prosecutions not to prosecute his employer for manslaughter.
fields.body:
The family of an untrained casual worker killed while unloading a ship in Shoreham docks won a historic high court battle yesterday when two judges overturned a decision by the director of public prosecutions not to prosecute his employer for manslaughter.

The judges ruled that the DPP, David Calvert-Smith, and crown prosecution service had behaved "irrationally" and failed "properly to address the relevant law" when they decided there was no realistic prospect of conviction. He ordered them to reconsider.

The judgment is the first successful judicial review of a decision not to prosecute for manslaughter over a workplace death and was hailed as a breakthrough in the campaign to hold companies and their directors to account for avoidable injuries at work.

The case centred on the death of Simon Jones, a 24-year-old student whose head was crushed and partly severed by a crane within two hours of his starting work for a Dutch-owned firm, Euromin, at Shoreham, West Sussex, on April 24 1998.

Mr Jones was killed while hooking bags of cobbles from the hold of a Polish ship on to chains which had been wrongly welded to the inside of the crane's grab jaws to save time and money. The grab was brought too low over the hold and accidentally closed on the student's head.

Yesterday's action was brought by the dead man's brother, Tim Jones, who has accused both Euromin and its general manager, James Martell, of "sacrificing safety for profit" and, along with other family and supporters, wants both to stand trial for manslaughter.

The CPS has twice refused to bring a manslaughter prosecution, despite a police recommendation to do so, arguing that there was insufficient evidence to convince a jury that Mr Martell had been guilty of gross negligence.

But Lord Justice Buxton, sitting with Mr Justice Moses, found that the most recent explanation of the CPS's reasoning by senior official Stephen O'Doherty had been insufficient and irrational, had included "unanswered questions" and had relied on an unsubstantiated "general view".

Giving his judgment, Lord Justice Buxton declared: "In cases such as this, that will not do. It is not good enough in such circumstances to rely on a blanket reference to a general view." He ordered that the DPP's decision should be reconsidered "with dispatch".

Instead of asking the Jones family's barrister to set out his case, the two judges had earlier taken the unusual step of calling on the DPP's QC, James Turner - who last year told an earlier hearing that the family's case was "doomed to failure" - to justify the decision not to prosecute.

Yesterday Mr Turner conceded that Mr Martell had been negligent and blameworthy for failing to have a safe system of work in place, but was repeatedly interrupted by the two judges, who said the CPS's positions had been "baffling" and "beggared belief". Mr Justice Moses said the dangers had been "plain as a pikestaff".

Mr Jones's father, Chris Jones, said afterwards: "We hope the CPS will now go ahead and prosecute. That's all we have ever asked - that this case is brought to trial for a jury to hear the evidence."

George Galloway, the Labour MP who sponsored a debate on the Simon Jones case in parliament last year, welcomed the high court decision as a "historic breakthrough in establishing corporate responsibility for the fate of employees to whom they owe a duty of care - a duty too many employers have dodged."

He demanded that Mr Calvert-Smith meet the Jones family and was joined by the Centre for Corporate Accountability pressure group in calling for a public inquiry into the CPS's handling of workplace deaths. Dozens of corporate manslaughter prosecutions have been blocked in recent years.

The health and safety executive, which was first warned about conditions at the firm five years ago - and is expected to prosecute Euromin for breaches of safety regulations if no manslaughter prosecution takes place - declined to comment on yesterday's judgment.

The CPS said it was studying the ruling "as a matter of urgency".

fields.headline: Sword death 'may be an accident'
fields.trailText: The death of a local councillor from samurai sword wounds may have been the result of a bizarre accident involving Nigel Jones, the Liberal Democrat MP for Cheltenham, a lawyer claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
The death of a local councillor from samurai sword wounds may have been the result of a bizarre accident involving Nigel Jones, the Liberal Democrat MP for Cheltenham, a lawyer claimed yesterday.

Andrew Pennington, a Liberal Democrat activist and aide to Mr Jones, died after an attack on the MP's constituency office by a man wielding a sword about one metre (40in) long. He had 11 stab wounds to his stomach, chest and back.

But at Cheltenham magistrates yesterday on the second day of the committal hearing of Robert Ashman, 49, a civil engineer charged with Mr Pennington's murder, Roger Everest, defending, claimed that there was no proof of a murder and that the MP could be implicated in the death.

Mr Jones had told the court of his struggle with the swordsman on January 28 which left him requiring about 60 stitches to his hands and specialist surgery.

fields.headline: Britons failing with toothbrush
fields.trailText: Four hundred years after the toothbrush was introduced to Europe from China, a government survey has discovered that two in three Britons still do not know the proper way to clean their teeth.
fields.body:
Four hundred years after the toothbrush was introduced to Europe from China, a government survey has discovered that two in three Britons still do not know the proper way to clean their teeth.

Even though almost three quarters of the population brush twice a day, serious plaque affects all but a handful of systematic tooth cleaners.

The UK annual dental statistics were published yesterday by the office for national statistics, which commissioned research from five university dental schools. Their figures pick out toothbrush ignorance from a generally healthy context: a marked decline in national tooth loss and a growth in non-toothbrush hygiene, including flossing and use of mouthwash.

Improvements in dental care meant that "most of us can look forward to having teeth for life", said Jimmy Steele of Newcastle University, who led research in the north-east. "Lifelong teeth mean we've got to keep up a high and consistent standard of maintenance."

Most brush users go in for vigorous but disorganised scrubbing, according to the data, using the considerable time they spend on it to poor effect. Dr Steele said cleaning needed "thought and planning to make sure that nothing gets missed". Plaque was often overlooked on the back teeth and the inside of side teeth, while a reluctance to floss left gaps between teeth uncleaned.

The baffling range of toothbrushes available might be adding to the problem, as people experimented with styles instead of sticking to a consistent regime. Dr Steele said a narrow head with tightly packed bristles was the only essential, with floss and mouthwash also recommended.

The survey looked into 3,817 randomly chosen mouths in Northern Ireland, Wales, Birmingham, Dundee and Newcastle upon Tyne, and interviewed a further 2,500 people about their tooth cleaning habits.

It found that 77% of the respondents' last course of treatment was on the NHS, with 18% going private and the remainder mixing the two.

The number of people having regular checkups has risen to 59% from 43% in 1978, with women (66%) more conscientious than men (52%).

webTitle: Radical boarding school escapes closure threat

fields.headline: Radical boarding school escapes closure threat
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The threat of closure hanging over the progressive Summerhill school was lifted yesterday after the government agreed not to pursue its complaints about the school's controversial teaching methods, which include the right of pupils not to attend lessons.
fields.body:
The threat of closure hanging over the progressive Summerhill school was lifted yesterday after the government agreed not to pursue its complaints about the school's controversial teaching methods, which include the right of pupils not to attend lessons.

Three days into a hearing before an independent schools tribunal at the high court in London, the internationally renowned Suffolk boarding school reached an agreement which was approved by the education secretary, David Blunkett, yesterday.

In the agreement, hailed by Summerhill's owner, Zoe Redhead, as "a triumph", the Department for Education and Employment appears to acknowledge that its inspection system is flawed by saying that future checks by the schools watchdog Ofsted must recognise that learning is not necessarily confined to formal lessons.

The school - which had complained about being "harassed" by Ofsted inspectors - will be removed from a "hitlist" triggering annual inspections, and will not be visited again before 2004.

Ms Redhead insisted yesterday that the school had not agreed to make any concessions to the DfEE, and that it would continue to provide a "stimulating environment" for youngsters both within and outside timetabled lessons.

There were colourful courtroom scenes yesterday as pupils commandeered the court for a meeting at which they voted unanimously to back the DfEE agreement.

Ms Redhead launched the action to appeal against a notice of complaint issued by Mr Blunkett last summer following an Ofsted report which said that pupils were allowed to "mistake idleness for the exercise of personal liberty". Reporting serious weaknesses in children's learning, it added: "The root cause of the defects is non-attendance at lessons."

The fee-paying school for children aged six to 16 - which currently has 63 pupils - was founded by Ms Redhead's father, AS Neill, 79 years ago to let children "develop free from fear". It developed a reputation for unorthodox methods of teaching, rooted in the fundamental belief that there should be no coercion of pupils, who would learn and learn well when they chose. Pupils choose when to attend lessons and agree school laws in regular weekly meetings with staff.

Last summer, following Ofsted's findings, Mr Blunkett gave Summerhill six months to improve its standards, or face closure.

Yesterday Ms Redhead's appeal was withdrawn after the two sides agreed that the complaints about non-compulsory attendance at lessons and the lack of assessment should be annulled. The DfEE was ordered to pay Ms Redhead's legal costs, which could have reached £150,000.

Her legal team - hired on reduced fees - included Geoffrey Robertson QC and the human rights solicitor Mark Stephens.

The school's fight to remain open included witness statements from some of its more famous, successful ex-pupils such as the American film actress Rebecca De Mornay.

In her statement she said: "I feel it would be a true crime to even contemplate closing down this historic school and its radically alternative approach to education ... I believe Summerhill was an essential early tool in my academic development."

Yesterday a jubilant Ms Redhead said: "This is the most wonderful triumph for us. My father always had faith in the law, and he would be delighted at how it has brought him victory and vindication over a bureaucracy which could never cope with his ideas. He would be delighted, wherever he is.

"We have lived for a year under the Ofsted falsehood that we have mistaken idleness for liberty. This verdict refutes that defamation and shows that liberty and learning go hand in hand at Summerhill. We can now put all the pettiness and incomprehension to which we have been subjected behind us".

Carman Cordwell, aged 15, the pupil who chaired the meeting in the courtroom, said: "This is our charter for freedom. It gives us the space we need to live and breathe and learn into the future.

"After 79 years, this is the first official recognition that AS Neill's philosophy of education provides an acceptable alternative to compulsory lessons and the tyranny of compulsory exams. With this one bound, we are free at last."

webTitle: Stores in a pickle over salad cream

fields.headline: Stores in a pickle over salad cream
fields.trailText: Heinz relaunched its new look, repackaged salad cream yesterday - and revealed that it will also have a new-look price of almost double the previous cost.
fields.body:
Heinz relaunched its new look, repackaged salad cream yesterday - and revealed that it will also have a new-look price of almost double the previous cost.

The company went ahead with the controversial price increase despite opposition from supermarkets, retailers, and customers.

Supermarkets predicted the price rise would force Heinz Salad Cream out of the market and signal the demise of the product.

Asda, Sainsbury's, and Tesco all vowed to continue selling their own brand salad creams at around 50p, while the same size Heinz bottle will now retail at 99p.

There was a public outcry in October when Heinz announced it was considering axing the brand due to falling sales and the popularity of more varied and unusual dressings and salsas.

A statement from Asda said: "Heinz are really in a pickle if they think doubling the price is going to boost sales."

A Sainsbury's spokesman said: "We are very disappointed. Our customers will have to pay 99p for a product that was until today just 59p. Sainsbury's own brand equivalent costs 55p."

The "new look" Heinz product comes in fluted bottles with a new label. Millions of pounds have been spent on an advertising campaign to accompany the relaunch and a nationwide comedy tour.

Stefan Barden, Heinz director of European sauces, said: "The ground breaking relaunch of Heinz Salad Cream will make it the table sauce choice for today's discerning consumer."

fields.headline: Man drove children in 'suicide bid'
fields.trailText: A man who drove his two children on a "suicide mission" the wrong way on the M4 after a row with his wife was jailed yesterday for six years.
fields.body:
A man who drove his two children on a "suicide mission" the wrong way on the M4 after a row with his wife was jailed yesterday for six years.

Rajesh Salhotra, 31, a computer operator, deliberately crashing his BMW into another car last July, Ieuan Morris, prosecuting, told Cardiff crown court.

Salhotra had been driving with his wife, Poonam, their son, Ashwin, five, and daughter, Pooja, six. But amid the row, Mrs Salhotra fled when the car pulled up at a toll booth at the Severn crossing, and her husband sped off with the children.

"What followed was utter madness," said Mr Morris. "The defendant turned around and drove against the flow of traffic. He drove on the hard shoulder for three miles at 75mph before driving straight at another car."

At the wheel of the other car was Anthony Jones, 53, of Newport, a businessman with the Welsh development agency, who was driving his wife and two teenage daughters home from holiday. Mr Jones sustained two broken ankles, a smashed arm, broken pelvis and cracked ribs.

When arrested, Salhotra told police the crash was an accident, the court heard.

Salhotra, of Southall, west London, was convicted of causing grievous bodily harm with intent to Mr Jones and of imprisoning his wife, Poonam. He was banned from driving for six years.

fields.headline: Crufts judge guilty of cruelty
fields.trailText: Caroline Gatheral, 65, an authority on King Charles spaniels and a judge at this month's Crufts dog show, was yesterday banned from keeping animals for two years.
fields.body:
Caroline Gatheral, 65, an authority on King Charles spaniels and a judge at this month's Crufts dog show, was yesterday banned from keeping animals for two years.

She and her sister Mary, 63, pleaded guilty at Bishop Auckland magistrates' court in Co Durham to 83 charges of causing unnecessary suffering to animals.

Kevin Campbell, prosecuting for the RSPCA, told the court that inspectors and police had found atrocious conditions at the sisters' home near Darlington, last October. He said floors were covered in up to six inches of "compacted dog excrement" and many animals were caged in home-made kennels.

Veterinary reports later showed that many of the dogs, including Jack Russells, King Charles spaniels and long-haired dachshunds, were suffering from eye, mouth and ear problems. Many had to have rotten teeth removed.

The sisters were ordered to pay £500 each to the RSCPA towards the cost of keeping the 83 dogs, which will become the property of the society. The sisters' solicitor said they would consider an appeal.

fields.headline: Man jailed for shampoo assault
fields.trailText: A man who smeared shampoo on the door handle of his former wife's home, knowing it could cause a severe allergic reaction in her, was jailed for 14 months yesterday.
fields.body:
A man who smeared shampoo on the door handle of his former wife's home, knowing it could cause a severe allergic reaction in her, was jailed for 14 months yesterday.

Colin Slane, 28, from Dundee, was found guilty of assault following a trial at Dundee sheriff court last month. The court had heard that Heather Brown, 33, suffered massive allergic reactions to a range of products and could die if she did not receive treatment quickly.

Slane had denied the charge and said he had only wanted to frighten her, not harm her.

Yesterday, Sheriff Richard Davidson sentenced the former Scots Guardsman to 12 months for the assault which took place on January 21 last year.

He was given a further two months to run consecutively and another two months to run concurrently for further offences of spitting in his former wife's face and damaging her car by stamping on the roof. Slane had also denied these charges.

fields.headline: For a few pounds more
fields.standfirst: Film posters auction
fields.trailText: Feel lucky, punk? Fans of Dirty Harry and the Man with No Name will need plenty of cash as well as luck to walk off with a Clint Eastwood poster when an outstanding collection goes under the hammer at Christie's in London on Monday.
fields.body:
Feel lucky, punk? Fans of Dirty Harry and the Man with No Name will need plenty of cash as well as luck to walk off with a Clint Eastwood poster when an outstanding collection goes under the hammer at Christie's in London on Monday.

The collection was assembled over 20 years by a Californian. Rarities include Per Qualche Dollaro In Piu, as the 1965 For a Few Dollars More was called in Italy, which is expected to fetch £1,200, and another for Il Buono, Il Brutto, Il Cattivo, otherwise The Good, The Bad and the Ugly of 1966, estimated at up to £1,000.

A 1971 Dirty Harry poster, featuring the legendary .44 Magnum six-shot revolver, should realise up to £1,200

At the same sale, the London owner of a French poster for the 1942 classic Casablanca hopes to get up to £15,000, while an American poster for the 1946 movie Gilda, starring Rita Hayworth, is expected to make up to £9,000. Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall's The Big Sleep (1946) may go for £1,200.

webTitle: Sick girl, 8, poisoned by excess salt

fields.headline: Sick girl, 8, poisoned by excess salt
fields.trailText: A girl aged eight is critically ill in an Edinburgh hospital after allegedly being poisoned with overdoses of salt in what police believe is a case of Munchausen's syndrome by proxy.
fields.body:
A girl aged eight is critically ill in an Edinburgh hospital after allegedly being poisoned with overdoses of salt in what police believe is a case of Munchausen's syndrome by proxy.

The girl has reportedly been in hospital more than a dozen times and seen by her GP more than 100 times. "It beggars belief no one has picked up on it before," a police source told the Scotsman newspaper yesterday. "Nobody noticed anything unusual until it was too late."

Ten detectives are investigating the case, interviewing the girl's family, doctors, paediatricians and social workers.

Last week the girl, from Edinburgh, was admitted to the Royal hospital for sick children, where she is said to be in a coma with suspected salt poisoning.

People with Munchausen's syndrome by proxy harm others to get attention from medical staff. Their victims are usually children.

A source in the city council's social work department said: "We are just appalled. The people who have been closely involved in this are feeling quite devastated."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: 18 charged in racism inquiry
fields.body:
18 charged in racism inquiry

The number of people charged in a police crackdown on alleged racial offences has risen to 18, Scotland Yard said yesterday. Dawn raids in London on Wednesday saw 100 people arrested for suspected offences including racially aggravated criminal damage, distributing racist literature, and threats to kill.

Gonorrhoea cases rise

There has been a huge increase in the number of people suffering from the sexually-transmitted disease gonorrhoea in the last year, figures showed yesterday. Cases of the disease have gone up 26% among men and 30% among women, with teenagers particularly affected, the public health laboratory service revealed.

Sackings in fraud inquiry

Eighteen workers at Glasgow city council have been sacked following an investigation into fraudulent benefits claims, it was confirmed yesterday. The inquiry found that some 80 current and former employees may have been involved in fraud amounting to £500,000. Some still face disciplinary hearings.

Driller Killer for Channel 4

A film which helped spark the "video nasty" controversy in the 1980s is to be screened on mainstream TV. Channel 4 will show the 1979 serial murderer movie Driller Killer next month.

webTitle: Moa wiped out by early colonists

fields.headline: Moa wiped out by early colonists
fields.trailText: A handful of Polynesian colonists may have wiped out the largest bird in creation in less than 100 years, according to new research today.
fields.body:
A handful of Polynesian colonists may have wiped out the largest bird in creation in less than 100 years, according to new research today.

Before the first humans arrived in New Zealand - probably in the 13th century from Pacific islands far to the north - two forested islands were home to 11 species of moa, giant flightless birds some of which would have dwarfed the ostrich. There were probably 160,000 alive at any one time.

By the time European settlers arrived in the 18th century, the moas existed only as fossils. The first anthropologists divided early New Zealand history into two phases, a "moa-hunter" period that might have lasted for centuries, and a later, more sophisticated Maori one.

webTitle: Pothole tax to cut road repair chaos

fields.headline: Pothole tax to cut road repair chaos
fields.trailText: Ministers are to respond to the public clamour over the utility companies repeatedly ripping up roads by imposing heavy fines if contractors fail to complete work on time.
fields.body:
Ministers are to respond to the public clamour over the utility companies repeatedly ripping up roads by imposing heavy fines if contractors fail to complete work on time.

They are also to seek legislation requiring all utility firms to pay standard fees for digging up the roads. The "pothole tax" could reach tens of thousands of pounds for what are described as traffic-sensitive roads.

The move will stir a row with the powerful utility firms which will insist the cost be passed on to consumers.

Roger Khanna, highways advisor to the London councils, said: "The problem is that the utility firms are incredibly powerful, and once they have a licence they have no financial incentive to complete the work quickly, or at a time convenient to road users.

"It is one of the great myths that local councils have any powers to co-ordinate the bulk of the utility work. They [the utilities] inform us overnight what they are planning to do, often claiming it is an emergency or a commercial necessity. We are powerless to stop most of them."

Many contractors for utility companies start work at the agreed time, but do not continue the work for many days thereafter.

Ministers concede the increase in traffic jams has been caused by the the utility industries and the cable companies.

The number of utility firms with licences to rip up roads has risen to 80. More than 30 have licences in London. Ten years ago only 10 firms had licences in London. In the capital alone roads are ripped up more than 350,000 times a year.

Lord Whitty, the transport minister, said the government already had powers under New Roads and Works Streets Act to give councils the right to charge for overstay by contractors. The reform would require a simple vote in parliament.

In London, the fine for over-stay is likely to be £2,000 a day.

Mr Khanna questioned the wisdom of fines based on over-stay since it would be difficult to agree a reasonable period to complete works.

"It is a struggle to keep up with the utility firms' work. We would be chasing ghosts."
