webTitle: GM trials upset as farmers pull out

fields.headline: GM trials upset as farmers pull out
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: The government's genetically modified crop trials were in disarray last night as it emerged that two of the 31 participating farms announced a week ago have already pulled out.
fields.body:
The government's genetically modified crop trials were in disarray last night as it emerged that two of the 31 participating farms announced a week ago have already pulled out.

Monsanto, one of the companies involved, said their contracts with individual farms were not intended to bind them to carrying out the trials.

This is a boost to anti-GM campaigners who hope the revelations will trigger a domino effect, with other farmers abandoning the trials. Monsanto said they had heard of "three or four" farms having second thoughts.

Scimac, the GM industry's umbrella organisation, conceded that farms in Friskney Tofts, south Lincolnshire, and in Ulleskelf, near York, had pulled out.

Both have been subject to local criticism and complaint, particularly at Friskney Tofts, where, according to a local environmental group, the Gaia Trust, some 300 of the 1,000 residents opposed the plan and local businesses had threatened to stop trading with the farm.

But Scimac said that last Saturday, a day after the announcement by the environment minister, Michael Meacher, the farmer, Andrew Roughton, decided to plant traditional sugar beet. Novartis, the company that would have produced the GM seeds for him, said he had decided he was not prepared to wait for them.

His wife told BBC Radio Lincolnshire: "We did not at any time have a contract to grow GM crops and we are not growing any."

It was not clear why the farmer at Ulleskelf, Carl Clayton, who was due to grow GM fodder beet, had pulled out. He told Friends of the Earth the trial "had been abandoned".

Though the government and the companies involved anticipated some farms pulling out of the trials these early announcements are an embarrassment.

Ministers had hoped to announce rather more than the 30 farms taking part last week, and need 75 participating farms across the country over the next three years for a viable study.

Andy Tait, of Greenpeace, said: "It is great news that two farmers have responded to a firm rejection of GM pollution by local residents and farmers in their communities by pulling out of the trial programme.

"All over the country local campaigns are springing up to reject these trials, with local residents disgusted by the complete absence of consultation. It is to be hoped that other farmers will also respect their communities' wishes and withdraw from the programme."

Pete Riley, GM campaigner for Friends of the Earth, said: "These trials are descending into farce. We urge other farmers considering taking part to think again."

Colin Merritt, biotechnology manager of Monsanto, said that contracts between GM companies and farmers set out the terms on which trials would be conducted. But they were not intended to force farmers who change their mind to go ahead.

"It's not a kind of gun to anybody's head - that isn't what it is intended to be. That is not in anybody's interest."

He expected some farms to drop out. "With more than 100 being submitted so far, of which 30 have been solicited, we expect one or two to drop out at some stage of the process."

A spokeswoman for the GM unit at the Cabinet Office said: "As far as we know Scimac are having no problems in delivering these sites. The farm-scale evaluations are vital if we are to answer important questions."

webTitle: Smyth in bid to oust Trimble

fields.headline: Smyth in bid to oust Trimble
fields.standfirst:
Opponent of Good Friday deal announces challenge

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: David Trimble is facing the most serious crisis in his leadership of the Ulster Unionists, after the party's chief whip at Westminster announced that he would mount a leadership challenge this weekend.
fields.body:
David Trimble is facing the most serious crisis in his leadership of the Ulster Unionists, after the party's chief whip at Westminster announced that he would mount a leadership challenge this weekend.

Rev Martin Smyth, the MP for South Belfast, ended weeks of speculation about a "stalking horse" leadership candidate when he declared that he would attempt to topple Mr Trimble, after the UUP leader indicated that he was prepared to re-establish Northern Ireland's power-sharing executive.

Hardline unionists were angered when Mr Trimble suggested during a visit to Washington last week that he would be prepared to sit down in government with Sinn Fein again - ahead of IRA disarmament - provided the republicans offered cast-iron guarantees about decommissioning their weapons.

Mr Smyth, an opponent of the Good Friday agreement, made it clear that he would abandon the peace process when he said yesterday that he would offer a "more vigorous promotion of Ulster Unionist policy".

A close ally of the former UUP leader Jim Molyneaux, Mr Smyth is unlikely to unseat Mr Trimble at tomorrow's meeting in Belfast of the 858-strong Ulster Unionist council. But a strong vote for the former grand master of the Orange Order could severely weaken Mr Trimble, paving the way for a heavyweight challenger, such as the party's deputy leader, John Taylor, or the dissident MP Jeffrey Donaldson.

Mr Smyth indicated that this was his aim when he said that he "had no real desire" to lead the party.

Mr Donaldson, who walked out of the Good Friday agreement hours before the 1998 signing ceremony, last night threw his weight behind Mr Smyth. "A vote for Martin Smyth on Saturday will be a clear warning to the government and to republicans that unionists have given enough," he said.

His remarks were echoed by MPs William Ross and William Thompson, who have been adamant opponents of Mr Trimble. Mr Thompson said: "Martin Smyth will have very significant support and I certainly believe he will give David Trimble a run for his money."

Mr Trimble remained defiant last night, saying that he was confident that his policy would be endorsed by the UUP council tomorrow. At a press conference at Stormont, he said he was "somewhat surprised and a little bit disappointed" by Mr Smyth's decision to challenge him.

"I think what Martin needs to do is to explain to people clearly what the objective is, and what policy is being pursued," Mr Trimble said.

The British and Irish governments will be carefully monitoring tomorrow's meeting, knowing that a strong vote for Mr Smyth could kill off hopes of reviving the power-sharing executive and set the peace process back by years.

Mr Smyth will tell the council that Mr Trimble was severely undermined when he entered government with Sinn Fein last year ahead of disarmament. He will hope to build on the 42% of party members who voted against Mr Trimble's decision to form the power-sharing executive.

Mr Trimble will seek to reaffirm his position by reminding the council that he honoured his pledge to abandon the executive if the IRA failed to disarm.

He yesterday received the support of the chairman of his party, Lord Rogan, his Westminster colleague Ken Maginnis and the former Stormont minister Michael McGimpsey, who said he was "astonished" by Mr Smyth's challenge.

Hardlinerwith a folksy appeal

For diehard Ulster Unionists who long for a return to the days when Sinn Fein was excluded from the political process, the Rev Martin Smyth is a comforting figure.

A Presbyterian minister who served as grand master of the Orange Order for 25 years, Mr Smyth made his greatest contribution to Northern Ireland during the annual Orange parades in July. In his familiar bowler hat, Mr Smyth delivered speeches which delighted his Orange audience but perplexed outsiders. His message appeared to be that the Union was at risk from the dark forces of nationalism, but that the good Orange folk should rely on the leadership provided by himself and the former UUP leader, Jim Molyneaux.

Mr Smyth, 68, and Lord Molyneaux, who resigned as party leader in 1995, refused to engage with nationalists in serious negotiations throughout the 1980s and early 1990s, ensuring that London and Dublin moulded the political process above the heads of Unionists.

It was only with the election in 1995 of David Trimble, who punched at the same intellectual weight as British and Irish ministers, that Unionism was able to influence the peace process.

Mr Smyth's leadership challenge will probably be remembered as his most remarkable achievement in an 18-year career as an MP.

Mr Smyth, married with two daughters, joined the Orange Order in the hardline Sandy Row area of Belfast and was educated at Methodist College, one of Northern Ireland's best schools.

webTitle: Scathing report reveals Law Society climate of fear

fields.headline: Scathing report reveals Law Society climate of fear
fields.standfirst: Kamlesh Bahl: the Law Society reportWork Unlimited
fields.trailText: The full picture of the climate of "fear and confusion" behind the scenes at the Law Society's headquarters in central London will become public today as the report of the independent inquiry into complaints of bullying by the society's vice president, Kamlesh Bahl, lands on solicitors' desks.
fields.body:
The full picture of the climate of "fear and confusion" behind the scenes at the Law Society's headquarters in central London will become public today as the report of the independent inquiry into complaints of bullying by the society's vice president, Kamlesh Bahl, lands on solicitors' desks.

The report by Lord Griffiths, a retired law lord, paints a picture described by the Solicitors' Journal as "truly shocking". Staff are seen as cowering under Ms Bahl's demands but frightened of complaining for fear of losing their jobs.

The report is accompanied by a recommendation that members vote to expel her from the society's council. That will no longer be necessary. Ms Bahl decided to resign this week.

The row is certain to heap further embarrassment on the beleaguered society, which faces threats by the government to take away its powers to regulate the profession after a huge pile-up of complaints against solicitors.

Solicitors, too, are increasingly disenchanted with the society following a series of disasters, which began when a previous presidential candidate resigned amid sexual harassment claims, and continued with fiascos over the society's computer system and a serious shortfall in its indemnity fund, which had to call for top-ups from the profession after seriously misjudging a shortfall in its finances.

The latest debacle will not help the society's image with influential City firms, which have come to see it as an irrelevance and cringe at the embarrassing headlines it has produced in the last few years.

The scathing report raises questions about how the sorry state of affairs could have gone on for so long without decisive action by others at the top of the Law Society structure. No one seems to have been willing to take decisive action over Ms Bahl's behaviour, though complaints date back to September 1998.

The report tells of how, when Ms Bahl was confronted over her "aggressive" behaviour, the reaction was as if a button marked "nuclear" had been pressed. The secretary general, Jane Betts, told the inquiry: "There was a switch in behaviour which then became very aggressive and frightening." Ms Bahl attacked her staff with "verbal onslaughts."

The report describes how two colleagues were subjected to treatment which was "aggressive and demeaning, and well beyond the acceptable bounds of firm management or questioning, and properly to be described as bullying."

Two colleagues - Ann Frazer, international policy executive, and Jean Johnson, director of human resources - told the inquiry how they received angry phone calls at home at night. Ms Johnson said that she was woken by one such call to be told a draft paper was unacceptable and the tone of voice upset her so much "she spent most of the night in tears."

At one meeting Ms Bahl subjected Russell Wallman, head of policy, to "a terrifying verbal onslaught".

The inquiry had "no doubt it gravely undermined his self-confidence and contributed to his stress."

Most members should receive the 40-page report today - the Guardian already has a copy. One London solicitor who received his yesterday said: "It seems to me the inquiry was conducted with scrupulous fairness and the findings seem to be justified by the evidence.

"No one seemed to stand up to this woman before the complaints were made. I would have voted for her expulsion if I were given the chance to vote."

Ms Bahl could not be reached for comment yesterday. She told the inquiry she acknowledged that her style was firm and direct, but she had not intended to cause offence or upset to any staff member.

The inquiry was launched after Mr Wallman filed a formal complaint of "persistent bullying and intimidation over a prolonged period of time." The union said it had received a number of similar complaints but the other staff had withdrawn their complaints "following serious concerns about possible repercussions."

However, four other staff joined Mr Wallman with formal complaints to the Griffiths inquiry.

Ms Bahl is still going ahead with a tribunal claim against the society alleging sex and race discrimination, launched after the Griffiths inquiry reported.

webTitle: Doors open today on best of British art from 1500

fields.headline: Doors open today on best of British art from 1500
fields.standfirst: New name, new image in first stage of Tate shake-up
fields.trailText: While a lone protester condemned the exercise as an act of "gross decadence", the Tate gallery in London was renamed Tate Britain yesterday and declared the greatest collection of "admittedly mostly English" art in the world.
fields.body:
While a lone protester condemned the exercise as an act of "gross decadence", the Tate gallery in London was renamed Tate Britain yesterday and declared the greatest collection of "admittedly mostly English" art in the world.

You could tell something important was happening because the artist Tracey Emin had crawled out of her bed for the early morning relaunch to pose with 50 other British painters and sculptors on the steps of the gallery on Millbank. Damien Hirst and the rest of the Brit art young turks, however, were notable by their absence.

The doors open today on a radically rearranged collection of the best British art from 1500 to the present, with further changes this spring when a £32m redevelopment of the building will create a third more space to show the large part of the Tate's collection now in storage.

With the validity of a British identity being challenged daily, the gallery's new director, Stephen Deuchar, said: "For me this is the perfect time to launch Tate Britain, when the very notion is being questioned because of devolution and our relations with Europe."

The shake-up is the first part of the restructuring. The Tate Modern museum opens in May. The Tate's guiding Svengali, Nicholas Serota, insisted that its new sister gallery in the converted Bankside power station farther down the Thames would not steal the old museum's thunder.

The arts minister, Alan Howarth, said that, far from being overshadowed, Tate Britain was at last becoming "truly the national gallery of British art" that its founder, the sugar tycoon Sir Henry Tate, had envisioned in 1898. British art was now in the "unfamiliar position" of surpassing the French and Italians, whom it had traditionally deferred to.

He hoped that the "bowler-hatted functionaries of MI6 who gaze upon Tate Britain from their headquarters across the river" might investigate the meaning of the neon sign proclaiming "the whole world + the work = the whole world" which the artist Martin Creed has placed across the front of the museum.

Mr Deucher, who worked through the night to complete the re-hang, has abandoned convention and organised the new gallery to point up contrasts and themes. A cartoon on the BSE crisis by the Guardian cartoonist Steve Bell - "the Gillray of the modern day", as he called him - is hung next to Hogarth's virulently anti-French The Roast Beef of Old England, while Jacob Epstein's sculpture of a soldier/robot, The Rock Drill, is placed near the fiercely patriotic Death of Major Peirson.

There are three large sculptures by the Beirut-born artist Mona Hatoum and rooms dedicated to nudes, David Hockney, Ben Nicholson as well as the Tate stalwarts Turner and Blake.

The Turner Prize show will remain at Millbank, and a big show of work by young artists, New British Art 2000, opens in July. The first big exhibition in 20 years of paintings and drawings by the romantic poet William Blake is planned for the winter.

The doors open today on a radically rearranged collection of the best British art from 1500 to the present, with further changes this spring when a £32m redevelopment of the building will create a third more space to show the large part of the Tate's collection now in storage. With the validity of a British identity being challenged daily, the gallery's new director, Stephen Deuchar, said: "For me this is the perfect time to launch Tate Britain, when the very notion is being questioned because of devolution and our relations with Europe." The shake-up is the first part of the restructuring. The Tate Modern museum opens in May. The Tate's guiding Svengali, Nicholas Serota, insisted that its new sister gallery in the converted Bankside power station farther down the Thames would not steal the old museum's thunder. The arts minister, Alan Howarth, said that, far from being overshadowed, Tate Britain was at last becoming "truly the national gallery of British art" that its founder, the sugar tycoon Sir Henry Tate, had envisioned in 1898. British art was now in the "unfamiliar position" of surpassing the French and Italians, whom it had traditionally deferred to. He hoped that the "bowler-hatted functionaries of MI6 who gaze upon Tate Britain from their headquarters across the river" might investigate the meaning of the neon sign proclaiming "the whole world + the work = the whole world" which the artist Martin Creed has placed across the front of the museum. Mr Deucher, who worked through the night to complete the re-hang, has abandoned convention and organised the new gallery to point up contrasts and themes. A cartoon on the BSE crisis by the Guardian cartoonist Steve Bell - "the Gillray of the modern day", as he called him - is hung next to Hogarth's virulently anti-French The Roast Beef of Old England, while Jacob Epstein's sculpture of a soldier/robot, The Rock Drill, is placed near the fiercely patriotic Death of Major Peirson. There are three large sculptures by the Beirut-born artist Mona Hatoum and rooms dedicated to nudes, David Hockney, Ben Nicholson as well as the Tate stalwarts Turner and Blake. The Turner Prize show will remain at Millbank, and a big show of work by young artists, New British Art 2000, opens in July. The first big exhibition in 20 years of paintings and drawings by the romantic poet William Blake is planned for the winter.

fields.headline: Electric dreams
fields.trailText: Robocritters | Dispatches - Video Nasties | Great Military Blunders | Jam
fields.body:
A big problem with lobsters is motivation. "It's very hard to persuade a real lobster to go out and find mines at the bottom of the ocean." That's why Joe has designed a robotic one. So he can boss it around.

Joe sat naked in his Canadian log cabin jacuzzi, showing us how he designs dream lobsters on his lap-top. "It's a cocoon in here," Joe said, Hal-like, "just the white noise of the jacuzzi. Nobody disturbs me."

There are Robocritters (BBC2) even more pointless than Joe's lobsters. Three Japanese men have designed a dream housewife called Wendy who can chop cucumbers... on a good day (on a bad one, she attempts to machete the scientists).

The Japanese scientists were unique in Robo World in that they didn't have beards. The size of a scientist's beard seemed directly proportional to the absurdity of their robot. A bald man with a full ZZTop called Gavin had spent 10 years in his LA bungalow perfecting a robotic snake. Why? "In a few years, I'll have one that can climb trees." That's why.

A Noah's Ark of Jan Svanmayer mutations passed before our eyes; mechanical pike; headless flamingoes; millipedes with faulty legs. In nature, we were told, the more legs the better. If you've a small brain, it means you can surmount any obstacle without thinking about it too much.

Dispatches - Video Nasties (C4) adapted the millipede principle to programme-making. "For the first time on TV, we test the psychological effects of video games on 100 British schoolboys. And you'll be shocked by the results!"

Dispatches incontrovertibly proved that prolonged exposure to spurious documentaries with a highly dubious thesis can be enough to turn you to video games. "What's your teenager like when he's been blasting zombies? Notice any changes?" the presenter asked, as if auditioning for a Daz commercial.

A deranged policeman who carried a huge gun (as do a large section of the American population) talked about the links between high school massacres and the existence of Sony Playstation, seemingly oblivious to the irony of carrying a piece whilst moralising about a toy. Even without the gun, his argument held about as much water as claiming the Columbine Massacre was down to drinking too much Sunny Delight.

Professor Kevin Brown, a forensic scientist, stood earnestly behind a burned-out car on a hilltop above Swansea, claiming that video games were responsible for the epidemic of joy-riding in the city. Nothing to do with the total lack of anything for teenagers to do, of course.

With a fast-cut montage of maps, candles and actors in chainmail waving cardboard swords, Great Military Blunders (C4) attempted video nasty action for history buffs. "The 11th century! The Holylands!" the voiceover began. "Christians mount their claim, determined to slaughter Muslim infidels!"

Medieval historians can be infinitely enlivened by dub bing battle cries beneath what they're saying. A producer of Pebble Mill once told me that you can spice up a whole daytime schedule by dubbing Radio Two-style muzak under the lot.

The Pebble Mill principle has of late been taken up with great enthusiasm by cutting-edge comedy. First, by Dom Joly's updated candid camera, Trigger Happy TV, now, by Chris Morris's Jam (C4).

Since Brass Eye, Morris has been linked with all sorts of improbable projects: ghost-writing the scripts for Ali G (untrue); a chat show with Will Self (untrue); and a TV version of Blue Jam (so true, the Radio One scripts have been reproduced ad verbatim; wobbly, ketamine images illustrating the radio). The overall effect is television as if it were recorded underwater. A doctor caresses his own knee, a woman mimes plaintively to Mini Ripperton (albeit sitting in a tree, being beaten with a Space hopper); a middle-aged man marries himself. "Occasionally, I meet a girl and think, yeah, I could spend my life with her....but I'm happy as I am."

There's no surrealism here, just low-key observations of the humdrum horror of living, upended by Morris-logic. At his best, Chris Morris makes everything else on television look like a parody of itself. That isn't the case with Jam, which is brilliant, of course, but no longer feels Out There. I suppose TV is becoming more absurd than anything Morris could dream up, and what's he going to do about that?

webTitle: Labour told to shake up 'dreary' constituencies

fields.headline: Labour told to shake up 'dreary' constituencies
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour must undergo its most radical transformation since its birth if it is to be re-elected for a second term, or even survive as an independent political party, the party leadership has been told.
fields.body:
Labour must undergo its most radical transformation since its birth if it is to be re-elected for a second term, or even survive as an independent political party, the party leadership has been told.

The warning, unusually coming from leading Blairite loyalists, rather than the party left, reveals the extent of the fear that disenchanted activists will not be able to bring out the core Labour vote at the next election. Labour is bracing itself for a major reverse in the May local government elections.

In a challenge to party orthodoxy, the modernisers warn that if members and activists feel ignored, they will desert as when party membership halved under Harold Wilson between 1964 and 1970.

However, there is also a strong condemnation of the culture of party activism beloved of the left: "Members are corralled into dreary school halls and community centres on cold dark nights, made to deliver newsletters and run bingo rounds up and down tower blocks. They are confronted by a bewildering array of jargon and acronyms, simmering local feuds and stultifying bureaucracy."

The modernisers, who are to publish a Fabian Society pamphlet next week, also warn that the party organisation's obsession with marginal seats leads it to neglect safe seats, so leading to a decline in the core Labour vote.

Junior ministers including John Denham helped draft the pamphlet, written by Paul Richards, a Labour candidate in 1997. Mr Richards calls for a sweeping modernisation, saying that the reforms prior to the last election have either not worked or not gone far enough.

He proposes abolition of what is the forum and decision making body of the local constituency parties - the general committee - claiming it would strike at the heart of the over-internalised culture and ethos of party activists.

Millbank, the Labour headquarters, headed off a row with the left at party conference by promising to consult this year before any attempt at abolition of the committees.

Mr Richards claims they are the product of an industrial age: they are unrepresentative; and encourage hyper-activism while simultaneously being inefficient. Instead he wants task forces - policy forums, social events, community campaigns- and for local parties to be social entrepreneurs, setting up creches, cleaning up parks, running community websites.

He also suggests the party introduce "registered supporters" without a party vote to bridge the gap between local Labour and the local electorate. Labour culture is a giant turn-off; 40% of people who join do not renew their subsciption. Sitting 10 hours a week in Labour meetings "advances the cause not one iota," he argues.

He attacks the fixes deployed by Millbank in the London and Wales elections, saying future elections must all be one member, one vote.

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Quorn ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Quorn ad says about you.
fields.body:
The ad: I love spoof ads. This one satirises those squeaky clean Happy-Days US soaps of the 50s, where Mom never gets out of her apron, Dad goes to work with a packed lunch and Jo Junior wears big specs. Here we enter the brightly coloured world of "Quornville, the town that's built on goodness".

We are introduced to a typical geeky family, who come out with crunching puns like "I've never tasted a sausage as swell as yours, Mr Nathan". The ad ends with Dad inviting the viewers to join him at an improbably-laden kitchen table in Quornville, "where the goodness shines through".

The jargon: Quorn is the vegetarian meat substitute thingy that has been around for over 10 years but is viewed as rather bland and worthy. This commercial is aimed at giving it a "personality boost", making it dynamic and everyday, using Quornville as a wholesome, family environment in which the product is central.

Personality: You are a householder, with or without kids, probably 25-plus, but not necessarily vegetarian. The point about Quorn is that it tastes like meat, so real hardcore veggies don't like it: this is targeting meat-avoiders who just eat fish and chicken (NB: only one fifth of Quorn consumers are vegetarian.)

Financial status: You are probably a bit upmarket, ABC1 rather than C1C2, given that you are cutting back on red meat.

Telling lifestyle detail: You like to think of yourself as a bit of a cook, who believes that eating any one thing too often is boring, weird and unhealthy.

Other relevant data: The director, Rob Sanders, used real US actors and copied the film techniques of American 50s sitcoms, with locked-off angles, no zooms or pans.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Best Years Of Our Lives | Dead Man Walking | Ghosts... Of The Civil Dead | Titanic
fields.body:
The Best Years Of Our Lives

(William Wyler, 1946)

7pm, Carlton Cinema

The year after the war had ended, perfectionist Wyler was already grappling with the mass post-traumatic stress disorder that returning veterans were facing - and hearts, minds and Academy Awards were well and truly captured by this highly accomplished tale. It charts the fates of three "heroes" returning to their hometown. Flawless performances from Fredric March, Myrna Loy, Dana Andrews and Harold Russell, who won an additional Oscar for "bringing hope to his fellow veterans".
Steve Rose

Dead Man Walking

(Tim Robbins, 1995)

10pm, FilmFour

An extraordinary film to come out of Hollywood: an honest, impassioned, but scrupulously balanced study of a state execution. It's based on the autobiography of Sister Helen Prejean, who became spiritual adviser to a convicted murderer in his last days on Death Row.The central performances are exceptional: Oscar-winning Susan Sarandon as Sister Helen and Sean Penn the irredeemable white-trash killer, Poncelet.

Ghosts... Of The Civil Dead

(John Hillcoat, 1988)

12.25am, FilmFour

We remain behind bars with this lacerating, documentary-style Australian prison drama. The cons are housed in an ultra-modern maximum security wing, but at heart they're pure Warner Bros jailbait, the daily brutalities inflicted on them leading to violent payback. And if it all sounds a bit relentless, there's an elevated message about the role of prisons in a civilised society in there too. Singer Nick Cave co-wrote and also appears.

Titanic

(James Cameron, 1997)

9pm, Sky Premier

As Oscar night approaches here's another chance to see the movie that grabbed 11 of them a couple of years ago. The film might have sunk without trace if the romance at the centre didn't hold. But Leonardo DiCaprio as penniless Jack and Kate Winslet's rich, spirited Rose are irresistible.

fields.headline: In the frame
fields.standfirst:
On Monday, Christie's holds one of its regular vintage film poster auctions. And these days, owning a genuine original is where it's at. But be prepared to fork out, as the market in movie artwork is booming, says Rebecca Taylor
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: On Monday, Christie's holds one of its regular vintage film poster auctions. And these days, owning a genuine original is where it's at. But be prepared to fork out, as the market in movie artwork is booming.
fields.body:
Clive Hirschhorn, author of The Hollywood Musical, bought his first original film poster in 1973, for the clunky 1941 Olivier epic, That Hamilton Woman. It cost him $10 in a New York store. Today, Hirschhorn, an avid poster collector, estimates its selling price at nearly $1000.

Once the sole preserve of obsessive film buffs, collecting vintage film posters is now big business. Competition is cut-throat and thousands of pounds can change hands for a prized original of classics such as The Maltese Falcon and Gone With The Wind, while a 1932 poster of horror classic, The Mummy, recently sold for a record-breaking $495,000.

On Monday, Christie's will put 400 lots of original film artwork under the hammer, ranging from a 1918 illustration for the DW Griffith film The Greatest Thing In Life, to a 1976 one-sheet depicting a youthful de Niro in Taxi Driver. A series of stark black and white 70s spreads for Magnum Force, featuring Clint Eastwood glowering menacingly over his gun, are expected to command especially high prices. Other desirables include an extremely rare French cafe poster for one of the first public screenings of Cinematographe De Salon "KOK", circa 1899, as well as a range of moody 40s film noir works featuring Rita Hayworth, Humphrey Bogart and Bette Davis. But the undoubted highlight is the chance to bid for rare original Casablanca posters, including Pierre Pigeot's steamily exotic 1942 design which was used to promote the film in France and is expected to sell for £10,000-£15,000.

Sarah Hodgson, of Christie's, says she has seen the market expand massively over the last 10 years. Christie's held a small auction in 1995, which proved so popular that the following year the auction house made the sales bi-annual. These events attract serious collectors from around the world, especially America and Japan, as well as big-time collectors who come to stockpile posters for investment, but the biggest group of poster punters are still the film fans who get their kicks from having a slice of cinema history on their living room walls. Jeremy Theobald, star of last year's indie hit, Following, enthuses wildly over the 1965 Ipcress File poster that was given to him as a birthday present. "It's a masterpiece of design, but also represents the iconography of the film," he says of the montage depicting a stony-faced Michael Caine in the reflection of a car's side mirror.

Bruce Marchant, co-owner of The Reel Poster Gallery in west London which specialises in hard-to-find film posters, believes the appeal lies in the special place that cinema holds in the public's consciousness. "It's something everyone can relate to."

"Some of these posters are works of modern art," says Kevin MacDonald, a documentary-maker and regular at Marchant's shop, who regards his cherished Polish poster for The Loneliness Of The Long Distance Runner as a seminal design. "Of the original stone lithographs from a film such as the 1946 classic, Gilda, only a few might have survived; poster collectors see these in the same way an art buff might regard an original Toulouse Lautrec print, or even Picasso," says Marchant.

The posters often generate particular emotional associations, or memories. Kids who saw the first episode of Star Wars at the cinema are now adults who can afford to put the original poster on their walls. "The typical customer here is a 20-30-something bloke, who wants something to liven up the walls of his bachelor pad," says Neil Palmer at Covent Garden's Cinema Store, which sells newer artwork. Hard-edged 60s films such as Get Carter or 70s Scorsese flicks that combine a touch of "culture" with Loaded-style kudos are best-sellers.

At Christie's, what is Hodgson's favourite at next week's auction? Rita Hayworth in a 50s gown, cigarette in hand, pouting on the poster for Gilda. It's expected to sell for £9,000. Hold on to that Toy Story spread - it could still make you a millionaire.

The posters you should be buying

* Any 50s sci-fi or horror films: lesser-known titles such as Devil Girl From Mars go for under £500. The Creature From The Black Lagoon (1954) or The Fly (1958) are £500-£700.

* 40s film noir is very highly prized. Double Indemnity (1944), Deadline At Dawn (1946) can be found for under £500.

* Hitchcock is highly collectible - posters for Rear Window (1958), Vertigo (1958), or North By Northwest (1959) go for between £200 and £500.

* Any James Bond. On Her Majesty's Secret Service (1969) and Moonraker (1979) go for around £300, then prices climb to over £1000 for From Russia With Love (1963).

* Any of the early Star Wars, especially the first and second films. They sell for around £100.

* Any 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968). They cost around £300-400 now and prices are expected to soar.

* Recent cult hits: Trainspotting (1995), Reservoir Dogs (1991), Pulp Fiction (1994) sell from around £80.

* Any early Disney. Disney from the 70s and 80s is also a good bet.

 For further information on Monday's auction, call Christie's on 0171-581 7611

At Christie's, what is Hodgson's favourite at next week's auction? Rita Hayworth in a 50s gown, cigarette in hand, pouting on the poster for Gilda. It's expected to sell for £9,000. Hold on to that Toy Story spread - it could still make you a millionaire. The posters you should be buying * Any 50s sci-fi or horror films: lesser-known titles such as Devil Girl From Mars go for under £500. The Creature From The Black Lagoon (1954) or The Fly (1958) are £500-£700. * 40s film noir is very highly prized. Double Indemnity (1944), Deadline At Dawn (1946) can be found for under £500. * Hitchcock is highly collectible - posters for Rear Window (1958), Vertigo (1958), or North By Northwest (1959) go for between £200 and £500. * Any James Bond. On Her Majesty's Secret Service (1969) and Moonraker (1979) go for around £300, then prices climb to over £1000 for From Russia With Love (1963). * Any of the early Star Wars, especially the first and second films. They sell for around £100. * Any 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968). They cost around £300-400 now and prices are expected to soar. * Recent cult hits: Trainspotting (1995), Reservoir Dogs (1991), Pulp Fiction (1994) sell from around £80. * Any early Disney. Disney from the 70s and 80s is also a good bet.  For further information on Monday's auction, call Christie's on 0171-581 7611

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Cast your minds back to the Brit Awards - that festival of talent that those in the industry like to call a celebration of pop music. For some, the Brits 2000, which were held at Earl's Court at the beginning of the month and broadcast by ITV, have already been cast into the dustbin of ephemeral cultural history.
fields.body:
Cast your minds back to the Brit Awards - that festival of talent that those in the industry like to call a celebration of pop music. For some, the Brits 2000, which were held at Earl's Court at the beginning of the month and broadcast by ITV, have already been cast into the dustbin of ephemeral cultural history.

But one corner of the country appears to want to keep this year's Brits Awards very much alive in the minds of many for months to come. Remember those outsized pink legs from between which Geri Halliwell made an unforgettable girl-powerful entrance onto the stage? Well, the designer of said appendages lives in Suffolk. Like the designers of the other Brits sets, he had to pitch his grand scheme to the Brits committee before getting approval. But there are rumours of even greater plans for the posterity of Geri's über-crotch.

As East Anglians know, Suffolk is a land of commuters, and Bramfield is just one of the main line stations from which commuter crowds disgorge daily. It was felt, in the local pub where all matters of community welfare are agreed, that the lot of the sorry travellers would be improved immeasurably if they were to emerge triumphant from the final tunnel on their homeward journey to find themselves panting to a halt between the giant Geri thighs. Sadly, the plan has as yet come to nothing and the legs are folded and demure, inside a Suffolk storehouse...

On an different note, Countdown's presenter Richard Whiteley seems to have been doing a spot of moonlighting. Mayoralty is in his sights. No, not the London race in which Dobbo and Red Ken are vying for the gold chain. Yorkshireman Whiteley is the mayor of Wetwang, a small village in north Yorkshire beloved of York university students in search of a cheap joke. But ridiculing an old-fashioned village name like Wetwang and an established presenter like Whiteley for a quick laugh is beneath the best of us. We're saying nothing.

 Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast Magazine

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: That Fateful Day | Performance on 3
fields.body:
For nearly a year members of the Royal Court Young Writers' Group have been collaborating with the BBC to prepare this afternoon's play. That Fateful Day (2.15pm, Radio 4) is a drama documentary built around the events of Wednesday March 24 last year, when NATO began bombing Belgrade in its campaign to stop the Serbian military action in Kosovo. The fictional experiences of a university student and his family are interwoven with recorded memories of some of the local people affected by the conflict.

Performance on 3 (7.45pm, Radio 3) offers the first of four special concerts from the Bridgewater Hall in Manchester. During the series the BBC Philharmonic, conducted by Yan Pascal Tortelier,offers a rare chance to hear all seven symphonies by the Finnish composer Jean Sibelius. The first part of tonight's performance opens with the wonderfully stirring Karelia Suite followed by the Third Symphony. The First Symphony comes at 8.35pm, after the interval.

webTitle: Section 28 deal collapses as peers inflict new defeat

fields.headline: Section 28 deal collapses as peers inflict new defeat
fields.standfirst: More about section 28
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's efforts to find a compromise in the row over section 28, banning the promotion of homosexuality in schools, fell apart last night as peers rejected the latest proposals and pushed through an amendment to compel teachers to place marriage at the centre of sex education.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's efforts to find a compromise in the row over section 28, banning the promotion of homosexuality in schools, fell apart last night as peers rejected the latest proposals and pushed through an amendment to compel teachers to place marriage at the centre of sex education.

This is the eighth major defeat inflicted on the government in the Lords since the hereditary peers were thrown out late last year. Mr Blair next week will appoint 19 new Labour peers, nine Liberal Democrats and four Conservatives.

Peers supported by 190 to 175, majority of 15, a Tory amendment to the learning and skills bill requiring schools to promote marriage as the key building block of society. The education minister, Lady Blackstone, said the move had "demolished" carefully constructed government proposals for new sex education guidance which would stress the importance both of marriage and "stable relationships".

That compromise, intended to defuse the row over plans to repeal section 28, would be reintroduced when the bill returned to the Commons, she said, and the Tory amendment - tabled by the former cabinet minister Lady Young - would be removed.

Lady Blackstone said teachers had to take account of "the real world" and the fact that people lived in stable, loving relationships as well as married ones.

Debate had been "confused and disconnected from the truth", and since the amendment had been tabled there had been a lot of comment in the press, much of it "factually incorrect", she said.

The guidance, backed by the Bishop of Blackburn, the Rt Rev Alan Chesters, says teachers should tell children about the "significance of marriage and stable relationships as the key building blocks of community and society".

Lady Blackstone said teachers would be clear about what they could tell children "rather than what they cannot".

She told peers: "We represent a wide range of society." Teachers would underline the importance of marriage and family and "the need to respect diversity".

Lady Young said the guidance to teachers could in "no way" be regarded as a substitute for section 28, and insisted the clause should stay. She urged peers to back her call for teaching guidance that stressed the importance of marriage.

Saying she had received 4,000 letters begging her to "stand firm", she claimed that majority of people were opposed to repeal.

Parents had a difficult job raising children and did not want them subjected to the promotion of homosexuality and some of the "appalling" literature published by health authorities.

The bishop, an architect of the latest proposals, urged peers to accept them. Though church leaders had not got everything they wanted, the government's amendment went "a significant way to achieving what is required".

The compromise had the backing of George Carey, Archbishop of Canterbury, he added. "He and I are both pleased with the focus on marriage in the context of family life and the desire to protect children from inappropriate teaching and materials."

The Liberal Democrat Lord Russell said the government amendment was a "fudge" he could live with.

The gay Labour peer Lord Alli attacked the "pure prejudice" expressed by people like Lady Young. Homophobia had "found a new home" in her proposals, he said.

fields.trailText:
Bad day
Goats. Thirty have perished after being used by the Navy to test submarines. According to a Commons answer goats - whose respiratory systems are similar to those of humans - are used to determine time limits for safe escapes from sunken subs. Those found to be be unfit afterwards are humanely killed.

Lady Jay. The leader of the Lords dealt a blow for equality by winning the right for daughters of peers to sit on the steps of the throne during debates in the upper house. Up until now the privilege has fallen automatically to the oldest sons of peers.

webTitle: PM rejects intervention on pound to help exports

fields.headline: PM rejects intervention on pound to help exports
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday stood firm against demands from Britain's struggling manufacturing sector for government action to reduce the value of the pound, despite fresh evidence from industry of weakening order books and an intensifying squeeze on profits.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday stood firm against demands from Britain's struggling manufacturing sector for government action to reduce the value of the pound, despite fresh evidence from industry of weakening order books and an intensifying squeeze on profits.

In the wake of criticism that this week's Budget failed to offer any help to exporters, the prime minister said it would be a "big mistake" to try artificially to lower the level of the pound, arguing that to do so would land the government with "far worse problems".

The latest snapshot of manufacturing from the CBI yesterday - coming in the wake of BMW's decision to dismember Rover - showed the impact of sterling's recent strength on industry, with both domestic and overseas orders falling back after four months of slight improvement. However, the government was cheered by evidence from the employers' organisation that factory output was increasing, and Mr Blair said that manufacturing was starting to live with the strong pound.

"Business can't rely on a perpetual devaluation," he said on BBC radio. "We've got to make the changes in productivity and working practices, and it's worth pointing out that - although I totally understand that there are certain sections of manufacturing that have been hard hit by the strength of the pound - on the whole, British industry is coping far better than people predicted."

The prime minister also rejected suggestions from industrialists and trade unionists that one way to bring down the level of sterling would be for the government to pledge itself to join the single currency at a much lower rate.

"You can't enter the euro on the basis of fluctuations in the exchange rate. You've got to enter the euro on the basis of the long-term interest of the country," he said. According to the CBI survey of more than 800 firms, only 15% of exporters reported that their order books are currently above normal for the time of year, against 42% who said they were below normal.

Sudhir Junankar, the CBI's associate director of economic analysis, said: "Export demand remains weak, but much less so than during most of 1999. Although sterling's strength against the euro continues to handicap UK exporters, improved demand conditions in Euroland and a buoyant US economy have so far eased the pressure on them."

Jeremy Hawkins, economist at Bank of America agreed with the prime minister that manufacturers appeared to have learned how to manage with the strong pound. "Given that they are as optimistic as they are, it would appear that all the whingeing about the pound was more rhetoric than a reflection of what is actually happening," he said.

fields.headline: David Fussey
fields.standfirst: Driving force behind a new university
fields.trailText: As vice-chancellor at the University of Greenwich, David Fussey, who has died aged 56, defined an approach to the development of the post-1992 universities which specifically rejected the stereotypes of the old binary system of polytechnics and universities. Although he died too young, it seems appropriate in some ways that his last seven years were spent leading an institution set up as part of the Victorian polytechnic movement to better the lives of ordinary men and women.
fields.body:
As vice-chancellor at the University of Greenwich, David Fussey, who has died aged 56, defined an approach to the development of the post-1992 universities which specifically rejected the stereotypes of the old binary system of polytechnics and universities. Although he died too young, it seems appropriate in some ways that his last seven years were spent leading an institution set up as part of the Victorian polytechnic movement to better the lives of ordinary men and women.

In David, these values were manifest in their modern form. He was strongly committed to widening the range of people participating in higher education, and was personally involved in this work both in the university and nationally. But he could see no reason why the mass of students now in higher education should not get the benefits previously reserved for an elite.

Students at the University of Greenwich now have access to a much improved estate, including, notably, the major part of Sir Christopher Wren's Greenwich hospital on the Thames, and to academic staff generating higher levels of research income than any other post-1992 university.

Fussey was born in Hull. His mother, Edna, still lives there, and he retained strong links with the area. Last autumn, knowing he was dying, David planted a tree on the meridian line at nearby Tunstall, as part of the University of Greenwich's Tree-Line project. He was educated at Hymers College, Hull, and at Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, where he was awarded a master's degree in mechanical sciences.

After graduation, he joined the Marchwood engineering laboratories, part of the Central Electricity Generating Board, as a research officer, where he worked until 1969. In 1970, he completed his PhD in engineering science at Warwick University. He was a lecturer in the department of mechanical engineering at Nottingham University from 1969-78, during which time he spent a year in Australia as a visiting fellow at the University of New South Wales, Sydney.

In 1978, he was appointed professor and head of the department of mechanical engineering at the University of Technology, in Papua, New Guinea. He returned to Britain in 1982 as professor and head of the department of mechanical engineering at Plymouth Polytechnic. Later, he was later appointed dean of the faculty of technology, before moving to Coventry Polytechnic in 1989 as deputy director.

David likened the management of a large university to steering a super-tanker - turn the wheel now, and in a few years' time the ship has changed direction. However, the clarity of his main agendas, and the tenacity with which he promoted them, enabled him to achieve much in a relatively short time. He was, by nature, a decision-taker and much preferred action to great debates. Even as vice-chancellor, he was always inclined to be a back-of-the-envelope man - as a former boss of his remarked, "David often shot from the hip, but invariably hit the target."

To senior management, he would say, with self-parody: "Engineers are people who will do for 50p what everybody else does for £1." But there was serious intent to this joke. The considerable progress at Greenwich was contingent on a level of operational efficiency that made the pips squeak; nevertheless, he also left the university recognised for the quality of its programmes and the academic standards of its awards.

As a distinguished researcher and administrator, David served on a number of professional bodies, including the Engineering Council and the National Association of Commonwealth Universities. He was a member of the Higher Education Funding Council for England from 1996 until his death, and a fellow of the Institute of Mechanical Engineers.

David was a committed Christian and a man of strong principles. He was an accomplished musician and would sometimes provide the music for services at his parish church, either on the organ or the piano, accompanied by his wife, Beryl, on the violin. He also composed music for the university's graduation ceremonies. He got on especially well with the students.

During his final illness, his colleagues saw the real extent of his commitment, tenacity and, indeed, bravery - qualities which, in better times, had made him a trailblazer for the new universities.

David Fussey is survived by Beryl, whom he married in 1966, and by two sons.

 David Fussey, mechanical engineer and university administrator, born September 5 1943; died March 16 2000

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText:
John Hudson:
The Guardian's former churches correspondent, Baden Hickman (Obituary, March 20) was so suave and urbane that there seemed to be little of the steelworker's son left in him in his later years.
fields.body:
John Hudson:
The Guardian's former churches correspondent, Baden Hickman (Obituary, March 20) was so suave and urbane that there seemed to be little of the steelworker's son left in him in his later years.

There was a brief resurfacing, however, in one of his last missions to the tropics, when he fell ill with a fever. One afternoon, he awoke to find a concerned-looking figure wearing the name tag "Dr Villa" peering over his hospital bed. It triggered something in his brain, and with one bound he was sitting up, waving his arms about and roaring "Cum on the Villa" in the richest Brummie accent.

Gladys Brooks writes:
I first met Esmé Goldberg (Obituary, March 8) 30 years ago through the Woodcraft Folk, the cooperative children's organisation, where she told us what it was really like in South Africa and inspired us with a passion against apartheid.

Her passion was well reflected at a Woodcraft camp in Dorset, when a day's walk, on a boiling hot day, included a climb up a very steep hill. At the top was a box of oranges, but the delight at seeing them turned to dismay when it became clear that they were Outspan. Not one of the children would touch them.

fields.headline: Out for votes
fields.standfirst:
Tatchell enters London elections battle

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Gay rights campaigner Peter Tatchell yesterday announced he will be an independent candidate in the Greater London Assembly elections, promising to plant 1m trees, introduce a £4.50 minimum wage and    turn the Mall into the world's biggest free ice-rink. "Everyone knows I'm a fighter and stick up for what I believe to be right," the Outrage! spokesman and former Labour parliamentary candidate said, describing himself as a "green left and human rights candidate" and declaring his support for Ken Livingstone's mayoral campaign.

"Everyone knows I'm a fighter and stick up for what I believe to be right," the Outrage! spokesman and former Labour parliamentary candidate said, describing himself as a "green left and human rights candidate" and declaring his support for Ken Livingstone's mayoral campaign.

But Mr Livingstone, who remains the favourite to win the May contest, insisted yesterday he would not endorse any or slate of candidates for the assembly.

Mr Tatchell, who said he needs only 8% of the vote to win a seat under the partly-proportional voting system, is joining an already crowded electoral market on the left.

Two leftwing slates - the London Socialist Alliance list headed by journalist Paul Foot and the Socialist Labour party list headed by miners' leader Arthur Scargill - have already been announced.

fields.headline: Fred Kelly
fields.standfirst: Gene's dancing brother, who gave the cha-cha-cha its zing
fields.trailText: The dancer and choreographer Fred Kelly, who has died aged 83, taught the latest American dances to the Queen and her sister, when they were the young Princesses Elizabeth and Margaret Rose during the war, and was credited with creating the cha-cha-cha in 1948. He devised the Latin dance for bandleader Tito Puente, based on the lindy, except that the dancers moved sideways and shouted "Cha-cha-cha".
fields.body:
The dancer and choreographer Fred Kelly, who has died aged 83, taught the latest American dances to the Queen and her sister, when they were the young Princesses Elizabeth and Margaret Rose during the war, and was credited with creating the cha-cha-cha in 1948. He devised the Latin dance for bandleader Tito Puente, based on the lindy, except that the dancers moved sideways and shouted "Cha-cha-cha".

Working for NBC, Kelly directed the first Steve Allen and Kay Kyser television shows, and choreographed the celebrated Ice Capades for three years. In the 1930s, he ran a dance studio in his home town of Pittsburgh, where many years later the young John Travolta studied. He also happened to be Gene Kelly's younger brother.

Fred was the youngest of five Kelly kids, of second-generation Irish parents. Like his two brothers and two sisters, he was encouraged by a stage-struck mother to take dancing lessons, and was soon considered the most talented of the children. He first performed professionally in vaudeville, as one of the Five Dancing Kellys. At the age of seven, he did an adagio dance with a six-year old girl on showboats, earning $50 a night.

During the depression, Fred teamed up with Gene to present a dance act punctuated with corny vaudeville jokes - rather similar to the Fit As A Fiddle number from Singin' In The Rain (1952), performed by Gene and Donald O'Connor. Fred and Gene were both excellent tap dancers, as well as proficient acrobats, and could do routines on roller skates; but they had to play rather cheap clubs. "They threw coins," Gene recalled. "I just had to grin and bear it. Fred, of course, took it all in his stride. He picked up the money, flashed a smile, and just went on dancing. But I was mortified, shocked and ashamed."

Nonetheless, the act paid for the brothers' college education, Fred obtaining a BA from the University of Pittsburgh. When their mother opened a dance school, both young men were the main teachers - until Gene left for New York and stardom. In 1939, when Gene, who had been playing Harry the Hoofer in William Saroyan's sentimental comedy, The Time of Your Life, on Broadway, decided not to tour with the show, he suggested that Fred take over. "Naturally, there were certain divergences of style, but basically the steps were the same and Fred picked them up without any trouble," Gene explained. "After all, he'd been a pro since he was five."

When America entered the second world war, Fred went straight from the play into the army, where he stayed for 4 years, during which time he appeared on Broadway in Irving Berlin's morale-boosting This Is The Army (1943). He married his childhood sweetheart, Dorothy Greenwalt, and, with their two children, settled in New Jersey to run a dance studio.

In 1954, Fred and Gene, wearing straw hats, striped shirts and shorts, danced together on film for the only time in I Love To Go Swimmin' With Wimmen, from the all-star Sigmund Romberg biopic, Deep In My Heart. The likeable and extrovert Fred seldom expressed any envy of his brother, though, when Deep In My Heart opened, he told a journalist, without irony, that he got higher billing than his brother. The credits read: "Fred and Gene Kelly."

Dorothy died in 1995, a year before Gene. Fred is survived by his son and daughter.

 Fred Kelly, dancer and choreographer, born June 2 1916; died March 15 2000

webTitle: Doctors say Suharto can be questioned

fields.headline: Doctors say Suharto can be questioned
fields.standfirst:
Indonesia's ex-dictator accused of taking billions

Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: Indonesia announced yesterday that it will pursue a corruption investigation of the country's former dictator, General Suharto, despite his doctors saying he is too ill to be questioned.
fields.body:
Indonesia announced yesterday that it will pursue a corruption investigation of the country's former dictator, General Suharto, despite his doctors saying he is too ill to be questioned.

The case has many similarities with the recent protracted, but ultimately unsuccessful, attempt to extradite from Britain to Spain the former Chilean president, Augusto Pinochet, to face charges of involvement in crimes against humanity.

The Indonesian attorney general, Marzuki Darusman, said the decision was taken after studying the report of an independent medical team which had examined the ailing Mr Suharto for several hours 10 days ago.

"We're satisfied that we're able to conclude from the report that it's possible to continue with the investigation," he said. "We will then be issuing a new summons to Mr Suharto to appear at the attorney general's office."

The summons is expected to be delivered at the start of next week.

Medical reports submitted by Mr Suharto's doctors were not taken into consideration, Mr Darusman said. "We only looked at the findings of the independent team."

Assegaff, one of Mr Suharto's lawyers, said Mr Suharto's family and doctors were disappointed by the decision. "This is a decision by the attorney general and we have to respect it," he said, adding that the team would discuss the matter more fully today.

For the past three months Mr Suharto's doctors, lawyers and children have repeatedly said he is too ill to be questioned. Mr Suharto was taken to hospital twice last year, once for a mild stroke and then with intestinal bleeding. His speech is now slurred and he finds it hard to walk more than very short distances.

Sources close to Mr Suharto say that, as with Mr Pinochet, the former dictator's mental health is more problematic and that he might escape trial on psychiatric grounds.

However, doctors linked to the independent team say Mr Suharto's recent check-up included psychiatric tests, and that the results were normal.

Mr Suharto, 78, ruled Indonesia with an iron fist for 32 years until May 1998, when he was forced to resign amid widespread social unrest and massive economic turmoil. His appointed successor, BJ Habibie, opened a half-hearted investigation into allegations that Mr Suharto amassed a multi-billion pound fortune, but then closed it, claiming there was insufficient evidence.

The new president, Abdurrahman Wahid, reopened the investigation last December after investigators uncovered new evidence.

Mr Suharto was named as a suspect last month, but he refused to answer two summonses that followed - one from the attorney general's office and the other from parliament. The latter wanted to question Mr Suharto about hundreds of millions of pounds of soft loans from the central bank to various troubled banks controlled by the former president's cronies in early 1997.

Legislators who went to Mr Suharto's home were turned away by his daughter, Siti Hardiyanti Rukmana, who, like all the Suharto children, is alleged to have made an enormous personal fortune through the corrupt, nepotistic practices of her father's regime.

Mr Darusman refused to divulge any details of the independent medical report. "I can't do that," he said. "It would be violating the limits of the [patient's] confidence."

He also denied suggestions that Mr Suharto's doctors had exaggerated the extent of the former president's illness. "We're not accusing anybody of lying. We're just pushing ahead to the very limits of the possibilities. The report has said that investigations are possible and we'll be going on from that conclusion."

Mr Wahid has said he is keen to pardon Mr Suharto if he is convicted of corruption, as long as he returns all illegally accumulated funds to the government.

webTitle: Drug-resistant TB on the rise in the west

fields.headline: Drug-resistant TB on the rise in the west
fields.trailText: A deadly new form of tuberculosis, resistant to the drugs normally used to treat it, is on the rise in the industrialised world and threatens complacent European countries which thought the TB epidemic would be restricted to the developing world.
fields.body:
A deadly new form of tuberculosis, resistant to the drugs normally used to treat it, is on the rise in the industrialised world and threatens complacent European countries which thought the TB epidemic would be restricted to the developing world.

In Denmark and Germany, resistance to at least one TB drug has increased by 50%, according to a World Health Organisation (WHO) report, published at a ministerial conference in Amsterdam yesterday.

The UK is also not immune; one new case of multi-drug resistant TB (MDR TB) - strains resistant to the two most powerful anti-TB drugs, isoniazid and rifampicin - is being found every week, half of them in London. The cost of curing people with MDR TB is very high - up to £100,000 for each person; the NHS's annual bill has reached £5m.

The WHO conference, which is being attended by ministers from 20 countries, aims to triple access to TB treatment in the developing world, to try to prevent MDR TB from spreading further.

New York and Russia have already suffered epidemics of the drug-resistant strain that cost hundreds of lives and more than $1bn to treat.

"For the first time, we have evidence the drug-resistant TB outbreaks that have shaken New York and Russia are increasing elsewhere," said Gro Harlem Brundtland, the WHO's director general. The WHO has already declared TB a global emergency.

The disease, which affects the poorest and most vulnerable people - 98% of deaths are in the developing world - kills 1.5m a year. A further 400,000 die of combined HIV and TB infection. And it is easily spread, with evidence that people have contracted it from strangers on long haul aircraft.

In affluent European countries such as Germany, Denmark and the UK, the multi-drug resistant strains of the disease are developing in immigrants whose TB has not been properly treated abroad.

"Improved screening of immigrants will not solve this problem," said Arata Kochi, the director of WHO's Stop TB initiative. "The only safeguard for wealthy countries is to help countries with poorly functioning TB control programmes to fix the problem immediately."

webTitle: Antarctic spawns iceberg the size of East Anglia

fields.headline: Antarctic spawns iceberg the size of East Anglia
fields.trailText: One of the biggest icebergs ever recorded, a gigantic slab roughly the size of East Anglia, is about to float loose into the world's oceans, scientists say.
fields.body:
One of the biggest icebergs ever recorded, a gigantic slab roughly the size of East Anglia, is about to float loose into the world's oceans, scientists say.

The iceberg, 183 miles long and 22 miles wide, is breaking away from the Ross ice shelf in Antarctica, the region of the continent closest to New Zealand.

The ice shelf regularly sets frozen chunks adrift, and the appearance of what is effectively a new floating island is not thought to be connected to global warming. But the size of this berg is exceptional.

"This is a very big iceberg, close to a record if not a new record," said Matthew Lazzara, a scientist at the Antarctic Meteorological Research Centre in Wisconsin. "It's not often that you see them of this magnitude."

Dr David Vaughan, a glaciologist at the British Antarctic Survey, said: "It may not be the biggest, but it's certainly a big one. It's not a climate warming thing. This is what ice shelves do."

The shelf splits when the steady build-up of fresh ice from glaciers and snowfalls makes its size unsustainable. Antarctica produces a massive iceberg once every ten years or so, although this may be the biggest since humanity began scientific monitoring of the region.

Big icebergs can eventually drift as far north as Cape Town, but there is no immediate emergency for shipping. Their progress is stately. Assuming the new monster berg, which is about 230m (750ft) thick, manages to clear the sea floor, it will circle Antarctica at a gentle one knot for up to 20 years before drifting north into warmer waters and starting to melt.

"From that moment we start measuring its life span in months rather than years or decades," said Dr Vaughan. "It's anybody's guess where the last bits of it will end up."

He was sceptical about the dangers to shipping the iceberg might pose. "It's hard to hit an iceberg that stands 100ft out of the water, is hundreds of kilometres long and has been mapped ever since it was born," he said.

The real menace to vessels like the Titanic, which sank after hitting an iceberg in 1912, is from waterlogged icebergs known as "growlers", which lurk low in the water.

The new iceberg is not thought likely to be carrying much in the way of wildlife with it, although as it scrapes the seafloor it will churn up clouds of microscopic sea creatures which draw scavenging seabirds like the albatross.

Dr Vaughan declined to be stirred by the sheer scale of the iceberg. "That's kind of Antarctic trainspotting," he said. "It doesn't do any harm, but don't expect me to put a bobble hat on and worry about it."

In 1987, an iceberg with an area of 2,450 square miles broke from the Ross ice shelf. It had a mass of around 1.4 trillion tonnes and could have supplied everyone in the world with 240 tonnes (2.4m litres) of pure drinking water. The largest ever iceberg is thought to be a 1956 behemoth, which measured 207 miles long by 62 miles wide.

fields.headline: Turmoil as Rwandan president quits
fields.trailText: Rwanda was thrown into political turmoil yesterday when President Pasteur Bizimungu, one of the few Hutus in Rwanda's Tutsi-led government, resigned as head of state.
fields.body:
Rwanda was thrown into political turmoil yesterday when President Pasteur Bizimungu, one of the few Hutus in Rwanda's Tutsi-led government, resigned as head of state.

Mr Bizimungu, 49, who became president in the aftermath of the genocide of 1994, when Hutu militias killed as many as 800,000 Tutsis and moderate Hutus, announced his resignation in a letter to the president of the country's supreme court.

"From today, 23 March 2000, I resign from the post of president of the Republic of Rwanda," he stated, citing "personal reasons" for his decision. However, it is believed that his position had become untenable after growing conflict with the ruling Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF), which is predominantly Tutsi.

His decision comes less than a month after the resignation of the former prime minister, Pierre-Celestin Rwigema, also a Hutu, following allegations of corruption.

Mr Bizimungu made no secret of the fact that he disapproved of Mr Rwigema's dismissal, accusing members of the government of disobedience and failing to respect him.

The vice-president, Paul Kagame, who is widely believed to hold the reins of power, said that Rwanda was going through a period of transition and political changes were inevitable. But the resignation of the most senior Hutu in the government is likely to have a destabilising effect on a country still deeply polarised along ethnic lines.

Government officials said yesterday that the speaker of the national assembly, Vincent Biruta, will take over as interim president.

 Congolese rebels and their Rwandan allies said yesterday that they had made fresh gains against President Laurent Kabila's army, closing in on the diamond-rich city of Kananga in southern Congo.

The United Nations warned on Wednesday that the flare-up of fighting in Congo in defiance of a ceasefire will make its planned deployment of 5,500 observers and troops impossible. But a rebel spokesman, Kin-Kiey Mulumba, said his troops were merely regaining positions lost after the signing of the peace accord last August.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Washington swaps Patriots
The US army has replaced hundreds of Patriot missiles in the Middle East and South Korea after discovering a pattern of technical faults in the air defence weapon system, the US defence department said yesterday.
fields.body:
Washington swaps Patriots
The US army has replaced hundreds of Patriot missiles in the Middle East and South Korea after discovering a pattern of technical faults in the air defence weapon system, the US defence department said yesterday.

Rear Admiral Craig Quigley, a Pentagon spokesman, confirmed earlier reports in the Wall Street Journal that the flawed missiles had been swapped with newer ones, adding that the army's technical experts were trying to determine what caused the "significant number" of failures. He would not say how many of the missiles had been replaced.
AP, Washington

Split agreed for Nazi funds
Clearing the last major obstacle to compensating the ageing victims of Nazi-era forced and slave labour, negotiators agreed yesterday on the details of dividing up a DM10bn (£3.1bn) German fund in the hope of starting payments by the end of the year.

All sides agreed at December on the size of the fund, to be contributed equally by German government and industry, but negotiators had been wrangling about how to divide the money among the various groups.
AP, Berlin

Population stalls in Japan
The Japanese government said yesterday that its country's population growth was at its slowest since the end of the second world war, rising just 0.16%.

Japan is worried that its rapidly ageing population and declining birth rate will sap economic growth because, unless the country lures more foreigners, there will be fewer workers to support the growing ranks of the elderly.
AP, Tokyo

Japan is worried that its rapidly ageing population and declining birth rate will sap economic growth because, unless the country lures more foreigners, there will be fewer workers to support the growing ranks of the elderly. fields.headline: Texas man shoots churchgoers
fields.standfirst:
Mothers plan Million Mom March for greater gun control as US counts cost of latest firearms incidents

Gun violence in the US: special report
fields.trailText: A second Texas church in six months has found itself at the centre of a US shooting outrage.
fields.body:
A second Texas church in six months has found itself at the centre of a US shooting outrage.

The latest incident came in the Houston suburb of Pasadena, where a man who was said to be angry about being spurned by a woman walked into a small, crowded church on Wednesday night and shot her and three other people before killing himself.

Last September a man shouting anti-Baptist insults entered a church in Fort Worth before shooting seven worshippers dead.

Larry Ashbrook then sat down in a pew and turned the weapon on himself.

In the latest Houston incident, the gunman, named by local television stations as Oscar Castillo, 32, walked into the Iglesia Cristiana Esposa del Cordero Pentecostal church at around 9pm local time armed with a semi-automatic pistol and shot an 18-year-old woman, Leslie Contreras.

Ms Contreras, who had earlier refused to be his girlfriend, was shot in the neck and then held overnight in hospital, although her injury was not though to be life threatening.

The most seriously injured of the victims were Ms Contreras's mother, Angela, 38, and the church pastor, Carlos Matamores, 49. Both were flown to a local hospital suffering from life-threatening wounds. The fourth victim suffered only a minor injury.

The gunman then left the church and went out to the car park, where he shot himself dead.

Elsewhere, New Yorkers were also shaken by a shooting yesterday in Dix Hills, on Long Island, where John Fenrich, 36, fatally shot himself during a stand-off with police after killing his stepson, dismembering the body and scrawling racist and anti-gay slurs on the remains.

And in Ohio, a primary schoolboy pulled a gun in the classroom yesterday morning, but a teacher at the primary school in Lisbon, about 100 miles south-east of Cleveland, persuaded him to drop the weapon.

No one was hurt and the boy, whose name was not released, was taken into custody.

A seemingly endless succession of shooting incidents such as these during recent months has prompted the formation of a gun-control initiative and movement, organised by American women.

The organisers of the Million Mom March aim to convene the largest crowd in Washington since the protests of the 1960s. The march is scheduled to take place on Mother's Day, May 14, and will be coordinated with supporting rallies in 20 US cities.

Its mandate is to promote "sensible legislation" on an issue that the generally pro-gun US Congress is increasingly at odds with generally pro-reform US public opinion.

"This will be the largest demonstration for gun control in American history," says a spokeswoman.

Hillary Clinton, who is running for election to the US senate from New York state, is among the prominent mothers who have agreed to take part in the march. But no politicians will be allowed to address the rally, unless they have suffered personally from gun violence.

American women have always been much stronger supporters of gun control legislation than American men, opinion polls show.

The demonstration has been timed to coincide with the US election campaign season, during which the Democrats see the gun issue as one of their strongest platforms in their bid to wrest control of the Congress from the pro-gun Republican majority.

The march's organisers say that they have tried to hone their demands in favour of "sensible" rather than "strong" gun controls, in order not to alienate groups such as women hunters, maximising support for the march.

The group's six main demands are: longer cooling-off periods and more background checks before a gun purchaser can take possession of a weapon; licensing of all handgun owners and registration of all handguns; a requirement for safety locks to be fitted to all handguns; a limit on handgun purchases to a maximum of one item a month; greater attention to the enforcement of existing gun control laws; and a campaign to enlist support from shops and businesses, with the threat of boycotts against companies that refuse.
