webTitle: A genuine lode of academic rubbish

fields.headline: A genuine lode of academic rubbish
fields.trailText: If you are going to wallow in rubbish then you may as well do it in the world's biggest dump, so extensive that it can be seen from outer space.
fields.body:
If you are going to wallow in rubbish then you may as well do it in the world's biggest dump, so extensive that it can be seen from outer space.

But this sort of information is kids' stuff to the excavators of knowledge on the post-graduate course Garbage in Gotham: the Anthropology of Trash, described in the New York University syllabus as "this maligned but revealing category of material culture".

Their Mecca is the 3,000-acre Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island and their teacher is Robin Nagle, who declares: "Garbage for me is a cognitive problem.

"I don't understand it. I don't understand litter. I don't understand disposability, how we get to the point where we throw out everything. I thought 'I'll teach this class and I'll get the answers', but we end up with more questions at the end of the semester.

"We're amputating and sending off parts of ourselves. It's logical to ask that if my identity markers can be buried in that huge space, so can I."

Fresh Kills is due to close in two years' time. Meanwhile it has further secrets to disclose. "Last year when we did the tour the circus was in town and an elephant died," says Dr Nagle. "Guess where it ended up."

fields.headline: Uganda inquiry into cult deaths
fields.standfirst: Doubts whether leader died with members come amid claims that authorities ignored warnings that sect was dangerous
fields.trailText: President Yoweri Museveni yesterday announced that the Ugandan government will establish a commission of inquiry to probe the circumstances surrounding the burning to death of at least 400 members of an extremist Christian cult last Friday.
fields.body:
President Yoweri Museveni yesterday announced that the Ugandan government will establish a commission of inquiry to probe the circumstances surrounding the burning to death of at least 400 members of an extremist Christian cult last Friday.

There were reports that security forces had failed to investigate two reports over the past six years from local officials saying that the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God sect, which was based at Kanungu in western Uganda, was a "threat to security".

Mr Museveni promised the inquiry would look into the allegations as the country struggles to make sense of the mass killing, in which at least 78 children were killed. He blamed the rise of such sects on rural poverty and the Aids epidemic.

"People start looking for answers in the realm of metaphysics because there is no answer in real life," he said, saying that the answer was to increase industrialisation.

A week after the fire, little is still known about the tragedy. The confusion is compounded by claims that police have mishandled the investigation - in particular by burying bodies in a mass grave before carrying out adequate forensic tests.

The sect's followers believed that on March 17, the Virgin Mary was coming to take them to heaven. What is not known is whether the ordinary cult members were killed or committed suicide.

It was originally thought that the sect's followers may have doused themselves in petrol to die in a mass burning. But police now believe they may instead have been killed in a fire started by six explosions in the church.

A receipt for two jerry cans of sulphuric acid was discovered in the sect headquarters, and police are investigating whether this could have been used to start the blasts.

Six bodies were also removed on Tuesday from a concrete-covered pit in the office of one of the sect leaders. The bodies had been slashed with machetes, burned with acid and then dumped in the pit. Police suggest that the dead could have been followers who knew about the plans of their leaders and were killed to ensure their silence.

The greatest speculation, has been over the fate of the leaders themselves. One, Dominic Katirababwo, a former Roman Catholic priest, is known to have died in the fire. His tall body, its dog collar fused into his neck, was found at the entrance to the church.

However, the fate of the sect leader, Joseph Kibwetere, and his principal prophetess, Credonia Mwerinde, is still not known. The two were in Kanungu last week, but it is now thought they may have escaped the blaze.

The minister for regional affairs, Amama Mbabzi, said yesterday that he spoke to a surviving 17-year-old sect member who told him that he had seen Ms Mwerinde and Mr Kibwetere in the early hours of Friday, fleeing the church grounds clutching small bags.

Police have also yet to establish exactly what happened to the money raised by sect followers who were instructed to sell off all their property in the days preceding their deaths.

"They sold off their chickens. They sold off sofa sets and sideboards," said John Ntwatawa, who looked after the house in a Kampala where the sect was based. "They left the house completely empty. Then they got in their car and said they were going on a crusade. But they didn't come back."

webTitle: US government to pay $508m for sex discrimination

fields.headline: US government to pay $508m for sex discrimination
fields.trailText: The US federal government agreed this week to pay $508m (£310m) to settle a sex discrimination suit brought by 1,100 women who claimed that they were denied jobs and promotion at the government-run Voice of America radio service.
fields.body:
The US federal government agreed this week to pay $508m (£310m) to settle a sex discrimination suit brought by 1,100 women who claimed that they were denied jobs and promotion at the government-run Voice of America radio service.

If it is accepted by the federal judge overseeing the case, it will be the biggest settlement ever recorded in a federal sex discrimination case. Each of the women will get at least $450,000.

The case was brought 23 years ago by reporters, editors, announcers, producers, technicians and others against Voice of America, which broadcasts news and entertainment programmes to listeners outside the US, and its former parent agency, the US Information Agency.

"We have won a just war in the land of freedom," said Jahanare Hasan, a former broadcaster in Pakistan, who was turned down when she applied for a job with Voice of America's radio service for Bangladesh.

"In the Bangla service, only men were allowed to announce the news," said Susan Brackshaw, a lawyer for the women.

Voice of America, which describes life in the US and promotes the virtues of democracy and equality in dozens of languages to a worldwide audience, broadcast the story of its own shortcomings on Wednesday.

In a straightforward script, its news service acknowledged that the case "disclosed that USIA and VOA regularly manipulated the hiring process to exclude women".

"The plaintiffs alleged that the agencies resorted in some cases to test fraud, altering test scores and destroying personnel and test files," it went on.

Despite the allegations of fraud and document destruction, a spokesman for Voice of America, Joseph O'Connell Jr, said the charges had not been proved and no managers had been disciplined.

The basic award of $508m is the largest settlement of any employment discrimination claim, public or private, in the US. It dwarfs the next largest - $176m awarded in 1996 to 1,400 Texaco employees in a race discrimination suit.

Under the 1964 Civil Rights Act, the government will also pay the women's legal fees - $12m so far.

The government's total bill could reach $550m, excluding its own legal costs, according to Bruce Fredrickson, one of the women's lawyers.
New York Times

fields.headline: No: 1601
fields.standfirst: Kate Simon
fields.trailText: Kate Simon.
fields.body:
Age: 50.

Appearance: Stylish, well-preserved Sloane ranger.

Claim to fame: Estranged wife of fish finger salesman-turned Accessorize and Monsoon tycoon Peter Simon, currently valued at £25m (the finer points of the divorce settlement have yet to be fully resolved).

Is that it? Patience. A certain tabloid has revealed that she is currently dating James Hewitt...

The James Hewitt? Yes, the James Hewitt; the "mad cad"; the barmy bounder; the emperor of the romance rodents.

Righto. So you mean that "love rat" chap who went out with Princess Di? The very same.

What on earth does she see in him, then? Everyone knows the ladies love a scoundrel. Anyway, he's a dashing ex-army type who served as a cavalry officer for 17 years, pausing from his duties only to spend quality time with the late Princess of Wales.

Quality time? He taught her how to ride.

Now. Military man, you say? And what of it?

Army pensions aren't what they were, are they? You could say that his pension is one of the more modest facets of Mr Hewitt.

Just how much could he count on? I believe that Mr Hewitt counts on a monthly pension of some £500.

Not a lot, is it? Doubtless he finds it difficult to make ends meet. It's not easy to get the VAT back on the fast cars, candle-lit dinners, expensive co-authors etc that he rather relies on.

Still, must be nice having a rich girlfriend... Now look here! It's plain to see that they are very much in love - you only have to look at the Sun's beautiful snaps of their recent trip to romantic Zanzibar to see that.

I want more proof. Cynic.

No, really. They must have declared their love. Okay, then, try this you old misery. Simon recently said of her youthful 41-year-old squeeze: "I can't give him up. He's wonderfully charming and I adore his company. He's my toyboy."

Do say: "I'm sure his wild days are behind him."

Don't say: "Doesn't she look like a princess?"

webTitle: Do my husband and I need genetic testing before we have a baby?

fields.headline: Do my husband and I need genetic testing before we have a baby?
fields.trailText: My husband and I married last year and have an excellent relationship. But now that we are considering having a child, I have a serious worry which he won't discuss with me. His sister is moderately retarded and I am concerned that there might be a genetic cause.
fields.body:
My husband and I married last year and have an excellent relationship. But now that we are considering having a child, I have a serious worry which he won't discuss with me. His sister is moderately retarded and I am concerned that there might be a genetic cause. This is a taboo subject in his family; he won't discuss it with me and his parents have simply said that she was deprived of oxygen at birth. This might be the case, but the wall my husband and his family put up against discussion makes me suspect there is more to it. In fairness to me and our children, how can I find out more in case we need genetic testing?

Don't let fear stop you

How fortunate that you have an excellent relationship with your husband. Long may that state of affairs continue. However, the issue of his sister seems to be taboo in your partnership.

You are being extremely sensitive to his feelings. Now apply that same sensitivity to your own - and to any children you may have in the future. We have a son, now 40, who was "deprived of oxygen" at birth, and we went for genetic counselling when our daughter was pregnant. We hadn't realised how anxious she'd been as an adolescent about the possibility of there being something inherently wrong with us and with herself, even though the topic was, in our situation, the subject of easy and frequent discussion.

Here, though, I must admit that the process of genetic investigation we underwent 13 years ago was pretty haphazard. Possibly this process has improved since.

If your fears force you to decide against giving birth, whatever the possible outcome would have been, you could be missing out on a wonderful experience. We wouldn't be without our son.
Margaret Vann
Bristol

Look at your own feelings

While it is important to have an open discussion with your husband about the possibility of a disabled child, you may need first to evaluate your own feelings and attitudes to disability.

There are many possible explanations for your husband's reluctance to talk about his sister, although a secret chromosome disorder is not the most likely. The family may feel negative about the sister, in the form of guilt or "shame" or fear for her. They may react defensively to what they see as your own negative approach. Your questioning may stir up complex feelings or conflicts which have not been addressed.

The fact that you are so worried and your use of the outmoded, unhelpful word "retarded" suggest that you do see learning disability as negative and to be avoided at all costs in a child.

I have a learning-disabled son of four with a chromosome disorder. Unlike many parents we were not devastated but relieved that he was healthy and happy. Certainly, it challenges you to deal with the many obstacles society puts in your child's way. As our son grows up, however, his first impact on people is as a beautiful, charming and charismatic person.

It is highly unlikely that you will have a learning-disabled child and less likely still that they would share any chromosome disorder that your sister-in-law may have. Genetic testing will not offer you any conclusive indications and nor will tests during pregnancy. The main question is whether you as parents would have the readiness and capacity to bring up a disabled child.

This will become clear as you talk with your partner. Talking may be easier if you seem positive and open about his sister and disability. How is your relationship with her? Try to find opportunities to get to know her and other learning-disabled people if you can. This may help discussion and will certainly clarify your own feelings. If both of you are fearful or negative about disability, you may not make great parents to a disabled child and should take the limited precautions available.
Name and address supplied

You need support

The danger of trying to deal with the problem in this way is that you are divorcing it from the emotions involved. If you want a child, could you love it no matter whether it was "normal" or not? Your husband's parents may be refusing to answer your questions for other reasons.

I faced a similar situation - in my family the female side (including myself) tend to inherit sensori-neural deafness. My first child was a boy, and in the four years between the first and second births, people asked me if I was going to have the sex of the baby determined. I did not, and had a daughter. Yes, she has inherited the condition, but she has lived among those who are experienced and can help her cope with it - whilst living her life as she chooses. She and I are very close, and I try to be a good role model to her. She now lives in London and at 25 is building a successful career with a wide circle of friends. Had I followed the advice of my "friends" she would not be here.

So if you can, don't probe any more. Develop a loving family circle and, if you feel you can go ahead, have a child if you know that your husband and his family will support you.

And remember, genes work in two ways - my son is plagued with hayfever and rhinitis, inherited from my husband.
Name and address supplied

Next week:

After several years of "putting up" with my eldest brother's abusive behaviour towards me, verbal I must add, but equally as damaging as physical, I could endure no more - once again, I had asked him not to phone me when he had been drinking - he did and I lost my temper completely. Suffice to say we haven't spoken since and this, I am sad to conclude, is the end of our "friendship".

However, since my mother's death seven years ago I am my father's prime carer. My brother is obviously angry that I choose not to see him any more and, to upset me, is using my relationship with our father as a means of getting back at me.

It puts a strain on both my dad and myself, and is causing deep distress to him. I have no more left in the tank for my brother, so please no advice on forgiveness - I've done that too many times! Any suggestions?

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 0171 239 9935, email private.lives@theguardian.com (please do not send attachments).

If your fears force you to decide against giving birth, whatever the possible outcome would have been, you could be missing out on a wonderful experience. We wouldn't be without our son. There are many possible explanations for your husband's reluctance to talk about his sister, although a secret chromosome disorder is not the most likely. The family may feel negative about the sister, in the form of guilt or "shame" or fear for her. They may react defensively to what they see as your own negative approach. Your questioning may stir up complex feelings or conflicts which have not been addressed. The fact that you are so worried and your use of the outmoded, unhelpful word "retarded" suggest that you do see learning disability as negative and to be avoided at all costs in a child. I have a learning-disabled son of four with a chromosome disorder. Unlike many parents we were not devastated but relieved that he was healthy and happy. Certainly, it challenges you to deal with the many obstacles society puts in your child's way. As our son grows up, however, his first impact on people is as a beautiful, charming and charismatic person. It is highly unlikely that you will have a learning-disabled child and less likely still that they would share any chromosome disorder that your sister-in-law may have. Genetic testing will not offer you any conclusive indications and nor will tests during pregnancy. The main question is whether you as parents would have the readiness and capacity to bring up a disabled child. This will become clear as you talk with your partner. Talking may be easier if you seem positive and open about his sister and disability. How is your relationship with her? Try to find opportunities to get to know her and other learning-disabled people if you can. This may help discussion and will certainly clarify your own feelings. If both of you are fearful or negative about disability, you may not make great parents to a disabled child and should take the limited precautions available. Name and address supplied You need support The danger of trying to deal with the problem in this way is that you are divorcing it from the emotions involved. If you want a child, could you love it no matter whether it was "normal" or not? Your husband's parents may be refusing to answer your questions for other reasons. I faced a similar situation - in my family the female side (including myself) tend to inherit sensori-neural deafness. My first child was a boy, and in the four years between the first and second births, people asked me if I was going to have the sex of the baby determined. I did not, and had a daughter. Yes, she has inherited the condition, but she has lived among those who are experienced and can help her cope with it - whilst living her life as she chooses. She and I are very close, and I try to be a good role model to her. She now lives in London and at 25 is building a successful career with a wide circle of friends. Had I followed the advice of my "friends" she would not be here. So if you can, don't probe any more. Develop a loving family circle and, if you feel you can go ahead, have a child if you know that your husband and his family will support you. And remember, genes work in two ways - my son is plagued with hayfever and rhinitis, inherited from my husband. Name and address supplied Next week: After several years of "putting up" with my eldest brother's abusive behaviour towards me, verbal I must add, but equally as damaging as physical, I could endure no more - once again, I had asked him not to phone me when he had been drinking - he did and I lost my temper completely. Suffice to say we haven't spoken since and this, I am sad to conclude, is the end of our "friendship". However, since my mother's death seven years ago I am my father's prime carer. My brother is obviously angry that I choose not to see him any more and, to upset me, is using my relationship with our father as a means of getting back at me. It puts a strain on both my dad and myself, and is causing deep distress to him. I have no more left in the tank for my brother, so please no advice on forgiveness - I've done that too many times! Any suggestions?  Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. fields.headline: Way of the samurai indies
fields.standfirst: LA inconsequential
fields.trailText: Way of the samurai indies
fields.body:
Two daddies of the independent film movement had new movies out this week. Steven Soderbergh, whose sex, lies, and videotape kick-started the indie boom of the 90s, has come so far since then that his new movie, the legal thriller Erin Brockovich, not only stars Julia Roberts, Ms Box-Office Catnip herself, it also leapt straight to the top of the box office charts without breaking sweat.

Meanwhile Jim Jarmusch, the New York-based film-maker who has stayed almost fanatically true to his indie/No Wave roots since his 1984 debut Stranger Than Paradise, released his latest work, a rap-samurai-mobster movie called Ghost Dog: Way of the Samurai. It didn't even make the chart.

On paper at least, Soderbergh - a director-for-hire in this instance - has the star, the budget, the studio and the godawful modern genre (the courtroom drama), while Jarmusch is defiantly knocking out another low-budget slice of his own parallel universe of comic books, art movies and trash culture. But there are similarities here all the same.

Soderbergh and Jarmusch may now be working in different idioms - the studio picture, the personal project - but the values that underpin independent cinema (more an abstract concept than a movement, I've always thought) are detectable in both pictures.

That might seem a risible thing to say about the new Julia Roberts film, but to see how good Erin Brockovich is you only have to compare it with outwardly similar legal-eagle movies like A Civil Action (worthy and tedious) and The Rainmaker (worthless and tedious), in which underdog lawyers bring powerful corporations to their well-tailored knees.

Roberts has a good feel for the minefield between comedy and tragedy; it's just that she's demonstrated it in so many excremental movies (Conspiracy Theory and Stepmom are just the first two that leap into my recoiling cranium) that you feel you never want to endure it again.

This time however her character is so well written and acted that mere Julia-phobia is not a workable excuse for skipping the movie. Soderbergh hasn't pulled any of the tricks with tenses, motivation and memory that preoccupied him in Out of Sight or its appendix project The Limey. Instead he's gone for a no-frills look that suits the modest origins and economic station of his heroine, and his adjustments have more to do with narrative compression and speed than with formal experiment, of which there's almost none.

One can detect his current interest in middleground 70s filmmakers like Don Siegel, Richard Fleischer and Martin Ritt (whose Norma Rae is an obvious point of reference). If there is a homage of any kind in Erin Brockovich, it is to their exciting, stripped-down, clear-eyed narratives.

I can't be sure, but I don't think Soderbergh uses any technical innovation in Brockovich that wasn't available to directors back in 1976. That's an admirably independent-minded way of just saying "No" and we should acclaim him for it. Any neophyte fresh out of the Sundance directors' workshop would be itching to get their hands on helicopters and steadicams, but Soderbergh tackles his material head-on - no fancy stuff.

And just to prove his instincts for doing it fast and cheap haven't deserted him, Soderbergh brought the film in four days before schedule and $1m under budget, which are indie virtues the majors really do respect.

If Jarmusch has ever lusted after a Brockovich-sized budget, then he's kept pretty quiet about it. I think the origins of his debut, Stranger Then Paradise, have more watertight indie credentials than any film I can think of. It started with a Raul Ruiz movie being filmed on the coast of Portugal in 1980. When the money fell through, first Jon Jost and then Wim Wenders suggested finding backing for an entirely new movie and just transplanting the original cast and crew.

Wenders prevailed and made The State of Things, his masterpiece about (well, fancy that) a cast and crew stranded on a bankrupt movie set in Portugal. It was loosely based on his horrible experiences making Hammett for Francis Coppola's doomed Zoetrope outfit. At one point the film-within-the-film's director asks the cameraman (Sam Fuller) if they have any "short ends" - the unexposed lengths of film at the end of a magazine. "We've been shooting on the short ends all week," says Fuller. (The State of Things, said the writer Jonathan Rosenbaum, "contains an in-built prediction of its own fate at the box-office.") But Stranger Than Paradise was filmed on the short ends from The State of Things. That's the real Poverty Row.

I confess I lost interest in Jarmusch after Down by Law, until he made a mighty comeback a couple of years ago with Dead Man. I never imagined a heliophobic Manhattan pale face like Jarmusch could adapt himself to the way-out west, but that misses the point: Jarmusch adapted it to himself, and rustled up the best western of the past 20 years, a violent, mystical, deadpan comedy, icily conveyed by Robby Muller's cinematography, which resembled silvery, living daguerreotypes.

Muller and Jarmusch are together again for Ghost Dog: Way of the Samurai, starring Forest Whitaker as a black urban samurai who works for the Italian mob. The fact that this urban crime movie arrives on the heels of Dead Man suggests Jarmusch may be doing his own version of Robert Altman's genre-tweaking trilogy of the 70s, McCabe and Mrs Miller, The Long Goodbye and Thieves Like Us.

If he made a western that was spacious enough to include a transvestite Iggy Pop and Lance Henriksen as a cannibal bounty hunter, then surely he can remake Jean-Pierre Melville's Le Samourai with a hip-hop found-sound soundtrack by the RZA?

Oh, yes he can. The result is disarmingly sweet-natured, though tempered with moments of extreme (and often extremely funny) violence. Jarmusch has always liked to hang out and just look around, and Ghost Dog is rich in the sort of triple-layered, slow-burning jokes he loves. Typical of these is Whitaker - who once played Charlie Parker - shopping for pigeon feed at a store named "Birdland", or a middle-aged mobster proclaiming his devotion to Flavor Flav's rhymes.

If Stranger Than Paradise was, in Jarmusch's words, "a neo-realistic black comedy in the style of an imaginary east European director obsessed with Ozu and The Honeymooners", then Ghost Dog is something equally weird and wonderful. How far he and Soderbergh have travelled - all the way round the block, without sacrificing a fragment of their essential selves.

fields.headline: David Hayman
fields.trailText: David Hayman
fields.body:
What was the first film you saw?

Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs at the Vogue Cinema, Glasgow. It changed my life forever. Ia fell in love with Snow White and married a woman who looks just like her.

What's your favourite film and why?

A recent favourite is Arlington Road. It's absolutely stunning, gripping and beautifully stylish. Jeff Bridges was brilliant and I'm surprised he wasn't nominated for an Academy Award.

When did you last walk out of a cinema?

I walk out of theatre but not the cinema. There's always something to look at in a film.

What was the most erotic moment in a film?

Don't Look Now, the best ever acted and because it was non-exploitative. A celebration of love-making.

What's the most annoying habit in a cinema?

The sound of sweetie wrappers.

When was the last time you snogged in a cinema?

Toy Story, with my wife. Unfortunately it doesn't happen often, as usually the kids are with us.

When was the last time you hid under your seat in a cinema?

I never do. I long to be scared and shit my pants.

When did you last cry in the cinema?

My kids laugh at this one: the joyous ending of Sister Act. Also Land and Freedom, which would bring tears to a glass eye.

What's your favourite piece of dialogue?

Bette Davis in Now, Voyager. "Oh Jerry, don't let's ask for the moon. We have the stars."

Which actor would you most like to be?

Who needs to be Robert De Niro when you could be David Attenborough? When he departs this life he'll leave an extraordinary legacy.

Which actress?

Gena Rowlands: she's awesome. But there are many actresses, such as Kathy Bates, whose performances tear you apart emotionally and strip away the veil. They also have their heads firmly on their shoulders.

Which film character?

Jimmy "Popeye" Doyle in The French Connection. He's explosive, anarchic and always in pursuit of the truth - similar to my character, Detective Sergeant Michael Walker in Trial and Retribution.

How different is Ordinary Decent Criminal from The General, both of which are based on the life of Martin Cahill?

It's a more lighthearted and tongue-in-cheek version, loosely based on some stories in his life. It's not a biopic but a romp aimed at a Hollywood audience.

Which do you enjoy most, acting or directing?

I joke that the acting is a day job. As a director you are responsible for so much more. It's the whole picture, the greater level of achievement, and of course being able to choose who you work with.

 David Hayman is in Ordinary Decent Criminal, on general release. Interview by Samantha Gillings.

fields.headline: Jacob's ladder
fields.standfirst: For more than two decades Gilles Jacob has been the main man at Cannes. He talks to Patrick Frater
fields.trailText: For more than two decades Gilles Jacob has been the main man at Cannes. He talks to Patrick Frater
fields.body:
If the Oscars are a grotesque display of Hollywood self-congratulation, then trying to pick winners is a game for suckers - spectators of a distant power game that is ruled by money. For those filmgoers less concerned with star power or box office grosses, the true sport at this time of year is predicting which movies will make the trip to Cannes.

For the real enthusiasts the game is played all year round, making use of advanced production lists and details of stars' schedules. The keenest players tend to be programmers of other festivals and film sales agents trying to come up with a slate of hot titles that will benefit from Cannes' unrivalled media spotlight.

For others the game takes an earnest turn in January after the year's first crop of US independents get an outing at Sundance. February's second round uses the Berlin festival selection to test early theories about what might have been held back for a Croisette outing in May. And the American Film Market at the end of the month gives buyers representing distribution companies from around the world the chance to see some early footage of films they have been tracking for the past year.

But what makes the game so fascinating and infuriating is that to a large extent it is an exercise in second-guessing the tastes and whims of one man, Gilles Jacob. Of course the festival has special sections for more specialist pictures, but for many directors and their films, a screening in competition is a career-making or breaking accolade. And that means striking a chord with Jacob.

Having held the job of délégué général for some 23 years, Jacob's leaning towards a certain kind of art-house film is now clearly established. In a rare interview, the usually sphinx-like Jacob warned that this kind of cinema is an endangered species. "Cinema is definitely alive as an artform capable in one year of assembling films as inventive and original as those of Almodovar, Tim Burton, Kitano, David Lynch, Wong Kar Wai, Kiarostami, Jarmusch, Spike Jonze and Finkiel, without forgetting the still on-form Malick and Forman. That is the kind of talent, making the kind of top cinema that gives me a genuine thrill. But from now on it is also necessary to ask about the survival of this art.

"We are witnessing both a revolution and an earthquake. The revolution is digital and its associated new technologies. Everything moves so quickly today, far quicker than with the arrival of the talkies or television. The earthquake is the merger of AOL and Time Warner, which gives the advantage to AOL. Who had even heard of AOL five years ago?"

As a film fanatic, Jacob subscribes to the maxim that "content is king." But sometimes he sounds as if he is clinging to this more as a hope than a firm belief. "Until now we were always able to analyse things along two lines; hardware and software, container and the content; pipelines and programming. Obviously what counts is the content; emotion will always win against technique for its own sake. But the challenge that has existed ever since television began majority financing cinema is now increasing. It is not just today that broadcasters are the decision-makers - choosing the subject, the technicians, the actors, what can or cannot be said. Rather, [what is new is that] whole branches of the industry (distribution, laboratories, etc) are now being forced to adapt or disappear."

While digital film-making got its first true platform at Cannes with the screenings of Lars Von Trier's The Idiots and Thomas Vinterberg's Festen, Jacob is still suspicious of the impact of hand-held video cameras on film-makers. "There is a risk that in the medium term we will be inundated with films shot digitally by amateurs who take themselves to be the new Scorsese, or Ken Loach or Stephen Frears. Unfortunately, a Loach or a Frears only comes along once every 30 years."

But for all his mixed feelings, Jacob looks poised this year to put on a show that will be one of his best ever. While the Cannes selection has yet to be announced - and will not be for another month - the star-gazers predict a festival line-up that includes films by art-house champions Loach, Von Trier, the Coen brothers, John Waters, Nagisa Oshima, and Terence Davies. Officially, Jacob makes a move upstairs, taking over as festival president in June. But this inquisitive, loyal, and some would say ruthless, man is determined not to let go of the position that makes his the mind every film-maker wants to get inside.

y Cooder went to Cuba for a record project, to see if some of the musicians he had heard were still around. Director Wim Wenders - with whom Cooder has often collaborated, notably on Paris Texas - went along to film them. It should have been a strictly minority-interest little film for musical archivists. But the music and its performers are so thoroughly enjoyable to watch as well as listen to that the pair ended up with a million-selling album and a beguiling film. It's a feelgood story too, as the musicians we first meet introducing themselves in their home streets later become tourists themselves in New York prior to an appearance at Carnegie Hall.

The music is subtle, powerful and very natural. It slides and swoons with a weird mixture of African, Spanish and New Orleans rhythms, a result partly, you assume, of the US blockade that has cut Cuba off from the US influence that swamps most of the world. It feels as though it has evolved at its own pace and is played by people who are clearly enjoying themselves and have been playing for longer than most of us even live.

In the middle of a lively interview, and in mid-cigar, singer Compay Segundo mentions that he's been smoking for "about 85 years". Others admit to being 77 or 80. But there's nothing elderly about the music. "Who are these kids you found in Havana?" Cooder was asked by someone who had heard the tapes, and mysteriously the players seem to look 20 years younger than they are.

This is a band you'd like to have at your local on a Saturday night. The gravel-voiced Cooder mostly keeps a back seat as the musicians, many of whom seem to have been forgotten for years in Cuba too, do their thing and radically change their lives as a result. For people of a certain age, it's reminiscent of the 60s blues tours that toured Europe while America ignored them. Intoxicating.

The General's Daughter
Rental
Paramount Cert 18
**

The General's Daughter assembles a cast you can count on to put flesh on scriptural bones. John Travolta is a military criminal investigator, Madeleine Stowe his co-investigator and ex-girlfriend, James Woods is on the post and James Cromwell is the titular general. The set-up closely resembles A Few Good Men, but I prefer Travolta and Stowe to Cruise and Moore any day.

All seems set for a classy whodunnit with some quirky human interest (Travolta's early discussion about bath products with the eponymous Leslie Stefanson is of almost Twin Peaks weirdness). But the plot grows increasingly murky and improbable and as director Simon West piles on the flashbacks, the film forgets all that and becomes straightforward in dialogue terms but muddled, grotesque and psychologically preposterous in terms of its plot. It seems grossly exploitative of Stefanson too, whose presence is missed once her part is restricted to flashbacks.

The Astronaut's Wife
Rental
Entertainment in Video Cert 18
**

It's serious deja vu for Charlize Theron. She's happily married until she has to accompany her husband to New York and then there's a really horrible pregnancy. She did all this in The Devil's Advocate and if that in turn pinched a little from Rosemary's Baby, this goes the whole hog down to Theron's early Mia Farrow hairstyle.

Johnny Depp is the husband just back from a space trip where he and a fellow astronaut were briefly out of contact with earth. Did anyone ever come back normal from that in a film? Of course not, and things proceed much as you expect, with dire warnings from an ex-Nasa worker. Almost every shot looks like a commercial as writer/ director Rand Ravich bathes everything in a the glow of a familiar filmic dreamworld and throws in something like Gregorian chanting at tense moments. It's awfully hard to get involved.

webTitle: Short pleads for debt relief speed

fields.headline: Short pleads for debt relief speed
fields.standfirst:
Debt relief: special report
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: Clare Short, the international development secretary, is seeking an urgent meeting with the chancellor Gordon Brown to discuss the faltering pace of international efforts to reduce the debt of the world's poorest countries.
fields.body:
Clare Short, the international development secretary, is seeking an urgent meeting with the chancellor Gordon Brown to discuss the faltering pace of international efforts to reduce the debt of the world's poorest countries.

Leaders from the world's seven biggest economies promised last autumn that they would deliver debt relief to 11 countries by Easter and to 25 in total by the end of the year. But yesterday Whitehall sources admitted the initiative, spearheaded by Mr Brown, was in danger of running into the sand.

Ms Short last night called on debt campaigners to put pressure on other G7 nations into joining Britain's call for faster debt relief.

Only six countries are expected to have their loan burden reduced by the Easter deadline which coincides with the spring meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. The target of 25 by the end of the year is starting to look unattainable.

Privately, Whitehall insiders are alarmed at how progress has stalled since last Christmas. "We need to inject more urgency into the process," one said.

Britain blames delays at the bank and the IMF but both bodies insist slow progress is necessary to ensure countries spend debt relief to reduce poverty. Ms Short says there is unnecessary paperwork.

webTitle: Judgment day fillip for Microsoft shares

fields.headline: Judgment day fillip for Microsoft shares
fields.trailText: Shares in Microsoft opened up 6% higher yesterday amid signs that settlement talks between the software group and the American government over their anti-monopoly battle were intensifying.
fields.body:
Shares in Microsoft opened up 6% higher yesterday amid signs that settlement talks between the software group and the American government over their anti-monopoly battle were intensifying.

Any agreement would be likely to be reached before the end of April, when Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson is expected to decide whether Microsoft broke the law by abusing its hold over the world's computer operating systems.

Shares in the world's most highly valued software company rose more than $6 to $109 yesterday morning after reports that it had reached common ground in separate mediation talks with the American government.

Newspapers yesterday indicated that the government may now be content to impose tough restrictions on Microsoft's behaviour rather than insisting on a full scale break-up of the company. The reports came a day after Joel Klein, the assistant attorney general who brought the case against Microsoft, said that any remedy should be "commensurate" with the company's "serious pattern of anti-competitive conduct".

His comments were largely taken as an indication that the government was continuing to press for a break-up.

Gina Talamona, a spokeswoman for the justice department, refused to comment on the talks. "Whoever is making these kinds of statements is engaging in a public relations exercise that should not be taken seriously," she added.

Lawyers for both sides indicated that the talks could in fact break down at any time, but Judge Jackson is understood to have called the parties together earlier this week to urge them to conclude the talks.

He is believed to be unlikely to deliver his verdict on the case until after the settlement talks are completed, with or without agreement.

webTitle: Prepare to fight for your jobs, Dagenham workers told

fields.headline: Prepare to fight for your jobs, Dagenham workers told
fields.trailText: The battle to save British car-workers' jobs spread to Dagenham yesterday when union officials urged members to resist any closure of Ford's biggest UK plant.
fields.body:
The battle to save British car-workers' jobs spread to Dagenham yesterday when union officials urged members to resist any closure of Ford's biggest UK plant.

Tony Woodley of the TGWU and Duncan Simpson of the AEEU told a series of mass meetings, due to be extended to today, that the US car company could close Dagenham's body shop and assembly line with the loss of up to 4,000 jobs.

The meetings were originally called in mid-February when Ford announced plans for 1,350 job losses at Dagenham by the summer. Since then a spate of volunteers has come forward, almost matching the redundancies sought by the company.

But, after declaring just $28m of profits on $30bn of sales in its European business, Ford began a full-scale review of its operations in the UK, Germany, Spain and Belgium to take out excess capacity of around 350,000 cars.

The review is due to be completed in May, raising fears that assembly work at Dagenham, already being run down to a single shift, could close completely, with the new Fiesta built solely in Cologne.

Ford UK said the review conducted by Nick Scheele, its European head, covered the whole of the company's European operations and not just Dagenham.

Mr Scheele said last month the aim was to build the new Fiesta first in Cologne and then at the Essex plant from early 2002.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
VW denies BMW rumours
Volkswagen, Europe's biggest car maker, insisted yesterday that it was not interested in acquiring rival German group BMW and that it had no plans to acquire permanent rights to Rolls-Royce. However, the group did not rule out a bid for Scania following the EC's decision to block the bid from fellow Swedish truck maker Volvo. Yesterday VW revealed that profits last year fell by 26% to DM1.651bn (£518m), but predicted that results for the current year would be "in the double-digit per cent range".

VW denies BMW rumours
Volkswagen, Europe's biggest car maker, insisted yesterday that it was not interested in acquiring rival German group BMW and that it had no plans to acquire permanent rights to Rolls-Royce. However, the group did not rule out a bid for Scania following the EC's decision to block the bid from fellow Swedish truck maker Volvo. Yesterday VW revealed that profits last year fell by 26% to DM1.651bn (£518m), but predicted that results for the current year would be "in the double-digit per cent range".

Vodafone set to clear EU hurdle
Vodafone yesterday appeared optimistic that it will win EU clearance for its takeover of German mobile phones group Mannesmann by the middle of next month. Brussels officials said the UK group had submitted "fresh remedies" to win approval, delaying the deadline for a decision of the one-month investigation - known as phase one - until April 11 or 12. Vodafone sources indicated that the group had given new assurances that its takeover of Mannesmann would not produce an over-dominant force in European telephony or unfairly damage the interests of big players such as Deutsche Telekom. They believe these are enough to avoid the inquiry by the EU's competition authorities entering a second phase - which would take up to six months.

Abbey tuned in to Telewest
Abbey National's partnership with cable company Telewest bears fruit on Monday when its television banking service goes live. Abbey already has TV banking on Open and will launch a service on NTL digital cable TV this year.

NHS drugs supply study
The government and the pharmaceutical industry yesterday agreed to a joint study of competition in the supply of drugs to the health service - a move that drug firms hope will lead to less regulation. The Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry said the study would look at sales of branded drugs to the NHS, estimated to be worth about £6bn a year. The association says controls should be relaxed, given increased competition.

BP takes China stake
BP Amoco yesterday announced a gas marketing joint venture with China's largest oil and gas company, PetroChina. BP will also take a 20% stake in shares being offered as part of PetroChina's flotation, up to $1bn.

webTitle: Marketing of diet yoghurt turns sour

fields.headline: Marketing of diet yoghurt turns sour
fields.trailText: Scotia Holdings' innovative weight-loss yoghurt is set to disappear from supermarket shelves because the drug development group has parted company with its European distributor.
fields.body:
Scotia Holdings' innovative weight-loss yoghurt is set to disappear from supermarket shelves because the drug development group has parted company with its European distributor.

The news emerged as Scotia disclosed a 76% jump in its full-year losses to £29.9m.

The yoghurt contains Olibra, a lipid-based substance which makes people feel exceptionally full after eating. Scotia believes the ingredient has huge potential in a wide variety of foods.

However, the Swedish dairy firm Skanemejerier this week wrote to Scotia saying it wanted to end an agreement allowing it to market the product in Britain and Scandinavia - the only areas where it has so far been launched.

Scotia's chief executive, Robert Dow, said he was glad the relationship was over.

"They just don't have the muscle and money to play in the big game." Skanamejerier lacked the "skill and experience" to achieve national distribution.

Mr Dow added that Scotia wanted to rebrand the ingredient, following tie-ups in the US with the food groups General Mills and Bestfoods.

Sources close to the Swedish company contradicted Mr Dow's account, saying the agreement had collapsed because of pricing issues. One insider said: "If it wasn't for this little Swedish dairy, Scotia wouldn't have a product to sell to the big American giants."

Scotia's shares fell 10p to 181p, despite a pledge that research and development spending would decline from £26m to around £22m this year. Costs have fallen following the completion of clinical trials of Foscan, Scotia's drug for head and neck cancer which is awaiting regulatory approval.

Scotia said it was making "good progress" in talks with potential partners for Foscan.

webTitle: IMF bruised by succession battle as Kohler steps up

fields.headline: IMF bruised by succession battle as Kohler steps up
fields.trailText: Germany's Horst Köhler was yesterday confirmed as the International Monetary Fund's new managing director, bringing to an end a bitter transatlantic dispute over who should head the global lender.
fields.body:
Germany's Horst Köhler was yesterday confirmed as the International Monetary Fund's new managing director, bringing to an end a bitter transatlantic dispute over who should head the global lender.

The fund's 24 directors unanimously agreed that he should succeed France's Michel Camdessus, who re signed in February after 13 years as head of the 182-nation organisation.

Mr Köhler, 57, was nominated by German chancellor Gerhard Schröder after his first candidate for the post, Caio Koch-Weser, was rejected by the United States as too lightweight.

Despite indications that Washington and some European governments would have preferred Giuliano Amato, the former Italian prime minister, to be the IMF's new boss, President Clinton decided not to risk a diplomatic row by vetoing a second German candidate.

But the episode has called into question both the diplomatic skills of chancellor Schröder and the process of selecting the IMF managing director. By unwritten rule, the Washington-based IMF job has always been held by a European while an American has led the World Bank. But a number of developing countries and Japan, the second largest contributor to the IMF after the US, have indicated they want a more open nominating process.

At a press conference in Washington last week, Mr Köhler said: "I agree that this process was really not the best I could imagine and I have no hesitation to say this process... should be reviewed and improved."

Mr Köhler is currently head of the London-based European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. He is credited with helping unify East and West Germany and with playing a key role in the birth of the euro.

Observers say that as a back up choice for leader he faces a tough time establishing his credibility with the fund's staff, its membership and a hostile US congress.

A report commissioned by congress wants a clearer delineation of the IMF and World Bank's roles, ensuring that lending is effective. It also calls for greater accountability and transparency, strong and well-targeted support for development in the world's poorest countries and a need for substantial debt relief for the most-heavily indebted.

webTitle: Glaxo chairman suffers a pay cut

fields.headline: Glaxo chairman suffers a pay cut
fields.trailText: Glaxo Wellcome directors had to tighten their belts last year, suffering substantial pay cuts as the drugs group failed to meet its earnings targets.
fields.body:
Glaxo Wellcome directors had to tighten their belts last year, suffering substantial pay cuts as the drugs group failed to meet its earnings targets.

Chairman Sir Richard Sykes saw his take-home pay slump 37% to £1.18m, including a performance bonus of £198,000 - compared with more than £900,000 in 1998.

Sir Richard, 57, was named Britain's business leader of the year last May but two months later Glaxo warned that it would fail to keep its promise of delivering double-digit earnings growth.

The company was hit by disappointing sales in the US, particularly of smoking cessation drug Zyban and migraine treatment Imitrex. These were intended to plug the gap left by the expiry of Glaxo's patent on ulcer treatment Zantac.

Chief executive Robert Ingram, who has responsibility for US operations, saw his pay fall by a quarter to £861,000, while finance director John Coombe's remuneration fell 24% to £861,000.

A company spokesman said bonuses were linked to "corporate and personal objectives".

The group's merger with SmithKline Beecham will mean its six executive directors can bank shares worth £8m as an annual incentive plan and an options scheme are prematurely wound up.

However, they will still be on the poorer side of the boardroom table - their gains pale into insignificance compared to the £113m windfall shared by five directors of SmithKline, which has a much more generous pay policy.

Sir Richard will be able to sell shares worth £1.9m as the schemes mature. He has also accumulated equity worth £3.2m under a long-term incentive plan which will be continued after the deal.

fields.trailText: The government, struggling to restore its industrial credibility after the Rover sale, came under pressure yesterday to stump up £73m to save jobs in another old economy sector - coal mining.
fields.body:
The government, struggling to restore its industrial credibility after the Rover sale, came under pressure yesterday to stump up £73m to save jobs in another old economy sector - coal mining.

RJB Mining, which controls about 60% of Britain's coal mining, is seeking a state subsidy so it can offer coal at competitive prices to the new American owners of Drax power station in north Yorkshire.

RJB's Selby complex has contracts to supply Drax until 2002, and it is thought up to 2,500 jobs could be lost if it fails to secure new contracts there.

AES, which bought Drax from National Power in January for £1.9bn, has said it would like to buy coal from Selby - but only if the price is competitive.

Industry sources said the strength of sterling had made British coal less competitive with imported supplies and subsidies would be needed to close the gap.

RJB has said it needs subsidies to keep the industry in its present shape. Competition from abroad and from other fuels has eaten deeply into its profits.

Earlier this month it said it was delaying the announcement of its full year results by a month "in the light of uncertainty within the coal industry as to whether the government will support the payment of operating aid enjoyed by the other European coal-producing states".

The warning led to a further decline in the mining group's share price. RJB's stock market value has fallen from £942m three years ago to just £39.5m.

A Department of Trade and Industry official said it was aware of the talks between RJB and AES. "We are considering some state subsidies. European Coal and Steel Community rules strictly govern the aid we could give, and we are having to go through it with a fine tooth-comb," he said.

webTitle: Fleming in £3bn takeover talks with Chase

fields.headline: Fleming in £3bn takeover talks with Chase
fields.standfirst: Breakaway threat in US as dynasty is divided
fields.trailText: Chase Manhattan, the US bank, is expected to lose Robert Fleming's "jewel in the crown" if it goes ahead with a takeover bid for the 110-year-old institution which is one of Britain's few surviving independent investment banks.
fields.byline: Lisa Buckingham  and Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
Chase Manhattan, the US bank, is expected to lose Robert Fleming's "jewel in the crown" if it goes ahead with a takeover bid for the 110-year-old institution which is one of Britain's few surviving independent investment banks.

It is understood that Rowe-Price Fleming, the joint venture asset management business in America, which has about $35bn of funds under management, will try to split away from its parent organisation if the Chase takeover succeeds.

Robert Fleming - which has been the target of numerous takeover approaches in recent years - confirmed last night that it has given up its struggle for independence and is holding takeover talks with Chase Manhattan.

Although no price has been put on the potential deal, Fleming has been valued at up to £3bn.

Managers of Rowe-Price Fleming have first refusal over their business in the US, which accounts for nearly a third of the group's entire funds under management and is believed to be one of the strongest and most profitable parts of the Fleming empire.

Flemings - members of whose founding family include the famed creator of James Bond, Ian Fleming - has 7,500 staff in 40 countries, with net assets of £1bn and profits in the six months to last September of £110m.

The decision to embrace takeover talks represents a dramatic about turn by the banking group - which is 17% owned by the Jardine Matheson trading empire. It immediately prompted speculation of a split among members of the founding family which still speaks for 30% of the shares. People who know the group well say the younger generation of Flemings is less loyal to the bank as an independent entity and see its only future as part of a global bank.

Banking experts in New York suggested that Chase Manhattan might not go unchallenged. Several European banks were understood to be weighing up approaches, although investment bankers said potential bidders such as Commerzbank and West Deutsche Landesbanken would need to act quickly to prevent a takeoever by Chase, which could be announced as soon as the weekend.

A counter offer is likely be difficult to pull off, however, as it would put the Europeans up against the financial muscle of America's second largest banking group. Chase is unlikely to encounter much resistance to a deal from Fleming's shareholders as long as the price is benchmarked at about £3bn.

An executive from Jardine Matheson said: "If shareholders were to be offered about 50% above the market rate they might have some (positive) feelings about that."

Another shareholder with a significant stake said: "It was only a matter of time before someone made a bid for it. Its independence has been in serious doubt for at least 12 months now. A premium of 50% would be very difficult to reject in those circumstances."

The Fleming family is understood to have been persuaded to reconsider its stake in the bank after the Schroders decided to sell out to Citigroup for £1.35bn earlier this year.

Tracking a family fortune

Robert Fleming might well have a head office address in the City of London's Copthall Avenue, but there has never been any doubt that the group's heart is north of the border.

The company still employs a dozen descendants of the founder, Robert Fleming, a doughty Scotsman who founded the firm in 1873 when he began investing in North and South American railways and cattle ranches. A family trust still owns about 30% of the shares.

Its main non-family backers are Scottish institutions such as Baillie Gifford and Stewart Ivory, while it owns the most extensive private collection of Scottish art.

Just over a year ago, the bank cemented its linked with fellow Scots clan, the Keswicks, in a transaction that gave the Keswicks a 17% stake in Flemings and rekindled speculation that the group was being groomed for sale. Under the terms of that deal, a 28-year-old joint venture - Jardine Flemings - became wholly owned by the bank. In return for its stake in the venture, the Hong Kong trading dynasty increased its direct stake in Robert Fleming from 5% to 17%.

The Keswicks can trace the foundations of their sprawling Jardine Matheson empire to the days of 19th century Scottish adventurers.

Employees in the company own 11% of the equity and many are believed to be keen to sell. Another 5% is believed to be held by Foreign & Colonial. In a world of financial gargantuans, Flemings is something rare - small and independent.

webTitle: Assembly turns down BAe Airbus grant

fields.headline: Assembly turns down BAe Airbus grant
fields.trailText: BAe Systems has warned that its Broughton factory in Flintshire might not reap the full benefit of expected work on the A3XX Airbus project after the refusal of £25m in grant aid by the Welsh assembly.
fields.body:
BAe Systems has warned that its Broughton factory in Flintshire might not reap the full benefit of expected work on the A3XX Airbus project after the refusal of £25m in grant aid by the Welsh assembly.

The company, which has already been promised £530m in start-up investment from the government towards the £2bn UK element of the project, had been expected to create 1,400 new jobs at the north Wales site where it wants to build a £100m-plus factory alongside existing facilities for the assembly of the new-generation Airbus's wings.

But workers have now been told that BAe's application for regional selective assistance towards construction of the plant has been turned down by national assembly first secretary Rhodri Morgan.

An internal memo told staff that the decision would force the company "to look again" at the extent of work that would be carried out at Broughton.

The company's warning has caused consternation among union leaders and politicians in north-east Wales.

Mr Morgan, who yesterday was opening a new Toyota castings plant in nearby Deeside, refused to be drawn into a slanging match over the decision to turn down BAe.

But sources in the Welsh assembly pointed out that all applications for RSA grants are subject to rigorous appraisal and that Mr Morgan had taken his decision following advice from the Welsh Industrial Development Advisory Board, an independent statutory body.

Regional selective assistance is a discretionary grant available in UK-assisted areas towards capital investment projects that create or safeguard jobs.

Officials pointed out that in order to qualify for such aid projects had to be viable, provide a net benefit to the UK economy and demonstrate a need for assistance.

Val Feld, who chairs the Welsh assembly's economic development committee, said: "We all want to see support given to British Aerospace, but we are subject to very clear rules on the whole question of the funding that goes to businesses."

webTitle: An old Laing sign for ruling clans

fields.headline: An old Laing sign for ruling clans
fields.trailText: After nearly 50 years on the market, construction and housing group John Laing has finally got round to modernising its share structure, moving to do away with the ludicrous non-voting/voting split between A and ordinary shares which has ensured this is a family-controlled company.
fields.body:
After nearly 50 years on the market, construction and housing group John Laing has finally got round to modernising its share structure, moving to do away with the ludicrous non-voting/voting split between A and ordinary shares which has ensured this is a family-controlled company.

The City hates such structures because shareholders are expected to carry risks without the voting rights that are supposed to come with ownership.

It was always assumed that the Laing family would have to be forced to give up control. In the late 70s, for example, when the last Labour government was threatening to nationalise the construction industry, the John Laing moved to split the group in two - John Laing Construction and Laing Properties - to protect the family's assets.

Now holders of the A stock will see their stake converted into ordinaries and, while holders of the voting stock will get a bonus issue on a one-for-20 basis as compensation, the family's overall stake will still fall from 52% to 37%.

Insiders insist the company wanted to do this for years but has been constrained by the fact that whenever it has been minded to act some part of the group has been playing up - in trading terms. Yesterday it issued a stunning set of final figures showing profits up from £20m to £52.7m and total dividend up 14% at 12.25p. That and the enfranchisement move were good for a 21% rise in the share price of the "As" to 214p.

There are few remaining companies where the founding family retains full control by keeping voting stock in trusted hands while insisting outsiders only have real access to non-voting paper. The City tends to eventually pick such structures apart, most famously in the case of Forte.

This must be a worry for Daily Mail & General Trust, which owns Associated Newspapers and is now a member of the FTSE 100. Its antiquated share structure outrages most institutions. Many fund managers would prefer not invest in the company but find are forced to do so because of its presence in the premier index. Yesterday, in line with the market as a whole, Daily Mail A shares slipped from £12.54 to £12.40.

fields.headline: British Biotech
fields.trailText: British Biotech's management took another stride towards rebuilding the company's respectability yesterday by licensing out Lexipafant, the company's drug for inflammatory diseases.
fields.body:
British Biotech's management took another stride towards rebuilding the company's respectability yesterday by licensing out Lexipafant, the company's drug for inflammatory diseases.

A private firm, DevCo Pharmaceuticals, has agreed to take on the product as a potential treatment for brain and liver dysfunctions.

DevCo was apparently undeterred by the compound's history - British Biotech spent millions unsuccessfully testing it as a treatment for acute pancreatitis. The product, then called Zacutex, achieved notoriety when former clinical research chief Andrew Millar said that it was having little or no effect on patients.

The deal is simple: no upfront payment but British Biotech gets royalties if DavCo puts Lexipafant on the market.

Any benefit will be years ahead and the market showed little interest; British Biotech's shares slipped 1p to 30p, valuing the business at £200m.

The stock has failed so far to benefit from the boom in the rest of the biotechnology sector. It has see-sawed between 47p and 23p.

Although British Biotech is sitting on a pile of cash - more than £98m at last count - it has little to spend it on.The company's main product, cancer drug Marimastat, has performed only moderately in trials, with patients showing little more improvement than from existing treatments.

A deal last year with Schering-Plough effectively handed on most of the drug's future development, along with its more promising successor, BB-3644.

Now British Biotech needs to license in more products, or even buy another company.

However, chief executive Elliot Goldstein's efforts in that direction have yielded little.

British Biotech has so little to do at present that it is letting out its labs to other scientific companies.

The group's results are due in June and if no corporate action has taken place by then, Dr Goldstein is likely to feel the heat from long-suffering shareholders.

webTitle: American Psycho: the story behind the film

fields.headline: American Psycho: the story behind the film
fields.standfirst: Nisha Gopalan traces the troubled passage of Bret Easton Ellis's novel from page to screen
fields.trailText: Nisha Gopalan traces the troubled passage of Bret Easton Ellis's novel from page to screen
fields.body:
"Leo, Leo, Leo." The name dripped longingly off the lips of teenage girls in 1997, following the unmatched success of Titanic. But adolescents weren't the only ones lusting after him. Studios everywhere were clamouring to seduce the golden boy into signing up for their next project, and, though their prospects were modest, the starry-eyed producers of American Psycho were no different. On a lark, Lion's Gate, the company that owned the project, sent a copy of the script and a $20m offer to Leonardo DiCaprio. To everyone's surprise, the actor was interested.

This, of course, was unbeknown to American Psycho director Mary Harron. The creator of I Shot Andy Warhol - and a rock critic at the Guardian in the early 80s - had been working for months on this black comedy about an 80s Wall Street serial killer - scripting a number of drafts with writing partner Guinevere Turner (Go Fish) and deciding, after an exhaustive search, to place British actor Christian Bale (Velvet Goldmine) in the lead role.

"When I offered him the part," the 46-year-old Harron recalls, "he said he had all these messages on his answering machine telling him this was career suicide. And that just made him more excited. That's sort of how I reacted, too." Lion's Gate, on the other hand, was less keen. Bent on reaping a healthy international profit, they wanted a bigger Hollywood name, someone like Edward Norton. "We had a huge battle over it," Harron says. "They would've taken almost anybody over Christian."

Lion's Gate announced DiCaprio's involvement at Cannes in May 1998. Bale was stunned; Harron aghast. "When you're trying to get your film financed, you're up against a bunch of people who don't care anything about that." She takes a deep breath. "Most of the time they don't care if the cast is appropriate or not, and movies have sunk like that. Like Demi Moore in The Scarlet Letter? Ridiculous."

Despite the urgings of the project's producer Ed Pressman, Harron, allied with Bale, refused to meet with the film's new star. "Leonardo wasn't remotely right [for the part]. There's something very boyish about him. He's not credible as one of these tough Wall Street guys." Besides, she adds, "he brought way too much baggage with him - I did not want to deal with someone who had a 13-year-old fan base. They shouldn't see the movie. It could've gotten us in a lot of trouble."

DiCaprio's fans were barely old enough to read in 1991, when writer Bret Easton Ellis shocked the literary world with American Psycho. His stomach-churning tale of a yuppie madman with a tendency to mutilate his dates was also was a clever, comically exaggerated satire of 80s materialism and conformity. Feminists and critics, however, were not amused. When original publishers Simon & Schuster dropped the novel after company employees objected furiously it akmost destroyed Ellis's career. Vintage eventually picked it up, but the furore remained.

As such, prospects of a film looked bleak - until 1992, when Johnny Depp apparently expressed interest in it. A succession of scripts followed, and various directors and stars would ultimately flirt with the project. "The years I spent on this property," sighs producer Ed Pressman (The Crow), "the only person who actually ever conveyed a clear solution as to how to do it was Mary."

But DiCaprio was not part of her plan. At the same time, the mere idea of one of Hollywood's highest paid actors starring in a would-be slasher film provoked a maelstrom of protest from activists, feminist icon Gloria Steinem prominent among them. It certainly didn't help Lion's Gate that their one strong female voice, the stalwart Harron, was unceremoniously bumped from the project.

"Basically, as soon as I said I didn't want to compromise my position, Lion's Gate wanted me out," she says. Soon after, DiCaprio had drafted a short list of directors, including Danny Boyle and Martin Scorsese, with whom he'd like to work. (DiCaprio would end up collaborating with both, starring in Boyle's The Beach and Scorsese's upcoming Gangs of New York.) While other names - David Cronenberg, Jonathan Demme, and even Stanley Kubrick - were also rumoured choices, no other female directors were considered.

Then in came Oliver Stone. "He was probably the single worst single person to do it," she says. "I like Stone's stuff, but social satire is not his forte... and he's not known for his well-rounded, three-dimensional female characters." Stone began to chip away at Harron's script, preparing to rewrite it altogether. "It was then an issue of how the script could be improved," says Pressman. "Oliver's approach was more psychological. Mary's was satirical."

The movie's progress then fell into the same slump that had plagued the project for years: DiCaprio and Stone couldn't agree on the film's direction. "Leo was looking for solutions to things that weren't problems when he first started. So they had many meetings together trying to figure out if they could do it together," Pressman says. "As time went on more and more questions came into Leo's mind - which might have been about the script or other factors." In the end, DiCaprio bolted off to make The Beach.

Harron had remained conspicuously quiet during this whole upheaval, which also resulted in Stone's exit. "I wanted the movie back," she says, explaining her silence. "I never actually felt like Leo would make that movie, because it was such a crazy thing for him to do. The film was so controversial." During this period, she'd frequently commiserate on the phone with Bale, who passed on projects for nine months confident that DiCaprio would depart. "Everyone thought we were crazy," she says.

Lion's Gate eventually agreed to give her the project back - with Bale playing the lead - under the agreement that her budget would not exceed $10m and that she'd cast recognisable talent (Chloe Sevigny, Jared Leto, Reese Witherspoon, and Willem Dafoe among them) in the supporting roles. "Lion's Gate wouldn't speak to me for four months," Harron says with a laugh. "Now they're apologising."

American Psycho eventually began shooting in March last year, in Toronto, Canada, against a backdrop of protest from an activist group called Concerned Canadians Against Violence in Entertainment. Apparently, local police had found a copy of American Psycho in the home of a convicted murderer called Paul Bernardo - though a recent article suggests it actually belonged to his wife. None of these protesters had read the script, much less seen the film, and Harron found herself again forced to live down the book's reputation. "If people are objecting to a level of graphic violence," she says, "then the attacks on American Psycho are very inaccurate."

"There are so many films that are much more violent," Harron continues. "Seven and 8MM never attracted the same kind of out rage." Then again, both these pictures are moralistic tales with despicable killers, ones that are categorically responsible for their actions. Harron agrees. "My film is upsetting, because it doesn't offer that kind of resolution. With Hollywood films, people want to be told that the good will win out. There is a very clear punishment at the end." Psycho, by contrast, throws that type of black and white morality into question, and is bold enough to do it with a sense of humour.

"The society is so obsessed with surface, that as long as Patrick obeys all these rules about wearing the right suit and going to the right restaurant and being seen with the right women, no one is going to look any further," Harron says. She spends a good portion of the movie detailing this type of narcissism, starting with the film's opening: a deadpan Bateman guiding us through his endless morning beauty routine, moisturiser by moisturiser.

"We were able to use French cosmetics," Harron says, referring to her uphill battle to get product approvals. "European companies were much more open to us." Most of the film's clothing, for instance, came from Cerruti and Vivienne Westwood, because American designers like Calvin Klein and Ralph Lauren "didn't want to be associated with anything so horrible." In an ironic marketing strategy, Psycho's German distributor will use this image of a taut-bodied, well-groomed, and somewhat homoerotic Bale to sell the actor as a sex symbol. Go figure.

From the moment he acquired the book's rights in 1992, Pressman was determined not to finance a film that was too offensive. The producer would ultimately reject a number of scripts, including one written by Ellis himself, that Pressman has described as being "completely pornographic and ending with a musical number." Harron's kinder, gentler, and decidedly more cerebral film looks restrained by comparison. "I felt that the only way to stop it from being really exploitative was [to affect] a kind of cool detachment," she says. "If we're seeing the murders from the killer's point of view, you would get into it."

But despite her many attempts at deflecting the hype about its violence, the buzz on the film was so intense that by the time it debuted at this year's Sundance film festival, tickets were being scalped for as much as $200. "There is a whole debate about representation: should you reflect the violence in your society? Or should you present the world as you would like it to be?" she says. "It's about the kind of film you want to make. And I don't want to present the world as I would like it to be."
