fields.bodyText: "Leo, Leo, Leo." The name dripped longingly off the lips of teenage girls in 1997, following the unmatched success of Titanic. But adolescents weren't the only ones lusting after him. Studios everywhere were clamouring to seduce the golden boy into signing up for their next project, and, though their prospects were modest, the starry-eyed producers of American Psycho were no different. On a lark, Lion's Gate, the company that owned the project, sent a copy of the script and a $20m offer to Leonardo DiCaprio. To everyone's surprise, the actor was interested. This, of course, was unbeknown to American Psycho director Mary Harron. The creator of I Shot Andy Warhol - and a rock critic at the Guardian in the early 80s - had been working for months on this black comedy about an 80s Wall Street serial killer - scripting a number of drafts with writing partner Guinevere Turner (Go Fish) and deciding, after an exhaustive search, to place British actor Christian Bale (Velvet Goldmine) in the lead role. "When I offered him the part," the 46-year-old Harron recalls, "he said he had all these messages on his answering machine telling him this was career suicide. And that just made him more excited. That's sort of how I reacted, too." Lion's Gate, on the other hand, was less keen. Bent on reaping a healthy international profit, they wanted a bigger Hollywood name, someone like Edward Norton. "We had a huge battle over it," Harron says. "They would've taken almost anybody over Christian." Lion's Gate announced DiCaprio's involvement at Cannes in May 1998. Bale was stunned; Harron aghast. "When you're trying to get your film financed, you're up against a bunch of people who don't care anything about that." She takes a deep breath. "Most of the time they don't care if the cast is appropriate or not, and movies have sunk like that. Like Demi Moore in The Scarlet Letter? Ridiculous." Despite the urgings of the project's producer Ed Pressman, Harron, allied with Bale, refused to meet with the film's new star. "Leonardo wasn't remotely right [for the part]. There's something very boyish about him. He's not credible as one of these tough Wall Street guys." Besides, she adds, "he brought way too much baggage with him - I did not want to deal with someone who had a 13-year-old fan base. They shouldn't see the movie. It could've gotten us in a lot of trouble." DiCaprio's fans were barely old enough to read in 1991, when writer Bret Easton Ellis shocked the literary world with American Psycho. His stomach-churning tale of a yuppie madman with a tendency to mutilate his dates was also was a clever, comically exaggerated satire of 80s materialism and conformity. Feminists and critics, however, were not amused. When original publishers Simon & Schuster dropped the novel after company employees objected furiously it akmost destroyed Ellis's career. Vintage eventually picked it up, but the furore remained. As such, prospects of a film looked bleak - until 1992, when Johnny Depp apparently expressed interest in it. A succession of scripts followed, and various directors and stars would ultimately flirt with the project. "The years I spent on this property," sighs producer Ed Pressman (The Crow), "the only person who actually ever conveyed a clear solution as to how to do it was Mary." But DiCaprio was not part of her plan. At the same time, the mere idea of one of Hollywood's highest paid actors starring in a would-be slasher film provoked a maelstrom of protest from activists, feminist icon Gloria Steinem prominent among them. It certainly didn't help Lion's Gate that their one strong female voice, the stalwart Harron, was unceremoniously bumped from the project. "Basically, as soon as I said I didn't want to compromise my position, Lion's Gate wanted me out," she says. Soon after, DiCaprio had drafted a short list of directors, including Danny Boyle and Martin Scorsese, with whom he'd like to work. (DiCaprio would end up collaborating with both, starring in Boyle's The Beach and Scorsese's upcoming Gangs of New York.) While other names - David Cronenberg, Jonathan Demme, and even Stanley Kubrick - were also rumoured choices, no other female directors were considered. Then in came Oliver Stone. "He was probably the single worst single person to do it," she says. "I like Stone's stuff, but social satire is not his forte... and he's not known for his well-rounded, three-dimensional female characters." Stone began to chip away at Harron's script, preparing to rewrite it altogether. "It was then an issue of how the script could be improved," says Pressman. "Oliver's approach was more psychological. Mary's was satirical." The movie's progress then fell into the same slump that had plagued the project for years: DiCaprio and Stone couldn't agree on the film's direction. "Leo was looking for solutions to things that weren't problems when he first started. So they had many meetings together trying to figure out if they could do it together," Pressman says. "As time went on more and more questions came into Leo's mind - which might have been about the script or other factors." In the end, DiCaprio bolted off to make The Beach. Harron had remained conspicuously quiet during this whole upheaval, which also resulted in Stone's exit. "I wanted the movie back," she says, explaining her silence. "I never actually felt like Leo would make that movie, because it was such a crazy thing for him to do. The film was so controversial." During this period, she'd frequently commiserate on the phone with Bale, who passed on projects for nine months confident that DiCaprio would depart. "Everyone thought we were crazy," she says. Lion's Gate eventually agreed to give her the project back - with Bale playing the lead - under the agreement that her budget would not exceed $10m and that she'd cast recognisable talent (Chloe Sevigny, Jared Leto, Reese Witherspoon, and Willem Dafoe among them) in the supporting roles. "Lion's Gate wouldn't speak to me for four months," Harron says with a laugh. "Now they're apologising." American Psycho eventually began shooting in March last year, in Toronto, Canada, against a backdrop of protest from an activist group called Concerned Canadians Against Violence in Entertainment. Apparently, local police had found a copy of American Psycho in the home of a convicted murderer called Paul Bernardo - though a recent article suggests it actually belonged to his wife. None of these protesters had read the script, much less seen the film, and Harron found herself again forced to live down the book's reputation. "If people are objecting to a level of graphic violence," she says, "then the attacks on American Psycho are very inaccurate." "There are so many films that are much more violent," Harron continues. "Seven and 8MM never attracted the same kind of out rage." Then again, both these pictures are moralistic tales with despicable killers, ones that are categorically responsible for their actions. Harron agrees. "My film is upsetting, because it doesn't offer that kind of resolution. With Hollywood films, people want to be told that the good will win out. There is a very clear punishment at the end." Psycho, by contrast, throws that type of black and white morality into question, and is bold enough to do it with a sense of humour. "The society is so obsessed with surface, that as long as Patrick obeys all these rules about wearing the right suit and going to the right restaurant and being seen with the right women, no one is going to look any further," Harron says. She spends a good portion of the movie detailing this type of narcissism, starting with the film's opening: a deadpan Bateman guiding us through his endless morning beauty routine, moisturiser by moisturiser. "We were able to use French cosmetics," Harron says, referring to her uphill battle to get product approvals. "European companies were much more open to us." Most of the film's clothing, for instance, came from Cerruti and Vivienne Westwood, because American designers like Calvin Klein and Ralph Lauren "didn't want to be associated with anything so horrible." From the moment he acquired the book's rights in 1992, Pressman was determined not to finance a film that was too offensive. The producer would ultimately reject a number of scripts, including one written by Ellis himself, that Pressman has described as being "completely pornographic and ending with a musical number." "I felt that the only way to stop it from being really exploitative was [to affect] a kind of cool detachment," she says. "If we're seeing the murders from the killer's point of view, you would get into it." But despite her many attempts at deflecting the hype about its violence, the buzz on the film was so intense that by the time it debuted at this year's Sundance film festival, tickets were being scalped for as much as $200. "There is a whole debate about representation: should you reflect the violence in your society? Or should you present the world as you would like it to be?" she says. "It's about the kind of film you want to make. And I don't want to present the world as I would like it to be." fields.headline: Bleeder
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: The stomach-turning jolts seem directionless, and without origin, explanation, or perspective. The characters in whose brooding souls all this horror has been long hatching are opaque and elusive
fields.body:
Nicolas Winding Refn's Bleeder is a dark, disorienting film from Denmark, a strange, violent slice of life from the streets - the sequel to his Pusher. Bleeder's indebtedness to American movies is foregrounded with the narrative device of having two of the characters work in a video store, and display an archival enthusiasm for the job by reeling off lists of directors. Out of what appears to be a faintly anaemic, talky urban drama, eruptions of hate suddenly materialise: a pregnant woman gets a kicking from her partner, there is race hate, shootings, and eventually a horrifying revenge murder, followed by a grisly retaliation.

But why has all this happened? The stomach-turning jolts seem directionless, and without origin, explanation, or perspective. The characters in whose brooding souls all this horror has been long hatching are opaque and elusive. If Bleeder wished to enact the impassive chaos of real life, this is undermined by the high-camp flourish of violence that ends the picture - ostentatiously derived from the American masters. Bleeder is well acted, but doesn't really add up.

fields.headline: Third World Cop
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Has a rough-and-ready plot from a familiar template, and the Jamaican dialogue isn't easy. But it's a film with undeniable brio, brashness and style
fields.body:
Third World Cop is a thriller set in Kingston, Jamaica from the same producers and writers who made 1997's Dancehall Queen. Playing the stately crime don Wonie is Carl Bradshaw - who played a much younger villain in Jimmy Cliff's 1972 The Harder They Come. Paul Campbell plays Capone, the tough, maverick cop who is drafted from his Port Antonio beat back to his home-turf of Kingston.

Third World Cop has a rough-and-ready plot from a familiar template, and the Jamaican dialogue isn't easy. But it's a film with undeniable brio, brashness and style. Paul Campbell, keen to take out some local villains on his first day, revives the spirit of the young Clint Eastwood of Dirty Harry and the spaghetti western, and cinematographer Richard Lannaman creates a garish, cartoon feel.

With its glacial hard men, macho cops, and post-colonial uniformed officers - at one stage, Capone asks an informer to "turn Queen's evidence" - Kingston might just be the new Hong Kong.

webTitle: A Matter of Life and Death

fields.headline: A Matter of Life and Death
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: There is extraordinary freshness to this film, a bloom of sanguine innocence and fantasy...It is a film with incredible self-possession, at once a playful miniature of innocent love and grandiose epic
fields.body:
The BFI has produced a ravishing new print of Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger's 1946 fairy tale A Matter of Life and Death, and it is a real, or rather surreal treat. This is the fable of a British airman Peter Carter (David Niven), who falls in love while in radio contact with an American air controller June (Kim Hunter) as he plunges to certain death in his blazing Lancaster bomber in 1945. A clerical mistake in heaven means he is miraculously allowed to live and meet up, passionately, with June - and is then called to a kind of celestial Supreme Court to plead the merits of his earthly love, versus the duty of submitting to the commands of the next world.

The debate assumes the proportions of a good-natured Special Relationship grudge match, as the prosecution's case is argued by a wig-and-knicker rebel colonist of 1776 who says that this effete Englishman has no business trifling with the affections of a good Boston girl. The heavenly trial is attended by many nations, mainly of the empire. When the seats are filled for this colossal event you can see where George Lucas got his inspiration for the senatorial debates in The Phantom Menace.

There is extraordinary freshness to this film, a bloom of sanguine innocence and fantasy - in spite of, or perhaps directly because of the fact that the grim realities of the second world war were hardly a distant memory in 1946. (Did audiences worry then about the lack of Germans in heaven, in or out of uniform?) The entire opening sequence, from the omniscient tour through an amiable, benevolent universe to the drama of Niven's flaming plane is bravura film-making. Jack Cardiff's Oscar-winning cinematography is beautifully composed and Alfred Junge's magnificent designs for the vast heavenly stairway, the filing-room for admitted souls and the gigantic amphitheatre are still breathtaking.

It is a film with incredible self-possession, at once a playful miniature of innocent love and grandiose epic. The scene in which Niven chances across a naked goatherd on a beach is unmissably weird: what ludic genius was there in Powell and Pressburger's joint creative mind to create that bizarre Hellenic moment? It is a must-see film, if only to gaze at Kathleen Byron - here playing a severe angel - one of the most beautiful, elegant and charismatic women in British screen history.

fields.headline: The Last Broadcast
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Muddled and unnecessarily complicated; it never seems to start and gives only a frustrating hint of the thrills and fear it could have delivered
fields.body:
The success of The Blair Witch Project has spawned a vast, web-driven scholarship in its various offshoots, sources and analogues; one of these is Stefan Avalos and Lance Weiler's 1998 movie The Last Broadcast. It is ostensibly a documentary about a TV show called Fact or Fiction which sent its two presenters plus two viewers into the Pine Barrens wilderness of New Jersey to search for the mythical "Jersey Devil"; three never return, the fourth is charged with their murder. But the documentary-maker thinks he can disclose the truth with their recovered footage.

The film sticks with the "reality" convention until the final revelation when it cheats outrageously: someone else, some omniscient narrator, seems to be doing the filming. Where Blair Witch had simplicity, clarity and narrative drive, Last Broadcast is muddled and unnecessarily complicated; it never seems to start and gives only a frustrating hint of the thrills and fear it could have delivered.

fields.headline: Girl, Interrupted
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: The bug-eyed, strangely sexless Winona might as well be a sensitive co-ed hunched on her bed after some sort of sorority hazing ritual. One for Channel 5
fields.body:
Winona Ryder is the star and co-executive producer of Girl, Interrupted, directed by James Mangold (Heavy, Cop Land), a film tremulous with self-importance. Throughout, Ryder is elfin-like, as if she is going to hop onto your palm any second and start emoting. She is Susanna, a troubled teen forced to check into a psychiatric hospital in 1967 after a suicide attempt. There she meets the statutory sub-Cuckoo's Nest line-up of weirdos and wackos, presided over by the ineffably smug and understanding female ward nurse Whoopi Goldberg.

The iron law of Prettiness-Apartheid applies. They are all uglies, plain-Janes, one of them actually having horrific burn-scars (just to emphasise the point), except for Winona and her co-star Angelina Jolie, the swaggering bad girl who has just been brought back after, of all the way-cool things, an escape attempt . Naturally, Winona and Angelina bond. But Winona never does any unsightly, unsexy things associated with genuine emotional or psychological disorder. It's the fatsos and the losers who do the arm-slashing and laxative-hoarding, while winsome Winona just scribbles sensitively in her notebook, sometimes writing in BIG CAPITAL LETTERS to emphasise that she does have a disorder of some sort. Otherwise, the bug-eyed, strangely sexless Winona might as well be a sensitive co-ed hunched on her bed after some sort of sorority hazing ritual. One for Channel 5.

fields.headline: Peel off the kid gloves
fields.standfirst: Peter Bradshaw is unimpressed by the tepid treatment of racial injustice in a worthy tribute to Rubin 'The Hurricane' Carter
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Rubin Carter's story is genuinely remarkable...But this movie feels dutiful and earnest, and oddly without the fire and anxiety and rage of real life
fields.body:
The Hurricane is Norman Jewison's long, slow, and unimpeachably worthy tribute to the spirit of Rubin "The Hurricane" Carter, the middleweight boxing contender of the mid-60s, fitted up on a phoney murder charge by racist cops and falsely imprisoned for nearly 20 years, along with another innocent man, John Artis.

Carter became a living legend once Bob Dylan wrote his 1975 song Hurricane about him. But what is extraordinary about his story - apart from the impenitent vindictiveness with which New Jersey state pursued its claim for years after Carter was finally released in 1985 - is the fact that his really was an American life with a second act.

His jailhouse autobiography, published in 1974, was read by a young Brooklyn boy, Lesra Martin (Vicellous Reon Shannon), who had been adopted by a commune-household of well-meaning white liberals in Toronto. Their remarkable joint efforts got Carter free, long after he'd given up. The film is based on Lesra's own book as well as Carter's, and Jewison's movie encourages us to think of them to some extent as parallel heroes, the film's senior and junior partner.

Denzel Washington brings to the lead role his habitual intelligence, dignity and calm. The film develops on familiar, conventional lines. Dan Hedaya is typecast as the vicious white cop who has got it in for Carter from day one. Carter's early fights are shown in black-and-white, introducing the names of the contenders in a sans-serif legend at the bottom of the screen - a straight steal from Raging Bull. His post-boxing career as a political prisoner of race unfolds as his marriage breaks down and his legal campaign on the outside runs into the brick wall of bigotry, corruption and cover-up. With almost supernatural inner strength, Washington's Carter retreats into a defiant yet defensive shell of stoicism.

But the movie's relative absence of radical anger is conspicuous when it is compared - as it inevitably must be - with Washington's prison experience in Spike Lee's Malcolm X. The Hurricane is not an overtly politicised movie in the same way, and there is an implicitly liberal, even paternalistic message in the fact that Carter's salvation comes because young Lesra has been adopted away from his black family by white Canadians - with nothing but happy results. (We learn later that Lesra's real parents have become alcoholics and his brother has done jail time, but these tricky subjects are not dramatised.) This outcome appears to betoken the possibility of happy, enlightened relations between the races - and why shouldn't it? - but no one discusses this out loud. And the film's implied belief that this state of affairs effectively supersedes 60s redneck racism looks naive.

Where the film is lacking is in its kidglove treatment of Carter's famous supporters. The film has clips of Bob Dylan, Ellen Burstyn, Muhammad Ali, and Joe Frazier all doing their sincere bit. In fact, celeb support for Rubin was a more interesting phenomenon than the film implies. Rolling Stone in the 70s reported on a show put on in prison by Dylan and a cast of superstars for Rubin Carter and a mostly black audience of prisoners in Clinton, New Jersey. They loved Dylan, Roberta Flack and Allen Ginsberg, but Joni Mitchell's supercilious songs were booed and she shrilly lectured Carter and the rest of the inmates: "We came here to give you love; if you can't handle it that's your problem." A more caustic film, less concerned with the lump-in-the-throat aesthetic, might have tried to show this. Not this film.

Later, Carter's lawyers wryly allude to the celebs who do not stay the course. The implication that Dylan et al are just fairweather friends (even unquestioned heroes like Ali) is not one that Jewison cares to pursue - and sometimes the movie looks uncomfortably like an extension of precisely this sort of celebrity support.

The film rolls on towards the conventional courtroom climax in which Rod Steiger, as a Solomon-like judge, rules definitively in Carter's favour and frees him. It certainly feels like a long and winding road. Rubin Carter's story is genuinely remarkable, as is the story of the ordinary, non-famous people whose persistent efforts got him out of prison. But this movie feels dutiful and earnest, and oddly without the fire and anxiety and rage of real life. The Hurricane is so concerned, finally, to construct a humane closure for the agonies of Rubin Carter, that it becomes disconnected from the burning sense of racial injustice that kick-started this extraordinary story in the first place.

A more caustic film, less concerned with the lump-in-the-throat aesthetic, might have tried to show this. Not this film. Later, Carter's lawyers wryly allude to the celebs who do not stay the course. The implication that Dylan et al are just fairweather friends (even unquestioned heroes like Ali) is not one that Jewison cares to pursue - and sometimes the movie looks uncomfortably like an extension of precisely this sort of celebrity support. The film rolls on towards the conventional courtroom climax in which Rod Steiger, as a Solomon-like judge, rules definitively in Carter's favour and frees him. It certainly feels like a long and winding road. Rubin Carter's story is genuinely remarkable, as is the story of the ordinary, non-famous people whose persistent efforts got him out of prison. But this movie feels dutiful and earnest, and oddly without the fire and anxiety and rage of real life. The Hurricane is so concerned, finally, to construct a humane closure for the agonies of Rubin Carter, that it becomes disconnected from the burning sense of racial injustice that kick-started this extraordinary story in the first place.

fields.headline: The best Tom Cruise scene
fields.standfirst: Magnolia
fields.trailText: Magnolia.
fields.body:
The Banqueting Room of the Burbank Holiday Inn. Frank TJ Mackey (Tom Cruise), mastermind of Seduce And Destroy, instructs around 200 single men on how to win over the opposite sex.

Prowling across a slightly elevated stage, he stares intently at his audience as he speaks.

"The thing about chicks," he announces, "and the thing about this course we're going through today is how universal the whole thing is. I mean, I wish I could sit here and say that's it's not. But the reality? If each chick had something new, something really new, that I'd never seen before, fuck, I'd be in the money! Because I'd have to create a hundred new cassettes, a hundred new books, a hundred new seminars, and a hundred new videos, just to deal with each and every situation a chick could create. But that is just not the case. They are universal. They are sheep. They are to be studied and watched. They have patterns that must be stopped, interrupted and resisted. I'd be making a fuckin' butt-load if they were actually as much of a challenge as they want you to think they are! Reality?"

He pauses for effect.

"They are all the same."

See also: Jerry Maguire, The Colour Of Money, Born On The Fourth Of July

Don't see also: Far And Away

Pointless trivia: In 1992, Tom Cruise claimed that his membership of the Church of Scientology helped cure his dyslexia

fields.headline: Lazio upset quarter-final calculations
fields.standfirst:
Manchester United will approach today's draw in more confident mood than unseeded Chelsea
The last eight, team-by-team
fields.trailText: David Lacey runs through the later stage permutations after Lazio's victory on Wednesday night exploded the cosy assumptions that had built up about the course of this season's competition.
fields.body:
The free-kick from Sinisa Mihajlovic which on Wednesday night found the top corner of Chelsea's goal with the unerring and unnerving accuracy of a cruise missile has also exploded some cosy assumptions about the course of this season's Champions League.

Far from being obliterated, Italian interest in the tournament is still very much alive. Having inflicted on Chelsea their first home defeat in Europe in 33 games spread over 42 years, Lazio will not only take part in today's quarter- final draw but will do so as seeds rather than runners-up.

As for Chelsea, beaten 2-1 and forced into second place largely because they could not match Lazio's combination of speed, strength and, crucially, will to win, they no longer appear equal partners in the Premiership's two-pronged march on the Stade de France in Paris in May.

Thoughts of reaching the final have been put on hold. As group runners-up, all Gianluca Vialli's side can do this morning is hope that the fates will be kind enough to keep them apart from Manchester United for at least another round.

This has nothing to do with results between the two in recent seasons. In October, in the Premiership, Chelsea gave United a thick ear 5-0 at Stamford Bridge, where two seasons earlier Sir Alex Ferguson's side had dispatched them from the FA Cup 5-3. As a rule the teams tend to play better on each other's ground.

In the Champions League, however, it would be a case of United's eight years' experience as a team at this level pitted against the number of times the likes of Didier Deschamps and Marcel Desailly have appeared in European Cup finals for other clubs.

Whoever they get today United, as group winners, will be away in the first leg. Imagine the pressure that would put on Chelsea at Stamford Bridge the week after next. Not that the prospect of an encounter with Barcelona or Bayern Munich would ease Chelsea's nerves.

If Wednesday's events at the Bridge proved anything it was how much Chelsea need Dennis Wise. The little captain was rested after an injury in training and his ability to get to grips with the opposing midfield, as well as his knack of appearing in scoring positions at crucial moments, was badly missed. The longer the game went on the more apparent it became that Deschamps needed more than Roberto di Matteo to challenge the Argentine authority of Juan Veron and Diego Simeone, augmented by the Czech subtleties of Pavel Nedved.

United have been spared the possibility of meeting the Italians, and of meeting Barcelona and Bayern Munich, until the semi-finals. They will, however, be given some idea of what success in the quarter- finals will bring them, since Uefa will also make an outline draw for the semi-finals today in Nyon, Switzerland.

Given the choice, Ferguson might be content with a quarter-final tie against Porto, whom United overcame without difficulty at a similar stage on their way to the semi-finals in 1997. United cannot meet Valencia, who were in the same second-phase group, and the only other alternatives to Chelsea are Real Madrid, who are struggling for consistency but are hardly mugs in Europe.

 Chelsea have asked the Nigerian Football Association to allow Celestine Babayaro, who sustained a groin injury against Lazio, not to travel for this weekend's Olympic qualifying match in Zimbabwe. Nigeria had insisted that the full-back must play in the under-23 fixture but allowed him extra time to take part in the Lazio match before joining their squad.

webTitle: Neither pedantic nor wild? Michael McNay on the Guardian's house style

fields.headline: Neither pedantic nor wild?
fields.trailText: Michael McNay gives an introduction to the Guardian's house style
fields.body:
The Guardian has always been a newspaper for writers, and so a newspaper for readers. All the other skills, copy editing, design, typography, illustration, photography, are there to enhance the writing and to make it more accessible, to make the paper a more desirable journal to read - though illustration and photography each has its separate justification as well.

It should not be necessary to add that Guardian writers and subeditors should all be interested in the language, in its proper use and its development, and that regular trips to books as wide-ranging as Gowers' The Complete Plain Words, Partridge's Usage and Abusage, Orwell's brilliant short essay Politics and the English Language, Fowler's Modern English Usage, or Kingsley Amis's The King's English, are useful in sharpening professional tools as well as for entertainment.

One says it should not be necessary, but it is very obvious all round the Guardian office that uncomfortably many people involved in producing and shaping text for the paper rely more on the casual question, "What's the style for x?" and the casual answer, "I think it's probably y." Journalists who are not sufficiently interested in house style to check the house style guide are not on the face of it very likely to be much interested in style at all.

But our approach to style in its broadest sense is, if anything, more important now than before, first because other newspapers, which may always have had good writing in specialist areas, have caught up fast across a whole range of news and features; second because the Guardian itself employs so many staff on freelance shifts or short contracts who arrive here with no particular idea of what makes this paper different from others, and even staff journalists who are never inducted into what values the Guardian holds particularly close; third, though more obscurely, because of the arrival of the internet: this style guide itself is the first to be published on the world wide web. That makes it accessible in seconds; it cannot get lost or suffer having coffee spilt on it. But though there is no reason in itself why new publishing methods should change the language for the worse, the example of radio and television shows that it can: at the top end, the best correspondents file spoken reports that could grace this newspaper; at the broad base, reporters speak a form of unlovely but infectious journalese destined only for the rubbish bin.

House style is the means by which a newspaper seeks to ensure that where there are permissible variants in spellings, the use of acronyms and so forth, a unified approach to these matters is adopted to help in disseminating a sense of rationality and authority in the use of language. What it does not mean is imposing a unified writing style on the newspaper. Many of the reporters, columnists, critics and at least one former editor who once ran a highly idiosyncratic gossip column and who have enlivened the pages of the Guardian and helped to build its international reputation could hardly have done so had they been edited from the beginning into a homogenous house style. A subeditor can do no worse disservice to the text before him and thus to the writer, the reader, and the newspaper, than to impose his or her own preferences for words, for the shape of sentences and how they link, for a pedantic insistence on grammar in all cases as it used to be taught in school; in the process destroying nuances and possibly even the flow of a piece. And I write this as a career copy and layout editor with the best part of 40 years' service on the Guardian and who regards the skills involved in copy editing not just as desirable but essential.

Editing involves fine judgment, particularly as the paper has so many sections today serving possibly quite different kinds of readership. But fine judgments mean good editing, blanket judgments mean bad editing. A piece written in the vernacular that would be inappropriate on the analysis page or even (even?) in a sports column might pass muster in the Guide, where the demotic language of an NME review would be closer to the mark than the high style of Macaulay or CP Scott. And dealing sympathetically with quirks of writing style certainly does not preclude tidying up cliche-ridden journalese, verbosity, the latest vogue words and phrases, the words and phrases that flatten out meaning, replace a range of better more finely tuned words and concepts, and anaesthetise writing.

The introduction to the Guardian stylebook of 1960, which itself was a revision to the initial guide published in 1928, was headed "Neither pedantic nor wild".

That much has not changed.

• Michael McNay worked for the Guardian from 1963 to 1999. He edited The Guardian Year 2000

fields.headline: Next derides net spending
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Next, the fashion chain, yesterday claimed to have become the country's number one online clothing retailer while at the same time questioning why rival store groups were pouring millions of pounds into e-tailing.
fields.body:
Next, the fashion chain, yesterday claimed to have become the country's number one online clothing retailer while at the same time questioning why rival store groups were pouring millions of pounds into e-tailing.

The store chain said it would achieve £12m in net sales this year and was attracting 700 new mail order customers a week via the web without pouring large amounts of cash into the online division.

Earlier this week, Kingfisher, the group which embraces B&Q and Woolworths, said it was investing £60m to develop its e-commerce operations this year and Iceland announced it was spending £8m to change its 700 store fascias to read Iceland.co.uk.

David Jones, the chief executive of Next, said: "We have spent £125,000 on our internet site and will do £12m of sales. I can't understand what people are spending their money on. Sometimes I wonder if the world has gone quietly mad."

Next's attitude towards e-commerce has left some analysts frustrated. They have accused the retailer of failing to communicate its e-strategy. But Mr Jones said he regarded the net as merely a new method of conducting "mail order" business.

He said: "The internet is just an extension of the telephone and the telephone was an extension of the envelope. In the 1960s mail order was conducted by envelope, then it moved to the telephone and now it is on the net."

He said Next did not need to pour millions into e-commerce and marketing its service because it already had the brand name required and the ability to fulfil orders efficiently.

"And we can advertise it on our carrier bags, which doesn't cost us a penny".

Mr Joneslast year said he thought people who were prepared to spend hours trawling through pictures of clothing on computer screens were "sad."

He offered his latest thoughts on web trading as the retail chain announced an increase in annual profits from £166.9m to £194.7m.

But the group's shares fell 12.5% - or 72.5p - to 504p as investors took fright at current trading figures, which showed like-for-like sales up only 3% on 1999 levels. They had been expecting nearer 5%.

Mr Jones said he thought there was no cause for concern. "We are in a low inflation economy and have negative selling price inflation. And we also have Easter three weeks later this year.

"I think 3% is a perfectly acceptable result. In fact I think to get any like-for-like growth is good".

The share price fall came despite Next also announcing plans to buy back up to 10% of the group's shares - a move normally applauded by investors - and a decision to sell its Clydesdale consumer credit operation.

It will retain its Ventura customer services division and develop it to offer "call centre-related activities" to other on-line retailers. Next might also start deliveries for other e-tailers.

Mr Jones dismissed analysts' criticisms that the chain was too narrowly focused. "The market doesn't like the fact that we are concentrating on the home market.

"But I believe the best way to increase the profitability of Next is to increase out market share in the UK. And I am still not sure how much the so-called global retailers really make outside their home market".

fields.headline: Adulthood's inner child
fields.standfirst:
The Red Thread
Young Vic, London
**
fields.trailText: It is hard to be hard on the final part of David Glass's The Lost Child Trilogy. Its heart is so obviously in the right place, and it offers some of the most exhilarating images currently to be seen on the stage. It is potentially so close to the kind of theatre that you dream of, its failure is all the more acute.
fields.body:
It is hard to be hard on the final part of David Glass's The Lost Child Trilogy. Its heart is so obviously in the right place, and it offers some of the most exhilarating images currently to be seen on the stage. It is potentially so close to the kind of theatre that you dream of, its failure is all the more acute.

The Red Thread consists of 1998's The Hansel Gretel Machine and 1999's The Lost Child, woven together with a newly composed requiem. The trouble is, the strengths of the first piece and the weaknesses of the second are magnified when seen side by side and the music, although beautiful, adds little except a sense of lamentation.

The first part works best, largely because the Hansel and Gretel story is familiar to us all. Exquisite though it is to look at, I'd defy anyone to have a clue what was going on in the second half without recourse to the synopsis in the programme. Glass and his ensemble have filtered the stories of children from all over the world who have lost their childhoods through war, poverty, abuse, through such a dreamy filter that the experience seems remote from the real world.

Glass spent three years working with children around the world and hearing their stories, but you wouldn't know it. There is no analysis, no sense of the political, social and economic factors that contribute to the plight of children, no sense that they own this piece. Or indeed that adults can do anything other than weep and wring our hands. The piece makes you feel helpless in every sense.

But if the emphasis on a subconscious journey into the inner child of the adult rather sells today's lost children short, it does give rise to some stunning imagery. The first picture of Gretel suspended as though in the womb but also like a small child on a meat hook, sets the standard for an evening of undoubted visual flair.

 Until April 1. Box office: 0171-928 6363.

webTitle: Kamlesh Bahl: the Law Society report

fields.headline: Kamlesh Bahl: the Law Society report
fields.standfirst: Lord Griffiths' Report | Ms Q: agressive phone calls | Ms M: bullied at work | Mr K: humilated in meetings | Ms P and Mr L: abused in Atlanta | conclusion
fields.trailText: Extracts from the statement of the council of the Law Society
fields.body:
Extracts from the statement of the council of the Law Society

The council recommends to members that they should vote for the motion to be moved at the special general meeting: that Kamlesh Bahl be removed as a member of council, pursuant to bye law 69.

The background is set out in the report of Lord Griffiths [extracts of which follow], sitting with two experienced lay members of the employment appeal tribunal as assessors. In paragraph 8.1, Lord Griffiths found that Ms Bahl 'resorted at times to bullying tactics. She treated the staff without due consideration demanding immediate response to her own wishes without regard to their other duties. Her treatment of staff was at times demeaning and humiliating and at other times offensively aggressive. In many ways, she usurped the secretary-general's role as head of staff and introduced an atmosphere of fear and confusion in the line of command'.

Extracts from Lord Griffiths' Report of March 10, 2000 including comments from the complainants

The report sets out to clearly define what is understood by The Oxford dictionary definition of "to bully", which is "To act the bully towards; to treat in an overbearing manner: to intimidate, overawe."

In section 5.4 the number of complainants are established: "We received evidence of bullying from five complainants. We also received evidence that other unidentified members of staff had complained to their union, their line managers and to other office holders of their treatment by the vice-president. It was said that these other members of staff would not come forward as complainants under the dignity at work policy because they were frightened of the vice-president and fearful that they might lose their employment if identified, particularly if she became president."

Ms Q: agressive phone calls

Ms Q's complaint is set down in the report, and refers to one instance when she received a telephone call from Kamlesh Bahl over a draft on the accountability of the head of staff.

"[Ms Q] had gone to bed early and was woken at 10.15pm [she had advised Ms Bahl that she could be contacted at home that evening by phone] by a telephone call from Kamlesh Bahl."

"She says Kamlesh Bahl was very angry and spoke in a loud aggressive tone because she had not been given the details of precisely which bye-laws and regulations covered the functions and duties of the head of staff."

"[Ms Q] said it was not the fact that she was told that her draft was unacceptable; it was the way in which she was told and the tone of voice that upset her so much and she spent most of her night in tears."

After interviewing Ms Q the report states, "We [Lord Griffiths sitting with two members of the employment appeal tribunal as assessors] and accept [Ms Q's] account of the two conversations. This was an instance of Kamlesh Bahl dealing with a senior member of staff in an unwarrantedly aggressive manner, properly described as berating her. And this was done "in a way that made it clear that Kamlesh Bahl did not think much of her ability and that members of her staff would be treated in a like manner."

Ms M was reported as having a great sense of anxiety over these meetings, which often turned "bad". When questioned on Kamlesh Bahl's behaviour, she said, "I would describe it as lecturing or hectoring . . . Sometimes it would be angry and cross and very impatient and moving onto another question before you had finished answering the first question. Other times would be more reasonable, but you never knew which way it was going to go."

Ms M believes that Kamlesh Bahl abused her position of power, and said, "I simply believe that the vice-president treated people in a way she should not have treated people, the way no person should treat another person in terms of discourtesy, rudeness, general hectoring, haranguing. But I believe she felt almost entitled because she was an office holder. I simply believe that is wrong."

Ms M's statements are supported by Mr I, Ms N, Mr H, and Mr K who said that Kamlesh Bahl behaved very badly and unreasonably towards Ms M and her staff at the committee meetings. He said her attention was not focused on him: "I recall wondering whether my turn would come."

She concluded that working with Kamlesh Bahl: "stands out as the most stressful and most horrible year of my working life. At times the pressure and stress was unbearable". The report states the enquirers' univocal acceptance of Ms M and her staff's version of the events.

The statement of Mr K, another complainant, supports Ms M - he says "My early contact with Kamlesh Bahl in the autumn 1998 was at various committee meetings. Kamlesh behaved very badly and unreasonably towards Ms M, the head of department and her office staff at those meetings, but her attention was not focused on me. I recall wondering when my time would come."

The report of the working party chaired by Kamlesh Bahl recommended a drastic reduction in the number of committees and [made] " a crude estimate of the present direct cost of the committee system [of] £1.8m per annum."

Without reference to Kamlesh Bahl, or any member of the working party or the head of staff, Mr K, wrote to the chairman of the committees serviced by his directorate criticising the estimate of £1.8m. "I was extremely embarrassed by the attack on Mr K. It was humiliating. I recall that Mr K finally gathered together his papers and began to walk out the room. We accept that the first Ms P and Mr L knew of the letter of August 2 was when Kamlesh Bahl telephoned them at their hotel on the morning of August 4 and read it over to them We also accept evidence their evidence that Kamlesh Bahl then launched into a menacing verbal onslaught upon them accusing Ms P of outrageous behaviour in fixing [a] meeting on August 7 without her permission.

There is no question of that. She was a menacing and threatening person."

Everyone involved in the planning meeting believed that at the last ABA conference in London 15 years earlier, the dinner had been hosted by the Law Society. At the conclusion of a breakfast meeting on the following morning August 7, she spoke to Mr L about this matter. Their accounts are different. webTitle: Oftel first to offer consumer protection

fields.headline: Oftel first to offer consumer protection
fields.trailText: Oftel, the telecommunications watchdog, has become the first regulator in Europe to issue standards on telephone contracts giving consumers clear guidelines on protection against "dishonest" service providers.
fields.body:
Oftel, the telecommunications watchdog, has become the first regulator in Europe to issue standards on telephone contracts giving consumers clear guidelines on protection against "dishonest" service providers.

It means the redefinition of "unfair" clauses in fixed line and mobile contracts - ranging from the right to terminate without notice, the right to increase prices, penalties and the right of final decision.

The regulator also set out standards on the type and quality of information that service providers must include in their contracts.

The new guidelines require that service providers outline the types of maintenance service offered and compensation or refund arrangements provided for subscribers.

David Edmonds, the director general of telecommunications, said: "Consumers should not be taken by surprise by hidden terms and penalty clauses. Telecom companies have a duty to consumers to set out the service they are providing within their contract in clear and unambiguous terms."

The explosion in mobile phone usage in the UK - now at 40% of the population - is understood to be the reason behind the need for more closely-defined contractual terms for service providers.

Consumers will be able to ask Oftel to investigate cases of unfair contracts on their behalf and the director general will be able to take action against service providers to force them to amend or remove unfair terms.

Alban Thurston, telecoms pricing consultant at research agency Ovum, said the EU had given directives to issue standards on telecom contracts. He said the UK was the first country to respond with a new set of guidelines.

"It looks like the UK regulator is taking the lead in implementing regulations from Brussels," Mr Thurston said.

"It's amazing this wasn't done before. There's been enormous anxiety caused for end-users because of inappropriate terms and conditions." The change in providing contractual standards is also expected to lead to fairer pricing for domestic consumers.

Elsewhere, however, the UK's performance came under fire. Mark Daeche, co-founder of fast-growing discount group First Telecom, said yesterday that the UK had lost out in the liberalisation of the market.

He made the comment during an announcement that his firm is to begin offering a £100m high speed pan-European data service in Germany, spurred by the removal of Deutsche Telekom's monopoly on the local network.

Rivals such as First Telecom and the Dutch group, KPN Qwest, have moved in to offer higher speed phone and internet connections and cheaper services to German homes and offices.

"We are rolling out our initial digital subscriber line services in Germany because the unbundling of the local loop here is far more advanced than in the UK, which I suspect is now two years behind," Mr Daeche said.

"This is an extraordinary situation, given the relative state of liberalisation in Europe five years ago, when the UK was at least two years ahead."

A row has been brewing between BT and the government over the timetable for opening the local loop to competition. Such deregulation would allow rivals to offer a range of services over BT's lines.

Oftel has said that BT must unbundle its local networks to rivals by July 1 2001.

Mr Daeche said First Telecom would invest £100m in the German market over the summer, and allow internet service providers to "piggyback" on the network.

First Telecom, preparing for a public offering that could value it at £400m, would not comment on the period over which it expected to recover its investment in Germany.

webTitle: NTL Mobile tops auction round with £965m offer

fields.headline: NTL Mobile tops auction round with £965m offer
fields.trailText: NTL Mobile yesterday moved to knock out its competition in the government's sale of third-generation mobile phone licences by putting in the highest bid so far.
fields.body:
NTL Mobile yesterday moved to knock out its competition in the government's sale of third-generation mobile phone licences by putting in the highest bid so far.

The offer of £965.5m was for licence A which has been reserved for new operators. It is the first time the highest bid in the auction was registered on licence A.

Attention has centred on licence B because it has the biggest spectrum of the four licences which the existing operators, Vodafone, Orange, One2One and BT, can pitch for.

Vodafone continued to dominate bidding for licence B with an offer of £932.6m, while Telefonica bid £637.3m for licence C, Eircom subsidiary 3GUK offered £655m for licence D and WorldCom £652.4m for licence E.

The 13 contenders for the five licences continue to remain in the auction as it nears the end of its third week with the total bids amounting to £3.8bn.

"The issue is how much longer can the auction sustain this rate before people start quitting," one analyst said yesterday.

The amount raised in the auction so far has dwarfed initial internal forecasts by the Radio Communications Agency of between £500,000 and £1.5bn.

fields.headline: Byers' search goes on
fields.standfirst:
Government unconvinced that Alchemy's Rover plan is viable

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The government is actively encouraging alternative bidders to take over the loss-making Rover operations at Longbridge from BMW amid continuing doubts about the viability of the plans by venture capitalist firm Alchemy.
fields.body:
The government is actively encouraging alternative bidders to take over the loss-making Rover operations at Longbridge from BMW amid continuing doubts about the viability of the plans by venture capitalist firm Alchemy.

The moves emerged yesterday as Stephen Byers, the Trade and Industry secretary, wrung from Rover's German owners a commitment to minimise job losses during talks in Munich with BMW chairman Joachim Milberg.

There is considerable scepticism in government circles that a genuine alternative buyer can be found, but City sources indicated that John Hemming, the Midlands software millionaire and would-be Birmingham mayor, had won serious backing for his plan, known as Project Phoenix.

John Towers, the Rover cars chief from the period when it was known as BL and now head of a Birmingham-based firm, is understood to be among the five backers alluded to yesterday by Mr Hemming in a series of interviews.

Whitehall sources discounted Square Mile speculation that Mr Towers, the real force behind the Hemming plan, was actively working at the behest of Mr Byers - who was left in the dark before last week's shock decision by BMW to pull out of Rover. But Mr Byers said in Munich: "We do know that over the last 48 hours or so other people have expressed an interest.

"Now it is up to them to come forward with a positive set of proposals to see if BMW will look at them."

BMW has entered a six-week period of exclusive talks with Alchemy over Longbridge but government sources indicated that Mr Byers had received expressions of interest, some of them from abroad and some with manufacturing pedigrees, to buy Rover.

"We've put out some feelers but nobody has come back to us; we're not aware of any serious players," one Whitehall insider said.

Alchemy, meanwhile, confirmed yesterday that Chris Woodwark, now head of Staveley Industries and a former Rover and Rolls-Royce executive, is to be chief executive of the MG Cars Company it is setting up to run the slimmed-down operations it is planning at Longbridge.

But it is understood that Alchemy found it extremely hard to recruit the chief executive of its choice, and Mr Woodwark emerged only after several others had turned down Alchemy's approaches.

Brandon Gough, chairman of MG Cars, last night refused to comment. But he said it remained uncertain how many jobs the new group would take over. "We may even have to create some new jobs," he said.

He added: "On the production side, the level of manning will be determined by sales. We aim to take ownership by the end of April and make sure we get momentum back into the business and put a lot more light into the market."

Countering union fears that as many as 9,500 jobs were at risk, BMW said between 2,000 and 3,000 could go. It agreed in yesterday's talks with Mr Byers to back his taskforce to bring new industry and jobs to the west midlands.

Sir Ken Jackson, leader of the AEEU union, said BMW should match the £129m contribution of the government to the taskforce.

webTitle: Laws of gravity hold true in cyberspace

fields.headline: Laws of gravity hold true in cyberspace
fields.standfirst:
Bubble bound to burst when the cash fails to materialise

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Do the rules of the old financial world affect the new economy? The answer appears to be increasingly yes.
fields.body:
Do the rules of the old financial world affect the new economy? The answer appears to be increasingly yes.

Lastminute.com is not the only internet stock to have come down to earth with a bump. Lycos Europe began trading on Wednesday on the Neuer Markt and immediately slipped below its issue prices of euro 24, closing at euro 22.85.

Previous fallers included the Dutch internet company World Online International, down more than 20% in its first three days on the market.

A new paper by Chris Higson and John Briginshaw of London Business School offers a possible explanation.

Published in the next issue of Business Strategy Review, it argues that while some of the high-priced internet stocks will survive and justify their valuations most will not.

The reason is simple: they will never generate enough cash. Like most analysts, Higson and Briginshaw dismiss traditional stock evaluation methods.

Because most internet companies are start-ups, it is pointless looking at price/revenue or price/earnings multiples because they do not have any revenues or earnings. The key issue is whether stock prices reflect reasonable expectations about the growth and profitability of internet businesses.

The only way to test that is to model the company's ability to generate cash in the future.

Predicting the market for internet businesses is difficult enough, given the range of alternatives. But expectations about the future competitive environment in which they operate are just as important.

A common mistake is to assume the competitive environment will be the same as it has been in the past and that new economy companies will earn fat, old economy margins.

In reality, Higson and Briginshaw argue, the internet will become much more competitive, making the new econ omy a difficult place in which to earn profits.

"In such a world, the market allows companies survival rations, no better," they say.

To illustrate their point that most internet valuations are stretched, Higson and Briginshaw examine two high-profile internet companies - Amazon.com, which in February, had a market capitalisation of $1.6bn, and Freeserve, which was worth £7bn.

After studying a range of revenue growth patterns, structures of costs and attainable profit margins, they conclude that on only the most optimistic assumptions is Amazon's value justified. Even more aggressive assumptions for Freeserve's profit margins and sales growth are required to justify the stock's price.

Higson and Briginshaw suggest that a lot of internet investors could lose their shirts. But it is not only individuals that stand to suffer. If the bub ble bursts, falling stock prices could hit economic growth. But even the bubble is doing damage to the real economy.

"In a bubble, companies which own successful internet operations may be tempted to spin them off to give shareholders the benefit of bubble valuations, at risk of compromising their ability to capture the synergies from a clicks and mortar strategy.

"On the other hand, high observed valuations may tempt corporate managers to build internet activities even though they possess no competency or advantage in this area. New economy companies with bubble valuations may use overvalued paper to facilitate acquisitions of businesses which they have little ability to manage."

webTitle: Fear and loathing in Chancery Lane

fields.headline: Fear and loathing in Chancery Lane
fields.standfirst:
'Intimidating and humiliating treatment' of staff revealed in retired law lord's report into modus operandi of ex-Law Society vice-president

Kamlesh Bahl: the Law Society report
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: 'Intimidating and humiliating treatment' of staff revealed in retired law lord's report into modus operandi of ex-Law Society vice-president.
fields.body:
The 80,000 solicitors in England and Wales will get an insight into the goings on in the Chancery Lane headquarters of their professional body this week when an envelope from the Electoral Reform Society lands on their desks.

Inside is the hitherto confidential report by Lord Griffiths, the retired law lord, into allegations of bullying against Kamlesh Bahl, vice-president of the Law Society until her resignation this week.

The 40-page document lays bare a workplace in which staff operated in "an atmosphere of fear and confusion", were subjected to "verbal onslaughts", demeaning and humiliating treatment by the vice-president who was determined to push through reforms to the bureaucracy. Staff were reduced to tears and one senior official was undergoing medical counselling for stress.

The society was told by management consultant Lord Stevenson, who reviewed it in 1998: "The society does not work. Its very structure prevents effective decision-making, and when decisions are made there is no means of ensuring they are implemented." Its regulating arm, the Office for the Supervision of Solicitors, faced a huge backlog of complaints and the government was threatening to remove its power to regulate itself. It had failed to anticipate the scale of negligence claims against solicitors and had to ask for big top-ups to plug a huge shortfall in its indemnity fund. At best it was seen as an irrelevance by the large city firms.

Into this morass marched Ms Bahl, the first woman and first ethnic minority solicitor to reach such heights. "She was the dynamo driving forward these much-needed reforms," said Lord Griffiths.

But along the way she seems to have steamrollered not only senior staff, but the secretary general (chief executive), Jane Betts, and the other Law Society leaders as well.

Michael Napier, then deputy vice-president, told the Griffiths inquiry he had been "slapped down" and given what was like "a kick in the stomach" at one meeting.

Five staff complained that they had been bullied, but there were others who complained to the union, MSF. They were said to have declined to come forward because they were frightened of the vice-president and afraid that they might lose their job, particularly if she became president - a post she was due to step into next July.

Her main target was Russell Wallman, director of policy. She "doubted his loyalty to the new regime", the report said. She was furious when she discovered he had written a letter to committee chairmen casting doubt on a figure given for the cost of committees she wanted to abolish.

She subjected him to a verbal onslaught of reprimand and recrimination, said Lord Griffiths. "We have no doubt it was menacing in tone and went far beyond the terms of any reprimand that might have been warranted by his behaviour."

The president, Robert Sayer, told the inquiry that it felt as if "hands were going to be chopped off". He added: "My abiding recollection is of Russell Wallman sitting there with an absolutely white shocked face looking as if he had been hit in the solar plexus."

It was "a terrifying verbal onslaught and a wholly unacceptable way in which to speak to any member of staff," said Lord Griffiths. "We regard it as a very bad example of aggressive verbal bullying."

At a meeting in Atlanta to plan the Law Society's participation in the American Bar Association conference in London next July, she accused another senior official, Jonathan Goldsmith, and his assistant, Ann Frazer, of being "lazy and incompetent" in a room full of 200 delegates, according to Mr Sayer's evidence. "It was a humiliating and wholly inappropriate way in which to deal with a senior member of staff," said Lord Griffiths. Mr Goldsmith described her as "a menacing and threatening person".

Lawyer who blazed a trail for minorities

Born: Nairobi, Kenya, May 28 1956

Education: University of Birmingham

Married: 1986, to Nitin Lakhani

Career: Became a solicitor in 1980. Worked for the GLC from 1978-81, British Steel Corporation 1981-84, Texaco Ltd 1984-87, Data Logic Ltd 1987-89. In 1993 became chairwoman of the equal opportunities commission. In 1998 when elected as deputy vice-president of the Law Society she became the first woman, the first person from an ethnic minority and the youngest candidate to hold such a senior position.

Member of justice sub-committee on judiciary 1991-92; Ethnic minorities advice committee and tribunals committee 1991-94; Foreign Office diplomatic service appeal board, 1993-present; EC consultative commission on racism and xenophobia 1994-present

Awards: Given a CBE in 1997 and has honorary degrees from North London, De Montfort and Liverpool John Moores universities.

In 1997 she was listed by the Guardian in the top 50 most powerful women in Britain

fields.headline: Marvellous night for it
fields.standfirst:
Van Morrison/Bobby Bland
Royal Albert Hall, London
****
fields.trailText: Van Morrison fits increasingly comfortably alongside the blues veterans who originally inspired him. In the past, Morrison has shared the stage with Ray Charles and John Lee Hooker. This time, the chosen living legend was Bobby Bland, the bluesman from Tennessee who turned 70 in January.
fields.body:
Van Morrison fits increasingly comfortably alongside the blues veterans who originally inspired him. In the past, Morrison has shared the stage with Ray Charles and John Lee Hooker. This time, the chosen living legend was Bobby Bland, the bluesman from Tennessee who turned 70 in January.

Wearing what looked like a pair of grey silk pyjamas, Bland occupied centre stage with nonchalant composure. Though his throat sounded ragged round the edges, and he kept emitting an alarming noise somewhere between a gargle and a snore, Bland can still use his light, precise tenor to point up a lyric with laser accuracy.

Van Morrison has evolved into his own one-man genre, and if his new songs often sound interchangeable, he has become a peerless live performer. As usual, he had surrounded himself with a band of apparently infinite capability, with every member ready to peel off a solo before dropping back to provide tactful support for Morrison's adventures at the microphone. In particular, Candy Dulfer was invited to take a string of blistering interludes on alto saxophone. Morrison cuts an increasingly Godfatherish figure in shades, dark suit and pork-pie hat, but this was a smiling, relaxed Van, dimensions removed from the curmudgeonly performer his audiences have often endured.

Morrison seemed to be bending over backwards to be friendly, flashing back to some of his best-loved songs. He kicked off with a sprightly I've Been Working, punched along by crisp horns and jabbing rhythm guitar, then slotted into a breezily-swinging Moondance. Bland joined him for Ain't That Loving You and When You Got a Heartache, before Morrison began to stretch himself a little on I Believe to My Soul.

But Bland wasn't the only guest. Morrison suddenly vanished, to be replaced by the bull-like shape of Chris Farlowe singing his 1966 hit, Out of Time. Later, Farlowe reappeared to swap lines with Van on a tribute to James Brown, and to duet on a stately rendition of Dylan's It's All Over Now, Baby Blue. Throughout, Morrison's mastery of the proceedings was assured.

webTitle: Gallery fails to link artists' credos

fields.headline: Gallery fails to link artists' credos
fields.trailText: The posters that lead the visitor out of Pimlico tube station put a brave face on what Tate Britain is about. See the original British "new wave", the posters rave, showing a festering sea under a burning sky. Then you notice people in the sea and the ship sailing away. It seems bizarre to borrow from America what is probably the best and most frightening British painting, Turner's Slavers Throwing Overboard the Dead and Dying (1840), only to advertise it as an ancestor of Damien Hirst and the Chapman brothers.
fields.body:
The posters that lead the visitor out of Pimlico tube station put a brave face on what Tate Britain is about. See the original British "new wave", the posters rave, showing a festering sea under a burning sky. Then you notice people in the sea and the ship sailing away. It seems bizarre to borrow from America what is probably the best and most frightening British painting, Turner's Slavers Throwing Overboard the Dead and Dying (1840), only to advertise it as an ancestor of Damien Hirst and the Chapman brothers.

Previews for Tate Britain have fished for connections between the British art of the past and today. British art has always been gritty, grotty, a bit cheeky, a bit common, goes the argument, from Hogarth to Hirst. How Gainsborough, Reynolds and Zoffany fit in is anyone's guess - perhaps Sam Taylor-Wood's photographs of people isolated in their spacious flats are descended from Zoffany's conversation pieces. But they are not, of course. Nor does Hirst have anything in common with Hogarth.

The art "re-presented" in the opening displays of Tate Britain radiates a confident belief in a singular national identity. That identity was argued over, satirised, celebrated, even loathed in the art of the 18th, 19th and much of the 20th centuries - but always taken as a given. Constable's matted dungballs of colour convey a deep faith in England. Hogarth's self-portrait with his pug dog advertises him as a tough-minded British individualist.

When you get to David Hockney's Mr and Mrs Clark and Percy (1970-71) speakers might as well blare out Elgar's cello concerto, so heartbreakingly does this painting capture a particular moment in British life.

The curators claim to hold up the idea of a national art tradition for scrutiny. Yet you are stirred despite yourself. Here are the green fields, the red-coated soldiers, the millstreams, the fairy rings. Here is the courageous young Major Pierson, shot down by a French rascal just as his men took back the island of Jersey from French invaders in 1781. This heroic moment was recorded by the American painter John Singleton Copley in 1783 as crowds queued for hours to see the canvas and weep.

There is almost too much historical texture here. I am not sure what people will gain from reading a letter, as the caption explains, "From the painter Samuel John Lamorna Birch to Caroline, wife of the painter Thomas Gotch, sending a recipe for tallow soap". Far more successful is the decision to show prints by Hogarth, Rowlandson and Gillray, restoring them to their rightful place in the history of art.

Although Tate Britain wants to surf the wave of enthusiasm for new British art what it contains is something else entirely. New British art really is new, but I am not sure if it is very British. Hirst did not set out to be the new David Hockney but the new Andy Warhol. This reflected a violent transformation in British life. The factory years, the triumph of the market, the fading of post-war social beliefs - all this made Britain feel like a different place. Damien Hirst's shark and Rachel Whiteread's concrete house do not belong in the same country, let alone the same museum, as Constable's Flatford Mill. Hogarth had an image for it. In Beer Street and Gin Lane he contrasts two societies, one of healthy British quaffing beer, the other of dead drunk gin- sodden collective squalor. The art that dominates Tate Britain conveys the confidence of people who lived on Beer Street. But we live on Gin Lane.

Tate Britain is a generous, fascinating museum, but despite its best efforts it cannot bridge the gap between these two worlds. There is young British art here, from Martin Creed's neon over the entrance to Mona Hatoum's solo show, but no real sense that contemporary art has a place in the whole. The only youngsters who look at home are the painters - Chris Ofili, Gary Hume, Fiona Rae. Later this year the first Tate triennial show of New British Art will be held here, and after that the Turner. But none of that stops you feeling this museum is dedicated to the art of another country.

In Beer Street and Gin Lane he contrasts two societies, one of healthy British quaffing beer, the other of dead drunk gin- sodden collective squalor. The art that dominates Tate Britain conveys the confidence of people who lived on Beer Street. But we live on Gin Lane. Tate Britain is a generous, fascinating museum, but despite its best efforts it cannot bridge the gap between these two worlds. There is young British art here, from Martin Creed's neon over the entrance to Mona Hatoum's solo show, but no real sense that contemporary art has a place in the whole. The only youngsters who look at home are the painters - Chris Ofili, Gary Hume, Fiona Rae. Later this year the first Tate triennial show of New British Art will be held here, and after that the Turner. But none of that stops you feeling this museum is dedicated to the art of another country.

fields.headline: Space invaders
fields.standfirst:
Celebration and The Room
Almeida Theatre, London
****
fields.trailText: More than 40 years separate these plays: Pinter's latest and his very first which together make up a richly entertaining double-bill. Yet, for all their obvious contrasts, I was struck by a curious similarity between the two works: both reveal Pinter's abiding fascination with hermetic, insulated figures who suddenly find their space invaded and their territory threatened.
fields.body:
More than 40 years separate these plays: Pinter's latest and his very first which together make up a richly entertaining double-bill. Yet, for all their obvious contrasts, I was struck by a curious similarity between the two works: both reveal Pinter's abiding fascination with hermetic, insulated figures who suddenly find their space invaded and their territory threatened.

In Celebration, the funniest, feistiest piece Pinter has written in years, the safe haven in question is a smart restaurant where a wedding anniversary is in full, raucous swing. Two married couples, actually brothers and sisters, sit at one banquette: a banker and his wife at another. What Pinter reveals, with a good deal of satirical verve, is the coarse swagger and loutish insensitivity of these walking wallets and their spouses.

But Pinter's play is much more than an obvious attack on the nerdy nouveau riche. Just as in Party Time we see a group of smart socialites rejoicing in a "club" which cuts them off from grim reality, so here the diners use the restaurant as a retreat from the outside world: a world in which the two brothers operate as strategy consultants whose job is "enforcing peace". And, as always in Pinter, there is no such thing as a harmless sanctuary: here the threat to an evening of crude conviviality comes from an intrusive waiter who offers increasingly bizarre, name-dropping tales of a grandfather who seems to have known everyone this century.

Behind the play's wild comedy lurks something strange and incalculable which is beautifully caught in Pinter's fast-moving production. The performances too are spot-on with Keith Allen and Andy de la Tour catching the matching vulgarity of the two brothers, Lia Williams combining sexiness and asperity as the banker's trophy wife and Danny Dyer as the far-from-dumb waiter implying a world of eccentric otherness far beyond the comprehension of these self-absorbed diners.

If the archetypal Pinter situation is one of space-invasion, then you see its origins in The Room, first performed at Bristol University in 1957. Here the immured heroine, Rose, finds the rooted privacy which she shares with her silent husband successively threatened by her talkative landlord, a pair of married flat-hunters and by a blind black man call Riley who mysteriously bids her to come home.

The milieu may be miles away from that of Celebration but in both womb-like retreats are opened up and anything "foreign" is seen as a potential menace. Admittedly the symbolism is more heavy-handed than in later, greater Pinter but what is extraordinary about his new production is the intensity of feeling between Lindsay Duncan's panic-stricken Rose and George Harris's monumentally imposing Riley.

 Until April 29. Box office: 0171-359 4404.
